fields.headline: Bank keeps rates on hold
fields.standfirst:
Eurozone borrowing costs are pegged too - for the time being
Money Unlimited
Monetary policy committee
fields.trailText: Industry leaders and homeowners reacted with relief yesterday to the Bank of England's decision to leave borrowing costs unchanged for the fifth month in a row.
fields.body:
Industry leaders and homeowners reacted with relief yesterday to the Bank of England's decision to leave borrowing costs unchanged for the fifth month in a row.

The monetary policy committee's counterparts at the European central bank in Frankfurt also decided to leave interest rates untouched yesterday, despite signs of rising inflation in the smaller economies of the eurozone.

Threadneedle Street did not issue a statement explaining its decision to leave base rates at 6%, but City analysts said a wealth of data since the last meeting of the committee suggested that the economy is cooling off.

"We have seen clear signs that UK domestic demand is slowing down since the last meeting," said Philip Shaw at Investec.

"We also had a very benign average earnings number, which hints at easier pay pressures in the economy. That adds up to a more benign UK inflationary outlook than a month ago, and underpins today's decision."

The Confederation of British Industry said all sectors of industry would be pleased with the committee's decision to leave rates on hold.

"Continued interest rate stability is the right medicine since the economy is still unsettled," said Kate Barker, chief economist at the CBI. "With sterling remaining strong, UK companies still face fierce competition from foreign competitors."

Although business surveys suggest that manufacturers are extremely gloomy about their prospects the latest official figures for the sector, published yesterday, show that output last month rebounded after April's fall. Companies raised output by 0.4% in May, according to the Office for Na tional Statistics, well above City forecasts.

However, the ONS said around half the rise was accounted for by a rebound in car production after a particularly bad performance in April. Vehicle production rose by 6% in May.

Most City analysts do not rule out one last rate rise from the Bank of England this year. Three members of the committee voted for an increase at the June meeting.

Renewed signs of sterling weakness against the dollar or of increased economic activity over the next month could give the hawks enough ammuni tion to push through a rate increase.

August will also see the publication of the Bank's quarterly detailed scrutiny of the economy.

"We suspect that the provisional quarterly inflation report forecast will conclude that, with 6% base rates, demand will not slow enough to offset the cost pressures from the lower pound and higher oil prices," said Michael Saunders, UK economist with Citibank. "Thus we expect that rates will rise at the August meeting to ensure that the MPC's two-year ahead inflation forecast that is actually published in the inflation report remains anchored at 2.5%."

As the ECB announced its decision to keep eurozone interest rates at 4.25% its president, Wim Duisenburg, hinted that European interest rates also have not yet peaked.

"Over the coming months, the rate of increase in consumer prices could continue to be affected by the lagged effects of the increase in import prices," he said.

fields.headline: Singing to a heartbeat
fields.standfirst:
Arnold/January ****
Notting Hill Arts Club, London
fields.trailText:
Arnold/January ****
Notting Hill Arts Club, London
fields.body:
In the sweaty box that is the Notting Hill Arts Club, Alan McGee, ex-Creation supremo, is a man with a mission. Shades in place, hands on decks, he's spinning some of his favourite songs and putting his past behind him.

Well, not quite. The tunes are firmly in the "classic" category - a bit of Byrds, a touch of Todd Rundgren and a slab of the Who - as befits the man who found a bunch of Manchester wannabes with a Beatles fixation and sold them as the rock'n'roll stars of the 90s.

McGee is showcasing two signings to his new Poptones label, an attempt to get back to his DIY, indie roots. But the "man who discovered Oasis" tag is going to be tricky to lose, which is hard on newcomers January. Rather than creating anthemic appeals to go out, get trashed, be cool, January make plaintive music to swoon to. And they're good at it. Lead singer Simon McLean sings in hushed tones to the shimmering slide guitar of Sarah Peacock, his eyes scrunched up earnestly. January live in their own gentle world and it almost feels intrusive to watch. As All Time washes by, its impression lingers, making January a month to remember.

Fragility is in vogue right now. Thanks to a rediscovered reverence for Nick Drake and the current success of Coldplay, every band is singing to a heartbeat. But to Arnold, the headliners and old Creation stalwarts, tenderness is nothing new. Back in the summer of '97 they released the Barn Tapes mini-album and the (sleazy yet strangely affecting) single Twist and were damned with faint praise as the "next big thing".

Ducking out of the rock rat-race and concentrating instead on their sound, Arnold have never really competed with the big boys, remaining a well-loved secret. Frontman Phil Morris has one of the sweetest voices and best haircuts in pop - Kurt Cobain as a choirboy singing bitter-sweet waltzes of love in all its fractured forms.

Arnold play with laid-back passion and pride. Acoustic guitars and restrained keyboards and bass create songs that charm but never lose their power - melodic but unsentimental, definitive but odd. While Oasis grow increasingly overblown, Arnold are small but perfectly formed. McGee should feel lucky to have them.

fields.headline: Names lambast 'vindictive' Lloyd's
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: A group of dissident Lloyd's investors yesterday grabbed their last opportunity in a gruelling month-long high court battle to accuse the insurance market of an elaborate fraud that cost them millions of pounds.
fields.body:
A group of dissident Lloyd's investors yesterday grabbed their last opportunity in a gruelling month-long high court battle to accuse the insurance market of an elaborate fraud that cost them millions of pounds.

Lloyd's of London was told it was ruthless, vicious and vindictive towards the investors, known as "names", who claim that they were fraudulently recruited to become the market's financial backers when senior executives knew that liabilities were soaring.

The attack came from Simon Goldblatt QC, as he began his closing speech in the legal action, which began early last month, in which a group of some 200 people headed by Sir William Jaffray, claim they were misled into becoming names.

They say Lloyd's recruited new names in a "recruit to dilute" campaign, with the aim of offsetting anticipated losses in the 1980s. The bulk of those - £4bn - are said to have involved asbestosis claims from the US.

Mr Goldblatt told the judge: "Lloyd's should have come to this court room with, at the very least, contrition for the financial devastation that as an institution it wreaked upon thousands and thousands of names."

He said it had not. Mr Goldblatt told Mr Justice Cresswell: "What we have seen is the action of an institution that has shown itself up to be ruthless, to be vicious and to be vindictive. How else can one explain the personal at tacks that were made in the course of the evidence?"

He rounded on Lloyd's over its witnesses. He said that at the outcome of the case, the Lloyd's QC, Charles Aldous, had told the court the reputations of 33 people who were mostly retired and who did not have the resources to contest the allegations against them were involved.

Mr Goldblatt said: "Of those 33 people we have seen in the witness box six, each of them probably a millionaire many times over, and the millions made at Lloyd's."

He said the way witnesses for the names had been treated had been repugnant.

"While the names' evidence and the names' cross examination has been directed to ascertaining truth in relation to the matters in issue, a great deal of what Lloyd's has done in the course of this case has been to divert attention from the main issues," he said.

The court was told during the hearing that losses at Lloyd's during the 1980s ran to about £8bn with the names hit by a run of claims.

About 95% of the 34,000 names at the time of the 1980s losses transferred to the new Equitas reinsurance set up by Lloyd's, paying premiums of £100,000 each.

There were 1,700 who refused to transfer, 600 of whom were successfully sued by Lloyd's. In 1997 the group led by Sir William Jaffray counter-claimed against Lloyd's alleging they were recruited on the basis of fraudulent claims. Collectively the 200 are said by Lloyd's to owe around £51m.

The hearing continues.

webTitle: Goldman sinks on new share sale

fields.headline: Goldman sinks on new share sale
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Wall Street yesterday reacted nervously to the announcement that Goldman Sachs, the investment bank, is preparing the largest ever secondary offering in the United States when rising interest rates have helped to create a lacklustre stock market.
fields.body:
Wall Street yesterday reacted nervously to the announcement that Goldman Sachs, the investment bank, is preparing the largest ever secondary offering in the United States when rising interest rates have helped to create a lacklustre stock market.

Shares in the bank fell 5% to $91 3/8 yesterday morning after it announced the sale of 40m shares held by former partners, as well as by two institutional investors, Sumitomo Bank of Japan and Hawaii's Bishop estate.

At yesterday's share price, the offering will raise about $3.6bn. Former partners, most of whom still work there, are set to receive about $1.5bn of this total, or up to 7% of their total stake in the bank. The decision to offer 16.3m shares held by former partners eases selling restrictions imposed on them by last year's initial public offering.

Jon Corzine, the bank's former chairman, who left amid a power struggle following the flotation, has already spent more than $30bn of his stake chasing a seat in the US senate.

Although Goldman had been expected to provide an orderly sale of restricted shares, some analysts voiced concerns about the timing and size of the offering.

Judah Kraushaw, financial services analyst at Merrill Lynch, said: "The timing is interesting as we are still in a tenuous recovery stage in the markets." The US market has not recovered levels reached before the April sell-off.

Goldman suffered the ignominy of having to withdraw its first attempt at a stock market listing in 1998 after the collapse of a US hedge fund hit market sentiment. It successfully listed in May last year and has since seen its shares rise from a low of $55 to a high of $128.

The roadshow and offering for the 40m shares are both expected in August, a traditionally quiet time of year in the market.

Other analysts were more bullish. Joan Solotar at Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette, said the outlook for Goldman was "pretty positive", adding that brokers had performed well against the broader market averages during recent market volatility.

The bank has indicated that it is keen to increase the percentage of its shares that trade publicly. At just 17% after last year's initial public offering, this float is much lower than that of the bank's Wall Street rivals such as Morgan Stanley or Merrill Lynch. Such a low float can lead to far greater volatility.

None of Goldman's four most senior executives is expected to sell his holdings.

fields.headline: Lastminute.com adds another 140 destinations
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com yesterday attempted to lift the gloom surrounding its prospects as a leading online booking agency when it announced an agreement with several small European airlines.
fields.body:
Lastminute.com yesterday attempted to lift the gloom surrounding its prospects as a leading online booking agency when it announced an agreement with several small European airlines.

The company said it had added more than 140 destinations to its roster thanks to a deal with the Qualiflyer Group of 11 European airlines.

The agreement applies to all flights on the 11 carriers which originate from countries where the Lastminute.com service is already online - Britain, Germany, France and Sweden - as well as Spain and the Netherlands, where the company is planning operations in the future, Lastminute.com said.

The company said the agreement would lead to shorter transfer times and more flexible routing, but failed to affect the company's share price which remained stuck at 209.5p.

The Qualiflyer Group includes Swissair, Sabena, Crossair, TAP, Portugalia, LOT, AOM, Air Littoral, Air Europe, Volare and Turkish Airlines.

webTitle: FSA warns its pay bill will climb

fields.headline: FSA warns its pay bill will climb
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Booming City salaries and rising demand for skilled workers will probably make policing Britain's financial services industry more expensive.
fields.body:
Booming City salaries and rising demand for skilled workers will probably make policing Britain's financial services industry more expensive.

Howard Davies, chairman of the financial services authority, yesterday put the industry on notice that his organisation will need an increase in its £160m budget next year.

In his annual report, Mr Davies said that demand for skilled labour in the financial sector and and the additional responsibilities following recent legislation would have a knock-on effect in the next financial year.

The FSA's budget was only 4.5% higher than the total 1998/99 figure for the separate regulatory bodies which it is replacing - but Mr Davies said that salaries in the relevant sectors of the industry had risen by 10% in the same period.

Daily rates among consultancy firms, which Mr Davies argued was perhaps the best benchmark, were up 20%.

"While our staff turnover has reduced somewhat over the last year, and is below the average for the financial sector, skilled people continue to be in heavy demand across the industry, reflecting its own buoyancy and success," he said.

"This pressure, together with the increasing scope of the authority following the passage of the Financial Services and Markets Act, is bound to have some consequences for next year's budget."

According to an FSA spokesman, turnover among the organisation's 2,000 staff was about 10% although he said the number of unfilled post was "less than 5%".

In his report Mr Davies said considerable progress had been made in designing the new regulatory regime.

It was founded on "a clear statement of the realistic aims and limits of regulation - one which recognises the proper responsibilities of consumer themselves and of firms' own management, and the impossibility and undesirability of removing all risk and failure from the financial system".

Both consumers' representatives and financial firms had responded positively to the new strategy, he said.

Consumers welcomed the more transparent approach while financial firms appreciated the benefits of risk-based supervision.

fields.headline: Celtic fusion
fields.standfirst:
Tommy Smith ***
Glasgow Jazz Festival
fields.trailText:
Tommy Smith ***
Glasgow Jazz Festival
fields.body:
Tommy Smith, commonly acknowledged as one of the world's best young jazz saxophonists, has long been trying to combine traditional Celtic music and jazz. On Wednesday at the Old Fruitmarket he unveiled the world premiere of his 15-piece epic of Celtic-jazz fusion, The Sons and Daughters of Alba.

This specially commissioned piece, the centrepiece of the Glasgow Jazz Festival, was an opportunity to bring a new lyrical fire to ancient Scottish themes. Reviving his collaboration with poet Edwin Morgan, Smith introduced Capercaille's spine-tingling singer Karen Matheson, pianist Donald Shaw, and uillean piper Michael McGoldrick into a mini-orchestra that included French brothers Jean-Baptiste Bocle (vibraphone) and Gildas Bocle (bass).

Smith is now a one-man jazz force. As musical director, he has led the Scottish National Jazz Orchestra to new heights and his output is extraordinary. But instead of an interlinking Ellingtonian suite of tone and space, this was a sometimes disjointed collection of short musical portraits of historical figures, from Robert Burns through the grave-robber William Burke to the "Dornoch Witch", Janet Horne. It was a fascinating idea of a people's history through music, yet Morgan's nursery rhymes seemed awkward beside Smith's elemental collage.

There were some exhilarating passages where Matheson's pure voice justified her reputation as the Edith Piaf of Celtic music, and Smith played exuberantly against a backdrop of pipes and vibraphone. But the pieces rarely worked and only the folk-samba for St Columba combined the Celtic laments and hard bop jazz in a seamless whole.

For the rest, the sudden shifts of tempo and style were strange. Smith believes that there is a common rhythmic pulse to Celtic music and the African-American sounds that evolved into jazz - but that heartbeat proved elusive. A great jazz combo and a superb folk outfit sat together but only occasionally connected.

fields.headline: Tribute to Klemperer
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonia/ Andras Schiff ***
Barbican Hall, London
fields.trailText:
Philharmonia/ Andras Schiff ***
Barbican Hall, London
fields.body:
The indefatigable Andras Schiff is taking time off from his year-long Bach retrospective to join the Philharmonia for a series of concerts dedicated to the memory of Otto Klemperer. Since we're nowhere near a Klemperer anniversary, the tribute is, one suspects, acutely personal.

Klemperer was the Philharmonia's first principal conductor, assuming the post in 1964 when the orchestra was battling for survival. He then steered it through what was for many its golden age. His achievement was captured in a series of landmark recordings, of which Schiff became an ardent fan in his teens.

There are other points in common, too: forceful (though very different) personalties; a willingness to speak out on matters of political principle; above all, the belief in music itself as a humanitarian, moral and redemptive force.

Klemperer was for many the supreme exponent of Mozart and Beethoven, and Schiff's programmes consist of a concerto by each, separated by a Haydn symphony.

He directs the concertos from the keyboard, which is fine for Mozart but worked less well with Beethoven's Emperor, in which the piano writing keeps the soloist so busy that responsibility for holding the performance together falls ultimately on the orchestra's leader. (Klemperer, his health impaired in later life by a series of strokes, was heavily reliant on his leaders, too).

The result was a hair-raising experience, almost incredible to watch, though not always penetrating the heart of the work. When not playing, Schiff, bouncing off the piano stool, coaxed emotion from the orchestra with a series of extravagant, dramatic gestures.

Led by James Clark, the Philharmonia was acutely responsive and dynamic, but Schiff's pianism is fierily twitchy, sometimes lacking in limpidity, and the whole had a nervy quality in music that should be magisterial, titanic and Olympian (adjectives usually applied to Klemperer's conducting, as well as Beethoven's concerto).

Schiff is also less than happy as a Haydn conductor. His performance of the 95th Symphony, sumptuously played, didn't always capture the sudden swerves of mood, the lightning transitions from bitterness to buoyancy, that it really needs if it's going to work. In Mozart, however, Schiff's approach is peerless. The 12th Concerto was bracketed with the A Major Rondo, which Mozart may have originally intended as the work's finale. The balance between emotion and form was immaculate, so that even the most simple musical gestures were infinitely telling.

The concerto's emotional ambivalence was maintained throughout. Above all, the performance had a spaciousness, an intensity and a resonance of which Klemperer himself would have been proud.
fields.bodyText: The indefatigable Andras Schiff is taking time off from his year-long Bach retrospective to join the Philharmonia for a series of concerts dedicated to the memory of Otto Klemperer. Since we're nowhere near a Klemperer anniversary, the tribute is, one suspects, acutely personal. Klemperer was the Philharmonia's first principal conductor, assuming the post in 1964 when the orchestra was battling for survival. He then steered it through what was for many its golden age. His achievement was captured in a series of landmark recordings, of which Schiff became an ardent fan in his teens. There are other points in common, too: forceful (though very different) personalties; a willingness to speak out on matters of political principle; above all, the belief in music itself as a humanitarian, moral and redemptive force. Klemperer was for many the supreme exponent of Mozart and Beethoven, and Schiff's programmes consist of a concerto by each, separated by a Haydn symphony. He directs the concertos from the keyboard, which is fine for Mozart but worked less well with Beethoven's Emperor, in which the piano writing keeps the soloist so busy that responsibility for holding the performance together falls ultimately on the orchestra's leader. (Klemperer, his health impaired in later life by a series of strokes, was heavily reliant on his leaders, too). The result was a hair-raising experience, almost incredible to watch, though not always penetrating the heart of the work. When not playing, Schiff, bouncing off the piano stool, coaxed emotion from the orchestra with a series of extravagant, dramatic gestures. Led by James Clark, the Philharmonia was acutely responsive and dynamic, but Schiff's pianism is fierily twitchy, sometimes lacking in limpidity, and the whole had a nervy quality in music that should be magisterial, titanic and Olympian (adjectives usually applied to Klemperer's conducting, as well as Beethoven's concerto). Schiff is also less than happy as a Haydn conductor. His performance of the 95th Symphony, sumptuously played, didn't always capture the sudden swerves of mood, the lightning transitions from bitterness to buoyancy, that it really needs if it's going to work. In Mozart, however, Schiff's approach is peerless. The 12th Concerto was bracketed with the A Major Rondo, which Mozart may have originally intended as the work's finale. The balance between emotion and form was immaculate, so that even the most simple musical gestures were infinitely telling. The concerto's emotional ambivalence was maintained throughout. Above all, the performance had a spaciousness, an intensity and a resonance of which Klemperer himself would have been proud.

webTitle: Germany and South Africa go to the wire

fields.headline: Germany and South Africa go to the wire
fields.standfirst: How the bidders pitched it
fields.trailText: The race to stage the 2006 World Cup was in the balance last night following predictions that it would be one of the most closely fought contests in football history and could well be decided by the casting vote of the Fifa president Sepp Blatter.
fields.byline: Vivek Chaudhary  and  Matthew Joseph  in Zurich
fields.body:
The race to stage the 2006 World Cup was in the balance last night following predictions that it would be one of the most closely fought contests in football history and could well be decided by the casting vote of the Fifa president Sepp Blatter.

With Fifa's 24-member executive committee due to vote on the venue for 2006 today, officials of the world governing body have been saying that nothing can be taken for granted and the two favourites, South Africa and Germany, could end up with 12 votes each. Under Fifa rules this would mean that Blatter, who has already publicly stated his support for South Africa, would then have a decisive vote.

All four candidate countries spent yesterday outlining their cases during 30-minute presentations to officials at Fifa House in Zurich, but England's bid still looks doomed and they could be eliminated after the second round of voting with only a small number of votes guaranteed. Only Scotland and New Zealand have so far said they will definitely back England's bid, while Morocco is expected to be eliminated after the first round.

South Africa is believed to have won backing from central and south American countries, as well as being the second choice for African and middle eastern countries, while Germany has strong backing within Uefa, the European governing body.

South Africa is believed to be just ahead of Germany but, with few concrete predictions on how Fifa delegates will vote in later rounds of the contest, officials are predicting an extremely tight result.

Robin Peterson, the general manager of South Africa's bid, said: "I think it's going to be very close between us and Germany. I think it could even go down to a tie with the president giving the casting vote. That could easily happen."

One Fifa official confirmed that there was a strong chance of Blatter being called upon for his casting vote. The official added: "I understand the executive will be split 12-12 once England and Morocco are out of the way. It is as close as that."

South Africa's campaign to become the first African country to host the World Cup received a boost this week when Brazil withdrew and promised the three south American votes in return for South Africa's support for their attempt to secure the tournament in 2010.

After making England's presentation, led by the head of the bid Alec McGivan, Sir Bobby Charlton and Sir Geoff Hurst, the English campaigners held a private dinner last night fearing the worst today.

England's bid appeared doomed following the violence of Euro 2000 and Uefa's subsequent threat to kick the country out of the tournament, one of the reasons for driving many of England's Fifa backers away.

English officials were in a sombre mood yesterday despite the fact that their presentation passed off smoothly and appeared to have gone down well with Fifa delegates.

The Fifa executive kicked off its two-day meeting by going for dinner at a roof-top restaurant on Tuesday night where Blatter once again outlined his reasons for wanting a World Cup in Africa.

Following their presentation Danny Jordaan, the head of South Africa's bid, said: "We were exceptionally pleased by our encouraging and attentive reception. The stream of congratulations from members persuades us that we are strongly in contention to win this contest."

Germany's presentation was led by Franz Beckenbauer and they too are confident of winning after a smooth and efficient campaign.

The executive committee will start voting this morning by secret ballot and once a final decision has been reached the result will be put into an envelope which will be taken to a press conference arranged for today, where Blatter will announce the winning bid.

fields.headline: How the bidders pitched it
fields.standfirst: Germany and South Africa go to the wire
fields.trailText:
England
England was the first of the four bidders to present its case to the 24 members of the Fifa executive and stressed the importance of football within popular culture and its reach across racial barriers. The state of English stadiums and the amount of investment that has gone into them was also outlined to delegates in a slick, professional 30-minute presentation.
fields.body:
England
England was the first of the four bidders to present its case to the 24 members of the Fifa executive and stressed the importance of football within popular culture and its reach across racial barriers. The state of English stadiums and the amount of investment that has gone into them was also outlined to delegates in a slick, professional 30-minute presentation.

There were numerous video clips of black and Asian youngsters playing football and footage also included shots of a Sikh referee as campaigners tried to press home football's universal appeal within England, one of the strongest selling points of England's bid.

Fifa delegates also heard a short message from Tony Blair, which was introduced by his special World Cup envoy Tony Banks with the prime minister declaring that the World Cup was not just for England and Europe but the whole of the world.

Unlike other presentations, England's was pitched by a number of members of the campaign team and not one individual. It was opened by the FA chairman Geoff Thompson and Alec McGivan, the bid committee chairman, who pointed out football's appeal within England among all sections of society.

Garth Crooks covered the recent levels of investment into English stadiums, which campaigners had hoped would be one of the bid's unique selling points until a Fifa inspection report rated English facilities behind those of Germany and South Africa. Crooks claimed that more than £1bn had been spent on improving stadiums and that campaigners had more than fulfilled Fifa requirements.

The worldwide popularity of the Premiership and the presence of high-profile foreign players was also prominent in the English presentation with video clips of Ginola, Poyet, Zola and other imports to the domestic league.

While trying to point out the strengths of the English bid, such as infrastructure and the universal appeal of football, campaigners also attempted to address recent concerns that have been highlighted by Fifa and Uefa. Banks spoke to the Fifa delegates on the recent measures taken by the government to try to combat hooliganism.

The 30-minute presentation, liberally sprinkled with vivid images of England such as red buses and the white cliffs of Dover, passed off without any technical problems and appeared to be well received by Fifa delegates.

McGivan ended by reiterating England's promise to invite 12 children from each of the countries that might qualify for the 2006 World Cup to the tournament as guests.

There was no doubting the smoothness and commitment of the English bid but the general feeling remained that it was not enough to rescue England's fading World Cup dream.

Backers: Scotland, New Zealand. Possible backers: Spain, Malta.

Germany
Smooth, personable presentation littered with German celebrities and revolving around the personality and appeal of Franz Beckenbauer.

The Kaiser stood before Fifa delegates holding a ball on a piece of turf he claimed was from the cen tre spot of Bayern Munich's stadium. "I have to get this back before the start of the season," he joked.

Beckenbauer appeared composed and at ease with the delegates and he was joined on stage by the German chancellor Gerhard Schroeder as well as Claudia Schiffer and Boris Becker. The Germans highlighted the amount of investment they plan for new stadiums and also claimed their country was one of the easiest to travel around. German efficiency and their ability to deal with major events was one of the main themes of the presentation.

Delegates were told that Germany was prepared for the World Cup and were also shown models of the new national stadium that will be built if they win. Beckenbauer praised Fifa for developing football around the world and also commended each continent, particularly Africa, but urged that Germany should be chosen.

Backers: Sweden, South Korea, Belgium, Norway, Turkey, Italy. Possible backers: Spain, Malta.

Morocco
By far the weakest bid, there was very little that is likely to cause a World Cup upset. Morocco stressed the point that they could rival South Africa as the continent's other country to stage the tournament for the first time.

The presentation was led by the sports minister, Ahmed Moussaoui, who pointed out the passion for football in the country and the strong government backing, with pledges to develop stadiums and infrastructure.

Fifa delegates were shown video clips of Moroccans playing and watching football and told that the people of the country would not understand why an African country has still not got the World Cup. With vivid images set to Moroccan folk music, delegates were told the time had come for the World Cup to be held in Africa.

Backers: Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, Qatar. Possible backers: Mali, Cameroon.

South Africa
The presentation was based on the country's emotional appeal as hosts and was led by Danny Jordaan, head of South Africa's bid, who appeared nervous with victory in sight.

Fifa delegates were told of the financial benefits the World Cup could bring South Africa and the importance of football with all communities. Video clips shown during the presentation included footage of white and black footballers.

Nelson Mandela, in a brief video message, also spoke about the benefits for South Africa and also how it was time for the tournament to come to Africa.

The theme of the world football family coming to Africa was prominent but the issue of crime and possible problems with security in the country were also addressed. Jordaan pointed out that English rugby and cricket teams had both visited South Africa recently and that the country had also been awarded cricket's 2003 World Cup.

Fifa executives were told South Africa is the affordable option given that food, travel and general costs are much lower than England and Germany. The presentation was hampered by a few minor technical problems.

Backers: Sepp Blatter (Fifa president, casting vote), Argentina, Cameroon, Trinidad and Tobago, Costa Rica, Brazil, Paraguay, Botswana, Mali. Possible backers: United States.

fields.headline: Newcastle splash out £7m on Cort
fields.trailText: Newcastle United last night won the race to sign the England Under-21 striker Carl Cort, paying Wimbledon £7m for his services. The lanky 22-year-old, chased by Tottenham as well as Leicester City, has signed a five-year deal and his arrival will cast doubt once more on the future of Duncan Ferguson at St James' Park.
fields.body:
Newcastle United last night won the race to sign the England Under-21 striker Carl Cort, paying Wimbledon £7m for his services. The lanky 22-year-old, chased by Tottenham as well as Leicester City, has signed a five-year deal and his arrival will cast doubt once more on the future of Duncan Ferguson at St James' Park.

Cort, who scored on his full debut for Wimbledon against Newcastle at St James' Park in a 3-1 win in 1997, joined Wimbledon as a schoolboy and signed professional terms in 1996. He broke into the first-team as a teenager and has gradually smoothed away the rough edges to become a tough man to mark with his pace and strength.

Last season he scored 15 goals for Wimbledon in their unsuccessful fight to avoid relegation, and despite failing to hit the target in the last two months of the season he was a key member of England's under-21 side which reached the European Championship finals in Slovakia this summer.

Now Cort can look forward to playing under Bobby Robson and alongside Alan Shearer in the Newcastle attack. "I am thrilled to be joining a club as big as Newcastle United," he said.

"The chairman and chief executive have impressed me with their ambitious plans for the club and I am delighted at the prospect of playing for Bobby Robson. It is a great career move for me."

Cort becomes the third, and most expensive, player to commit himself to Newcastle this summer after the Argentines Christian Bassedas and Daniel Cordone, and his acquisition takes Robson's summer spending to £11.5m. But with the sale of the Italian defender Alessandro Pistone to Everton for £3m and further departures seemingly inevitable, there could be more arrivals before the new season.

Right up to yesterday Newcastle played down talk of their interest in Cort but his signing suggests they will now consider offers for Ferguson. The Scot has struggled to find full fitness since his £8m move to Tyneside in November 1998, and although the club insists that he remains a Newcastle player a reasonable offer could prove fruitful.

Yesterday's events seem to have ended speculation that the Belgian international striker Emile Mpenza could be heading for the north-east. Robson has admitted an interest in the player, but the asking price of more than £8m was far in excess of what he was prepared to pay.

The player has admitted Newcastle was an attractive proposition, but it now appears the temptation on the club's part was not strong enough. Mpenza said: "The Magpies don't have the same reputation as Manchester [United] and the town itself doesn't offer the same advantages as London. But from a sports point of view the challenge is very tempting."

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: If Hansie Cronje is still after a fast buck, he could do worse than try a Lancashire win-Durham lose double whenever the planet's most venerable one-day competition pitches up. Essex and Hampshire duly played their appointed parts yesterday, with varying degrees of willingness.
fields.body:
If Hansie Cronje is still after a fast buck, he could do worse than try a Lancashire win-Durham lose double whenever the planet's most venerable one-day competition pitches up. Essex and Hampshire duly played their appointed parts yesterday, with varying degrees of willingness.

That "form is temporary, class is permanent" mantra has evidently been working overtime for Saurav Ganguly. The son of a Bengal tin tycoon, relatively unaccustomed to life's little turbulences until becoming captain of India, had mustered just 329 runs at 25 since popping a red rose in his buttonhole. He has, however, reserved his best for the NatWest, where Lincolnshire and now Essex have felt the backlash of that elegant bat.

Following his century in round three, Ganguly hit 97 off 119 balls at Old Trafford where Lancashire, seven-time winners of the Gillette/NatWest, swanned home by 69 runs. He set the stage for Andy Flintoff to rattle up 43 off 29 balls and then claim two for 21, proclaiming his fitness to join the England camp for the Triangular tournament.

Once upon a time, Durham were dab hands at this. Qualifying a record 21 times as a minor county, snooks already cocked at Yorkshire and Derbyshire, they reached the quarter-finals in their maiden first-class season, since when they have failed to scale even those modest heights.

Duffed up by the Dutch last year, it at least took Shane Warne to undo them this time. In his first senior match since suffering a groin injury in January, the England A opener Michael Gough endured longer than seven colleagues, but 32 balls was not quite what was required: his exit presaged the loss of all 10 wickets for 66 and a total of 91. Hampshire's favourite Victorian took two for 12.

While rain had the final say at Southgate and the Oval, at Edgbaston that stout son of Chertsey, Ashley Giles, enhanced his drive for all-round certification, scoring the second century of his career just three weeks after the first.

Michael di Venuto threatened to make that an irrelevance but Derbyshire's Tasmanian was trumped in turn by Warwickshire's South African, Allan Donald dismissing him for 84 en route to four for 42 as the visitors lost their last six men for 16, keeping the winners bracketed with Lancashire on 108 NatWest victories. Dominic Cork reacquainted himself with terra firma, falling for six.

fields.headline: Strongbow shoots to thrill
fields.standfirst:
Northamptonshire 252
Yorkshire 183
Northamptonshire won by 69 runs
fields.trailText:
Northamptonshire 252
Yorkshire 183
Northamptonshire won by 69 runs.
fields.body:
Michael Strong, aka Strongbow, Stronglager and Stella, is best remembered at Sussex for running across the Hove ground last season wearing only a batting helmet, a pair of underpants and an inflatable banana. He had lost a bet and possibly a marble or two.

When wearing cricket clothes, alas, he did not catch the eye in the same way. He played just one match last year, doubling his career aggregate of games, and shuffled to Northampton. Here, he is mostly a back-up fast bowler, though he took five for 39 against Zimbabwe last weekend.

Yesterday, making his debut in the NatWest Trophy, he produced figures of 7-3-10-3 at the top of the innings to place Yorkshire in the A&E unit. They never recovered and Northamptonshire won by 69 runs with 6.1 overs to spare.

Strong, 26 last week, took the wickets of Gary Fellows, Richard Blakey and, most crucially, Darren Lehmann in the space of 20 deliveries to win the man-of-the-match award as Yorkshire embarked on the already considerable task of scoring 253 to win. Northants now play the holders, Gloucestershire, at Bristol in the quarter-finals later this month.

Strong's only serious contender for the MoM gong was his captain, Matthew Hayden, who before taking three catches scored a fluent 63 from 69 deliveries. He hit seven fours and a six, over mid-on off Gavin Hamilton, and his partnership of 118 in 24 overs with David Sales (65) was the meat of the innings.

Northants looked capable of reaching a summit with even thinner air when they were 169 for two in the 38th, the over in which Hayden perished, well caught by his opposite number David Byas at midwicket. But their innings ended suddenly when they lost their last five wickets for eight runs in 18 balls.

When Yorkshire replied, Fellows was undone by Strong's in-swing, and bowled. Blakey was then caught behind off a pacey delivery before Lehmann's square drive found Graeme Swann at point.

Yorkshire were 36 for four when Michael Vaughan fell to Devon Malcolm but their effort was revived by a stand of 73 between Byas and Anthony McGrath. A target of 144 off 20 was on. But then Byas was caught by Hayden at extra-cover and McGrath, after hitting Tony Penberthy for six, was caught attempting a repeat.

webTitle: Terry Paine hopes for World Cup failure

fields.headline: Terry Paine hopes for World Cup failure
fields.standfirst: Terry Paine was one of the boys of '66 - but today he desperately wants England to lose the World Cup
fields.trailText: Terry Paine was one of the boys of '66 - but today he desperately wants England to lose the World Cup.
fields.body:
He was part of Sir Alf Ramsey's 1966 World Cup winning squad with Sir Bobby Charlton, has lost none of his passion for English football and still visits his beloved Southampton whenever he can. But Terry Paine will shed no tears if England are soundly beaten today in their bid to stage the 2006 World Cup.

In fact the former international winger, who made 19 appearances for his country between 1963-66, will be one of the first to roar his delight if, as expected, South Africa edge out Germany when Fifa's executive committee cast their votes in Zurich today.

Paine has lived in South Africa for the past 16 years and in recent months has travelled the globe as one of their official 2006 ambassadors.

Surely this represents a conflict of interest for a man who once held the record for Football League appearances with 824 games? The majority were with Southampton - at 713 it is still the most by any player for the south coast club - and the rest for Hereford United before he retired in 1980.

Paine, who works for South African television presenting a number of football programmes with the former Manchester United goalkeeper Gary Bailey, understands that some people may not feel comfortable with his apparent switch of allegiance.

"I thought about it for a couple of weeks when they asked me to be an ambassador," he explained, "but all I can say is, I have been there since 1984 and I believe our need is greater than England's. It's Africa's time."

Indeed, in the build-up to today's vote, he received several pieces of hate mail including two emails. "I received them a couple of weeks ago, out of the blue. One accused me of being a traitor and the other said I should be charged with treason for siding with South Africa," Paine said.

"I had others as well but these were the two most heated ones, shall we say. One of them said I should hand back my OBE but that upgraded me because I only have an MBE."

Paine admits his relationship with Charlton has deteriorated since he decided to rival his former international team-mate on the political front.

fields.headline: Telephone tycoon takes over Palace
fields.trailText: The financial cloud which has engulfed Crystal Palace since the First Division club entered administration 15 months ago was lifted yesterday as the mobile telephone entrepreneur Simon Jordan completed his £10.6m purchase of the club.
fields.body:
The financial cloud which has engulfed Crystal Palace since the First Division club entered administration 15 months ago was lifted yesterday as the mobile telephone entrepreneur Simon Jordan completed his £10.6m purchase of the club.

Jordan, 32, who sold his company the Pocket Phone Shop to One2One last month for £36.5m, is a former schoolboy player at Palace, who will continue to play at Selhurst Park. "I have achieved exactly what I set out to do," he said.

"I have been prepared to put my money into something I truly believe in, and my first job in hand is to turn the fortunes of this club around."

Bradford have opened negotiations with Leeds to sign the former Palace midfielder David Hopkin. The Scotland international, who cost Leeds £3.25m in 1997, has also attracted interest from Everton.

Ricky Hill will today be appointed manager of Second Division Luton Town. The former Tottenham defender John Scales has completed his free transfer move to Ipswich Town, while the Birmingham striker Dele Adebola is expected to join the Spanish club Las Palmas today.

fields.headline: Gunners draw close on £15m Wiltord
fields.trailText: Clearly hoping that success is contagious, Arsène Wenger was yesterday trying to add a sixth Frenchman to his Arsenal team, the Euro 2000 striker Sylvain Wiltord.
fields.body:
Clearly hoping that success is contagious, Arsène Wenger was yesterday trying to add a sixth Frenchman to his Arsenal team, the Euro 2000 striker Sylvain Wiltord.

Talks are underway over a £15m move for the Bordeaux striker, whose injury-time equaliser against Italy set up France's golden-goal win in the final. If successful, the deal would take Wenger's summer spending to over £30m as he seeks to wrest the Premiership title from Manchester United and improve on poor recent showings in the Champions League.

The French manager is presumably hoping the world and European champions' success will rub off on Arsenal having signed another Euro 2000 winner, Robert Pires, earlier this week. He joined his compatriots Emmanuel Petit, Patrick Vieira, Thierry Henry and Gilles Grimandi at the club and yesterday Wiltord's agent Giselaine Dugueteroux was confident her client would be coming too.

"The situation looks quite good at the moment," said Dugueteroux. "We expect him to join Arsène Wenger and his French team-mates from the European Championship. We are just waiting for the agreement between Arsenal and Bordeaux to be finalised. Sylvain likes England and he wants to play in the Champions League. Arsenal are a great club."

Arsenal have been searching for another quality striker all summer to add to their recent acquisitions, the £5m winger Pires and two midfielders, the Cameroonian Lauren, bought for £7m and the Brazilian Edu, who joined for an undisclosed fee thought to be around £5m.

Middlesbrough have called off their bid to sign the Chelsea striker Chris Sutton, but France's midfielder Christian Karembeu and the Australian captain Paul Okon are both on their way to Teeside. Boro had offered £6m for Sutton amid competition from Celtic and Aston Villa, but have now pulled out after the player asked for more time to decide.

Karembeu, 29, has joined Boro from Real Madrid for £2.1m on a four-year contract, while Okon, a 28-year-old midfielder, arrives on a free from Serie A's Fiorentina and has been given a two-year deal.

Derby have signed the Manchester United left-back Danny Higginbotham for £2million. The 21-year-old arrived at Pride Park on a four-year contract.

webTitle: Sketch: A day in the life of One Word Man: he says a word

fields.headline: Sketch: A day in the life of One Word Man: he says a word
fields.trailText: July 6 2000: Sketch: A day in the life of One Word Man: he says a word
fields.body:
There is a cartoon by HM Bateman called, I think, The One Note Man. A series of beautifully detailed drawings shows a chap waking up, having breakfast, going to work with his instrument case, joining the orchestra, and, at the climax of his day, playing a single note on the triangle. The story ends with him tucked up again in bed.

Yesterday Michael Fabricant became The One Word Man. We can follow his day because it is detailed on his brand new, freshly overhauled website which, for some of us, holds even more interest than the likes of www.hotbabes.com.

He gets up, brushes his teeth, feeds his hair from a bottle of Baby Bio, goes to the House, answers the mail, then ponders the state of his stomach. "Sometimes I have lunch appointments, but more often than not I take a sandwich back to the office."

Fascinating! (Though I may have invented the bit about the Baby Bio). Next he made his way to the chamber and left a card marked " Fabricant " at his favourite seat. So later he was in his place and poised as prime minister's questions proceeded.

Mr Blair was having a hard time. In the gallery were five Australian prime ministers, in town to celebrate 100 years in the Commonwealth. Mr Blair paid tribute to the relationship between our two great countries, slightly spoiling things by calling them "Americans", although the massed ranks of Antipodean statesmen seemed to be amused rather than offended.

Mr Hague had decided to attack him on the scheme for on-the-spot fines for drunken hooligans. (This is a typical New Labour wheeze, in that it was worked up in a panic over the opinion polls and bunged in to grab the head lines, without any reference being made to the people who would have to enforce it).

"Can you tell the House which person in government came up with this brilliant idea?" Mr Hague asked, adding: "Who came up with the obviously fatuous idea of getting drunken criminals to form orderly queues at cashpoints around the country?"

Mr Blair did what he always does when caught out he pretended Mr Hague was opposed not to the batty scheme, but to the idea of controlling yobs. "If we introduce fixed penalty notices, on the spot, for disorderly conduct, will you support it?"

Mr Hague was enjoying himself. Like a yob, he had found a victim and was not going to let him go. "You spend your time clutching for another empty headline instead of getting a grip on your divided and shambolic government!"

The prime minister was getting seriously rattled. The yob was shouting at him and there was no bobby in sight, no cashpoint within half a mile. Passers-by were scurrying along with eyes averted. "Let's deal with spin, rather than substance!" he yelled, getting it wrong again.

"The truth is that when the debate turns to policy, we shall see who is standing!"

For some reason, time also stood still. There was a sort of muted hubbub, but in the comparative calm came the manic shout of "Resign!" It was Mickey Fabb, making in one second the finest oration of his parliamentary career.

The Speaker barked at him, "any more of that and you will be out!" But it didn't matter. Teresa Gorman, wearing a blue gingham tablecloth, leaned over and squeezed his shoulder. He turned red with pleasure. Then I assume, he had his tea, brushed his teeth, put on his jim-jams and went to bed.

(PS: he has just faxed me a press release. "Now my website has had a cyber-makeover, perhaps I should now have one for real!" Next week, with any luck, the new bald Fabricant ).

More Michael Fabricant at www.michael.fabricant.mp.co.uk

webTitle: Last points of order as time called on late night sittings

fields.headline: Last points of order as time called on late night sittings
fields.standfirst: Labour MPs back 'family friendly' modernisation move but Tories fear undermining of opposition in big Commons culture change.
fields.trailText:
Late night sittings of the House of Commons , which fequently force MPs to remain at
          Westminster until the early hours, are to be consigned to the past as part of the most radical
          shake-up of parliament in more than 20 years to be unveiled today.
fields.body:
Late night sittings of the House of Commons , which fequently force MPs to remain at Westminster until the early hours, are to be consigned to the past as part of the most radical shake-up of parliament in more than 20 years to be unveiled today.

In a move which will delight modernisers, but dismay traditionalists who like to drink through the night in Westminster's numerous bars, the business of the Commons is to be brought to an end by 10pm throughout the week.

Labour backbenchers, who have been pressing for more "family friendly" hours, will warmly welcome the reform to be announced today by Margaret Beckett, the leader of the Commons. But Conservative MPs will criticise the end of late night sittings, saying that it will weaken the ability of the Opposition to hold the government to account.

Mrs Beckett, who chairs the Commons modernisation committee which yesterday approved the reforms, will insist that the government is planning to give opposition parties a far greater role in the running of the house.

In a gesture to the Tories and the Liberal Democrats, Mrs Beckett will announce the unprecedented setting up of a cross-party committee to agree on how the government arranges its business in the Commons. The committee, which was the brainchild of the Liberal Democrat chief whip Paul Tyler, will meet after the annual Queen's speech in November to try to reach agreement on the order of parliamentary bills in the following session.

The government will also agree to give opposition MPs a say in how bills are debated. The government will allocate an overall time for a bill, but it will be up to MPs to decide how much time to devote to specific areas. But the greatest attention today will focus on the demise of late night sittings, which will usher in the greatest cultural change in Westminster in more than a century.

Under the government's plans, strict timetabling of government business will mean that debates on bills will end at 10pm from Mondays to Wednesdays, allowing MPs to escape from Westminster after voting at around 10.30pm. MPs are already free to leave early once a week after the Commons started sitting on Thursday morning

One government source said that reform of the Commons hours was long overdue. "Most people have come to the conclusion that you cannot allow legislation to be taken through the house at 3am," the source said. "This is the biggest shake-up at Westminster since the introduction of select committees in 1979."

The source said that ministers regarded the setting up of the cross-party "Queen's speech committee" as an example of the government's at tempts to co-operate with other parties, most notably the Lib Dems. "The government is particularly keen to be inclusive because that will eventually lead to better legislation," the source said.

However, today's report will be denounced by the Tories who will dismiss it as a cynical attempt by the government to tighten its grip over the Commons. Forcing MPs to sit through the night is an old tactic deployed by opposition parties down the ages - including Labour in the 1980s - to upset the carefully choreographed timetabling of Commons business. Some Tory MPs on the modernisation committee rejected the report.

The government had been criticised by some of Labour's new backbenchers for refusing to embrace change, although . it has also introduced debates in Westminster Hall, which have to be attended by the relevant minister, to give backbenchers greater scope to debate issues dear to their hearts.

The reforms to the Commons will be unveiled today as MPs rounded on broadcasters for their coverage of Westminster. The all-party Commons broadcasting committee accused the BBC and ITN of "cherry-picking" sound bites and focusing on rows in televising parliament. However, the MPs recommended an expansion of broadcasting facilities at Westminster.

Special report on parliament at www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/ parl

The committee, which was the brainchild of the Liberal Democrat chief whip Paul Tyler, will meet after the annual Queen's speech in November to try to reach agreement on the order of parliamentary bills in the following session. The government will also agree to give opposition MPs a say in how bills are debated. The government will allocate an overall time for a bill, but it will be up to MPs to decide how much time to devote to specific areas. But the greatest attention today will focus on the demise of late night sittings, which will usher in the greatest cultural change in Westminster in more than a century. Under the government's plans, strict timetabling of government business will mean that debates on bills will end at 10pm from Mondays to Wednesdays, allowing MPs to escape from Westminster after voting at around 10.30pm. MPs are already free to leave early once a week after the Commons started sitting on Thursday morning One government source said that reform of the Commons hours was long overdue. "Most people have come to the conclusion that you cannot allow legislation to be taken through the house at 3am," the source said. "This is the biggest shake-up at Westminster since the introduction of select committees in 1979." The source said that ministers regarded the setting up of the cross-party "Queen's speech committee" as an example of the government's at tempts to co-operate with other parties, most notably the Lib Dems. "The government is particularly keen to be inclusive because that will eventually lead to better legislation," the source said. However, today's report will be denounced by the Tories who will dismiss it as a cynical attempt by the government to tighten its grip over the Commons. Forcing MPs to sit through the night is an old tactic deployed by opposition parties down the ages - including Labour in the 1980s - to upset the carefully choreographed timetabling of Commons business. Some Tory MPs on the modernisation committee rejected the report. The government had been criticised by some of Labour's new backbenchers for refusing to embrace change, although . it has also introduced debates in Westminster Hall, which have to be attended by the relevant minister, to give backbenchers greater scope to debate issues dear to their hearts. The reforms to the Commons will be unveiled today as MPs rounded on broadcasters for their coverage of Westminster. The all-party Commons broadcasting committee accused the BBC and ITN of "cherry-picking" sound bites and focusing on rows in televising parliament. However, the MPs recommended an expansion of broadcasting facilities at Westminster.

webTitle: Blair's son says sorry after 'drunk and incapable' arrest

fields.headline: Blair's son says sorry after 'drunk and incapable' arrest
fields.standfirst:
Comment by Michael White
Who said what
Downing Street full statement
Policing crime: special report
The press complaints commission
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's 16-year-old son Euan has apologised after he was arrested last night for being "drunk and incapable" in London's West End.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's 16-year-old son Euan has apologised after he was arrested last night for being "drunk and incapable" in London's West End.

In a statement the prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, said Mr Blair's oldest son was "very sorry for the inconvenience he caused to the police" as he celebrated the end of his GCSE exams.

Police officers found the teenager sprawled in Leicester Square on his own at around 11pm. He initially gave a false name, age and address to the police, saying he was called Euan John, was aged 18, and lived at his old home in Islington.

"Euan was out last night with friends to mark the end of his GCSEs. The police late last night saw him lying on the ground in Leicester Square," Downing Street said.

"He was clearly ill and had been vomiting. An ambulance was called but ambulance personnel decided he didn't need hospital treatment and he was then taken by the police to Charing Cross. He was, in the view of the police, drunk and incapable."

"I think he saw the inside of a cell," Mr Campbell later added.

Euan was released without charge and driven home by special branch officers early this morning.

A Scotland Yard spokeswoman confirmed: "A male youth was arrested at 23.00 last night in Leicester Square for being drunk and incapable.

"Police were not responding to a call regarding the person, an officer on patrol just came upon him."

"The options are now that he could be brought back and issued with a formal warning or he could be cautioned," said the spokeswoman.

Mr Campbell said: "In the near future he will have to return to Charing Cross with his parents to hear what, if any, further action is going to be taken."

"Being a parent is tough"

In a speech to religious leaders in Brighton, Mr Blair did his best to shake off his son's embarrassing arrest, which comes just days after the prime minister's call for police to be given powers to levy on-the-spot fines on drunken youths.

Reaching a section of his speech praising values such as as "tolerance, family, trying to bring up children properly", Mr Blair paused, looked down and smiled. "Er, that part was written a long time ago," he said.

As his audience laughed the prime minister went on: "Being a prime minister can be a tough job but I always think being a parent is probably tougher. Sometimes you don't always succeed, but the family to me is more important than anything else."

Mr Blair and his wife Cherie have gone to great lengths to protect the privacy of their children - Euan, Nicky, 14, Kathryn, 12, and baby Leo.

Asked if it was the first time Euan had been drunk, Mr Campbell said: "It is the first time special branch have had to go and pick him up" and added that it was the first time on "this type of scale".

Mr Campbell said Mr Blair was up last night working on today's speech and was "a bit worried" that his son had not come home.

He said both Mr and Mrs Blair were "strict disciplinarians" and insisted the incident would not stop Mr Blair spelling out his message about the need to increase individual responsibility.

"That is how he lives his life and how he brings up his children but that does not mean his children will not misbehave."

Press coverage

Lord Wakeham, chairman of the press complaints commission, said in a statement: "The incident involving Euan Blair inevitably raises questions about the application of the editors' code of practice in relation to it.

"As Euan is over 16 and was not at school at the time of the incident there is no restriction in the code on the use of photographs of him relating to the incident or reports about the incident itself, as the prime minister and Mrs Blair themselves recognise.

"However, I am sure that on the wider front, all editors will take into account the prime minister and Mrs Blair's clear commitment to do all they can to protect the privacy of their children and will bear in mind the general provisions in the code on the reporting of private lives of children, and family life."

Troublesome teenagers

The incident comes two-and-a-half years after the teenage son of home secretary Jack Straw was caught selling cannabis to a tabloid newspaper reporter.

William Straw, 17, was cautioned by police after he sold the drugs for £10 to a Mirror reporter in a pub in Clapham, south London, at Christmas 1997.

There were nine days of legal wrangling before William, who is now a second year student at Oxford University, could be named by the media in England.

The teenager was identified in Scotland, in foreign newspapers and on the internet while a ban on naming him remained in force in the rest of the UK.

After a judge ruled the ban could be lifted, the home secretary said he had been "disturbed" by legal issues which had prevented him "speaking openly" about his son's actions.

The home secretary, whose post includes responsibility for youth crime and drugs policy, took his son to Kennington police station in south London to admit his drug dealing, after being warned by the Mirror of the forthcoming story.

fields.headline: Excitement, Excuses and Exchanges
fields.trailText: KIWI POLISHES OFF SOUTH AFRICANS
fields.body:
KIWI POLISHES OFF SOUTH AFRICANS

As the sun rose over Zurich this morning, South Africa, Germany and Morocco were all still in with a chance of hosting the 2006 World Cup (alright, alright, England were in with a shout as well, but come on). Later in the day, however, as Fifa's 24-man Fifa executive committee got down to the business of voting, it soon became clear to even the most myopic English jingoist that the real race was between favourites South Africa and the Germans.

This was because England and Morocco had been told to sling their hook early doors after receiving a piffling number of votes. Morocco, with three votes, were knocked out in the first round; England, who had polled a mammoth five votes in the first, were eliminated with two in the second.

Once the chaff had been separated from the stunningly low-quality chaff, Germany and South Africa were level with 11 votes each, leaving the Africans in a strong position. They only needed one of the two remaining floating votes: Sepp Blatter, who favoured their bid, would have the casting vote in the event of a draw, and New Zealand's Charles Dempsey had promised to vote for South Africa if his first choice, England, had been eliminated. Which, of course, they had been.

A South African shoo-in, you'd imagine. But, amazingly, Kiwi Dempsey threw a frozen leg of lamb in the works, abstaining from the final round of voting and handing Germany a 12-11 victory - and with it the 2006 World Cup. "I am sorry for all three of those countries who did not win," said Franz Beckenbauer as he pulled on an All-Black shirt. "I know, having been a sportsman, what it is like to lose and what it is like to win," he continued, breaking into a haka.

FIFA FO FUM, HERE ARE THE BONES OF SOME ENGLISHMEN

And what of England? You'd think that after mustering a paltry five votes in the first round, and a pathetic two in the second, some sort of public apology would be forthcoming from those responsible. Especially given the £10.5m they've spent. Well think again, sucker. Instead, campaign director Alec McGivan oh-so-predictably passed the buck onto those pesky hooligans going riot-about during Euro 2000.

"I think our hopes of getting one or two European votes died the day the hooligans took to the streets of Charleroi," claimed McGivan. "If we could have built on five or six votes from either the South Americans or one or two Europeans this result today could have been very, very different." Very, very different? In the very, very different sense that England would have got seven votes in the first round and four in the second, and still been KO'd when they were?

But he wasn't the only guilty party. Last Friday, Tony Banks was telling all and sundry that "Germany cannot win the race to host the 2006 World Cup". So today you might have expected him to be a little bit sheepish. But was he? Oh no. "The situation changed dramatically hour by hour," claimed Banks, who refused to admit he'd got it wrong. "At some stage over the past few days, everyone thought Germany had lost and South Africa had won as well," he explained. "With the benefit of hindsight, no-one ever gets it wrong."

That maybe the case, but you don't need hindsight to predict that you'd have more chance of success if you didn't renege on a gentleman's agreement to back Germany, offend Lennart Johannson and most of Uefa by doing so, or annoy Sepp Blatter by saying he'd "live to regret supporting South Africa". In fact, such sterling work has probably ensured the World Cup won't come to England again for at least another generation. Nice work lads!

LET'S CHEER UP ALEC, TONE AND BOB!

Poor Alec McGivan. Such a shame for Bobby Charlton. And aah diddums to Tony Banks. They've all worked very hard to bring the 2006 World Cup to dear old Blighty, and for what? For nothing, that's what. So let's cheer them up.

If you have an idea which may bring a smile back to their glum little faces, email the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll set the wheels in motion. If we can be bothered, that is.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Africa is a member of the Fifa family and a family can't keep feeding one child and leaving the others to starve which is what they have done today" - South African bid leader Danny Jordaan, neither bitter nor melodramatic.

COME HOME

Football isn't just about political manoeuvring on a massive scale - it's also about football. So with a heavy but responsible heart, the Fiver turns its attentions back to domestic matters. And isn't it all so very exciting?!?

Take events at Bradford, where new high-profile boss Chris Thingummy is buying as many players as he possibly can. Only a few days after landing Ian Nolan and Peter Atherton from Sheffield Wednesday, Whatshisname Hutchings has agreed a club-record £2.5m deal for Leeds midfielder David Hopkin. Obviously having one ginger midfielder of limited talent in Stuart McCall is not enough.

"Paying this kind of money is something we have got to do if we are going to compete in the Premiership," explained City chairman Geoffrey Richmond, showing off his fancy new wallet. "And this won't be the last signing of the summer!" he continued, wafting it irritatingly in the faces of innocent bystanders. "By the time the Premier League season starts we will have signed another one or two players," he boasted, wantonly posting 20p pieces down the nearest drain cover.

Hopkin is expected to sign a four-year contract this weekend and - hoy, stop reading the small print of Morocco's World Cup bid and listen!

THE RUMOUR MILL

Real Madrid are hoping to sign Luis Figo in a world record £38.1m deal. The Spanish club are also reported to be "very serious" about signing Zinedine Zidane.

Juventus captain Antonio Conte has rejected overtures from Chelsea and Aston Villa to stay in Serie A. "As I have said, I want to end my career with Juve, and my attachment to the club is beyond argument," confirmed Conte.

NEWS IN BRIEF

The redevelopment of Wembley Stadium will go ahead, despite England failing in their bid to stage the 2006 World Cup.

Liverpool have told Leicester manager Peter Taylor that first-team coach Sammy Lee is going nowhere. Taylor would reportedly like to make Lee his assistant at Filbert Street after working with him when England Under-21 boss.

Sunderland have renewed their £4m interest in Rangers captain Lorenzo Amoruso, despite the Italian defender being sidelined with an ankle problem.

Everton striker Kevin Campbell should be back in action by the middle of September. Campbell is recovering well from knee surgery and is due to resume full training at the start of August.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Channel 5: Major League Soccer (4.30am)

From a country capable of putting together a half-decent World Cup bid.

Sky Sports 2: Fifa TV (6.30pm, 11.15pm)

From an organisation capable of rejecting a half-arsed World Cup bid.

fields.headline: 'Failing' jail may be privatised
fields.standfirst:
Brixton prison faces takeover after revelation of punishment scandal

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Brixton prison in south London faces the threat of privatisation after the discovery of a punishment scandal in which mainly young, black inmates were locked in their cells without the governor's permission.
fields.body:
Brixton prison in south London faces the threat of privatisation after the discovery of a punishment scandal in which mainly young, black inmates were locked in their cells without the governor's permission.

The prisons minister, Paul Boateng, is believed to have pressed yesterday for the troubled jail - which he has already described as a "failing institution" - to be offered to a private prison company.

Last night a prison service spokeswoman said: "No decision has yet been taken. An announcement on the future of Brixton will be made very soon, possibly next week."

A decision to offer Brixton to the private sector would make it the first public sector jail to be market tested and would send a shock wave through the rest of the 120 state-run prisons in England and Wales.

A press briefing on the future of the jail, which had been scheduled for today, was last night cancelled at short notice. It is believed that a serious argument is going on within the prison service about whether the jail will be privatised.

It is thought that inmates, often young and black, were locked up and segregated as punishment without the proper guidelines being followed. Proper procedure would include a written report to the governor followed by an adjudication hearing the next morning at which the inmate would be able to give his side of the story.

A week ago the chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, visited Brixton in an unannounced snap inspection. The conditions he found in the healthcare wing were so appalling he said: "I have never seen such conditions anywhere in the country."

He rang the director general of the prison service, Martin Narey, and demanded that he see the conditions for himself. Mr Narey has since visited Brixton.

The crisis at the jail has been exacerbated by the fact that the governor, Bob Chapman, is leaving and is believed to have been unaware of what was happening.

He is to be replaced by Stephen Twinn, the first prison governor to come back to the public sector from a private prison company. Mr Twinn, the first director of Group 4's Wolds prison on Humberside, has been working in Australia and is now at prison service headquarters working on a computer project.

Brixton was the scene of an infamous IRA escape in the late 1980s and conditions at the prison last became a matter of national concern in the early 1990s.

Since then the jail has lost its role as the main high security remand prison for major trials taking place at the Old Bailey in London. It is now used mainly as a local prison.

Last night a prison service spokeswoman confirmed that market testing, or privatisation, was under consideration.

"An audit is currently looking at staff/prisoner relations, including the state of race relations within the prison. The findings will be sent to the director general," she said.

The discovery of the punishment scandal is particularly embarrassing as it comes at a time when the prison service, along with the rest of the criminal justice system, is making a particular effort to combat racism.

The threat of privatisation had been hanging over a second London prison, Wormwood Scrubs in the west of the capital, but this was lifted after the chief inspector of prisons published a report showing a sharp improvement in conditions.
