fields.headline: Buying weapons for Britain's army
fields.trailText:
Why is defence spending in the news?
A national audit office (NAO) report out today says delays in producing weapons are costing taxpayers more than £3bn. A wide range of projects, including the Eurofighter, frigates and helicopters for the navy, are running far over budget.
fields.body:
Why is defence spending in the news?
A national audit office (NAO) report out today says delays in producing weapons are costing taxpayers more than £3bn. A wide range of projects, including the Eurofighter, frigates and helicopters for the navy, are running far over budget.

Is the situation getting worse?
Yes, according to the spending watchdog. It found that the country's 25 major defence projects are running, on average, 47 months late compared with 43 months in its report last year.

What does the government have to say for itself?
It says its new "smart procurement initiative" should improve the purchase of major pieces of equipment, identify problems earlier and ensure costs do not escalate. The NAO, however, said it was too early to tell whether the programme would fulfil all of its goals.

What weapons are the armed forces are waiting for?
They include the Trigat anti-tank weapon. The delays have forced the army to order more of the weapon the Trigat is designed to replace - the Milan - even though the ministry of defence admits that the Milan is not ideal against modern tanks.

Have shortages and delays affected forces in the field?
All 300,000 rifles used by Britain's forces are expected to be recalled for modifications costing millions of pounds because they tend to jam in extreme temperatures. During the Kosovo war, the Tornado GR4, the latest version of Britain's warplane, had trouble dropping precision-guided, or smart, bombs because a new laser-guided targeting system was not delivered in full working order.

Who purchases military equipment?
The buying is done by the defence procurement agency (DPA), part of the ministry of defence (MoD). The DPA buys over £5bn of new equipment and spares for the armed forces annually, which makes it the single biggest purchaser of manufactured goods in the UK. At any one time, its 5,500 staff are managing more than 13,000 contracts, ranging from the purchase of submarines to small parts for a field radio.

What is the history of the DPA?
Based at Abbey Wood, north Bristol, the DPA was created on 1 April 1999, replacing the MoD procurement executive, which could be traced back to its roots in the admiralty, war office and air ministry. The Labour government created the DPA in an attempt to streamline a complicated process as part of its smart procurement initiative.

How does the purchasing process work?
The DPA says competition is fundamental to achieving value for money so competitive bidding is used wherever possible. MoD does not simply accept the cheapest bid, but that which provides the best overall value for money, taking account of all relevant factors. Politics also enter the equation; governments sometimes will opt for buying domestic instead of cheaper foreign systems for reasons of national pride and security. During the Thatcher years, there was an almighty split within the Conservative government on whether to buy helicopters made by Westland (British) or Sikorski (American).

So why are cost overruns so common in buying weapons?
Buying a weapon is like getting an estimate on a new building; the final cost invariably is more than the initial estimate. Cost overruns in the US defence procurement are legion and legendary - the Pentagon was once charged $800 for a toilet seat. The problem could get worse as European governments encourage weapons makers to merge to cut costs. In the US, there is now only a handful of giant defence corporations like Lockheed Martin and Boeing. With fewer companies to supply arms, governments could have less bargaining power.

What will be the future of British procurement?
This is going to get even more complicated as Britain has set up a joint armaments procurement agency with, France, Germany and Italy. Occar (Organisation Conjoint de Co-operation en matiere d'armement) will establish a centre of practical expertise, developing procedures based on best practice and learning lessons from the past.

fields.headline: England's World Cup bid
fields.standfirst: Football's world governing body met today to decide who will host the 2006 World Cup. Randeep Ramesh explains why it wasn't England.
fields.trailText: Football's world governing body met today to decide who will host the 2006 World Cup. Randeep Ramesh explains why it wasn't England.
fields.body:
Who decides?
The executive committee of Fifa, the Fédération Internationale de Football Association, which has run world football since 1904. Its 24-strong ruling council - made up of representatives from countries not pitching for the 2006 World Cup - had to choose between England, Germany, South Africa and Morocco. Germany won.

What did the front runners have to do?
All four would-be hosts went through a beauty contest in front of the executive committee where they paraded their bid's best points. In the case of Germany, that appeared to be Claudia Schiffer, Franz Beckenbauer and chancellor Gerhard Schroeder.

How is the decision made?
Each member of the council casts a vote in secret. If no country has an overall majority, ie 13, the candidate with the least votes drops out and the process is repeated until one of the bidders comes out on top. This year, one country abstained, ensuring that Germany clinched the cup without the executive committee having to resort to the casting vote of Fifa president Sepp Blatter.

Why was England's bid doomed?
England's bid was led by Sir Bobby Charlton and former sports minister Tony Banks and its slick presentation concentrated on the £1bn spent on improving stadiums as well as the importance of the English Premiership - with such stars as Kanu, Ginola and Beckham - to the rest of world football. But England's hopes have been dashed since English football hooligans rampaged through the streets of Belgium during Euro2000.

So who were the favourites?
Germany and South Africa, by a football pitch. Germany had been quietly working Fifa conferences, highlighting its impressive sporting facilities and the ability to handle the thousands of football fans who will arrive should the country host the 2006 tournament. South Africa's bid was spearheaded by former president Nelson Mandela and its emotional appeal centred around crowning the country's rise from political pariah during the apartheid years to African model of post-colonial success. Its hand was thought to be strengthened by the fact that Africa has never hosted the competition - whereas Germany had the World Cup in 1974. This failed to swing it with the judges, however.

So it should have been Africa's turn?
Many countries think so. Brazil dropped plans to host the 2006 World Cup and backed South Africa saying that the competition should not be "repeated in Europe". Many of the smaller nations who had a vote were supporting South Africa - including Mali, Trinidad and Tobago, Argentina and Paraguay. South Africa in return said they would support moves in Fifa that would help boost these countries' soccer industries.

What does Fifa have to do with these smaller countries?
Back in 1974, the World Cup was very much a trial of strength between Europe with nine teams and South America with four. The ripples created by political upheavals, particularly in Africa where many former colonies had been granted independence, were beginning to be noticed on the international sports scene. At that time Africa, Asia, and North/Central America and the Caribbean (Concacaf) were each still sending one selection to the world's greatest football fiesta. For the 1982 World Cup in Spain, political pressure on Fifa increased the table of competitors to twenty-four teams.

Who was backing England?
By the second round, it appeared that only its neighbour, Scotland and its former colony, New Zealand.

webTitle: Maoists and police sow terror in Nepal

fields.headline: Maoists and police sow terror in Nepal
fields.trailText: They arrived at Rama Yadav's house at night, locked his children in the kitchen and seized his cashbox. Then the Maoist rebels who have been fighting the Nepalese state for four years fled to a nearby village.
fields.body:
They arrived at Rama Yadav's house at night, locked his children in the kitchen and seized his cashbox. Then the Maoist rebels who have been fighting the Nepalese state for four years fled to a nearby village.

The police caught up with them there. Six rebels unwisely took shelter in a house. The police set light to it. In the gun battle that followed all the rebels were shot dead except one - 17-year-old Bhagwati Chaudhary.

According to human rights agencies, the police interrogated her, then shot her. That summary execution last month is just the latest example of extra-judicial killing in Nepal.

Since 1996 the authorities have been struggling to contain the growing communist insurgency in the remote middle west of what was once a peaceful Himalayan kingdom. At least 1,500 people have been killed, two-thirds of them by the Nepalese police.

"We have very clear evidence that extra-judicial killing is going on," Krishna Pahadi of the Human Rights and Peace Society said. "If the police suspect someone of being a Maoist, they simply kill them."

The situation has become so grave that the European Union recently intervened for the first time, urging the Nepalese government not to violate human rights and to begin talks with the Maoist rebels.

Nepal's hardline prime minister, Girja Koirala, who came to power in March advocating a military solution to the Maoist problem, now appears to have responded to international pressure. "There is no alternative to talks," he said. But his critics say he is not serious about negotiation.

The Maoist guerrillas have also been responsible for a series of outrages. Two months ago the rebels beheaded a suspected informer, leaving the victim's head in a tree. Last month they killed 21 people, including 12 policemen, during a gunfight in the Jarjarkot district of western Nepal.

They have ruthlessly eliminated supporters of the ruling Nepali Congress and other rival parties. About 1.5m of Nepal's 20m people now live under their control, in what amounts to a de facto state run from the hill district of Rolpa.

Active also in several districts in the east of Nepal, they have an army of between 3,000 and 5,000 troops, armed with home-made guns and primitive bombs.

Successive governments in Kathmandu have been slow to respond to the crisis. Last month 150 refugees from the west of Nepal arrived in Kathmandu after a gruelling 26-day trek, seeking government protection. They say that their MPs are now too scared to live in the districts they represent.

"We have become victims of both police and Maoist guerrillas. In the eyes of the police, we are the supporters of Maoists, and in the eyes of Maoist guerrillas we are informers to the police," Him Bahadur Budha, from Rolpa, said.

The insurgency is masterminded by Prachanda, the general secretary of the underground Maoist Communist party. His aim is to overthrow Nepal's constitutional monarchy and replace it with a Maoist republic.

The group, which began its uprising in February 1996, has links with other revolutionary groups. In Maoist villages, where the red flag flies, Prachanda has introduced collective farming. His cadres collect taxes and impose justice.

Padma Ratna Tuladhar, a former MP who has been asked by the prime minister to negotiate with the rebels, said last weekend that he was "pessimistic" that the conflict could be swiftly resolved.

Before sitting down to talks, the Maoists want the police to account for more than 40 supporters who have disappeared while in custody. Before his government collapsed under the pressure of the Maoist problem, the former prime minister Krishna Bhattarai said that many of the detainees had been executed without trial.

The Maoists' paper, Janesh, recently conceded that some members had grown corrupt. The movement was going through a period of "critical self-evaluation", it said.

But in many areas the Maoists continue to enjoy a high level of popular support. In the village of Kara, for example, which the police burned to the ground last year, the son of a prominent politician kidnapped by the Maoists has been put to work as a stonemason.

Pitamber Sharma, of the Integrated Centre for Mountain Development, said last weekend that only economic reform could stop the insurgency.

"In the mountains, 60-65 per cent live below the poverty line. There is no electricity, no television and no transport," he said.

"I don't see any prospect of the Maoists taking over Nepal. But if conditions continue as they do, we are going to create a situation of protracted civil war."

webTitle: Making trading grades an educational option

fields.headline: Making trading grades an educational option
fields.standfirst: Education correspondent Rebecca Smithers welcomes government moves to standardise vocational qualifications with academic exams
fields.trailText: Education correspondent Rebecca Smithers welcomes government moves to standardise vocational qualifications with academic exams.
fields.body:
It's all in a name, so they say, and never more so than in the case of qualifications. The government has struggled in vain to give more credibility to the appallingly-named GNVQ (General National Vocational Qualification) in order to encourage more take-up. Today it is announcing that it is relaunching foundation, intermediate and part one GNVQs as 'vocational GCSEs' in 2002. The move follows the government's parallel decision earlier this year to rename advanced level GNVQs as 'vocational A-levels' from September.

Vocational GCSEs will be available in subjects such as manufacturing, information technology, healthcare, catering, construction, retail, engineering as well as art and design and business. Ministers envisage that the new qualifications will attract not only 14 to 16-year olds as part of their Key Stage Four studies but also 16 to 19 year olds in college who want to study a vocational course below advanced level. Students would typically move through apprenticeship schemes and into the new-style foundation degrees and on to work-based qualifications.

The problem has been that since their introduction in 1992, GNVQs have been hailed by ministers as the practical equivalents to GCSEs and A-levels. But the public perception of the qualification has lagged behind the more academic options, and completion rates of the GNVQ have been overall very low.

So will a change of name make a difference? 'Vocational' qualifications have always suffered as the poor cousins of their 'academic' counterparts. And the kind of careers which they lead to are often treated rather scathingly by politicians and educationalists. Education and employment secretary David Blunkett is always a bit sniffy about young female hairdressers, who he thinks should strive much higher and aspire to university. And his colleague, chief inspector of schools Chris Woodhead, has appeared equally condescending towards teenagers who are not academically gifted, who he thinks should be allowed to leave education and train for a trade such as bricklaying or plumbing.

The whole issue of how training and the attainment of practical skills is formally recognised as qualifications on pieces of paper is not as polarised as it used to be. In the old days a trade was a trade, and that was it. You opted for university, an office or clerical job or a 'trade'. These days the picture is more blurred. There is now, thankfully, a recognition that there is an entire spectrum of children whom it would be unfair to label either academic or vocational, with nothing in between.

The final report from the Skills Task Force last week found that 40% of all skills shortages were in craft and technician-type jobs, requiring high-level skills gained through substantial job-specific, work-based training. The government's move today is to be welcomed, although further simplification of the maze of different qualifications should be the next step. in order to create a readily understandable common currency.

fields.headline: Is the price right?
fields.standfirst:
As the summer sales get underway Claire Phipps charts the perils and pitfalls facing the bargain hunter

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: As the summer sales get underway Claire Phipps charts the perils and pitfalls facing the bargain hunter
fields.body:
We all love a bargain. Or at least, we all love to think we're getting a bargain. But with "sale" notices now a permanent fixture in many high street shop windows, how can the consumer be sure of leaving the store with a genuine saving?

There are, of course, regulations which aim to protect the consumer from the more unscrupulous traders. A sale cannot continue indefinitely, as curtain firm Roseby's discovered two years ago, when the director general of fair trading, John Bridgeman, ruled that the display of "closing down sale" signs in their shop windows - some for up to a year at a time, and with no stated closing date - was misleading. "Using extended closing down sales to entice consumers into a shop and spend money when there is no closing date in prospect is extremely misleading," said Bridgeman. "Consumers should be able to shop in the confidence that they are getting genuine closing down offers."

And they should, by extension, be able to shop in the confidence that a sale price is just that. With constant sales - spring, summer, late summer, autumn, winter, new year, vernal equinox, any excuse - it can be difficult to keep track of what the real price of merchandise ought to be. It also arouses suspicion among shoppers asked to pay the full price for an item. If a store can flog televisions with a saving of £200 for half the year, are their prices artificially inflated in the non-sale periods?

It's this scepticism which has persuaded some of the larger chains to eschew one-off sales in favour of a permanent commitment to match competitors' prices. It's a policy that department store chain John Lewis has long held. "A sale can mean all kinds of things," says spokesman Greg Williams. "We call our events a clearance, because that's exactly what we do - we get the goods off the shelves at special terms to make room for the new. Any shop can say, 'we're good value' or have a July 2 sale. But we avoid the word sale because we should be beating our competitors all year round." And he believes the store's "never knowingly undersold" motto gives customers the confidence to shop without suspicion: "They can be reassured that they're getting the best price. If you have a sale price, customers are going to wonder why you've not got that price the next day."

Retailers cannot conjure sale prices out of thin air (although where they find the merchandise to stock the sale is another matter). According to the Consumer Protection Act 1987, the previous price, as well as the reduction, should be clearly marked. Moreover, "the product must have been available to consumers at that price for at least 28 consecutive days in the previous six months". If this is not the case, the retailer must display a notice to that effect. An item doesn't have to be on sale at its sale price for 28 days before being reduced again, but the code requires the store to mention all the intervening prices for the item.

Higher prices don't have to be displayed, however, for "special purchases". These are what you see on sale day when you enter a favourite store to see the rails stacked with unfamiliar merchandise - goods that have been bought in just for the sale, and have never previously been sold there, at a reduced, or any other price.

"At Next, everything is genuine, this season's merchandise," explains spokesperson Christine Gerrard. "People know it's the same quality, and the same value, but often half price. There's a low risk involved in buying at our sales." Next branches have sales promotions only twice a year - July and Christmas - and don't discount merchandise at any other time. Sales are scheduled to last 10-14 days, but often finish earlier as the mountain of stock disappears quickly. "People often queue from 2am," says Gerrard. "We have to draft in extra help just to limit the number of customers coming into the store."

Next also flags its no-quibbles returns policy, even on sale goods. Many consumers are confused by the new signs that spring up in shops at discount time, warning that there are "no refunds on sale goods."But this isn't the case, says the Consumers' Association, which points out that your statutory rights allow you to return any item that is faulty, no matter when you bought it. Retailers are within their rights, however, to refuse to give you your money back on a sale item bought in haste and resented at leisure - after all, the point of these sales is to prevent the stock clogging up the company warehouses.

"Your rights are exactly the same in the sales as at any other time," explain the Office of Fair Trading. Your statutory rights, which state that any items you buy must be of satisfactory quality, fit for their purpose and sold as described, remain the same, unless you buy goods that are clearly marked as faulty.

The real difference, of course, is the consumer's attitude towards the sales - that almost manic enthusiasm that inspires the most dedicated to camp out overnight in the hope of snaring the ultimate bargain. If most of us are not so resolute, there can be few people who can honestly say that they have never been tempted by a "50% off" price tag and impulsively purchased an item which would forever remain at the back of the wardrobe. (Incidentally, beware those "up to 50% off" notices: only 10% of the goods have to be thus discounted.)

Could our addiction to the sales be weakening? With many stores now making "price promises", offering your money back if you can find the same item cheaper elsewhere, and the internet opening up a new avenue for discounted goods, it's perfectly possible to track down a good deal at any time of year. According to the Consumers' Association, it's time to go back to basics: "the best way to get a good deal is to shop around and simply buy from the store which offers the best price."

As if the endless queues, the bruises from fellow shoppers with specially-sharpened elbows and the multi-paged credit card bill weren't proof enough, the speed with which retailers manage to clear out their unwanted stock simply by posting a sale banner is a clue to the fact that sales aren't just there for the penny-conscious shopper. They do, in addition, have the power to make us abandon the usual rules of buying goods, namely: is it any good? If it's a rip-off at full price, chances are that it won't be the bargain of a lifetime even with 50% off. After all, says Williams, "there's a difference between cheapness and value."

webTitle: How much can you pay for

fields.headline: How much can you pay for
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: ... a bath plug and chain
fields.body:
... a bath plug and chain

If, as Adam Smith had it, "the chief enjoyment of riches consists in the parade of riches", you could be forgiven for asking why anyone would spend £140 on a Czech and Speake plug and chain for the bath.

True, if you adhere to Czech and Speake's belief that bathing should be "a pleasurable ritual of privacy, comfort and well-being", you won't want to run your toe along just any old chain - and few are as smooth and sumptuous as this wonderful chrome creation.

As you lie back and admire the elegance of your overflow, neatly engraved with the company name, it will be hard to dispel the doubt that this is a rather pointless extravagance. But you could congratulate yourself on your restraint. The chrome bath, with its special waste system that dispenses completely with the need for a plug and chain, would have been a far greater indulgence at £2,650. But at least it would be one your guests would notice. Call Czech and Speake on 020 7439 0216.

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: For your baby
fields.body:
For your baby

Ideal for shopping if you just happen to be up at 3am, baby-focused web sites look set to boom.

Launched on Friday, www.b4baby.com offers information, advice and shopping for new parents and parents to be.

Split into four areas or lifestages, which span pre-conception to being a parent, the site promises a "grown-up" approach to "controversial" questions, such as "Does an orgasm help you conceive?" There is plenty of advice on things you might genuinely be too embarrassed to ask, but need to know - such as how to change a nappy.

Having brought on board many of the major suppliers of nursery goods, toys and clothing the b4baby shop will stock everything from nappies to baby buggies. In addition to the likes of Maclaren, Pampers and Safety First, they hope to source some of the harder-to-find brands.

Mothercare.com took its first tentative steps into the world of e-commerce last month. There are around 2,500 products, ranging from toys and clothing to furniture, but this is just a taster: the site launches officially in September. In addition to bulletin boards and chatlines, the site offers expert advice on health, pregnancy, childcare and parental issues.

Delivery is usually within five working days and is £3, or free on orders for more than £60.

webTitle: Soldiers return to the Belfast streets

fields.headline: Soldiers return to the Belfast streets
fields.standfirst: Former Northern Ireland correspondent Derek Brown traces the troubled history of British troops in the province.
fields.trailText: Former Northern Ireland correspondent Derek Brown traces the troubled history of British troops in the province.
fields.body:
British soldiers are back on the streets of Belfast for the first time in two years.

The decision to send in the troops in support of the Royal Ulster Constabulary came after four successive nights of loyalist violence across the province, in support of the Orange Order's demand to be allowed to march along the nationalist Garvaghy Road in Portadown.

Security spokesmen in Northern Ireland insist that there will be no return to routine military patrolling, and that the few hundred soldiers involved will be deployed at trouble spots, especially the 'front lines' between loyalist and nationalist areas.

There are less than 10,000 regular soldiers in Northern Ireland today, not including the full and part-time locally recruited members of the Royal Irish Rangers. At the peak of the Troubles in the 1970s, more than 22,000 British troops served in the province, most of them on short tours of four to six months at a time.

The first troops were deployed in August 1969, when the RUC and its notorious reserve force of B Specials failed to control republican rioting in Derry. At first, they were greeted as protectors by the Catholic population. All that changed when the old Unionist government in Stormont insisted that the troops be used to suppress the IRA.

From 1970, and especially after the introduction of internment without trial in 1971, the army was engaged in a brutal campaign against the republican paramilitary movement, spearheaded by the Provisional IRA. It has also from time to time been embroiled in ugly battles with the various loyalist paramilitary groups. Gunner Robert Curtis, the first of more than 400 soldiers to die in Northern Ireland, was shot in the staunchly Protestant Shankill Road in Belfast in February 1971.

In the early days, the top brass was appalled to be involved in a police action, within the United Kingdom. But it quickly became apparent that Northern Ireland was the army's best training ground, for ordinary infantry and for special units alike.

The constant danger of patrolling and garrisoning nationalist areas instilled discipline and teamwork. It allowed the development of new techniques, for example in surveillance and bomb disposal. It also spawned a new military jargon, as the planners worked on the new concept of 'low intensity operations'.

Though the generals and staff officers quickly latched on to the usefulness of Northern Ireland, most squaddies loathed it. It wasn't a hardship post for the few battalions which served two-year tours in long established military barracks, accompanied by their families. But for the majority on four-month tours it was deeply uncomfortable as well as deadly dangerous.

One of the early makeshift barracks in central Belfast was literally a bombsite, the remains of an old hotel. Another was a crumbling, derelict factory in Hastings Street, the target of many an IRA sniper.

In Derry, units were housed in ancient Nissan huts, while others were cooped up in a hastily fortified abandoned garage in the heart of the hostile Creggan estate. Perhaps the worst outpost was the hugely sandbagged and steel-plated police station in Crossmaglen - XMG to the officer-class - in South Armagh, known to all ranks as cowboy country.

Patrolling the mine- and sniper-infested country around Crossmaglen was so dangerous that soldiers were helicoptered in and out of the police station compound. Even the rubbish was sent out by air.

Though it is more than five years since the IRA and the main loyalist paramilitaries declared their first ceasefires, there will be no shortage of serving soldiers with experience of active operations in Northern Ireland. Perhaps some of them will be exhilarated by the prospect of more of the same. The majority, almost certainly, will be deeply depressed.

fields.headline: What they said
fields.trailText: Today
fields.body:
Today

Prime minister Tony Blair
"It's, well, being a prime minister can be a tough job but I always think being a parent is probably tougher. Sometimes you don't always succeed, but the family to me is more important than anything else."

Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman
"Euan is very sorry for the inconvenience he caused to the police, the state he was in, and for the false statement that he made. He is in no doubt of the seriousness of it and the view that his parents take of it."

Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy
"I think everybody in the country will have every sympathy with the Blair family. We all shared a great deal of happiness for them with the new baby arriving, and they are experiencing a slight domestic setback of a type which probably affects just about every home in the land."

John McIntosh, headmaster of Euan's school, the Oratory
"As far as I'm concerned it is a private matter, not a school matter because term has finished."

Chairman of the press complaints commission Lord Wakeham
"The incident involving Euan Blair inevitably raises questions about the application of the editors' code of practice in relation to it. As Euan is over 16 and was not at school at the time of the incident there is no restriction in the code on the use of photographs of him relating to the incident or reports about the incident itself, as the prime minister and Mrs Blair themselves recognise.

Dean Cooper, a doorman at the Odeon Cinema, Leicester Square, who saw an ambulance arrive and a youth put inside it
"Here when you see an ambulance arrive and pick up some kids it's not a big deal, nobody thought much of it."

Dorit Braun, Parentline chief executive
"It probably isn't a coincidence that Tony Blair has been speaking about the unfortunate consequences of using too much alcohol and that's precisely what his son does. That is classic teenage rebellious behaviour - and it's completely normal."

Last week

Prime minister's official spokesman Alastair Campbell
"There is a very real issue with young louts causing mayhem up and down the country on a Friday night."

Tony Blair, in a speech in Germany
"A thug might think twice about kicking in your gate, throwing traffic cones around your street or hurling abuse into the night sky if he thought he might get picked up by the police, taken to a cashpoint and asked to pay an on-the-spot fine of, for example, £100."

webTitle: Germany to host the 2006 World Cup

fields.headline: Germany to host the 2006 World Cup
fields.standfirst:
Germany and South Africa go to the wire
How the bidders pitched it
fields.trailText: Germany will host the 2006 World Cup after coming from behind to shock massive favourites South Africa in the final round of voting. England were knocked out in the second round.
fields.body:
Germany will host the 2006 World Cup after coming from behind to shock massive favourites South Africa in the final round of voting. England were knocked out in the second round.

But Germany won by the narrowest margin possible - 12-11, after New Zealand's Charles Dempsey inexplicably decided to abstain in the last round, despite earlier promising South Africa his vote.

Fifa president Sepp Blatter announced the verdict of his 24-man Fifa executive committee to a packed press conference at the Hallenstadion in Zurich.

England's £10m bid picked up only two votes in the second round after receiving five in the first. Their first-round support is understood to have come from Scotland's David Will as well as Charles Dempsey and the three Central American representatives.

However, that Central American trio abandoned the English bid after the first round, in which Morocco were eliminated with just three votes.

Campaign director Alec McGivan couldn't hide his disappointment after seeing England's bid fail. And he laid the blame for the defeat firmly at the feet of the rioting hooligans in Charleroi before last month's game with Germany in Euro 2000.

"I think our hopes of getting one or two European votes died the day the hooligans took to the streets of Charleroi," conceded McGivan. "And if I'm honest I think that was an impossible position to recover from within the context of European opinion.

"We could have progressed if we'd got one or two votes and only one or two votes would have done the job for us from Europe. And right throughout this campaign we hoped that we could pick away at the German votes in Europe and achieve one or two for ourselves," he added.

"If we could have built on five or six votes from either the South Americans or one or two Europeans this result today could have been very, very different."

The key to Germany's shock triumph was a last-ditch deal hatched with the four Asian representatives on the Fifa executive last night. Sensing that Asian discontent over a disagreement with Fifa president Sepp Blatter about voting rights on the executive committee was still lingering, the Germans exploited the advantage to its maximum.

Both Germany and South Africa received 11 votes each in the second phase, which meant that South Africa need just one more vote to shift in their favour to host the tournament - because Blatter, who holds the casting vote in the event of a tie, was in favour of their bid.

At that stage the South Africans were confident they would get at least one of the two remaining votes.

"I think, if we have counted right, the vote will come to us from Charles Dempsey. He had promised us that if England were eliminated before the final round, his vote would come to South Africa," said Emmanuel Maradas, one of the South African bidding team.

However, the Germans managed to nose ahead at the last minute by persuading the Asian delegates to back their bid - and because of Dempsey's surprise abstention.

fields.headline: Spike Lee slams Patriot
fields.trailText: Director Spike Lee has lashed out at The Patriot, and all but accused the Mel Gibson blockbuster of racism, in a forceful letter to the editor of the Hollywood Reporter
fields.body:
Director Spike Lee has lashed out at The Patriot, and all but accused the Mel Gibson blockbuster of racism, in a forceful letter to the editor of the Hollywood Reporter. The Patriot stars Gibson as a hero of the American War of Independence and opened in the States to decent reviews and solid business on the July 4 holiday weekend.

But the Do the Right Thing director this week took issue with what he regards as the way The Patriot is portraying a gung-ho, sanitised version of history which turns a discreet blind eye to slavery.

In his letter, Lee, never known as the most retiring of film directors, writes that he travelled to see the film with his wife on its opening weekend. "We both came out of the theatre fuming," he claims. "For three hours The Patriot dodged around, skirted about or completely ignored slavery. How convenient... to have Mel Gibson's character not be a slaveholder... The Patriot is pure, blatant American Hollywood propaganda. A complete whitewashing of history."

Lee's broadside is not the only knock The Patriot has received in recent months. Back in March, the movie attracted criticism for a scene in which two children murder a British soldier (see our report), while last month came revelations that the true-life inspiration behind Gibson's character was, in reality, a serial rapist who hunted Red Indians for fun and - yes - kept slaves to boot (our report). Just last week, Liverpool city council was up in arms over the film, demanding an apology from the movie-makers over alleged misrepresentation of a former leading civic figure (our report).

To add insult to injury, the movie was surprisingly pipped to the US number-one slot last week by The Perfect Storm, a disaster movie starring George Clooney.

webTitle: Microsoft offers EC concession on Telewest bid

fields.headline: Microsoft offers EC concession on Telewest bid
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft offered further concessions to the European commission yesterday in an attempt to salvage its £2bn investment in Telewest, the British cable company, amid increasing doubts that the deal will go ahead.
fields.body:
Microsoft offered further concessions to the European commission yesterday in an attempt to salvage its £2bn investment in Telewest, the British cable company, amid increasing doubts that the deal will go ahead.

The American software group, which has already been found guilty of breaking US anti-monopoly laws, said yesterday that it was confident of reaching some kind of agreement with the commission over its position in British cable market.

A spokeswoman said: "We are working very closely with our colleagues in Europe and hope to come to the best conclusion for all."

However, analysts are increasingly doubtful that such an agreement can be reached. The commission is concerned about the impact of Microsoft's purchase of a 29.9% stake in Telewest on competition in the burgeoning market for digital television software in Britain.

Under the terms of the acquisition, the company would have gained joint control of Telewest with Liberty Media, another American group.

Analysts believe that the commission could insist on Microsoft giving up any control over its stake, effectively making the software company a non-voting partner for Telewest and ensuring that it has little or no control over what software is used. Telewest now uses operating software in its set-top boxes supplied by Liberate - the US group that is Microsoft's main rival.

Microsoft has already offered to adopt a laissez-faire attitude to Telewest's use of software. However, such a promise would have to be policed by regulators, something they are wary of doing.

webTitle: Bank sits on rates to flatten economy's fizz

fields.headline: Bank sits on rates to flatten economy's fizz
fields.standfirst:
The Bank of England's decision to maintain interest rates at their current level may just be enough to cool off the economy, says economics reporter Charlotte Denny
Interest rates on hold
fields.trailText: The Bank of England's decision to maintain interest rates at their current level may just be enough to cool off the economy, says economics reporter Charlotte Denny
fields.body:
The longer the Bank of England leaves rates on hold, the greater are the expectations that its next move will be to start cutting borrowing costs from the current level of 6%. Today's decision by the bank's monetary policy committee to leave the main lever for controlling the speed of the economy unchanged makes it the fifth month in a row that its members have sat on their hands. Nobody was particularly surprised - all the indicators since the MPC last met suggest that the economy is slowing down - house prices are falling, retail sales growth has slowed and wage inflation is falling back.

The bank's job is to keep inflation excluding mortgage interest payments, the underlying measure, at 2.5%, a target it has undershot for more than a year. However, the City is not yet ready to call a peak to the interest-rate cycle. Some believe that inflation in the UK economy has only been kept in check by sterling's high levels against other world currencies. A robust currency strangles manufacturing exports and makes imports of raw fuels and materials cheaper, which in turn keeps price pressures down.

Sterling is no longer in such robust form - since May it has slipped by nearly 10% against the currencies of Britain's major trading partners and it is now trading at the equivalent of DM3.10. However, by historic standards this is still quite high - when Britain joined the Exchange Rate Mechanism in 1990, DM2.95 was considered a sustainable rate, but in the event it proved cripplingly high for most exporters.

Three of the MPC members favoured raising rates at their last meeting, according to the minutes issued two weeks after the decision. Part of their argument was that the pound's fall had loosened the external choke on the economy and there was a danger of inflation creeping up again. However since the June meeting other indicators have suggested that the domestic economy is losing some of its fizz. If the MPC are satisfied that they have done enough to cool things off, then interest rates could be on hold for some time to come.

fields.headline: Mission: invisible
fields.standfirst: Dougray Scott's latest film role puts him opposite Tom Cruise in the biggest release of the summer. But, he tells  Steve Rose, he prefers the quiet life
fields.trailText: Dougray Scott's latest film role puts him opposite Tom Cruise in the biggest release of the summer. But, he tells Steve Rose , he prefers the quiet life
fields.body:
Dougray Scott's audition to play the villain in Mission: Impossible 2 was a visit to Tom Cruise's house in Los Angeles. "Tom and I chatted for about two hours," Scott recalls. "John Woo, who was going to direct the movie, was in the corner looking at me. Then we played some pool."

His opponent, the movie's hero, was also one of the film's producers. Cruise, who starred opposite Paul Newman as a pool-shooting ace in The Colour of Money, could hand Scott the biggest role of his career. So what did Scott do? "First game I wiped the table. Then I thought, 'What did I do that for? My competitive spirit has just lost me a job.' " Woo and Cruise exchanged wry glances as Tom racked up the balls for another game. "He is good, though," Scott continues. "I just got lucky. He beat me in the second game."

By the time Scott got back to his hotel room that evening, Woo and Cruise had offered him the role of Sean Ambrose, the lapsed member of the Impossible Missions Force who ruins Cruise's rock climbing holiday and generally makes his life hell. It was a huge break for Scott, best known in Britain for the TV series Soldier, Soldier.

From the outset, Scott's relationship with his co-star was a balancing act: they would be spending a great deal of time together, yet their characters had to hate each other's guts. The two roles mirror each other, from the first scene, when "Cruise" rips off his mask to reveal himself as none other than his arch-enemy. For pretty much the rest of the film, anything good guy Cruise does, bad guy Scott does, even down to getting the girl.

"He's a lovely man. He's still very humble and you can feel very comfortable with him," says Scott, who clearly doesn't believe in biting the hand that feeds him. "So that aspect of the relationship was good. But when we came to do all the fighting at the end, we naturally just kept our distance, tried to wind each other up so we got to that point of aggression where it's going to explode on screen."

The requirement that they measure up to each other physically meant Scott was trying to catch up with the perpetually buff Cruise before they'd even started shooting. "I was training for nearly a year before the film because I was really slight at the time so I had to build up a lot of muscle."

Cruise's insistence on doing his own stunts upped the ante, however, and Scott could not match his near-suicidal commitment, especially when it came to the rock climbing scenes, where Cruise dangles from a sheer rock face. "You've got to take your hat off to him and say: 'The guy's a madman, but let's admire him.' He gets a thrill out of that stuff. He's an adrenaline junkie."

Ironically, it was Scott who came closest to really hurting himself, when he fell off his motorbike. "It was one of the easiest shots: I was coming round a corner and I just had to stop the bike. But the seventh time I did it there was some gravel on the road and the front wheel just skidded. I rolled off into the curb and hurt my shoulder, but I stood up. Panicky faces all around me, I tell you, but we didn't lose any time."

This injury was one of the reasons cited in the press for the film's prolonged shooting time - nine months. Scott puts it down to bad weather and Woo's impenetrable technique. It was impossible to judge from the script how long it would take, he says. For the climactic half-hour action scene, the script merely said: "Ethan and Ambrose chase each other on motorbikes." Then: "They fight." "No one understood how it was going to look - even very experienced technical people would just shake their heads. I queried John once on how something was going to work and he said, 'Ah! I used to be an editor, you know. Get back on set!' "

The overrun cost Scott the part of Wolverine in Bryan Singer's forthcoming comic book adaptation, X-Men. So his next role exercised his brain rather than his body: a cryptographer in Michael Apted's adaptation of Robert Harris's wartime novel, Enigma. Scott shed the pounds he'd gained for M:i-2, and instead of hours in the gym spent hours in the library, learning the basics of codebreaking. Scott is now waiting to see how Britain will take to M:i-2. It has already enjoyed massive success in the US, taking around $200m. Perhaps he will never be able to pass unrecognised again.

He initially dismisses the notion. "The most famous actors in Britain are people who do TV series. When I did Soldier, Soldier, people used to stop me all the time at airports and train stations. It was just embarrassing really."

But he has just had his first brush with obsessive fans. Someone recently hand-delivered a letter to him asking for a signed photo, even though he had just moved house. And he had three stalkers in Australia, despite registering in hotels under a false name - phone calls from strangers asking him to come out and meet them, people chasing his car, faces that appeared in crowds again and again. This is one side of Cruise's lifestyle that he'd rather not share. "Poor guy. His life's under scrutiny the entire time. I'm not aware of my status as a celebrity because I don't think I am one."

M:i-2 opens tomorrow.

fields.headline: A flare for chaos
fields.standfirst:
Natasha McDowell on why the sun occasionally takes a shine to destruction
Space exploration
fields.trailText: Natasha McDowell on why the sun occasionally takes a shine to destruction
fields.body:
The ancients worshipped her. The Japanese still venerate her. As patriarchy developed, she became he; Helios and Apollo to the Greeks, and Ra, the supreme god, in Egypt.

Yet we are only now starting to understand the sun and its various moods; moods that have led a worried insurance consortium to contact Andrew Coates, at the Mullard Space Science Laboratory, part of University College London.

The sun is a rather insignificant star among its 100 billion siblings in our galaxy. But as our nearest star it is sovereign of our sky: the hub of our solar system and provider of heat and light. Earth would fit 109 times across the sun's disc; the sun's interior could hold more than 1.3 million earths. A gaseous ball, the sun's core is an immense nuclear furnace, fusing hydrogen into helium and generating the energy that is heat and light.

The solar wind is a result of the immense heat. Gases continuously boil off the sun's surface and their particles speed towards earth at more than 500km per second. Normally the earth's magnetic field helps buffer us from these particles, but when the wind turns into a gale they can penetrate our magnetic shield. For the billion-dollar satellite industry that circles out sky, the results can be catastrophic.

"Each lost satellite can be a $200m loss", says Dr Coates, "and the insurance industry is worried because it is losing money." This week he began investigating how the sun causes satellites to fail.

Just like a hormonal teenager, the sun goes through a phase every 11 years, known as the solar maximum, when it is spotty and bad-tempered. The greater the number of sunspots - dark patches where the solar magnetic field is exceptionally strong -the more violent is the sun's activity and magnetic eruptions, known as coronal mass ejections, become more common and intense. These huge bubbles of boiling gas threaded with magnetic field lines explode with the power of one billion hydrogen bombs, according to Nasa, and spray their particles into space.

"Normally the solar wind is a fairly constant flow of 1 million tons per second. When a coronal mass ejection occurs, 10 billion tons of particles erupt and some are addressed to earth," says Coates. At solar maximum, four such eruptions can happen per day.

"If the solar wind did not exist, the earth's magnetic field would be like that of a bar magnet in space," says Coates. "But like pushing on an invisible balloon, the solar wind compresses the field on the front [day] side and the night side moves away from the earth like a comet's tail."

Coronal mass ejections push the magnetic field in even further, from 60,000 km in front of the earth to around only 36,000 km. This is within the geostationary ring where satellites are positioned and can cause problems. However, the danger of solar maximum is not just one of compression.

"When the solar magnetic field is opposite to that of the earth, magnetic reconnection occurs and all hell breaks loose," says Coates. The result is an explosive process over a small volume that rips the earth's magnetic shield. Solar particles fly through the fissure. Once inside the Earth's magnetic field, they are accelerated.

Once all we knew of such geomagnetic storms were beautiful auroras, the dancing curtains of light seen at the poles. In a technological age, chaos can ensue: in the last solar maximum in 1989, the entire Quebec power system went down due to such a huge current of particles. However, as we become more dependent upon satellite communication, the danger will increase.

"To supply the mobile phone and internet demand, hundreds of satellites are being planned that will orbit the earth in the heart of the radiation belt," says Dr Coates. "Satellites have failed in the past and we need to know why."

His project is to build the communication satellite prototype of the aeroplane black box. Only this is a box that will never be retrieved. Instead, it will continuously send information about energetic particle conditions to earth. At the same time he will look at satellite losses from the past and use the information to help predict future losses.

The black box won't be built in time for the next solar maximum, only a few months away. However, the maximum effects will last for another two years and the black box will be ready during this time. So, as Coates puts it, all we can do for now is to hold our breath.

fields.headline: Spike Lee slams Patriot "whitewash"
fields.trailText: Director Spike Lee has lashed out at The Patriot, and all but accused the Mel Gibson blockbuster of racism, in a forceful letter to the editor of the Hollywood Reporter
fields.body:
Director Spike Lee has lashed out at The Patriot, and all but accused the Mel Gibson blockbuster of racism, in a forceful letter to the editor of the Hollywood Reporter. The Patriot stars Gibson as a hero of the American War of Independence and opened in the States to decent reviews and solid business on the July 4 holiday weekend.

But the Do the Right Thing director this week took issue with what he regards as the way The Patriot is portraying a gung-ho, sanitised version of history which turns a discreet blind eye to slavery.

In his letter, Lee, never known as the most retiring of film directors, writes that he travelled to see the film with his wife on its opening weekend. "We both came out of the theatre fuming," he claims. "For three hours The Patriot dodged around, skirted about or completely ignored slavery. How convenient... to have Mel Gibson's character not be a slaveholder... The Patriot is pure, blatant American Hollywood propaganda. A complete whitewashing of history."

Lee's broadside is not the only knock The Patriot has received in recent months. Back in March, the movie attracted criticism for a scene in which two children murder a British soldier (see our report), while last month came revelations that the true-life inspiration behind Gibson's character was, in reality, a serial rapist who hunted Red Indians for fun and - yes - kept slaves to boot (our report). Just last week, Liverpool city council was up in arms over the film, demanding an apology from the movie-makers over alleged misrepresentation of a former leading civic figure (our report).

To add insult to injury, the movie was surprisingly pipped to the US number-one slot last week by The Perfect Storm, a disaster movie starring George Clooney.

fields.headline: Kissing
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the day we celebrate osculation
fields.trailText: 1. Hooray, it's National Kissing Day! So we're coming out all cuddly and romantic as a nation, right?
fields.body:
1. Hooray, it's National Kissing Day! So we're coming out all cuddly and romantic as a nation, right?

2. Er, no. It was dreamed up by Denplan, a health insurance outfit. Still, any excuse...

3. On this day of days, we may usefully reflect on some great artistic smackeroos. Like the famous bronze by Auguste Rodin, subtly entitled The Kiss.

4. Or there is the Kiss by the Hotel de Ville, by Robert Doisneau, which has been described as the most famous photograph of all time.

5. You must remember this, "a kiss is just a kiss," warbled Dooley Wilson in Casablanca. He was, of course, quite wrong.

6. Famous kisses of history: Admiral Horatio Nelson expired shortly after inviting his favourite lieutenant to "Kiss me, Hardy." Some authorities prefer to believe that he sighed "Kismet, Hardy", and that the young officer made a bit of an arse of himself. Monty Python also had something to say on the matter.

7. Famous kisses of modern times: The Buckingham Palace balcony embrace of Charles and Diana on their wedding day. Very tentative; rather poignant.

8. So, back to Monty Python: what did the Romans really do for us? Well, they made osculation - that's your actual Latin for kissing - socially acceptable. Though in some parts of the world, even today, kissing is thought disgusting.

9. In our own enlightened times, there is much valuable kissing information on the internet, including a kissing tip of the day. fields.headline: Interest rates on hold
fields.standfirst:
The monetary policy committee
MPC decisions
fields.trailText: The Bank of England today extended a further breathing space to industry and homeowners, leaving interest rates on hold for the fifth month in succession.
fields.body:
The Bank of England today extended a further breathing space to industry and homeowners, leaving interest rates on hold for the fifth month in succession.

The Bank's nine-member monetary policy committee voted to keep the official cost of borrowing unchanged at 6% - a decision widely expected by City analysts.

Nevertheless it will have come as a relief to hard-pressed manufacturers who had feared a rate hike would drive the pound back up against the euro, adding to their difficulties competing in overseas markets.

There had been concerns among the "hawks" on the MPC that sterling's recent slide on foreign exchanges could threaten the government's inflation target - by causing the price of imported goods to rise - unless rates went up.

However, with signs that the economy is slowing, it would appear that their worries were outweighed by concerns about the damage to industry a rate rise could cause.

The confederation of British industry expressed relief that interest rates were left unchanged.

Kate Barker, the CBI's chief economist, said: "Continued interest rate stability is the right medicine since the economy is still unsettled. There are clear signs that inflationary pressures are slackening as earnings growth slows and hours prices stabilise.

"With sterling remaining strong, UK companies still face fierce competition from foreign competitors.

"Keeping interest rates on hold should be enough to keep the lid on inflation, despite the slight decline in the level of sterling during May, and should not put the inflation target in doubt."

The British chambers of commerce also said the rate hold was the right decision.

Dr Ian Peters, deputy director general of the BCC, said: "Economic conditions justify keeping rates on hold. The exchange rate against the euro has stabilised at a level which is still uncompetitive for UK businesses. Manufacturing output is now at a standstill and this is holding back growth in the economy as a whole.

"A further rate hike would risk prompting a renewed surge in the value of the pound, at a time when exporters are still under severe pressure. With inflation still significantly below target, interest rates can be safely left on hold for now."

Martin Temple, director general of the engineering employers' federation, also welcomed the rate hold, but urged the MPC to do more to help exporters.

"To have raised rates in the face of clear evidence that inflationary pressure is easing would have been excessive tinkering. With some sectors of manufacturing having weakened significantly, we would urge the MPC to go further and help the pound stabilise at a more realistic level by signalling that interest rates have reached their peak at the earliest opportunity."

Meanwhile, Britain's manufacturing sector staged a surprise recovery in May, due to a surge in car production, official figures showed today.

The office for national statistics recorded a 0.4% rise in manufacturing output in May, to stand 1.8% higher than a year ago, although analysts cautioned it was too early to suggest an end to difficulties in the sector.

webTitle: Walsh wins Wisden Cricket Monthly award

fields.headline: Walsh wins Wisden Cricket Monthly award
fields.trailText: Courtney Walsh continued his amazing year on Monday night by becoming the first winner of the Wisden Cricket Monthly Moment in Time Award at a gala dinner in London.
fields.body:
Courtney Walsh continued his amazing year on Monday night by becoming the first winner of the Wisden Cricket Monthly Moment in Time Award at a gala dinner in London.

Walsh was presented with a Waterford Crystal trophy by David Graveney, his former captain at Gloucestershire, now chairman of the England selectors.

The award refers to the moment on March 27 when Walsh, playing for West Indies on his home ground of Sabina Park, Kingston, dismissed Henry Olonga of Zimbabwe to become the highest Test-match wicket-taker of all time, breaking the record of 434 wickets held by Kapil Dev of India.

WCM editor Tim de Lisle said: 'This was a moment that was bound to come sooner or later, yet it was still a spine-tingling moment, with Courtney running around like a small boy being an aeroplane, and his mum on the boundary with her home-made scoreboard, and the whole of Jamaica sharing their joy. Walsh has rewritten the rules of fast bowling by getting better as he has got older. He's rising 38 yet he has just taken five-wicket hauls in four Tests running. It will be no great suprise now if he goes on for ever.'

The award was one of four main prizes handed out at a dinner at the Grosvenor House Hotel in central London, given by the international cricketers' association FICA and attended by many leading players past and present.

All four awards went to fast bowlers. Australia's Glenn McGrath won the prestigious International Cricketer of the Year Award, based on the PricewaterhouseCoopers Ratings, while his New South Wales team-mate Brett Lee was voted the International Newcomer of the Year.

The late Malcolm Marshall was also recognised for his contribution to cricket. The great West Indies bowler who died of cancer last winter was posthumously honoured with the Regus International Special Merit Award.

A memorable night concluded with the induction of five former players to the FICA Hall of Fame: England's biggest Test run-maker Graham Gooch, West Indies fast bowler Andy Roberts, longserving Australian captain Ian Chappell and two great names from the days when England produced allrounders - Wilfred Rhodes and Frank Woolley.

fields.headline: Downing Street's full statement
fields.standfirst:
The statement given by the prime minister's official spokesman Alastair Campbell
Blair's son arrested
fields.trailText: Euan was out last night with friends to mark the end of his GCSEs. The police late last night, saw him lying on the ground in Leicester Square.
fields.body:
Euan was out last night with friends to mark the end of his GCSEs. The police late last night, saw him lying on the ground in Leicester Square.

He was clearly ill and had been vomiting. An ambulance was called but ambulance personnel decided he didn't need hospital treatment and he was then taken by the police to Charing Cross.

He was, in the view of the police, drunk and incapable.

He [Euan] gave his name during the interview as Euan John. He gave an old address and he gave a date of birth which suggested he was 18.

The police searched him and established his correct identity.

They immediately called the special branch here [10 Downing Street] who immediately went to Charing Cross and identified him. He was then processed, released and taken home.

Euan is very sorry for the inconvenience he caused to the police, the state he was in, and for the false statement that he made.

He is in no doubt of the seriousness of it and the view that his parents take of it. They will of course fully co-operate with any further action the police propose to take.

In the near future he will have to return to Charing Cross with his parents to hear what if any further action is going to be taken.

The prime minister and Mrs Blair appreciate that as this is a case of under-age drinking which required the involvement of the police, the press will report this but they will continue to do all they can to protect their childrens' privacy and ensure as normal an upbringing as possible for them.

webTitle: June 6: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: June 6: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Bafta move confirmed, Lopez ready for stick over serial-killer thriller, Kate Winslet takes the independent route, FilmFour gets military, and Rose McGowan signs for Fast Sofa
fields.body:
 Following discussions earlier this year, (see our report) it was confirmed yesterday that the next Bafta awards ceremony would be on Sunday, February 25, 2001, two months earlier than this year, and exactly a month before the Hollywood razzamatazz. The British Academy of Film and Television Arts hopes this will make the ceremony a form predictor for the Oscars, instead of its current inevitable anti-climax after the bigger night. Peter Dunne of Steven Spielberg's Dreamworks production company backed the move. He said: "I am delighted about this change of date. It will encourage more nominees to attend, rather than just those who have already won an Oscar." The nominations will now also be announced earlier, on January 31. Next year, all films released during 2000 will be eligible, and some films due for release in early 2001.

 Out of Sight star Jennifer Lopez (pictured) is steeling herself for some major flak with the release of her latest film The Cell. A gruesome and eccentric serial-killer thriller, the picture features several fantasy scenes which feature the singer-actress as, variously, the Virgin Mary and a sexed-up dominatrix. On another occasion, a lunatic killer played by Vincent D'Onofrio is shown plucking his victims' intestines like a guitar string. "We're going to get a lot of stick for this," Lopez excitedly told Wednesday's Daily Express. "There were days when I'd think 'Are we going to get away with this?'. It's very extreme." Meantime, co-star D'Onofrio was still more succint with Entertainment Weekly. "People," he said, "are going to throw up." The Cell opens in the US on August 18 and the UK on September 8. Don't say you haven't been warned.

 Kate Winslet is in the process of setting up her own film production company with her assistant-director husband Jamie Threapleton. As well as providing Winslet with more control over her career choices, the company - Telltale Films - will produce European films and showcase fresh British talent. But, presumably, Kate's new baby will have to take a back seat for a while - a real flesh-and-blood baby is expected in September.

 FilmFour are throwing their weight behind Buffalo Soldiers, a dark comedy of army life which begins shooting this autumn with a budget of around $15m. Adapted from the 1992 novel by Robert O'Connor, the film follows the fortunes of a bunch of boozy American GIs stationed in West Germany at the end of the Cold War. Australian director Gregor Jordan (acclaimed for his Aussie award-winning Two Hands) will be behind the camera, and the film has been breathlessly described by insiders as a cross between Three Kings and Trainspotting, and by FilmFour chief Paul Webster as "the M*A*S*H for the new millennium."

 Anarchic Valley Girl Rose McGowan has signed at the eleventh hour to star in the indie comedy Fast Sofa. The star of Scream (she was the one caught in the garage door) and The Doom Generation will play the illicit love of a gawky Hollywood bartender (Adam Goldberg). Salome Breziner is slated to direct and the film is scheduled to roll before the cameras at the end of the month.

webTitle: Computer hacker never endangered shuttle astronauts

fields.headline: Computer hacker never endangered shuttle astronauts
fields.standfirst:
Space exploration: special report
Today@Nasa
fields.trailText: News reports that a computer hacker endangered the lives of Space Shuttle astronauts during a 1997 mission are wrong. A report from the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) said a hacker compromised Nasa computers, endangering the lives of American astronauts.
fields.body:
"News reports that a computer hacker endangered the lives of Space Shuttle astronauts during a 1997 mission are wrong. A report from the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) said a hacker compromised Nasa computers, endangering the lives of American astronauts.

Nasa's Inspector General's office found that during the STS-86 mission in September of 1997, the transmission of routine medical information was slightly delayed due to a computer hacker. However, the transmission was successfully completed.

At no time was communication between Nasa and the astronauts compromised. The communication interruption occurred between internal ground-based computer systems.

There has never been an interruption of communication service with the Shuttle due to computer hacker attacks. The command and control communications links between Mission Control and a Space Shuttle in orbit are extremely well insulated.

The 1997 incident is currently under investigation by Nasa's Inspector General's office."

webTitle: Rebels cut power to Fiji capital

fields.headline: Rebels cut power to Fiji capital
fields.standfirst: Coup supporters protested against the newly appointed government today by taking over an electricity supply station in Suva, writes Mark Tran
fields.trailText: Coup supporters protested against the newly appointed government today by taking over an electricity supply station in Suva, writes Mark Tran.
fields.body:
The political crisis in Fiji escalated today after rebels took over an electricity supply station, plunging the capital, Suva, into darkness.

Fijian television reported that water to the main power station was cut by supporters of coup leader George Speight, who seized the entire government hostage on May 19 and has been holed up with his captives in the parliament complex ever since.

Before the power cut, hundreds of Speight supporters had massed at the entrance of Fiji's main military base to demand the resignation of the new civilian government, named this week by the military. About 300 people identifying themselves as indigenous landowners and coup supporters said they would reclaim the land on which the Queen Elizabeth Barracks is built if the government did not resign.

"We are here to protest the new government," spokesman Jah Senikudra said. "We don't know these guys. We want a new government."

In parliament, three rebels dressed in palm-frond skirts, raised a handmade flag made of pounded bark in a show of defiance at the military's plan to restrict access to the compound while offering amnesty to those who walk out before midnight on Friday.

In the latest effort to break the seven-week impasse, the a senior military official held more than four hours of talks with coup plotters. Neither side commented on the talks, the first to take place between the two sides since June 25, when a tentative agreement between rebels and the military rulers collapsed.

Today's protests followed the military's decision to stop people entering the parliament complex from midnight tonight.

Enforcement of the "total exclusion" zone has so far been lax but "we could tighten it at any time in the 48-hour period," Major Howard Politini said. During that period, the hundreds of Speight supporters would be allowed to leave without arrest, he added.

Mr Speight has warned that the hostages could be harmed if the military stops the until now fairly free access or cuts off utilities.

"It now appears that the military has grossly underestimated our support and they have, in their own stupidity, decided to call our bluff," rebel spokesman Jo Nata said. "The military should take responsibility for any backlash that may result."

Earlier, a two-hour sit-in by a couple of dozen villagers closed down the airport in Labasa, a town on the northern island of Vanua Levu that was the site of a brief military mutiny Tuesday.

Commodore Frank Bainimarama, who assumed power 10 days after the coup, has been reluctant to take strong action provided no harm comes to any of the hostages, who include deposed prime minister Mahendra Chaudhry, the first Fijian of Indian ancestry to lead the country. Many in the military support the coup's stated objective of giving indigenous Fijians priority over ethnic Indians.

51% of the population is indigenous to Fiji and many resent the economic and political clout of ethnic Indians who make up 44 % of the population.

Mr Chaudhry's deposed coalition, which was dominated by ethnic Indians, today charged the military with complicity in the coup. "The People's Coalition insists that the military has demonstrated through its successive actions that it is fully complicit, and indeed an active player, in the unlawful overthrow of a democratically elected government," the coalition said, in its first major statement since May 19.

webTitle: The name's Connery, Sir Sean Connery

fields.headline: The name's Connery, Sir Sean Connery
fields.trailText: The original and most famous 007, Sean Connery, was yesterday knighted by the Queen in an hour-long ceremony at Holyrood Palace in his native Edinburgh
fields.body:
The original and most famous 007, Sean Connery, was yesterday knighted by the Queen in an hour-long ceremony at Holyrood Palace in his native Edinburgh.

The 69-year-old star attended the event in full highland dress, accompanied by his wife Micheline and younger brother Neil. Speaking to reporters afterwards, Connery described it as "one of the proudest days of my life. It means a great deal for it to happen in Scotland." As if we hadn't quite got the message, Connery then added that: "I consider it as much an honour for Scotland as it is for me."

Connery's references were interpreted by many as a subtle gesture of defiance to those who had allegedly blocked his knighthood when it was first mooted two years ago. There was talk then that the Labour government were opposed to the actor receiving the honour because of his staunch and vocal support of the Scottish National Party and the cause of an independent Scotland.

Connery was raised in a working-class neighbourhood of Edinburgh and worked as a milkman before striking it big as James Bond in 1962's Dr. No. Five further Bond films followed suit (the last, Never Say Never Again, in 1983). Connery successfully avoided being typecast as 007 and won acclaim for his roles in films such as The Name of the Rose and The Rock, plus an Oscar for his turn in The Untouchables. Despite his success, Connery remains fiercely proud of his roots and still sports a "Scotland Forever" tattoo on his arm. These days, however, the millionaire tax exile resides in a villa in Marbella.
