Connery was raised in a working-class neighbourhood of Edinburgh and worked as a milkman before striking it big as James Bond in 1962's Dr. No. Five further Bond films followed suit (the last, Never Say Never Again, in 1983). Connery successfully avoided being typecast as 007 and won acclaim for his roles in films such as The Name of the Rose and The Rock, plus an Oscar for his turn in The Untouchables. Despite his success, Connery remains fiercely proud of his roots and still sports a "Scotland Forever" tattoo on his arm. These days, however, the millionaire tax exile resides in a villa in Marbella.

fields.headline: MoD equipment delays cost taxpayer £3bn
fields.standfirst:
National audit office voices concern over hold-ups that can result in defence hardware being ineffective by the time it comes into service

National Audit Office report
fields.trailText: Delays in producing and buying major new pieces of military equipment for the armed forces are costing taxpayers more than £3bn, a report published today reveals.
fields.body:
Delays in producing and buying major new pieces of military equipment for the armed forces are costing taxpayers more than £3bn, a report published today reveals.

Problems and cost overruns are hitting a wide range of projects - the Eurofighter, frigates and helicopters for the navy, and a new anti-armour weapon due to have replaced controversial cluster bombs nearly 10 years ago.

An anti-tank weapon, Trigat, has been delayed for so long that it will be ineffective by the time it is brought into service and the Ministry of Defence is already looking for a foreign-made alternative.

The report, by the national audit office, says important new equipment ordered for the armed forces are on average four years late. It adds that the MoD's "performance in procuring equipments to approved timescales is getting worse", with delays leading to "significant operational implications".

A new air-launched anti-armour weapon (AAAW) is expected to enter service in October next year, nearly 10 years later than estimated. It is designed to replace the BL755 British cluster bomb, the RAF's most frequently used weapon in the Kosovo conflict.

The report points out that the cluster bomb leaves up to nine of its 147 "bomblets" unexploded on the ground. "British forces", it notes, "have been engaged in clearing several thousand unexploded cluster bomb munitions since the end of the Nato air campaign."

Unexploded cluster bombs have killed two British soldiers and maimed a number of Kosovan civilians.

Yet the MoD admitted that in the Gulf war in 1991 -the year the new AAAW weapon, codenamed Brimstone, was due to enter service - the BL755 cluster bomb was not a credible weapon against modern battle tanks. It was used in Kosovo against "soft" targets such as trucks.

The MoD spent £20m upgrading and ordering extra stocks of the cluster bombs even though the weapon remains ineffective against modern tanks, the report says.

Delays in developing the Trigat anti-tank weapon for the army has forced the MoD to order more of the weapon it is designed to replace - the Milan - even though the ministry admits that if British troops were required to defend themselves against modern tanks a more effective weapon than the Milan would be "essential".

Yet even the Trigat will not be suitable for Britain's mobile rapid reaction force which will be faced with what the report calls a "significant shortfall".

Meanwhile, the MoD is shopping around for a better weapon and facing the prospect of having to sell back to the manufacturers £40m worth of "excess" Trigats which it is already committed to buying.

The cost of the RAF's Eurofighter, estimated at just over £3bn in 1984, has risen to over £4.5bn, the report says.

In a separate report yesterday, the Commons defence committee accuses the MoD of using "wholly misleading criteria" in describing the date the Eurofighter will first enter service.

Though the ministry says the first of the RAF's 232 aircraft will be delivered in June 2002, the Eurofighter will not be operational until later and its main air-to-air weapon will not be available "for some years after the aircraft enters service".

The audit office says in its report that delays in replacing the navy's ageing Type 42 destroyers have led to a "significant capability gap". The destroyers are equipped with the 1960s Sea Dart missile system which is of limited use against threats from modern sea-skimming missiles.

Delays in replacing amphibious assault ships mean that the two existing boats -HMS Fearless and HMS Intrepid - may become unserviceable because of spares obsolescence and the declining number of "steam engineers".

The report comes at an embarrassing time for the MoD which is engaged in tough budget negotiations with the Treasury. However, it can draw some comfort from the audit office's support for the ministry's "smart procurement initiative" which, it says, "should help to address many of the underlying causes of delay".

Lady Symons, the defence procurement minister, said yesterday: "Smart procurement has already had a number of successes." She mentioned the Challenger 2 tank and upgrading engines for RAF Harriers.

The audit office says Britain's 25 major defence projects are running a total of £2.7bn over their original budgets. The cost to the MoD of keeping old planes, ships and weapons in service is estimated at another £426m.

Hold-ups: Why costs of military projects are soaring

Brimstone An air-launched anti-armour weapon due to have entered into service in 1991 to replace the RAF's freefall cluster bombs which were shown to be ineffective against modern battle tanks in the Gulf war that year. Cluster bombs were used by the RAF in Kosovo - when the MoD spent £9m on an "urgent operational requirement" - against such "soft" targets as trucks. The national audit office report says: "British forces have been engaged in clearing several thousand unexploded cluster-bomb munitions" in Kosovo.

Trigat An army anti-tank weapon due to enter service in 1996 but not now expected to be ready before 2005 by which time it will be out of date. Though the MoD says the delay did not threaten the effectiveness of troops in the Balkans, if they were required to defend ground against modern battle tanks a more effective weapon than the existing Milan system - which Trigat would replace - would be "essential". The MoD is now looking for a better weapon than Trigat. Meanwhile, it has to get rid of £40m worth of "excess" Trigats.

Type 45 destroyers Due to have been introduced in 2002 but delayed for seven years mainly because of arguments with France and Italy. The MoD estimates the delay will cost it an extra £537m in keeping the ageing destroyers operational. The audit office says the delays have led to a "significant credibility gap" - the Type 42 destroyers' Sea Dart anti-missile system is unreliable against modern sea-skimming missiles.

Amphibious assault ships HMS Fearless and HMS Intrepid are due to be replaced by HMS Albion and HMS Bulwark, but they are, respectively, four and a half and three years late. Fearless may need her sea safety certificate revalidated. Both may become unserviceable because of spares obsolescence.

Merlin mark 1 helicopter A joint project with Italy, the anti-submarine helicopter en tered service in 1999, five years late and £1bn over estimate. It is a victim of the MoD's decision to reduce the number it first ordered.

Bowman A tactical communications system for the army due to have replaced the obsolescent Clansman system in 1995. "Slippage on the Bowman project means that forces supporting land operations must operate with an insecure, cumbersome and unreliable" system. The MoD hopes it will be ready by 2004. As an interim measure, it plans to deliver a short-range, non-secure "tactical radio capability", ahead of the Bowman system, next year.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.body:
Surfing impossible

In his memorable speech to the Women's Institute, Tony Blair urged us to "harness change to drive through opportunity". And what better highway could there be than the internet? If you can struggle on to it, that is. Another group of readers has come to Consumer complaining that they're not getting what they paid for. Liz Wheeler, Malcolm Warner and Derek Bell all paid £20 to Liberty Surf, which is supposed to entitle them to a year's free off-peak surfing. Liberty Surf has unbashfully trumpeted its offer of unmetered access with no strings attached. But, it seems, there is one drawback - you can't get through. Our three correspondents were unable to access the net. Worse, they couldn't access the technical help line to find out why. Bell's attempts to email were met with the message that the mailbox was full.

Reeti Sarma Sweetman of Ashford has also been having thoughts about going online. She recently responded to a sales pitch offering a service provider from Singlepoint (4U). Instead of the promised CD, however, a mobile phone was delivered while she was on holiday, along with a letter requesting that she sign a direct debit mandate. On her return, she wrote to ask for the phone to be collected, but was told she'd missed the cooling-off period and that the supplier, Dial A Phone, refused to cancel her contract.

Dial A Phone blames a breakdown in communications between the various companies involved and has now cancelled the contract and promised to settle Singlepoint's airtime charges itself.

Delayed refund

Heather Norman, a teacher from Suffolk, has also been trying to harness change with a helping hand from the government. A new scheme gives teachers who invest in a home computer a 50% subsidy. The blurb promises that the money will be refunded within a month. Eight weeks later, however, Norman has received nothing. Nor have her answer machine messages encouraged any response. "I have colleagues who are also waiting for money. We're now feeling the pinch because of a monumental lack of efficiency," she says.

The Department for Education and Employment blames the popularity of the scheme for administrative hiccups. "We very much regret these delays and have taken urgent action," says Michael Wills, minister for learning and technology. "The backlog will be cleared this week and claims made in June will be settled within four weeks." Norman, he says, has now been sent her refund and any teacher who has had to wait more than 30 days will be given £15 by way of apology. Teachers with lingering concerns should call 0870 000 2288.

Penalty payment

Interest-free credit is delightful when £2,000 stands between you and that leather three-piece. Its unhappier side can show when pay-off time arrives and you've forgotten all about it. Tina Davis says she received no statement from GE Capital bank in two years after buying a television on credit from Dixons. Eventually she enquired when her last payment was due, only to be told she'd missed the deadline and incurred a penalty payment of £221. "Am I entitled to take action, as I feel I've been conned?" she asks.

Alas, Davis will have to grin and bear it. It's up to consumers to settle the debt at the end of the interest-free period, whether or not they receive a bill - although the Institute for Trading Standards says decent lenders will send a reminder.

Statements of interests

Paperwork is something GE Capital appears to have problems with. Jill and Oliver Hogan also bought electrical goods on interest-free credit and were advised by the Curry's store (part of the Dixons Group) that the account should be settled on receipt of the final statement. This never arrived, despite two calls from the Hogans to ask how much they owed. Six months after the first call a statement did arrive - informing them that the interest-free period had expired and that they owed £143 in interest. Eventually GE Capital agreed that they need only pay half the sum and wrote confirming this. The Hogans did so, only to receive notice of legal action for recovery of the £143. Now the Hogans claim that the company refuses to respond to their letters and phone calls.

The Guardian must have a special place in GE's corporate heart. One call and GE Capital hastens a letter of apology to the Hogans plus a refund of the £65. Furthermore, Curry's, which has until now ignored the Hogans' letter of complaint, has also written - only six months late. GE claims it sent a statement last December which Hogan never received. So the two parties reached a compromise deal, whereupon GE's recalcitrant letter-dispatch service went into overdrive, churning out further demands for interest.

Scarce engineers

Michael Thorn of Oxfordshire pays £56 a year for "Three Star Service Cover" from British Gas. That funds an annual service and the promise (but not the cost) of an engineer, should things go wrong. "Getting hold of an engineer when you need one can be difficult," warns his renewal notice. "With Three Star Cover you can contact us 24 hours a day 365 days a year and normally receive same-day service." So when Thorn's heating failed two days into December he rang the hotline and was promised a visit the following day. No one turned up - and when he next rang he was told he couldn't be visited until after Christmas and should find a local engineer himself. This he did, "but getting hold of an engineer when you want one . . ."

Thorn, when he protested, was told that despite the promise of "peace of mind", the service cover cannot always guarantee service during busy periods. However, British Gas tells Consumer that he was given low priority by mistake and it has now written him a letter of apology.

Mortgage nightmare

Along with several million homeowners, Peter Bacos of London was talked into an unsuitable endowment mortgage 13 years ago. Now he's been told that his investment won't cover his loan and that he will have to find up to £10,000 when his policy matures. "Friends Provident, the insurer, has disclaimed any responsibility because the policy was bought by an independent financial adviser who has since vanished without trace," he says. "I bought a service for which Friends Provident paid the adviser a commission, but when it transpires that it was missold, the company washed its hands of the matter. Surely it is liable?"

According to the Financial Services Authority, the industry regulator, it is the independent adviser who is liable, not the investment company. If the adviser sold its client list to another firm when it ceased trading, that company is also likely to be liable. If all else fails, the Investors' Compensation Scheme provides a rescue fund, bankrolled by the industry, for victims of failed investment companies and bad advice. However, redress can only be given to those advised after August 1988. Customers whose original adviser has vanished should write to the Investors Compensation Scheme, Cottons Centre, Cottons Lane, London SE1 2QB with details of the company, their investment and why they are making a claim.

Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 020-7713 4731, send a fax on 020-7239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the rumours put on the Victoria line at Pimlico and sent to Brixton
fields.trailText: Is Luis Figo really about to "stun Spanish football" by moving from Barcelona to arch-rivals Real Madrid in a world record £38.1m deal? Oh yes he is, according to Planet Football. And they have evidence to back it up.
fields.body:
Is Luis Figo really about to "stun Spanish football" by moving from Barcelona to arch-rivals Real Madrid in a world record £38.1m deal? Oh yes he is, according to Planet Football. And they have evidence to back it up.

Apparently Florentino Perez, who is fighting Lorenzo Sanz for the presidency of Madrid, has signed a deal to pay the full release clause in Figo's contract if he is elected. Furthermore, Figo's agent Jose Veiga has confirmed contact had been made. So it's not beyond the bounds of possibility that Perez - if elected - will pay the full fee on July 16th and Figo will be unveiled at the Bernabeau.

Planet Football's "sources in Spain" also reckon that Real Madrid are "very serious" about signing Zinedine Zidane, and "negotiations are already said to be underway". Hmm. We'll see

Juventus captain Antonio Conte has rejected overtures from Chelsea and Aston Villa to stay in Serie A. "As I have said, I want to end my career with Juve, and my attachment to the club is beyond argument," confirmed Conte.

Aston Villa hope to have more luck with 27-year-old Italian defender Mauro Bonomi, who wants a move from relegated Torino.

Bradford have agreed a £2.5m fee with Leeds for David Hopkin, although personal terms have yet to be agreed.

Chelsea are interested in Barcelona's want-away French international Frederic Dehu - but Gianluca Vialli may balk at paying £4.7m for the 29 year-old defender.

Sheffield United striker Marcus Bent is a £3m target for Charlton, reports the Star.

Liverpool's Steve Staunton is poised for a shock return to Aston Villa, two years after walking out on a Bosman free.

Tottenham are maintaining their interest in Wimbledon's £5m-rated Ben Thatcher, although they face competition from Sunderland. Graham said: "We have a keen interest in Thatcher and I would be delighted if we can clinch the deal."

Fulham manager Jean Tigana has made a move to bring George Weah to Craven Cottage, but has had a £1.2m bid for John Collins rejected.

fields.headline: Crude politics
fields.standfirst: Oil price falls
fields.trailText: Crude oil prices plunged more than 6% yesterday as US markets reacted to the decision earlier this week by Saudi Arabia to lift production by half a million barrels a day.
fields.body:
Crude oil prices plunged more than 6% yesterday as US markets reacted to the decision earlier this week by Saudi Arabia to lift production by half a million barrels a day.

Monday's announcement from the world's largest producer provoked a frenzy on the New York mercantile exchange when dealers returned to work yesterday, after the July 4 holiday.

After plunging 7% immediately after the opening bell, the near-term contract - crude for August delivery - stopped its free fall but was still down $1.80 at $30.70 a barrel. In London, Brent blend futures for August delivery recovered a big part of its $2-plus losses earlier in the day to trade at 36 cents down at $29.22 a barrel by late afternoon.

webTitle: New row over Labour 'gag' on Oxford admissions

fields.headline: New row over Labour 'gag' on Oxford admissions
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A fresh political row about elitism at Oxford university blew up yesterday, after the Labour chairman of the influential cross-party education committee was accused of trying to stifle debate about the individual case of schoolgirl Laura Spence.
fields.body:
A fresh political row about elitism at Oxford university blew up yesterday, after the Labour chairman of the influential cross-party education committee was accused of trying to stifle debate about the individual case of schoolgirl Laura Spence.

Nick St Aubyn, Conservative MP for Guildford, was repeatedly warned by the committee chairman, Barry Sheerman, not to ask questions involving "individual cases" as he tried to ask senior Oxford dons about controversial remarks made recently by chancellor Gordon Brown on the university's admissions procedures.

But Mr St Aubyn persisted with his questioning amid furious exchanges in the Commons committee room, and later accused Mr Sheerman, Labour MP for Huddersfield, of breaking the sacred rule of independence in order to support Mr Brown.

The case of Laura Spence, a comprehensive school pupil, attracted national attention earlier this year after she failed to win a place at Magdalen College, Oxford to study medicine despite her brilliant academic record.

Gordon Brown was criticised for wading into the row, claiming during a speech that her rejection was "scandalous" and accusing Oxford of discriminating against state school pupils. The education committee, which had already launched an inquiry into higher education, then decided to extend it to examine how top universities choose their students.

"I had asked the chairman before the meeting started whether there were any forbidden areas and he said there were not," Mr St Aubyn said after the committee hearing yesterday.

"The idea that we should skirt around the incident which sparked this strand of our inquiry is frankly ludicrous. The way this was handled did great damage to the reputation of the committee and to the standing of our chairman".

He stressed that Mr Sheerman's first duty was to be "a non-partisan chairman rather than a member of the Labour party who supports Gordon Brown".

Questioned earlier about the impact of Mr Brown's comments, Oxford's vice-chancellor, Dr Colin Lucas, hinted that the chancellor had not had the full facts about the case of Laura Spence. "Whatever remarks were offered were offered on the basis of incomplete information," he told MPs.

He said he had had no contact from anyone at the Treasury prior to Mr Brown's speech at TUC lunch. But Oxford was worried about the "international resonance" of such opinions, which could affect its ability to attract the best students from around the world.

Dr Lucas said the university needed at least £1m from the government to implement a raft of new "access" initiatives to attract more applications from state school pupils. But the biggest single obstacle was still "the attitude of pupils from state schools and the schools themselves who believe that Oxford isn't right for their pupils", he insisted.

He was satisfied that admissions tutors could see through the "gloss" of those private school pupils who were specially coached for interviews.

"When you set about choosing somebody to teach, you don't really want a quick-tongued smart alec, you want somebody interesting and exciting to teach and who has great potential," he told MPs.

Oxford was piloting new tests developed by John Stein, professor of physiology at Magdalen College, to try and assess students' potential, he said.

Dr Lucas rejected MPs' suggestions that prospective youngsters should be targeted much earlier about applying to the university, possibly as young as 13 or 14, saying it would be too cost and labour-intensive.

fields.headline: Word perfect
fields.standfirst: Matthew Klam, recently named in the New Yorker's top 20 best young American fiction writers, on what the net means to him
fields.trailText: Matthew Klam, recently named in the New Yorker's top 20 best young American fiction writers, on what the net means to him
fields.body:
Any favourite places on the net? I really like Mcsweeneys, a literary site coming out of Brooklyn. There's also another site set up by a woman in the States called My Bunnies which is a whole website just devoted to her rabbits! At the moment I've been sending greeting cards from Moonpig.

Has the net changed the role of the writer? I haven't written much stuff purely for online. I still have quite a fond attachment to writing I can hold in my hand! It's maybe changed research more radically than writing. I have access to a thing called the Lexis-Nexis Database at Florida State University and that puts almost every book and newspaper article at my fingertips. Some writers say the e-book is going to change everything and others say that it won't because we love paper too much. I think as long as the story or the content is good it doesn't matter so much how it's delivered.

How do you feel about the some of the copyright implications of content on the net? Writing fiction has never really been that much of an exercise in making profit! I think that the people responsible for publishing books will find some way to put people in a vice and get the money out of them somehow.

Should companies put more open source content on the web? It would be a great thing if libraries were allowed to put out open source books. I guess some other services in the world would have to be free if good writing was made free. I would say that I've seen it in the past with rock shows or theatre that if people have to pay money they're more attentive.

Is information freer in the online community? Tom Paine.com deals with the freedom of information on the web. I think there might be a broader range and I think the online magazines seem to have a freedom to be more individual. I used to write about the military so I find sites like the Federation of American Scientists' site invaluable for letting you know the stuff that the American military don't really want you to know. However, you can't always take all the information on the web to be true.

Are you a gadget man? I have a Palm Pilot and I really wanted this thing for it called a Rolodex which was the size of a PCMCIA card but I don't think they do them any more. I'd love to get an MP3 player. I'd also like someone to make me a remote control that I can use to bring my other remote control to me.

Shall the geek inherit the earth? I think they already did! There was an article in the New York Times magazine about how high school kids who show an amazing aptitude towards maths and science don't think of themselves as geeks anymore and they don't look like geeks anymore.

 For more information on Matt Klam visit: www.matthewklam.com

webTitle: Tyndale bible reprinted for first time in 500 years

fields.headline: Tyndale bible reprinted for first time in 500 years
fields.trailText: The British Library is to publish the first reprint in almost 500 years of the New Testament that cost William Tyndale his life.
fields.body:
The British Library is to publish the first reprint in almost 500 years of the New Testament that cost William Tyndale his life.

Although the beauty of the language of the 1611 King James version is universally acknowledged, few realise that it incorporates most of Tyndale's 1526 text.

Copies of his pocket sized book had to be smuggled into England, since a bible in the language of the people was seen as highly subversive, and Tyndale was burned at the stake for heresy in 1536.

His translation from the Greek is credited with coining the phrases "salt of the earth", "sign of the times" and "eat drink and be merry".

The first run of the new edition will be the same as Tyndale's, 3,000 copies, and will be on sale from today, in the library's bookshop in Bloomsbury, for £15.

The text retains the old spellings but uses a modern typeface.

The library hopes for a slightly better survival rate than that of the original run, which was destroyed. Fragments of one copy and two complete copies survive, one in Germany, and the one bought by the library from the Bristol Baptist college in 1994, for more than £1m.

webTitle: The last man to do the double

fields.headline: The last man to do the double
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: Who was the last cricketer to achieve the double of 1000 runs and 100 wickets in an English season? asks Fiona Duxbury
fields.body:
Who was the last cricketer to achieve the double of 1000 runs and 100 wickets in an English season? asks Fiona Duxbury

Since the number of County Championship matches started being reduced in 1968 it has become more and more difficult to play enough games to complete the allrounder's double, which was once quite commonplace. New Zealand's Richard Hadlee achieved the feat for Nottinghamshire in 1984, the first time anyone had managed it since Surrey's Stewart Storey in 1967. But the last man to do it was another Notts player, the Barbadian Franklyn Stephenson, in 1988. By the time of the last match of the season, against Yorkshire at Trent Bridge, he had 114 wickets (many of them with his speciality, a looping slower ball or donkey-drop), but was still 210 runs short - a bit of a problem, as he'd never scored a hundred for Notts. Stephenson rectified that with 111 in the first innings and 117 in the second - and took 11 wickets in the match for good measure.

When did Jonathan Agnew begin his commentating career? asks Chris Robinson

We weren't sure, so we asked Aggers: "I was a summariser on BBC Radio's 'Test Match Special' throughout the England-West Indies series of 1991. And I made my debut as a ball-by-ball commentator at the end of that year, in the one-off Test against Sri Lanka at Lord's." Agnew, now 40, was a fast bowler in his younger days. He played for Leicestershire from 1978 to 1990, and won four England caps in the 1980s. After injuries to other bowlers he came out of retirement to play in a one-day semi-final for Leicestershire in 1992. Unlike many players-turned-commentators, he served his apprenticeship in the media by spending his winters working in the trade, for BBC Radio Leicester.

Is it true that Majid Khan of Pakistan once hit a bowler for five sixes in an over? asks Ilyas Choudry

Majid Khan - or Majid Jahangir as he was known then - was touring England with Pakistan in 1967 when he smashed 147 not out in 89 minutes against Glamorgan at Swansea. His innings included 10 fours and 13 sixes, five of them in one over (606666) from offspinner Roger Davis. Majid didn't do much in that year's Tests, but Glamorgan obviously liked the look of him - they signed him up as their overseas player the following year, and he stayed until 1976. He blossomed later in his Test career and finished with 3931 runs from 63 matches. Until recently he was chief executive of the Pakistan Cricket Board. He is the cousin of Imran Khan - but it is said that they haven't spoken since 1982 when Imran, in his first series as captain, decided to drop Majid from the Test side in England.

Could you please settle an argument for me? I say that the fastest bowler in the world has been clocked at above 100mph. Is this true? I have money riding on this ... asks Les Bradshaw

No. The highest recorded speed is 99.6 miles per hour, by Australia's Jeff Thomson in the mid-1970s. That was in a special net - but Thommo still maintains he wasn't trying that hard! In recent years the radar-gun "Speedster" has become a familiar sight at international matches, and the highest speed recorded in a match has been 96mph, by Shoaib Akhtar of Pakistan and Australia's Brett Lee.

In that amazing Test against West Indies at Lord's, at least part of all four innings took place on the Friday. Has this ever happened before? asks James du Pont from Spain

No, this had never happened in 1501 previous Tests. There was one ball of West Indies' first innings, all of England's first and West Indies' second, and seven balls of England's second innings before bad light finally stopped play. For full details of this and 19 other remarkable happenings from that dramatic Lord's Test click here

Can you purchase the new England one-day shirt on the net? asks Tom Dibley

The official Lord's site is about to set up an online shop at http://www.englandcricketstore.com , so you will soon be able to buy one there. The shirts may also be available later on from specialist cricket-equipment suppliers.

Who captained Australia when the top players were away playing World Series Cricket? asks Russell Crerar

World Series Cricket, the brainchild of Australian TV mogul Kerry Packer, was set up in opposition to traditional Test cricket in 1977. For the first season (1977-78), 41-year-old Bobby Simpson came out of a ten-year retirement to captain the official Australian team. He did well against India at home - he scored two centuries and Australia won 3-2 - and unsurprisingly struggled a bit in West Indies, losing 3-1. The following season Simpson could not agree terms with the Australian Board, and he retired again. Graham Yallop took over, but suffered a record 5-1 defeat to England, and was replaced before the end of the 1978-79 season by Kim Hughes. Hughes led Australia in the 1979 World Cup and in India in 1979-80, but then peace broke out, the Packer players returned, and Greg Chappell resumed as captain.

I have been asked to speak on the subject of cricket at Old Trafford, and even though as a schoolboy I watched Jim Laker taking his 19 wickets there, I can never remember the names of the two "ends". What are they called? asks John Cowan

The one at the city end at Old Trafford is called the Warwick Road end, after the road that runs by the main entrance. The other one is called the Stretford end, after the nearby suburb. Laker took all of his record haul of 19 wickets in that 1956 Test against Australia from the Stretford end.

Who were Australia's wicketkeepers between Wally Grout's retirement and Rodney Marsh's debut? asks Sankar Chatterjee

Grout retired after the 1965-66 Ashes series. Three years later, aged only 41, he died of a heart attack. His immediate replacement was Brian Taber, a small, neat keeper from New South Wales, who went on Australia's 1966-67 tour of South Africa, with WA's Gordon Becker as his understudy. Taber made five dismissals on debut (at Johannesburg), and finished with 19 in the series. But he didn't score many runs, and for the following season's home series against India Australia went back to Barry Jarman, Grout's long-term understudy. The chunky Jarman was Bill Lawry's vice-captain in England in 1968, but retired after the 1968-69 home series against West Indies. Taber regained the gloves for the tours of India and South Africa in 1969-70, then Marsh made his debut against England in 1970-71. It was a controversial choice at the time, as Marsh's wicketkeeping wasn't very polished, and he picked up the mocking nickname "Iron Gloves". Taber finished with 60 dismissals from 16 Tests and later became a coach. Jarman, who is now an ICC referee, had 54 from 19. And Marsh improved dramatically after that unpromising start and topped everyone, until Ian Healy came along, with 355 dismissals from 96 Tests.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: Video footage of missing Sarah to be released

fields.headline: Video footage of missing Sarah to be released
fields.standfirst: Police to scale down investigation
fields.trailText: Video footage of missing schoolgirl Sarah Payne is being released by police as the hunt for her moves into its sixth day.
fields.body:
Video footage of missing schoolgirl Sarah Payne is being released by police as the hunt for her moves into its sixth day.

Clips of the eight-year-old are to be released by her mother Sara in the desperate hope of new clues to her whereabouts.

Mrs Payne is convinced her daughter is still alive. Sarah was last seen heading towards her grandparents' house in Littlehampton, West Sussex.

Sussex police have released two men who had been held in connection with the missing girl.

But they said the move made "no difference" to the progress of the investigation or the intensity of the search.

One of the men later released from custody, a man in his 40s from Littlehampton, took part in an identity parade with Sarah's distraught elder brother, Lee, 13.

He has told police he saw a white van and a grey Ford Mondeo shortly before Sarah vanished.

Detectives are also investigating reports from another eight-year-old that she was chased by a man just four hours before Sarah went missing in the same area.

Police may stage a reconstruction of Sarah's last-known movements and have enlisted the help of a crime profiler from the National Crime Faculty.

However police are scaling back the blanket search for Sarah to focus on specific leads.

"This makes no difference to the way the investigation is going in terms of direction and strategy," Assistant Chief Constable Nigel Yeo told reporters. "The desire to find Sarah is every bit as great as it was at any stage of the operation."

fields.headline: Inflow of foreign cash lifts Blair
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday warned that ruling out entry into the European single currency would endanger the newly announced record levels of inward foreign investment flowing into Britain.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday warned that ruling out entry into the European single currency would endanger the newly announced record levels of inward foreign investment flowing into Britain.

After days of infighting between pro- and anti-single currency factions at Westminster, Mr Blair again aligned himself with Gordon Brown in backing the chancellor's "prepare and decide" policy.

He did so while managing to please more ardent supporters of UK membership of the euro zone - including Robin Cook, Peter Mandelson and Stephen Byers - by sounding more upbeat at that eventual prospect.

In his heart Mr Blair is keen to join - if he can. But Downing St remains adamant that the cabinet will wait until after the coming election to decide whether the economy is gradually "converging" with Europe's very different economic cycle, as judged by Mr Brown's 1997 five tests.

Privately, Downing St officials admit that the pressure on manufacturing industry created by a high pound is starting to ease - as sterling slipped from a peak of 3.45 German marks to 3.10 yesterday, a fall of 10%. That should ease the political pressure evident in leaked memos warning of industrial "meltdown".

Mr Blair's sharp Commons exchanges with the Conservative leader, William Hague, came on the day that the Invest in Britain Bureau (IBB) confirmed that the number of inward investment projects was 757 in the year to March 31 when sterling was starting to slide against the euro.

That is up by 16% on the previous 12 months, creating 52,783 new jobs, a rise of more than 16%. The number of jobs safeguarded by the investment was 81,411, an increase of 8.4% on the previous year, the IBB report suggested, though one of the leaked memos, from IBB chief, Andrew Fraser, had suggested that a decision on the euro is needed soon.

That news delighted Euro-sceptic business and political groups which again denounced "the euro lobby's scare stories." The report proved that Britain can thrive without losing political or economic control over its currency, they said.

Less partisan overseas investors argue that certainty is what is needed: Britain should decide one way or another.

Addressing a business conference in London yesterday, the chancellor stuck to his formula. "In principle, we see benefits from the euro and have set five economic tests for membership. They will be rigorously assessed early in the next parliament and, if met, put to a referendum of the British people," he said.

Mr Blair used almost identical words to the Commons, but added: "What of course would be absolutely disastrous for British jobs and inward investment, what would mean an immediate loss of jobs and investment in this country, is to rule out the euro altogether."

Evidently keen to dispel claims that Mr Brown is cooling on the euro, he added: "Which is why the Conservative policy is the surest way to lose jobs I know."

The fierce domestic debate, which has flared again in recent weeks, was yesterday fuelled by the president of the European Central Bank, Wim Duisenberg. He said that the high level of sterling is "damaging to the UK economy" and hoped Britain would join it.

The pound fell on the foreign exchanges after his remarks, helpful to ministers increasingly anxious about job losses in industry - and about industry's belief that Blairites are too concerned with the so-called "new economy" in the booming south-east, not with heartland industries.

The IBB report will also provide some comfort, though Sir David Wright, head of British Trade International, denied complacency.

"We can acknowledge that the appreciation of sterling against the euro is a problem," said Sir Richard. But there is nothing to suggest a "catastrophe" is around the corner.

The IBB confirms that the US remains the largest single investor, responsible for 363 projects last year - almost half the total - to the delight of anti-euro campaigners. Investment from Canada almost doubled to 48 projects, overtaking France as the fourth largest source of investment after the US, Germany and Japan. German projects rose to a record 63, up by over 50% on 1998-99.

webTitle: Japanese firms 'still keen on UK stake'

fields.headline: Japanese firms 'still keen on UK stake'
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Japanese companies are still ready to invest heavily in Britain despite official warnings this week of a big pull-out unless the government gives clearer signals about its plans for joining the euro, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Japanese companies are still ready to invest heavily in Britain despite official warnings this week of a big pull-out unless the government gives clearer signals about its plans for joining the euro, it emerged yesterday.

Sir David Wright, chief executive of British Trade International and UK ambassador to Tokyo until last year, said Japanese firms were actively discussing 40 investment projects with British officials on top of the 58 that took place last year.

In a leaked memo this week his successor in Tokyo, Sir Stephen Gomersall, said that until Britain was clearly on track to join the single currency further Japanese investment in the UK carried unnecessary risks.

But at the launch of Invest.UK's annual survey of foreign investment in Britain, Sir David said: "I have got nothing to suggest something catastrophic is around the corner." Japan remains the third largest foreign investor in the UK, behind the US and Germany, and last year's 58 projects created or safeguarded 11,401 jobs. Britain retains 45% of all Japanese investment into the EU.

Despite recent alarms raised by some Japanese investors, notably car makers Nissan, Honda and Toyota, Britain is still seen as what Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, called "a gateway between the US and Europe". Firms are still attracted by flexible labour markets, low levels of regulation and taxation, a stable economy and, increasingly, the UK's role as "portal" to the global web-based economy.

Insiders admit the investors pouring into the UK assume that the country will join the euro within the next two years. But Sir David said nothing in the record figures "suggests that the attitudes of foreign companies are being significantly affected by the (government's) policy in respect of the euro".

Britain retains 22% of global investment into the EU and the total stock of foreign investment to the UK rose last year 23% to £252.4bn.

But the record figures mask a shift in both the origins of investors and the types of investment they are making. North America is by far the biggest investor, with the US accounting for 48% of the 757 projects and Canada overtaking France as the fourth largest source of funds.

Andrew Fraser, Invest.UK's chief executive and author of a leaked report warning of a manufacturing "meltdown" without clarity on the euro, pointed out that German projects were up 51% to a record 63 and French schemes up 24% to 47.

Nick Herbert, chief executive of Business for Sterling, the anti-euro lobby, seized on the figures to assert that the most serious threat to Britain's inward investment success would be to "forfeit our stable business environment and economic advantages, such as lower taxes, by joining the eurozone".

Invest.UK's own report said that European groups, like their US counterparts, were investing more and more in software, internet and e-commerce related projects. The figures also underlined a substantial shift away from manufacturing towards services and a trend towards smaller projects, both in terms of jobs and capital spending.

The only blot on the horizon is the continuing weakness of the euro, with the strong pound forcing UK-based foreign groups to rethink their competitiveness, according to Sir David.

fields.headline: Still the money pours in
fields.standfirst:
Euro doubts have not deterred investors
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Earlier this week, Andrew Fraser, head of the Invest in Britain Bureau in the Department of Trade and Industry, warned of the prospect of a "manufacturing meltdown" if Britain did not join the euro. Yet the widely leaked IIB figures published yesterday confirm that last year saw a record number of jobs, projects and investment created by foreign money in the UK.
fields.body:
Only the British would turn a big success story - the way foreign investment is pouring into the country - into an imminent tragedy. Earlier this week, Andrew Fraser, head of the Invest in Britain Bureau in the Department of Trade and Industry, warned of the prospect of a "manufacturing meltdown" if Britain did not join the euro. Yet the widely leaked IIB figures published yesterday confirm that last year saw a record number of jobs, projects and investment created by foreign money in the UK. Only 4% of the total came from Japan, which has been making the loudest noises about withdrawing, while 49% comes from America, which has not uttered a peep.

If membership of the euro were the only issue, this would be an odd time to be withdrawing. After all, whatever arguments there might be about meeting the convergence criteria, eventual membership of the euro is much more likely now than it was during the deeply euro-sceptic Conservative years - when investment was flooding in. Any overseas company has known for years that Britain is unlikely to rush into another fixed currency system after the debacle of the ERM. Companies realise that there is, say, an 80% chance of Britain joining the euro during the next parliament if Labour wins and a zero chance if William Hague does. Gordon Brown reaffirmed yesterday that "in principle" he sees benefits from the euro as long as the economic tests he has laid down are "rigorously" assessed.

The real worry for companies is not future uncertainty about the euro but current fears about the overvaluation of the pound and the devastating effect it is having on large swathes of industry. The two are linked in businessmen's minds because of the presumption, not shared by our EU partners, that entry into the euro would be accompanied by a steep downward realignment of sterling. The government has been ambivalent. Both prime minister and chancellor make occasional references to the currency being too strong, but do nothing about it. And neither has come out with a ball park figure at which sterling might join the euro should the conditions be met. If they did, and backed it with international support for intervention in the foreign exchange markets, then foreign investors would have to factor that into their assessments of the pound's worth.

Mr Brown and Mr Blair both hope that questions about membership of the euro can be swept under the carpet until after the election. They hope that whenever the question is raised by the Conservatives they can smother it by saying that it will be decided by the British people in a referendum, in accordance with Labour policy. That may sound logical, but elections are not about logic: they are about street fighting. And the Conservatives, aided by the tabloid press, will keep asking the prime minister for a definitive declaration that he will not "ditch the pound". Meanwhile, Britain may lose some inward investment in the future partly because it is difficult to keep on winning the lion's share forever. Some Japanese firms which have been threatening to reduce investment - like Nissan, in which Renault of France now has a big stake - may have another agenda. For others the overvaluation of the yen against the euro ought to be a bigger worry. Overseas companies are attracted to the UK because it is a base for exporting to the EU with a business-friendly, low-tax environment, and speaks English. If these factors hold there is only one other thing that the government need worry about: getting the pound back to a realistic level.

fields.headline: Ask Jack
fields.standfirst: Send your questions and comments to Jack.Schofield@guardian.co.uk. Published letters will be edited for brevity but please include full details with your original query
fields.trailText: Basic instincts | Adobe Business
fields.body:
Basic instincts
I used to do a lot of things on my old Acorn BBC computer using Basic: solving complicated equations, statistical mechanics etc. Do you know of anything that would do the same on a PC? PeterRowland
PeterRowland@compuserve.com

Jack Schofield: Those were the days, and they haven't quite gone. Although BBC Basic appeared first on the Acorn BBC, an Intel-compatible version has been on sale almost unchanged for 14 years. It was written by Richard T Russell and others at the BBC, and costs £50. You can download an evaluation version of BBC BASIC (86) Plus from Russell's website at www.rtrussell.co.uk, or try an alternative implementation called BBCBASIX at www.bbcbasic.com. The drawback is that both were written for MS-DOS, not Windows.

If you are nostalgic for the BBC B Microcomputer, there are lots of emulation programs for PC. There's a useful list on The BBC lives! website at www.nvg.ntnu.no/bbc/emulators.shtml.

But if your nostalgia is for the Basic language, why not go back to the source? Basic was created by John Kemeny and Thomas Kurtz at Dartmouth College in the US in 1964. They offer several versions of True Basic for different platforms, including Windows and Mac OS. Prices start at $39.95 for the Bronze Edition. You can download a trial version from www.truebasic.com.

Use this
My photos open by default in Adobe Business. I wish them to open in Adobe Photoshop or Corel. Can I change the default program? Yvonne Kedge
y.kedge@lineone.net

JS: This is a frequently-asked question (FAQ) because Microsoft has put the control panel where few people think to look for it.

First, find one of the photos you want to open in Photoshop and check the three letter extension (it's probably .jpg).

Then open an Explorer Window by, for example, double-clicking the My Computer icon. Select View and then Options, and click on the tab for File Types. Scroll down to select the entry for the program that "owns" the .jpg extension (Adobe Business in your case), and click the button that says Remove. Use OK to close the tabbed dialogue box.

Go back to the photo you wanted to open in Photoshop, and double click the file. You'll be asked to choose the program you want to load it, so take your pick (Adobe Photoshop or Corel in your case). A tick box lets you make that choice for future files too.

You can "associate" each type of file with only one program. However, you can still load a file into a different program by, for example, using the mouse to drag the file from Explorer and drop it on the open program or on its icon.

Exit Excite
I have another email address in Excite and would like to be able to get my mail from Excite in my Outlook Express inbox. How do I do that? Lily Mcloughlin
Lily@rocastle35.freeserve.co.uk

JS: Sorry, you can't do that: Excite has not made its POP3 mail server publicly accessible, and nor have most providers of web-based email. You could, however, switch to Yahoo, which does let you collect email with Outlook Express.

Cleaning up Windows
Our PC has been upgraded from Windows 3.1 to Windows 98. It is functioning well, but the Windows directory is huge. It seems not to have deleted any old files, but just left them there. Because it is on a relatively small 1GB disk, the disk is nearly full. The PC has another disk onto which I load any new programs.

How can I reclaim some of the space taken up by unused W3.1 files?
Hannes Botha
hannes.botha@ntlworld.com

JS: Microsoft gives each file in each version of Windows its own time and date stamp. If you sort a Windows Explorer directory by date (go to View|Details then click the Modified tab in Explorer), you will be able to see how many files belong to which version. For example, all the W95 files on my W95 PC were created at 9:50 on 11/07/95.

However, deleting files that may still be in use is not recommended. The best approach is to do a "clean" install of Windows instead of an upgrade, but this means reinstalling all your applications too.

There are many programs that will analyse the contents of your hard drive and try to identify surplus files. The one I've used with some success is Quarterdeck's CleanSweep, which is now owned by Norton/Symantec. It costs about £35, or half the cost of a bigger hard drive.

Deleting temporary (.tmp) files manually may save some space. To do this, close down all programs and restart your PC. Go to Sart|Find|Files or Folders and type *.tmp next to Named. This will find all the temporary files on C:. You can delete them by using Ctrl-A (select all) then hitting the Del key.

fields.headline: Elian helps breach US-Cuba barriers
fields.trailText: The drama of Elian Gonzalez's triumphal return to Cuba last week overshadowed another development in United States-Cuban relations that was admittedly less photogenic than the impish six-year-old castaway, but far more likely to change the lives of Elian's impoverished compatriots.
fields.body:
The drama of Elian Gonzalez's triumphal return to Cuba last week overshadowed another development in United States-Cuban relations that was admittedly less photogenic than the impish six-year-old castaway, but far more likely to change the lives of Elian's impoverished compatriots.

In the US Congress, Democrats and Republicans from both houses got together and agreed on a bill to lift the food and medicine embargo on Cuba first imposed by President Kennedy in 1962, after instructing aides to buy up all the Cuban cigars they could find in Washington.

Four decades later the new measures are part of a broad agricultural bill that is not due to pass before mid-July, so it is a little early to start mixing the rum and Coca-Colas.

President Clinton said that he supports the easing of sanctions in principle, but is unhappy about some of the wording in the new bill, which would weaken presidential power to impose future sanctions on recalcitrant nations. So there are still some obstacles to be negotiated.

Furthermore the easing of sanctions is hedged by a host of conditions imposed by anti-Castro hardliners intended to mitigate its effects. The limited import of US medical supplies is already permitted under existing regulations and will not be much expanded. Where food is concerned, Cubans will not be able to export their own crops to the US, nor will they be able to finance the import of US produce with American credits, private or government. It will be strictly cash-on-delivery.

British and European financial institutions have offered to lend Havana funds at commercial rates to buy US crops, and it is likely that Cuba will buy a limited quantity of rice from US farmers. But even that will mostly go towards feeding tourists. Ordinary Cubans, on $10-a-month wages, are unlikely to be able to afford it.

But to describe the bill as largely symbolic is not to diminish its importance. Symbols have been crucially important in the 40 years of US-Cuban hostility. The maintenance of an embargo against a small island of 11m people, harsher than the sanctions against any other country, was purposefully vindictive. It was intended to discourage any other nation in the US hemisphere from flouting Washington's will so brazenly.

The demise of that policy suggests that America has become more self-confident in its dealings with Central America and the Caribbean. In any case the main hemispheric threat now is perceived as the drug industry, not communism. More importantly, the new Cuban measures reflect a fundamental rethink of the usefulness of sanctions as a foreign policy tool in general.

The new bill agreed by Congress also lifts sanctions on Libya, Sudan, Iran and North Korea, which are no longer to be known as rogue states, but rather "states of concern" - the somewhat absurd-sounding new label conjured up by the state department to mirror the change in attitude.

The rethink on Cuba has been in the works for some time. As far back as 1995 Bill Richardson - who is now energy secretary but was then just a congressman - was holding talks with Havana on easing sanctions. But those negotiations were called off when Fidel Castro's air force shot down four Cuban exile pilots, three of them US citizens, at the edge of the island's airspace in February 1996. Clinton was outraged, and agreed to sign the Helms-Burton Act imposing sanctions on non-US companies dealing with Cuba.

For those inclined towards conspiracy theories, Castro's decision to down the small planes was aimed at halting the drift towards normalisation. Dissidents in Havana believe his regime would not long outlast the lifting of sanctions. The end of the embargo, they argue, would rob Castro of a unifying national foe and a convenient scapegoat for the nation's ills while opening up Cuba to new ideas and flows of private money.

Only now are the emotions over the pilots' deaths beginning to subside, and Washington is once again ready to contemplate the relaxation of sanctions. Last year it cleared the way for more "people-to-people" contacts, including a couple of baseball games between a Cuban national squad and the Baltimore Orioles.

Meanwhile the trickle of US businessmen and farmers visiting Cuba to plan future trade deals has turned into a flood in recent months. The lobbies of Havana's hotels resound with American accents these days, and US delegations are often given greater priority than their European counterparts. The Cubans know that the Americans will ultimately become their most important partners. US visitors meanwhile can see that their government's embargo has not prevented a tourist boom and a sizeable import market from which they are excluded. They have returned home and set to work turning up the pressure on their local congressmen.

Elian has also helped the softening process along. The desperate actions of his Miami relatives in their bid to prevent the shipwrecked boy returning to his father in Cuba alienated many Americans, who saw the boy's fate as a clearcut family matter, not a political issue. In the wake of the Elian saga the US public knows considerably more about Cuba, and is not convinced that it should be the target of far more restrictive sanctions than even Saddam Hussein's Iraq. Americans were touched by the gratitude for their support and hospitality expressed by Elian's father, Juan Miguel, who emerged as a sympathetic Cuban everyman hoping for better times.

Furthermore, thanks to Elian, Washington and Havana found themselves fighting on the same side. By all accounts that experience has made it easier to talk face-to-face.

So Cubans had good reason to celebrate Elian's return. He may not put cheap rice on Cuban tables in the immediate future, but he has helped open a crack in a sanctions wall, already weakened by its own absurdities and uselessness. The real question now is whether Castro himself will tolerate his nation's gradual emergence from the shadow of US isolation.

fields.headline: Drama at Drumcree
fields.standfirst:
A battle for supremacy inside unionism
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: It is always depressing when Northern Ireland appears to descend back into its bloody past. But the violence of the last few days at Drumcree has been particularly shocking: early yesterday morning water cannon was used against protestors for the first time in 30 years
fields.body:
It is always depressing when Northern Ireland appears to descend back into its bloody past. But the violence of the last few days at Drumcree has been particularly shocking: early yesterday morning water cannon was used against protestors for the first time in 30 years. In Belfast, shots were fired at the Royal Ulster Constabulary in a loyalist neighbourhood, prompting the police to fire back. Later a vast steel wall of concrete-filled containers was erected at Drumcree bridge, blocking the route of Orangemen who want to march down the mainly Catholic Garvaghy Road on Sunday. Violence, tension and sectarianism are all back in Northern Ireland.

To the naked eye, this might look like a civil liberties demonstration about the Orange Order's fundamental right to march on what they still call "the Queen's highway". But few are convinced by that. Candid unionists admit that the Orangemen could actually get their march if they really wanted it: by sending an official delegation to speak with the Parades Commission, which makes these decisions. They have so far declined to do so, preferring the purity of boycott over the compromise of dialogue.

So this is not about winning the right to stage a march. Instead, this is yet another skirmish in the rejectionists' war against the Good Friday Agreement in general and David Trimble's acceptance of it in particular. The rioters of Drumcree are in concert with the naysayers of the Democratic Unionist Party in seeking to destablise the frail new settlement of Northern Ireland. Note Tuesday's DUP motion to keep Sinn Fein out of government, timed to coincide with the Drumcree stand-off - and to make life as difficult as possible for Mr Trimble.

What is also going on here is a power struggle within loyalism. The peacemakers are under assault from the men of violence: witness the chilling presence of Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair at Drumcree, and his denunciations of loyalist political leader Gary McMichael, whom he accuses of collaborating with British intelligence. Things are getting nasty for the loyalists who have dared make peace. They are left to point out the absurd contradiction of unionist ultras who have made a religion of defending the RUC - and yet now rain stones on that very police force. Theirs is now a dangerous task. They need support - and the continued resolve of the government not to be bullied into backing down.

fields.headline: Summit hopes hit by defections
fields.standfirst:
Clinton's Camp David initiative sparks political revolt in Israel
Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Within hours of agreeing to take part in a last-chance summit in the US to make peace with the Palestinians, the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, was stung by the enemy within when two hawkish parties gave notice last night of their intention to quit his coalition.
fields.body:
Within hours of agreeing to take part in a last-chance summit in the US to make peace with the Palestinians, the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, was stung by the enemy within when two hawkish parties gave notice last night of their intention to quit his coalition.

The threatened defection of parties representing Russian immigrants and Jewish settlers in the West Bank came o after President Bill Clinton put his legacy as the Middle East peacemaker on the line by inviting Mr Barak and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, to a summit at Camp David.

Even before the threatened revolt - which could reduce Mr Barak's coalition to a minority government - next Tuesday's summit was a highly risky proposition.

Apart from Mr Barak's constant scramble to keep his unmanageable coalition intact, Mr Clinton is well past his political prime, and Mr Arafat presides over a cauldron of popular resentment.

But Mr Clinton said yesterday that a summit was the only option left if Israel and the Palestinians were to sketch out an agreement before the September 13 deadline, now just 10 weeks away.

"While Israeli and Palestinian negotiators have made real progress, crystallising issues and defining gaps, the truth is they can take the talks no further at their level," Mr Clinton said. "The negotiators have reached an impasse. Movement now depends on historic decisions that only the two leaders can make."

After just a year in office, Mr Barak, Israel's most decorated soldier, has never looked less like a warrior, and it seems increasingly unlikely that he can take those brave steps towards peace.

Already hostage to the whims of one coalition partner - Shas, which combined Oriental Jewish ethnic pride with ultra-Orthodoxy - Mr Barak's coalition would be reduced by the threatened defection to 59 seats in the 120-seat Knesset.

Under Israeli law, last night's resignations come with a 48-hour grace period, which means Mr Barak can still try to hang on to his government.

But he is clearly in a bind. The rightwing members of his broad and unwieldy coalition are balking at the prospect of returning large portions of the West Bank to the Palestinians and the other compromises that may emerge at the summit.

Mr Barak and Mr Clinton also know that unless Israel agrees to deep concessions on territory, the future status of Jerusalem, and the rights of Palestinian refugees, it cannot even dare to hope of reaching an agreement that will be acceptable to Mr Arafat. That means Mr Clinton could face a very public failure at Camp David.

But the risk of not holding a summit is even greater. In re cent days, Israeli security officials have been warning about an explosion of violence in the West Bank and Gaza as frustrations with Mr Arafat's regime - and the barely tangible returns of the peace process - boil over.

There is also potential for confrontation in Mr Arafat's intention to declare an independent state some time after September 13, since Israel threatens to respond by annexing territory in the West Bank.

The former Soviet dissident Natan Sharansky told a rally in Jerusalem last night that he was quitting the government because he feared that Mr Barak would make dangerous compromises at the summit, and then be unable to sell them to the Israeli public.

During a stopover in London yesterday, Mr Barak said he was undaunted by the increasingly noisy attacks from the right wing.

"Basically we are implementing exactly what we have taken upon ourselves during the election, and we are determined to push it forward if there is a possibility of having an agreement," he told Israel Radio.

"Even if I stay prime minister with only one quarter of the Knesset behind me, we will do it and put it to the people."

Palestinians would argue that the peace process is in such a parlous state precisely because Mr Barak has lacked the will to move forward. During his first months, he focused almost entirely on making peace with Syria.

Now that he is ready to talk, Mr Arafat's room for manoeuvre has drastically eroded. After Israel ended its occupation of south Lebanon in May, withdrawing scrupulously from every metre of territory, Mr Arafat will find it almost impossible to agree to the compromises the Israeli demand.

webTitle: Bafta ups the ante on Oscars

fields.headline: Bafta ups the ante on Oscars
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Fed up with living in the long shadow of the American Academy Awards, the Bafta awards, Britain's own home grown Oscars, upped stumps and announced yesterday that the next ceremony would be on Sunday, February 25, 2001, two months earlier than this year, and exactly a month before the Hollywood razzamatazz.
fields.body:
Fed up with living in the long shadow of the American Academy Awards, the Bafta awards, Britain's own home grown Oscars, upped stumps and announced yesterday that the next ceremony would be on Sunday, February 25, 2001, two months earlier than this year, and exactly a month before the Hollywood razzamatazz.

The British Academy of Film and Television Arts hopes this will make the ceremony a form predictor for the Oscars, instead of its current inevitable anti-climax after the bigger night.

Simon Relph, chairman of Bafta, said last night that the change would give the British awards "a pivotal role" in the run-up to the Oscars.

Peter Dunne of Steven Spielberg's Dreamworks production company backed the move.

He said: "I am delighted about this change of date. It will encourage more nominees to attend, rather than just those who have already won an Oscar."

He added: "In international terms this move will make the awards more important, since they will take place during those weeks when the global media is fully focused on our industry."

The nominations will now also be announced earlier, on January 31.

Next year, all films released during 2000 will be eligible, and some films due for release in early 2001.

webTitle: Missing student prodigy contacts family by email

fields.headline: Missing student prodigy contacts family by email
fields.trailText: Missing teenage prodigy Sufiah Yusof is thought to have contacted her family for the first time since she disappeared two weeks ago, police said yesterday.
fields.body:
Missing teenage prodigy Sufiah Yusof is thought to have contacted her family for the first time since she disappeared two weeks ago, police said yesterday.

The 15-year-old Oxford student's father Farooq received an email on Tuesday night.

Police are still checking the email's authenticity but it is believed to come from Sufiah and reveal that she is safe and well, and does not wish to come home for family reasons.

The mathematics genius, in her third year of a four-year master's degree at St Hilda's, disappeared on June 22 after finishing her final exam of the year, which she passed.

She had been expected to return to the family home in Coventry, but failed to make contact with her mother, father or four brothers and sisters.

The only contact from her before the email was a telephone call to her college dean, made shortly after her disappearance, saying she was "OK, but needed some space".

The teenager had recently become interested in politics and was known to have attended local meetings of the Socialist Workers' party.

One theory is that she may have travelled to London with a political acquaintance. However, her father claimed yesterday that his daughter was being held against her will.

Mr Yusof believes his daughter has fallen into the hands of someone interested in his methods of accelerated learning, and has been brainwashed. "I make an appeal to whoever is with Sufiah to get in contact with me."

Thames Valley police have trawled through her deleted e-mails and studied CCTV images taken of her in Oxford city centre.

webTitle: Dope springs eternal from May Day riot

fields.headline: Dope springs eternal from May Day riot
fields.standfirst: May 2K: special report
fields.trailText: Green-fingered protesters, who dug up Parliament Square on May Day, have had the last laugh after a crop of marijuana plants was discovered in the shadow of Winston Churchill's statute.
fields.body:
Green-fingered protesters, who dug up Parliament Square on May Day, have had the last laugh after a crop of marijuana plants was discovered in the shadow of Winston Churchill's statute.

MPs rushed across to the square last night to inspect the fledgling plants - each no more than four inches high - which sprouted up thanks to the efforts of the "Avant Gardeners" who invaded the square during the May Day riots.

The crop was discovered yesterday by a group of aboriginal protesters as they launched a protest in Parliament Square to coincide with the visit by the Australian prime minister, John Howard. "We should all emigrate to England," declared Michael Anderson of the Sovereign Union of Aboriginal Peoples.

There was mixed reaction at Westminster last night as news filtered out that parliament now had its own supply of marijuana.

The Labour MP Paul Flynn, who campaigns for the legalisation of cannabis, pledged to mount a vigil to protect the crop. "This is a sign of hope that nature can triumph over prejudice," he said. "But no doubt Jack Straw will be down there first thing in the morning to destroy the plants with the ritual stamp of intolerance."

The Home Office minister, Paul Boateng, remained firmly on message when asked about the crop. "Have you told the police?" he barked.

Police said last night that they would move in quickly to remove the "illegal plants". One source said: "Officers will arrange for the plants' speedy removal before destroying them. But there are unlikely to be any prosecutions because it all happened eight weeks ago."

The May Day gardeners will be delighted with their handiwork, which shows that the authorities have failed to clear up the square. The plants were last night clearly visible behind the metal barriers, which are meant to bar access to the square to give fresh grass a chance to grow back.

webTitle: Hijacker shot dead, 15 hurt on Syria flight

fields.headline: Hijacker shot dead, 15 hurt on Syria flight
fields.trailText: Security officers foiled the hijacking of a Jordanian airliner last night, shooting dead one of the gunmen moments after he set off a small bomb out-side the cockpit, injuring 15 passengers.
fields.body:
Security officers foiled the hijacking of a Jordanian airliner last night, shooting dead one of the gunmen moments after he set off a small bomb out-side the cockpit, injuring 15 passengers.

The plane, which was on a flight from Amman to Damascus, landed safely back in Amman, despite the exchange of fire, airport officials said.

They said the Royal Jordanian airbus had been hijacked 10 minutes after take-off by three men carrying Syrian passports.

One of the hijackers threw a bomb at security officials who attempted to prevent him from going into the cockpit. Three passengers suffered shrapnel wounds.

Captain Jihad Rashad, head of the civil aviation authority, said: "One of the hijackers, carrying a pistol and a grenade, tried to go into the cockpit 10 minutes into the flight.

"When security men on board stopped him, he fired a shot and threw the grenade, which exploded wounding 15 passengers but causing little damage to the aircraft."

A senior security official said the Syrian who was killed was in his mid-20s. His two accomplices were being interrogated by the police.

"It all happened shortly after the plane took off from Amman's Queen Alia International Airport bound for Syria," he told the Associated Press.

"Security officials on board the plane were on alert and took control of the situation instantly."

"There was an explosion and panic," Said Taibi, an Algerian passenger, said at a hotel near Amman airport.

"The first thing that came to mind was that there was a malfunction in the plane."

Another passenger, Majed Saba, said he heard the hijacker saying: "I want to go in to see the captain, open the door", before he took out the pin of what Mr Saba believed was a stun grenade.

"One feels like he cheated death," said another passenger, Ghada Shamout. "I can't describe the horror of the first few seconds of the incident."

There was no word on the motive for the hijacking. But there have been repeated warnings in recent days from American and Jordanian security officials about the possibility of attack from followers of the Saudi Islamist militant Osama bin Laden, who is a fugitive in Afghanistan.

On Tuesday, officials at the US embassy in Amman cancelled the Fourth of July party, and increased security around the mission.

It was also unclear whether the foiled hijacking attempt was linked to the recent changing of the guard in Damascus. Although Bashar Assad appears to enjoy the support of the military and security agencies, he has yet to be confirmed as Syria's president.

His anti-corruption purges have upset some members of the security establishment, and his estranged uncle Rifaat has been agitating against his succession from his homes in exile in Marbella and outside Paris.

Jordanian airliners were also the target of Palestinian hijacking attempts in the 1970s and 1980s by factions opposed to the moderate stance of the late King Hussein.

The plane, which was on a flight from Amman to Damascus, landed safely back in Amman, despite the exchange of fire, airport officials said. They said the Royal Jordanian airbus had been hijacked 10 minutes after take-off by three men carrying Syrian passports. One of the hijackers threw a bomb at security officials who attempted to prevent him from going into the cockpit. Three passengers suffered shrapnel wounds. Captain Jihad Rashad, head of the civil aviation authority, said: "One of the hijackers, carrying a pistol and a grenade, tried to go into the cockpit 10 minutes into the flight. "When security men on board stopped him, he fired a shot and threw the grenade, which exploded wounding 15 passengers but causing little damage to the aircraft." "It all happened shortly after the plane took off from Amman's Queen Alia International Airport bound for Syria," he told the Associated Press. "Security officials on board the plane were on alert and took control of the situation instantly."
