webTitle: Drumcree ignites the passion but north Belfast feels the heat

fields.headline: Drumcree ignites the passion but north Belfast feels the heat
fields.standfirst:
The clashes might be 30 miles away but at least one family feels so threatened they cannot sleep in their own beds

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A mother-of-two shook in the nationalist New Lodge area of north Belfast, fumbling for a cigarette. She wanted tranquillisers but the surgery, just a hundred yards away, is in loyalist Tiger's Bay, and with sectarian tensions running high, she refused to risk the trip.
fields.body:
A mother-of-two shook in the nationalist New Lodge area of north Belfast, fumbling for a cigarette. She wanted tranquillisers but the surgery, just a hundred yards away, is in loyalist Tiger's Bay, and with sectarian tensions running high, she refused to risk the trip.

She lives in a development of 35 executive homes built six months ago on wasteground formerly called No Man's Land. She quickly learned why the area on the religious frontline earned that name.

As she talked, workmen were speedily erecting five metre fences to prevent petrol bombs being thrown across. Her children, aged 12 and 14, preferred to sleep in a tent in relative shelter at the back of the house rather than take their chances in bed.

She said: "My sister has said I can go and live with her for a time. But this is my home. I refuse to go.

"But we are terrified. We stand on the street until four in the morning because were are too afraid to stay indoors."

She said loyalists had on Tuesday fired shots at them, and several had tried to attack their house. As she drew heavily on her cigarette, a motorist roared past, shouting: "Fenian bitch."

About one-fifth of the 3,500 deaths in 30 years of violence have occurred in north Belfast, a patchwork of conflicting districts. Residents said they had hoped the days of sectarianism were gone.

But it is almost like old times here, though now it is disaffected Protestant youths who are hijacking cars and lorries and setting them alight. They pelt the RUC with petrol bombs, littering their areas with the charred remains of protest.

The Orange Order protest is at Drumcree, more than 30 miles away. None of the youngsters in Tiger's Bay yesterday said that he ever went to church or was able to grasp the irony of those supposedly loyal to the crown attacking that crown's forces.

It was, said one just into his teens, simply a good excuse for fun.

Sinn Fein's Gerry Kelly, the Old Bailey bomber who represents the area in the assembly, said: "When there is tension in Drumcree, the ripples hit north Belfast. It too is a microcosm of the Troubles."

Six-year battle

Thus has spread throughout Northern Ireland this week Portadown Orangemen's campaign for what they call their civil and religious liberties, a six-year-old battle for the right to march their traditional route down the nationalist Garvaghy Road. The parades commission has barred them for the third year running.

Demonstrations hit at least seven towns across Northern Ireland on Tuesday, the third consecutive night of increasing rioting, and more than a dozen roads in Belfast were cut off. Many protests were violent, and they were beginning much earlier last night.

The RUC, so stoutly defended recently by many Orange Order members in the face of EU commissioner Chris Patten's reform recommendations, is once more under attack from those who affect to support it. More than 20 officers have so far been injured.

At Drumcree they have come under a hail of fireworks, stones, and iron bars. Syringes of acid have been squirted at officers, and laser pens shone in their eyes.

The RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, is clearly tiring of it. Scores of officers were forced to leave their homes in 1996, the worst year of violence, when poor tactics saw them standing face to face with protesters, many of whom were neighbours.

Several officers were badly injured by bombs in 1998. PC Frankie O'Reilly, 30, a father-of-three, died in October that year weeks after he was injured in an explosion during a loyalist riot in Portadown related to the ongoing Drumcree dispute.

He was a Catholic, and was the last of 302 RUC officers killed during the Troubles. Loyalists also killed the first of those police victims, Victor Arbuckle, 29, with two children, on the Shankill Road in Belfast in October 1969.

Police had adopted a low key approach for last Sunday's parade, when Orangemen had sought permission for another parade including the Garvaghy Road a week earlier than their scheduled annual march. They hoped in vain for a responsible approach.

Violence was inevitable from the point four days ago when Harold Gracey, the Portadown district master, called for demonstrations across Northern Ireland in support of his lodge's protest. One protester told the cheering crowd last Sunday: "The war starts today."

One liberal Orangeman said yesterday: "However much Harold says he wants no trouble, he must have known it would follow. We can't wash our hands of responsibility." He was echoing nationalist opinion, and Sir Ronnie fears the Orange Order's ambivalence will allow loyalists to hijack the protest.

Frustrations

The Orange Order source said he cringed at the appearance on Monday underneath an Ulster Freedom Force (UFF) banner of convicted terrorist Johnny Adair. He feared the violence could only end in tragedy.

But a spokesman for the Portadown Orange Order, David Jones, prefers to blame Tony Blair and the parades commission for the violent confrontations. He says it is not that he condones violence, but he understands Orangemen's frustrations.

Mr Jones feels Mr Blair sold them out, claiming he promised them a march in the autumn if they walked away from confrontation last July.

They yesterday rejected an olive branch from Tony Holland, the commission's chairman, who laid out four conditions, including engaging with residents, which would permit a march within eight months. He said: "If these steps are taken, the parades commission has effectively committed itself to authorising a limited, orderly parade along the Garvaghy Road."

The violence at Drumcree is institutionalised. The odd major player is there during the day, when there is only the faintest element of menace. Families with young children and courting couples arrive soon after lunch, though many are already beginning to drift away as night begins to fall. Then youths begin to appear in numbers, hiding their faces with scarves.

The violence looks much worse on television. The RUC is clearly in control and opened up with water canon for the first time in nearly 30 years on Tuesday.

They had hoped to avoid the massive engineering work of previous years but the security forces were yesterday beginning to dig in at Drumcree. Barricades were erected to replace armoured vehicles set alight the previous night.

Violence, notably in 1996 and 1998, has taken place after the annual parade. This time, significantly, it is preceding it.

Security sources say they are unsure what Adair's game is. He denied the UFF opened fire on the RUC late on Tuesday. It is believed that more than one gunman was involved in the attacks on the Lower Shankill Road. It was the first time in several years the RUC has come under such attack, the most sinister development yet in a week when the battle is about who is winning in Northern Ireland, rather than a juggling of rights and responsibilities.

There were no injuries. Nor has anyone been killed. Yet.

webTitle: Britain lifts ban on Pakistan arms sales

fields.headline: Britain lifts ban on Pakistan arms sales
fields.standfirst:
Pakistan: special report
Labour's ethical foreign policy: special report
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, lifted the arms embargo on Pakistan yesterday, only 10 months after condemning the military regime that overthrew the country's democratically-elected government.
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, lifted the arms embargo on Pakistan yesterday, only 10 months after condemning the military regime that overthrew the country's democratically-elected government.

Ending the ban so quickly will create concern in a region which is one of the world's flashpoints. It will also raise questions about Mr Cook's ethical foreign policy, which has been repeatedly undercut by British defence firms.

Mr Cook put a block on arms sales and successfully led calls for Pakistan to be suspended from the Commonwealth after General Pervez Musharraf's coup last October.

All 46 applications for export licences to Pakistan from British arms firms have been blocked since the coup. Now, supplies of naval and other equipment are to be resumed.

But in a deal agreed between Mr Cook and other ministers, the export of small arms and ammunition, which could be used in the disputed Kashmir region or for internal repression, will still be blocked.

Ending the ban will almost certainly be condemned by India, but will be welcomed as an important gesture by Pakistan, which has been heavily criticised internationally.

India and Pakistan both have nuclear weapons and tensions have been high over Kashmir. Pakistan is widely believed to have been responsible for an incursion into the Kargil area of the territory last year.

Mr Cook, in a parliamentary written answer, said: "The government has considered the situation in Pakistan and the wider region since the coup before deciding on a number of licence applications."

He said: "We remain concerned about defence exports to Pakistan, in the light of the incursion at Kargil, the coup, the possibility of diversion to undesirable end-users and continued regional tensions."

The decision contrasts with Mr Cook's tone at the European summit in Finland in October following the coup. Then he said: "It is important to send a clear message that we deplore the overthrow of democracy". He wanted "a swift and orderly return to democracy and rule of law."

The diluting of the ban has taken place despite a lack of movement by Gen Musharraf's government to set a date for a return to democracy. The government has also failed to tackle the Islamic terrorists operating within Pakistan's borders, who are among "the undesirable end-users" of Mr Cook's statement.

Britain's change of view towards Pakistan stems from a belief that it should be engaged rather than isolated and that the country's previous governments, though democratic in name, were shambolic. The fear is that an alternative to Gen Musharraf could be a hardline Islamic government, more tension with India over Kashmir and the attendant threat of nuclear conflict.

A Foreign Office source said yesterday's decision was not "triggered" by any one event but "if you take a look at what was happening in Kargil last year, we have not seen a repetition, which is a fairly crucial indication of whether there has been renewed aggression."

The move followed a battle between cabinet ministers earlier this year, revealed in internal memos leaked to The Guardian. Mr Cook at the time was fending off attempts by the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, and the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, to restore arms sales.

Twenty applications will now be approved, and 26 denied. A Foreign Office spokesman said: "Mr Cook is very happy with the decision."

Although the embargo has been lifted, approval will only be given to exports regarded as the least contentious. These will include spare parts for ships, naval helicopters and naval planes. The Foreign Office believes these would have no role in Kashmir. Approval will also be given to supply bomb disposal equipment and goods for civilian end-users.

webTitle: In love? Congratulations, you just lit up your medial insula

fields.headline: In love? Congratulations, you just lit up your medial insula
fields.trailText: Cupid does not aim his arrow at the heart but at four regions of the brain, scientists revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Cupid does not aim his arrow at the heart but at four regions of the brain, scientists revealed yesterday.

Researchers at University College London have for the first time observed what happens to the minds of the lovestruck and their findings may explain many of the symptoms of lovesickness - butterflies, euphoria, and craving.

Professor Semir Zeki and postgraduate student Andreas Bartels sought out volunteers who were "truly and madly" in love. They picked 11 women and six men, in their mid 20s, who had fallen in love during the last six months to a year. Each was asked to supply a photograph of their beloved.

The volunteers had their brains scanned as they looked at either a picture of their lover or a friend of the same sex. The scanner was able to pick out the most and least active areas of the brain by revealing levels of blood flow.

The physical effects of love could be traced to specific regions of the brain which "lit up" when volunteers saw the image of their loved ones.

Mr Bartels said: "When you're very much in love, you have this butterfly feeling in your stomach.

"That might be due to the medial insula, which is a highly connected region with links to all the sensory areas of the brain."

Also highly active was part of the anterior cingulate, which is known to respond to euphoria-inducing drugs.

Two areas in the deeper and more primitive basal ganglia region of the brain were also markedly active. These are involved in the process of finding experiences rewarding, and may play a role in addiction.

Prof Zeki, whose work was reported by the New Scientist yesterday, said: "The results showed us that there is a limited number of brain areas which are expressly involved in this very, very emotional state which can govern your whole way of life."

The researchers said that equally significant were the brain areas where activity was lowered or "switched off" by being in love.

The rose-tinted spectacles through which lovers view the world might be explained by reduced activity in parts of a brain region called the post-cingulate cortex, normally activated when people feel sad. Another region of the pre-frontal cortex, known to be overactive in depressed patients, was deactivated.

fields.headline: Milosevic ploy for new term
fields.standfirst: Serbia: special report
fields.trailText: Slobodan Milosevic will today try to tighten his grip on the presidency of Yugoslavia by remoulding its constitution.
fields.body:
Slobodan Milosevic will today try to tighten his grip on the presidency of Yugoslavia by remoulding its constitution.

The country's ruling coalition will vote to change the law so the president can be elected directly. This would allow the indicted war criminal to sidestep a constitutional ban on him seeking re-election after his term ends next year.

The proposals would also adjust the election of the federal parliament to downgrade Montenegro, Serbia's pro-western partner in the Yugoslav federation. This could push Montenegro towards independence and trigger another Balkan conflagration.

Serbia's opposition parties were caught off-guard by news of Mr Milosevic's move.

Staying in power has been Mr Milosevic's best guarantee against prosecution since being indicted for atrocities in the Kosovo war last year.

It was reported last month that US president, Bill Clinton, who is anxious for a diplomatic triumph, was considering ways to allow Mr Milosevic to leave office without a war crimes trial at the Hague, possibly by offering a safe house in Greece, Russia or China.

The new constitutional move will strengthen Mr Milosevic's position. A reliable source told the Guardian that Mr Milosevic was anxious for a deal but only on the right terms. Securing another term was geared towards that end. The Hague tribunal has vowed to oppose any amnesty.

Deputies from Mr Milosevic's ruling coalition will propose to scrap the system whereby the assembly's two chambers appoint the president, which is how Mr Milosevic became president in 1997.

Once the method of electing the president is changed Mr Milosevic's supporters could argue that the one-term-only rule no longer applies.

In addition to circumventing the two-term ban, it would fulfill Mr Milosevic's dream of being the elected federal president, said Bratislav Grubacic, editor of the newsletter VIP.

Serbia's opposition is not expected to offer much resistance. It remains as divided as ever and no closer to ousting Mr Milosevic under its own steam. One opposition leader, Vuk Draskovic, said the move constituted "a form of legal state terrorism and an attack on the constitution".

fields.headline: Tricks of snoopers' trade
fields.standfirst: How a few relaxed phone calls can unlock private information
fields.trailText: Lord Levy is not the first public figure - and certainly will not be the last - to complain that he was undermined by underhand means.
fields.body:
Lord Levy is not the first public figure - and certainly will not be the last - to complain that he was undermined by underhand means.

When Lord Lamont was plain Norman he suffered the indignity of having details of a spending spree and personal overdraft being splashed across the newspapers, while as chancellor of the exchequer he lectured the nation on the need to live within its means.

Actor Stephen Fry's credit card purchases and phone calls are believed to have been used to help track him down in France when he spectacularly fled the London stage.

And Tory treasurer Lord Ashcroft is convinced that a bogus caller conned a Royal Bank of Scotland branch in the Strand, central London, into disclosing the time and precise amount of his donations to the Conservative party.

Two figures are known to produce information that is difficult to obtain by fair means for some newspapers and TV programme-makers as well as companies and suspicious spouses.

One, a private eye, another a former actor, charge up to £1,000 a time to assist those seeking bank, mortgage, credit card or tax details.

The pair are renowned for their homework - checking dates of birth, occupations, addresses, maiden names, relatives and other information that could persuade an unwary employee that they are genuine.

Sometimes they will ring more than once, gathering a little more information each time before going in for the kill. Often they phone at lunchtime when fewer staff are working and offices tend to be more relaxed. Pay-as-you-go mobile phones make it virtually impossible to trace the impersonator.

The trick is to mimic an accountant, bank official or the individual concerned to put at ease the person on the other end of the phone.

Officials at the Inland Revenue, which receives 38m calls a year, yesterday refused to say if Lord Levy's affairs are handled by its VIP complex in Cardiff, which deals with the royals, MPs and other prominent figures.

But it did confirm that no password or ring-back system is operated. A spokeswoman said the employee who took the calls did not suspect they were anything other than genuine after basic details were confirmed.

In his letter to Lord Levy, Nick Montagu, chairman of the Inland Revenue Board, said: "We have established that two separate telephone calls were made on the 9th and 23rd of June by a caller purporting to be you to the tax office which handles your affairs. We have established that, in fact, you made neither call and that we are therefore dealing with an impersonation."

The prime minister's spokesman said: "It is our view it was either the Sunday Times or someone working on its behalf who was involved in either illegal or improper activity. It's for the paper to explain how this happened."

Though the Sunday Times denied either making the hoax calls or asking anyone else to, two former Sunday Times staff reporters, one of whom worked on investigations, yesterday told the Guardian the paper had in the past used at least one private eye to seek confidential information.

"He charged £1,000 a pop and we'd say 'Can you help us out like you did before' and he'd try to do the business," said the ex-staffer. We didn't go on trawling operations; normally we'd had a good tip-off and were fairly confident of the information but needed confirmation. We were not always successful."

webTitle: Mad Dog marks out his territory with a flourish

fields.headline: Mad Dog marks out his territory with a flourish
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Sporting a gold ring in each nipple, Johnny Adair was hard at it after his appearance at Drumcree hill. His shaved head gleamed in the sun in the Lower Shankill as he lavished gloss paint on lamp-posts and kerbstones to mark out his red, white and blue domain.
fields.body:
Sporting a gold ring in each nipple, Johnny Adair was hard at it after his appearance at Drumcree hill. His shaved head gleamed in the sun in the Lower Shankill as he lavished gloss paint on lamp-posts and kerbstones to mark out his red, white and blue domain.

Adair, 35, a father of three, likes to decorate, though the murals he has commissioned on the estate he calls his own are a mixed bag. Alongside one lauding comrade Billy Wright, the murdered leader of the Loyalist Volunteer Force, is one commemorating the Princess of Wales. The Queen Mother is soon to feature.

The most recent appearance is of a blood-red mural depicting five sectarian Ulster Freedom Force (UFF) atrocities against Catholics. They include the massacres at Sean Graham bookmakers on the Lower Ormeau Road, Belfast, where five were shot dead in February 1992, and the murder of six at Greysteel, Co Londonderry, in October 1993.

It is adorned with lyrics by Van Morrison, including the slogan reading: "Wouldn't it be great if it was like this all the time?" Those words were used five years ago in a Northern Ireland office commercial to promote peace.

Adair, with his alsatian, Rebel, alongside, denied he had gone to Drumcree with up to 50 colleagues from the UFF's 2nd battalion, C company, to spark trouble. He simply supported the Orange Order protest over the ban on marching down the nationalist Garvaghy Road, and would be back at Drumcree again before Sunday's parade.

Adair, a smile playing on his lips, said: "I have done nothing wrong and have not broken the law. I came peacefully and left peacefully. I would call on people to stay clear of violence."

Adair, nicknamed Mad Dog, is the most charismatic loyalist, the only figure capable of inspiring the devotion shown to Wright, who was 37 when he was shot dead by the Irish National Liberation Army at the Maze prison in December 1997. He can be charming and has a fine line in black humour. But he is a maverick, and there are some in his own ranks who want him dead.

Adair left the Maze last September under the early release programme of the Good Friday agreement after serving five years of a 16-year sentence for directing terrorism. No one had ever been convicted of the offence, and many believe it was created to take Adair off the streets.

Pat Lynch, prosecuting at his 1995 trial, said Adair, trapped because jokey conversations with RUC officers were secretly taped, was a sinister and manipulative terrorist. He was "dedicated to his cause which was nakedly sectarian in its hatred of those it regarded as militant republican, among whom he lumped almost the entire Catholic population."

His murderous activities meant he was at loggerheads with the IRA in nearby Ardoyne, and he was the target for the ill-fated Shankill Road bomb, which left nine Protestants and bomber Thomas Begley dead in October 1993, sparking tit-for-tat killing. One man who had recently bought his car was mistakenly shot dead by the IRA.

Police sources say he clears £1,500 a week from drugs, but he denies it.

He sometimes bumps into his rival in the IRA in Ardoyne, and they goad each other about who will be killed first.

The meetings are said to be almost good-humoured.

fields.headline: Hi-tech firm's $13bn slump
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Investors wiped almost $13bn from the market value of Computer Associates, one of the world's largest software companies, yesterday after the group issued a profits warning.
fields.body:
Investors wiped almost $13bn from the market value of Computer Associates, one of the world's largest software companies, yesterday after the group issued a profits warning.

Shares in the company opened 40% lower at a 52-week low of $29 (£19). The company warned that its first-quarter revenues would be lower after US stock markets closed on Monday, just before the July 4 holiday. Shares fell as low as $28 yesterday morning from an opening price of $41.

A conference call yesterday designed to explain the company's negative outlook failed to satisfy sceptical analysts yesterday. One fund manager described the call with senior executives of the company as not especially helpful.

Several investment banks, including Goldman Sachs, downgraded the company as a result of the warning that its revenues in June would be about $300m-$350m short of consensus estimates of $1.6bn. Operating profits were also expected to be lower.

Several analysts were angry about the timing of the announcement, which could provoke criticism from the securities and exchange commission. The SEC refused to comment yesterday, while the company said that it had simply made the announcement when it became aware of the shortfall.

Computer Associates was also subject to criticism and shareholder lawsuits in 1998 after the company's decision to grant $1.1bn in stock to its three senior executives.

The company blamed three things for its profits warning on Monday: weak demand for its mainframe software, a failure to integrate acquisitions as quickly as promised and a disappointing performance in Europe.

fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText:
• Decision
Telecom firm Sprint will decide within days whether it will withdraw from its merger pact with WorldCom, a spokesman for Sprint said. WorldCom declined to comment on recent reports that Sprint will as early as the end of this week pull out of the pact.
fields.body:
 Decision
Telecom firm Sprint will decide within days whether it will withdraw from its merger pact with WorldCom, a spokesman for Sprint said. WorldCom declined to comment on recent reports that Sprint will as early as the end of this week pull out of the pact.

 Funding
Hi-tech firm Cambridge Positioning Systems, a British company whose technology is poised to turn mobile phones into people-tracking devices, said yesterday it was raising £30m in investment from the mobile industry ahead of a flotation next year. The move comes as internet newcomer CPS gears up for launch next summer.

webTitle: A day in the life of One Word Man: he says a word

fields.headline: A day in the life of One Word Man: he says a word
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: There is a cartoon by HM Bateman called, I think, The One Note Man. A series of beautifully detailed drawings shows a chap waking up, having breakfast, going to work with his instrument case, joining the orchestra, and, at the climax of his day, playing a single note on the triangle. The story ends with him tucked up again in bed.
fields.body:
There is a cartoon by HM Bateman called, I think, The One Note Man. A series of beautifully detailed drawings shows a chap waking up, having breakfast, going to work with his instrument case, joining the orchestra, and, at the climax of his day, playing a single note on the triangle. The story ends with him tucked up again in bed.

Yesterday Michael Fabricant became The One Word Man. We can follow his day because it is detailed on his brand new, freshly overhauled website which, for some of us, holds even more interest than the likes of www.hotbabes.com. He gets up, brushes his teeth, feeds his hair from a bottle of Baby Bio, goes to the House, answers the mail, then ponders the state of his stomach. "Sometimes I have lunch appointments, but more often than not I take a sandwich back to the office."

Fascinating! (Though I may have invented the bit about the Baby Bio). Next he made his way to the chamber and left a card marked "Fabricant" at his favourite seat. So later he was in his place and poised as prime minister's questions proceeded.

Mr Blair was having a hard time. In the gallery were five Australian prime ministers, in town to celebrate 100 years in the Commonwealth. Mr Blair paid tribute to the relationship between our two great countries, slightly spoiling things by calling them "Americans", although the massed ranks of Antipodean statesmen seemed to be amused rather than offended.

Mr Hague had decided to attack him on the scheme for on-the-spot fines for drunken hooligans. (This is a typical New Labour wheeze, in that it was worked up in a panic over the opinion polls and bunged in to grab the head lines, without any reference being made to the people who would have to enforce it).

"Can you tell the House which person in government came up with this brilliant idea?" Mr Hague asked, adding: "Who came up with the obviously fatuous idea of getting drunken criminals to form orderly queues at cashpoints around the country?"

Mr Blair did what he always does when caught out; he pretended Mr Hague was opposed not to the batty scheme, but to the idea of controlling yobs. "If we introduce fixed penalty notices, on the spot, for disorderly conduct, will you support it?"

Mr Hague was enjoying himself. Like a yob, he had found a victim and was not going to let him go. "You spend your time clutching for another empty headline instead of getting a grip on your divided and shambolic government!"

The prime minister was getting seriously rattled. The yob was shouting at him and there was no bobby in sight, no cashpoint within half a mile. Passers-by were scurrying along with eyes averted. "Let's deal with spin, rather than substance!" he yelled, getting it the wrong again.

"The truth is that when the debate turns to policy, we shall see who is standing!"

For some reason, time also stood still. There was a sort of muted hubbub, but in the comparative calm came the manic shout of "Resign!" It was Mickey Fabb, making in one second the finest oration of his parliamentary career.

The Speaker barked at him, "any more of that and you will be out!". But it didn't matter. Teresa Gorman, wearing a blue gingham tablecloth, leaned over and squeezed his shoulder. He turned red with pleasure. Then I assume, he had his tea, brushed his teeth, put on his jim-jams and went to bed.

(PS: he has just faxed me a press release. "Now my website has had a cyber-makeover, perhaps I should now have one for real!" Next week, with any luck, the new bald Fabricant).

www.michael.fabricant.mp.co.uk

fields.headline: Getting things in proportion
fields.standfirst:
As Labour looks again at the PR debate, the most recent proposals continue to stack the electoral cards in favour of the Liberal Democrats
Proportional representation: special report
fields.trailText: The electoral reform debate is hotting up. The Labour-Liberal Democrat coalition in Edinburgh is thinking about adopting the single transferable vote for Scottish local authority elections. This weekend Labour's policy forum deliberates its next manifesto. Labour's days of prevarication are numbered.
fields.body:
The electoral reform debate is hotting up. The Labour-Liberal Democrat coalition in Edinburgh is thinking about adopting the single transferable vote for Scottish local authority elections. This weekend Labour's policy forum deliberates its next manifesto and what to say about its unfulfilled pledge to hold a referendum on voting for seats in the House of Commons. Labour's days of prevarication are numbered.

It's not, however, that all hope of fudge has evaporated. Some of Labour's strategists think a halfway house could yet be found between what we have and proportional representation. This system would be a little fairer to the Lib Dems and would not undermine Labour's ability to win elections in future.

In his distinguished but dusty report, Lord Jenkins recommended that the British public should consider a new beast called Alternative Vote plus (AV+). This has two parts. In the first or AV part up to 550 MPs would be elected, as now, in single member constituencies. However, voters would no longer simply put an X against their preferred candidate; instead they would mark the candidates in order of preference. If no single candidate won 50% of the first preference votes in a constituency, the votes of the lower-placed candidates would be redistributed in accordance with their second and lower preferences until one candidate had half the votes.

Meanwhile in the second or plus part, around 100 additional MPs would be elected from county-wide party lists. These seats would go to the parties that had most obviously failed to get their proportionate share in the first part of the election.

This has led some Labour strategists to a simple conclusion. Why not implement the AV half of Lord Jenkins's proposal while leaving the plus half to gather dust? It would mean that all MPs would continue to be linked to an individual constituency. And it would ensure that every MP had the backing of at least half of their constituents. Peter Mandelson, who is close to Tony Blair, backed the idea in a speech last week.

The logic behind this proposal is simple, if ruthless. At Westminster the Lib Dems are far more of a threat to the Tories than they are to Labour. There are just four seats where a Lib Dem lies second and less than 10% behind a Labour MP. But there are no fewer than 21 seats where they are breathing down the neck of the local Tory MP. If second preferences help to push some second-placed Lib Dems into first place, William Hague has more to lose than Tony Blair.

And there seems to be a further advantage for Labour. Given the relatively good relations between Labour and the Lib Dems, it seems that Lib Dem voters would be more likely to give their second preferences to Labour than to the Tories. In other words, the system might even enable some second-placed Labour candidates to overtake a first place Tory too.

The British election study confirms this assumption. At the time of the last election, two in three of those who voted Lib Dem said they would have given a second preference vote to Labour. Just one in five would back the Tories. The picture was very similar when this question was asked after last year's European elections.

As a result, under AV Labour's 1997 landslide would have been even greater than it was. The party's majority might have been as much as 245 compared with the 179 it actually secured. The Lib Dems would have seen their representation nearly doubled while Mr Hague's motley band would have numbered fewer than 100. It is hardly a more proportional system, as Mr Mandelson claimed it would be, but it is certainly more satisfactory for both Labour and the Lib Dems.

This analysis is dangerously short-sighted, however. Lib Dem voters may be well disposed toward Labour at the moment. But it has not always been so. From 1983 to 1992 more Lib Dem voters preferred the Tories to Labour. Indeed, in 1987 over a half of them preferred the Tories and just one in three backed Labour.

AV would have done little harm to the Tories at those elections. In 1987 they may well have had an even bigger majority. In 1992, John Major would still have scraped back into Downing Street, albeit with a majority in single figures. Labour's woes would have been even worse.

Some proponents of AV might take comfort from these figures. The system might give the Lib Dems more seats, but they would remain powerless when it comes to government. No third-party tail would be wagging the big party dog.

Yet this is to ignore a vital feature of AV. A more proportional system might make Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy powerful after polling day, but AV would help make him a powerful figure before a single vote is cast. If the battle between Labour and the Tories looked at all close, the outcome might well appear to hinge on what Mr Kennedy recommended his potentially volatile voters to do with their second preference. Securing that endorsement is hardly likely to come for free.

At the moment, Mr Kennedy appears surprisingly relaxed about Labour's PR debate. Little wonder. He might continue to back Lord Jenkins in public. But in private the Lib Dem spider has reason to savour the AV fly.

John Curtice is deputy director of the ESRC Centre for Research into Elections and Social Trends.

J.Curtice@strath.ac.uk

The party's majority might have been as much as 245 compared with the 179 it actually secured. The Lib Dems would have seen their representation nearly doubled while Mr Hague's motley band would have numbered fewer than 100. It is hardly a more proportional system, as Mr Mandelson claimed it would be, but it is certainly more satisfactory for both Labour and the Lib Dems. This analysis is dangerously short-sighted, however. Lib Dem voters may be well disposed toward Labour at the moment. But it has not always been so. From 1983 to 1992 more Lib Dem voters preferred the Tories to Labour. Indeed, in 1987 over a half of them preferred the Tories and just one in three backed Labour. AV would have done little harm to the Tories at those elections. In 1987 they may well have had an even bigger majority. In 1992, John Major would still have scraped back into Downing Street, albeit with a majority in single figures. Labour's woes would have been even worse. Some proponents of AV might take comfort from these figures. The system might give the Lib Dems more seats, but they would remain powerless when it comes to government. No third-party tail would be wagging the big party dog. Yet this is to ignore a vital feature of AV. A more proportional system might make Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy powerful after polling day, but AV would help make him a powerful figure before a single vote is cast. If the battle between Labour and the Tories looked at all close, the outcome might well appear to hinge on what Mr Kennedy recommended his potentially volatile voters to do with their second preference. Securing that endorsement is hardly likely to come for free. At the moment, Mr Kennedy appears surprisingly relaxed about Labour's PR debate. Little wonder. He might continue to back Lord Jenkins in public. But in private the Lib Dem spider has reason to savour the AV fly. webTitle: Fake calls exposed in Levy row

fields.headline: Fake calls exposed in Levy row
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's embattled special envoy Lord Levy last night challenged the newspaper which published his personal tax details to explain how two telephone calls were made to the inland revenue, by someone pretending to be him, to confirm disputed information about his financial affairs.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's embattled special envoy Lord Levy last night challenged the newspaper which published his personal tax details to explain how two telephone calls were made to the inland revenue, by someone pretending to be him, to confirm disputed information about his financial affairs.

After receiving a letter from the chairman of the inland revenue, Nick Montagu, revealing that his staff are still trying to trace the unknown caller, the wealthy music impresario went back on the offensive to clear his name of charges of hypocrisy - or worse - over his modest £5,000 tax bill in 1998-99.

The fightback came on a day when Mr Blair, who is standing by his special envoy to the middle east, saw Ehud Barak, the Israeli prime minister, without him. "There was never any intention that I should be there," said Lord Levy who was hosting a dinner last night which the prime minister was expected to attend.

Lord Levy is furious at what he see as a politically-motivated smear by the Sunday Times. The man who has raised at least £7m for Labour admitted he had been through a "quite awful" time since he failed to obtain a high court injunction preventing the paper from publishing its findings.

After Mr Montagu revealed that the fake caller had "quoted detailed, accurate information by way of identification". He explained that his staff had accepted this as proof that the caller was, as he claimed to be, the real Lord Levy.

In a brief statement last night, the Sunday Times said the disputed details were passed to it "by a source during a general investigation into tax avoidance".

"The newspaper did not make any phone calls impersonating Lord Levy and did not ask anybody to do so. It is a newspaper's job to publish the truth which we have done, and to disclose information which is in the public interest," the statement continued.

Lord Levy last night disputed the paper's claim to innocence in the impersonation and its public interest defence.

"It is a strange coincidence that the Sunday Times sent a letter to me at around 4.30pm on June 23 [two days before publication] on the same day that the second of the two calls were made to the inland revenue," he said in an interview with the Guardian.

Backed by Downing Street, Lord Levy challenged the paper to be "as open as I have been" and explain who obtained the details of his tax affairs and who verified them with the inland revenue. Last night, the inland revenue said "our inquiries about the source of the call are continuing". However, chances of tracing it must be slim.

The Sunday Times statement cited Mr Justice Toulson's remarks in denying the injunction at the high court.

The judge argued that it was "relevant and proper" that a man in public life, who is allied to a party that is opposed to tax avoidance schemes could not complain.

Lord Levy has argued throughout that his tax affairs - which are complicated by most people's standards - have involved neither illegal evasion nor lawful tax avoidance. He says he has paid millions in tax rather than engage in such schemes.

The Sunday Times, he said, had not been interested in the fact that he had paid £30,000 in corporation tax via his company, Wireart, as well as the £5,000 in 1998-99. His expenses - the subject of a second article - had been agreed with the inland revenue.

Complaining of a gap in the inland revenue's identification system, he said last night: "I was very surprised to learn that two calls were made impersonating me and also surprised because I have not telephoned the inland revenue for 27 years. Since I left professional practice as an accountant I have used the same firm of accountants to do my personal and professional work. "The least I would have expected was that they [the inland revenue] would have called back to my home number or looked in the records and rung my accountant," Lord Levy told the Guardian.

The Conservatives are still pushing the issue, though yesterday their focus was on Lord Levy's unaccountable role.

"He does not answer questions in the House of Lords like a minister. He is operating outside the Foreign Office framework so there is a problem of democratic accountability," said the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude.

Lord Levy argues that he is accountable because British ambassadors accompany him at all his meetings with foreign dignitaries, where even Tory MPs admit he performs well.

"I am accountable through the ambassadors, they send back everything I do through their cables," said Lord Levy, adding that he would carry on in this role "as long as they want me to carry on. Anything I can do is a privilege for me".

The row is a bitter one because the Sunday Times was also the paper which printed details of the Blair blind trust - Lord Levy prefers the term "Labour leader's office fund" - before the election after someone purporting to be a trustee, the former home secretary, Lord Merlyn Rees, also made fake phone calls.

Lord Levy's aides last night pledged to take the case to the press complaints commission.

webTitle: Half of Britain on the mobile

fields.headline: Half of Britain on the mobile
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Evidence of Britain's insatiable appetite for mobile phone technology emerged yesterday as figures showed that more than half the population has a mobile. The latest quarterly results showed that network operators had more more than 30m subscribers.
fields.body:
Evidence of Britain's insatiable appetite for mobile phone technology emerged yesterday as figures showed that more than half the population has a mobile. The latest quarterly results showed that network operators had more more than 30m subscribers.

Vodafone AirTouch maintained its position as Britain's leading operator as it added 572,000 new customers to achieve a total of 9.36m. It has a global subscriber base of 59m users.

Chris Gent, Vodafone's chief executive, said: "The customer growth figures we have reported highlight the importance of being a global player. Through organic growth and acquisition we have seen our customer base increase almost tenfold in the last two years."

Vodafone has quadrupled its size in the past 18 months with its string of takeovers that included German mobile group Mannesmann.

BT Cellnet said it gained a further 670,000 users in the quarter to take its total to 8.1m. Of the new customers, 26% were connections to BT's mobile internet service.

BT said it had reached agree ment with some of its financial service partners, including Prudential's online bank Egg, First Direct and HSBC, to have placed orders for 330,000 mobile internet phones this financial year.

"These early adopters [of mobile internet] are proving to be heavier users compared to traditional voice-only customers," said BT Cellnet managing director Peter Erskine. "This quarter has been a strong commercial success for BT Cellnet in voice and mobile internet."

Orange, the third largest operator and the fastest growing, reported its subscriber figures on Monday, saying that it had added 1.2m customers to achieve just over 7m.

John Jensen, analyst at Chase Manhattan, has predicted that Orange could leapfrog BT Cellnet to become Britain's second biggest mobile provider by subscriber numbers.

He said Orange's rapid growth had been driven by its products and quality network, offering user plans such as Everyday 50, that offers users 50 minutes for 50p.

"By the end of this year Orange should be bigger than Cellnet," Mr Jensen said.

One2One reported an increase of 1m customers in the quarter to have 6m overall. More than two-thirds of its customers are on pre-paid contracts, which are less profitable than post-paid.

One2One said its churn rate - the measure of customers switching from one mobile phone operator to another - was steady at 23%.

One2One also has a joint venture with Virgin Group in Virgin Mobile.

One2One said Virgin Mobile increased its customer base by just over 70,000 in the quarter with the joint venture.

webTitle: FA club faces purge of racist fans

fields.headline: FA club faces purge of racist fans
fields.trailText: The Football Association's official England supporters' club is disfigured by racists, xenophobes and hooligans, Home Office ministers believe. They are to demand a radical tightening of the club rules as part of a wider drive to "rebrand" and remarket the national game.
fields.body:
The Football Association's official England supporters' club is disfigured by racists, xenophobes and hooligans, Home Office ministers believe. They are to demand a radical tightening of the club rules as part of a wider drive to "rebrand" and remarket the national game.

The drive will also see the FA open up its membership book to scrutiny by the National Criminal Intelligence Service. The NCIS will be able to use the list to cross-reference any member who has a criminal conviction. Anyone found to have a record for public order offences, including drunkenness and crimes of violence, could be debarred.

Ministers are determined to fight hooliganism not just by tougher laws, but also by changing the whole culture surrounding football in Britain. They also want to make sure more is done to encourage both women and "dads with lads" to attend football matches.

Last night a minister told the Guardian: "There is clearly a big problem with the members' club and we will use legal powers if necessary to end its degradation. There is a problem with racist chanting and xenophobia."

A Home Office working party, including members of the FA and unofficial supporters' clubs, will report by the autumn on measures to stamp out hooliganism.

The FA has privately acknowledged in the wake of the violence at the Euro 2000 championship in Holland and Belgium that there is a problem with its 28,000-strong supporters' club and admits it must be harbouring hooligans.

The anti-hooligan bill due to be rushed through parliament this month will contain powers giving the NCIS authority to hand details of all criminal records to the FA.

Membership of the supporters' club gives privileges to buy tickets. For some England matches abroad club membership is the only certain method of obtaining tickets.

At present, the FA only debars from its club anyone found guilty of a football-related offence - only a little more than 1,000 such convictions have been handed down.

But as many as a third of the fans deported from Brussels by the Belgian police have emerged to have had a criminal record. About 3% were also claiming some form of welfare benefit.

Ministers have been struck that hundreds of English football fans sitting in areas reserved for the official supporters' club were chanting racist or provocative songs.

Government sources said it should be possible for the FA to identify the individuals singing racist songs using spotters, video cameras and and cross-checking with seat numbers.

One government member said: "If this means throwing hundreds of them out of the club, then hundreds should be thrown out. We either deal with this or go on pretending it is beyond our control. It is a matter of will. Exhortation is not enough."

The sources pointed out that the FA has already been fined £30,000 by Uefa, the European football authority, following racist chants by members of the English supporters' club during an England-Sweden match in Malmo.

The working party on hooliganism, to be chaired by Lord Bassam and only agreed last Friday, will cover ticketing arrangements, travel sponsorship, the involvement of clubs in the community, tackling racism and "looking at good practice".

Ministers acknowledge that the FA is reforming under the leadership of Adam Crozier, its new chief executive. Mr Crozier yesterday wrote to both the Conservative leader, William Hague, and the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, urging them to give full support to the new emergency anti-hooligan legislation unveiled by the home secretary Jack Straw.

webTitle: Authors petition for a penny a book more

fields.headline: Authors petition for a penny a book more
fields.standfirst:
Downing Street protest seeks 50% rise in library royalties

Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Authors marched on Downing Street yesterday demanding a 50% rise in their royalties - from 2p to 3p for each time one of their books is borrowed from a public library.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Authors marched on Downing Street yesterday demanding a 50% rise in their royalties - from 2p to 3p for each time one of their books is borrowed from a public library.

It was more of an amble than a protest march, and the leaders, with their petition signed by more than 4,000 authors, were invited in for a civilised chat with the arts minister Alan Howarth, while the rest of the delegation, including the agony aunt and bestselling author Claire Rayner, serial Booker prize nominee Beryl Bainbridge, and royal biographer Philip Ziegler, sloped off to a pub to await developments.

The Society of Authors secretary, Mark Le Fanu, said Mr Howarth was sympathetically non-commital. "We pointed out fairly forcefully that the public lending rights scheme was a Labour success, introduced in the dying days of the Callaghan government after the Tory backbenchers scuppered various measures in the 1970s, but that the funding hasn't been touched for seven years. The engine is still motoring along nicely, but the gas is running out."

The authors, led by the novellist Deborah Moggach, chairwoman of the society, are calling for an immediate increase in the royalties fund from £5m to £7m a year.

The petition is a roll call of the best known British authors, including Martin Amis, Alan Bennett, Malcolm Bradbury, AS Byatt, Sebastian Faulks, Alan Ayckbourn, Pam Ayres, Antonia Fraser, John Fowles, PD James, John Mortimer and Tom Stoppard.

The society's figures show that the tiny royalties are a lifeline to some of the poorest authors: a recent survey showed that 46% of British authors earn less than £5,000 a year.

Because the royalties reflect the books that readers borrow, rather than the hyped best- seller list, the scheme provides a small but steady income to many authors who have never made it on to bestseller lists, or dropped off the list years ago.

The sum any one author can earn from the scheme is capped at £6,000 a year, to prevent the entire fund being paid over to the estate of the late Catherine Cookson. Although her books no longer appear on bestseller lists, of the top 20 borrowed books in 1998-1999, 12 were by Cookson.

Over a third of the public lending rights royalties go to children's authors, who rarely make it on to bestseller lists. JK Rowling, author of the Harry Potter books, does not make it to the top of the borrowing list, presumably because the market is already saturated with books sold.

Mr Le Fanu said the society had asked authors if they felt the £6,000 limit should also be raised. "It was really rather touching - the richer authors were adamant that they didn't want any more money from the scheme, they wanted the payments spread wider. We thought that was another thing that might appeal to Labour."

webTitle: 'Another child chased' hours before Sarah disappeared

fields.headline: 'Another child chased' hours before Sarah disappeared
fields.trailText: Detectives hunting the missing schoolgirl Sarah Payne are investigating a claim that another eight-year-old girl was the target of an alleged abduction attempt just hours before her disappearance.
fields.body:
Detectives hunting the missing schoolgirl Sarah Payne are investigating a claim that another eight-year-old girl was the target of an alleged abduction attempt just hours before her disappearance.

Sussex police confirmed last night that a mother had come forward to say her daughter had been chased by a strange man just five hours before Sarah vanished from near her grandparents' home at 8pm on Saturday evening.

The second child had been playing on her bike on a private estate in Littlehampton, West Sussex, three miles from Kingston, where Sarah was last seen.

As police spent their third day hunting for Sarah, a spokesman said the second child had told her mother of the incident after hearing of the feared abduction of Sarah on television.

"A lady called us from the Beaumont Park estate in Littlehampton just after 5.30pm on Sunday to say she had just been told by her daughter that she was chased by a strange man."

The spokesman denied reports that the man, who was described as bearded and with thinning brown hair, had been driving a white van similar to the one seen passing the cornfield where Sarah had been playing with her brothers and sister before she disappeared.

As police spoke of their "increasing concern" for Sarah's safety, her teenage brother attended a police identity parade in an attempt to find the man detectives believe may have snatched her from the lane.

Lee Payne - described as a "bright sparky teenager" by assistant chief constable Nigel Yeo - viewed a line-up at Brighton police station, including a man in his 40s, from Littlehampton, who had been held since Sunday evening before being released yesterday on police bail.

It was hoped the 13-year-old would be able to clarify whether the man, whose white van is being forensically tested, was the person he saw driving in the lane at that time.

Detectives had until midnight last night to continue questioning him. A second man, in his 30s, and believed to be from Crawley, West Sussex, who was arrested on Monday evening, was also released yesterday on police bail.

As some 250 volunteers finished sifting through fields and copses in the area, officers focussed their attention on known sex offenders, and those with a criminal record.

The Metropolitan police and other neighbouring forces have been drafted in as calls on the case have escalated to 800, and a psychological profile has been drawn up of the abductor. "We've been getting assistance from other agencies, including a profile from the national crime service," said Mr Yeo.

Meanwhile Sarah's parents said their other children, Lee, Luke, 11, and six-year-old Charlotte, were struggling under the strain of their sister's disappearance. "They are getting worse and worse. They've never been apart this long, never," said Sara Payne.

Clutching her husband Michael's hand, the 31-year-old barmaid added: "Lee is very quiet. He keeps himself away most of the time now, and they're getting snappy with each other."

But she insisted her daughter was alive, and, addressing the television cameras in case the little girl was watching, added: "We're coming. I know we're taking our time, darling, but we're coming. We are all missing you."

The spokesman denied reports that the man, who was described as bearded and with thinning brown hair, had been driving a white van similar to the one seen passing the cornfield where Sarah had been playing with her brothers and sister before she disappeared. As police spoke of their "increasing concern" for Sarah's safety, her teenage brother attended a police identity parade in an attempt to find the man detectives believe may have snatched her from the lane. Lee Payne - described as a "bright sparky teenager" by assistant chief constable Nigel Yeo - viewed a line-up at Brighton police station, including a man in his 40s, from Littlehampton, who had been held since Sunday evening before being released yesterday on police bail. webTitle: Ananova  - the face of mobile news

fields.headline: Ananova  - the face of mobile news
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: She's slick, sultry and coming to a mobile phone near you. Ananova - the world's first virtual cyberchick newsreader - and her parents, the Press Association's new media division, have been bought by Orange for £95m.
fields.body:
She's slick, sultry and coming to a mobile phone near you. Ananova - the world's first virtual cyberchick newsreader - and her parents, the Press Association's new media division, have been bought by Orange for £95m.

Britain's third largest mobile phone operator will use Ananova on its internet portal. This will complement its established text message news service which delivers information such as weather and stockmarket reports.

Orange's video compression technology will deliver full-motion images on mobile phones by the end of the year, using its GSM network. Manufacturers have already been signed up to produce the video hand sets. Ananova, marketed as a cross between Posh Spice and Carol Vorderman, was owned by the Press Association newswire agency.

PA put Ananova and the media division, which employs 100 people, up for sale in February after a review of the business suggested that it was ripe for sale.

The business is led by its chief executive, Robert Simpson, and commercial director, Vivienne Adshead, above right.

PA said that the deal would return value to shareholders and provide funds for further development of services for media and other customers.

The news agency will provide Orange with news and information services as part of the deal.

fields.headline: Good day, bad day
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Lady Thatcher's handbag. The online auction for the former prime minister's trademark continues apace. The highest bid last night topped £100,000, money raised going to Breast Cancer Care. And what of Cherie Blair's tiger print bag? A paltry £255 was the best.

Bad day

Chris Evans. The millionaire broadcaster finally opened his chequebook and honoured his pledge to give Ken Livingstone £200,000. Evans told listeners to his Virgin radio breakfast show: "My accountant will drop it off at Ken's office en route to playing golf with me this morning." Evans had initially pledged £100,000 but doubled it when he took umbrage at a jibe at redheads by Labour mayoral candidate Frank Dobson.

Today

Commons: Education and employment questions. Debates on HM Customs and Excise and Department of Social Security medical services. Backbench debate on anti-social behaviour, crime and damage caused by illegal camping. Lords: Transport bill, committee.

webTitle: Chauffeur recounts fury of accused union boss

fields.headline: Chauffeur recounts fury of accused union boss
fields.trailText: Union leader Roger Lyons wanted whistleblower Marcia Solomon "dead and buried" for making allegations that he had fiddled thousands of pounds of expenses and fraudently obtained cash through false bank accounts, his former chauffeur, Bryan Keegan, told an employment tribunal in central London yesterday.
fields.body:
Union leader Roger Lyons wanted whistleblower Marcia Solomon "dead and buried" for making allegations that he had fiddled thousands of pounds of expenses and fraudently obtained cash through false bank accounts, his former chauffeur, Bryan Keegan, told an employment tribunal in central London yesterday.

He said the general secretary of the Manufacturing, Science and Finance trade union was "almost paranoid" about the secretarial assistant who had raised questions of impropriety by him and Nelson Mendes, head of finance, and people who had taken up her case. Ms Solomon is claiming unfair and wrongful dismissal.

Mr Keegan said Mr Lyons described John Chowcat, the former assistant general secretary, who called for an investigation, as someone "who didn't know what he was doing" and " never did any work". "They're all dead and buried, that lot - Colin Adkins, Marcia Solomon, Chowcat - all of them. They're all on the way out. Finished," he told senior officials on his mobile phone, said Mr Keegan.

He had been declared redundant two days after he said he obtained £7,000 owed in overtime for driving Mr Lyons for up to 18 hours a day.

He also disclosed he had been required to take Mr Lyons's daughter to work as a solicitor.

Colin Adkins, an MSF research assistant, told the tribunal that he had been told by his line manager that he had been sent off to Caerphilly from head office for a year because he had taken up Ms Solomon's case. "It was clear to me that the question of my employment future was being brought into question," he said.

He was told by union officials that Ms Solomon was "mad and insane" for making the allegations. Mr Adkins said: " It was well known that some senior officers had fairly extravagant expenses claims. There would often be an unjustified level of wining and dining, an over-reliance on using taxis instead of public transport, an over-reliance on using mobile telephones and a high level of unreceipted expense claims. "

He also said that regional managers of the union were quite differently treated from head office staff.

"They would not be allowed to incur expenses by using the hotel telephones to call home - they were to use public telephones. Officers had two thirds of their home telephone bills and the full cost of mobile telephone use paid by the union."

Mr Chowcat - who was also a member of the ruling TUC council - broke a year's silence to reveal that the disclosures about Mr Lyons's hidden interest-free loans meant that the union had submitted inaccurate returns to the union's certification office and the Inland Revenue for its 1997 accounts.

He also disclosed that Mr Lyons appeared to have broken the rules by not providing receipts for items under £10 - since in 1995 the head of finance had insisted on receipts for all expenditure.

The union's accountants, HW Fisher and Company, were also criticised by Bartholomew Madge, a chartered accountant, for not conducting a forensic inquiry into the allegations against Mr Lyons and Mr Mendes. He said they had failed to check bank accounts held by Mr Lyons and Mr Mendes.

He said that there was "an acute breakdown in normal accepted business practice" for checking expenses receipts and there were serious weaknesses in the investigative methods.

"The MSF union cannot rely on the report to state that the allegations [about false accounts] are so manifestly false that they must therefore have been fabricated ...

"It therefore cannot be said, with confidence, that improper manipulation of funds in such accounts was not occurring."

The hearing continues today.

webTitle: Officers still held in Welsh murder inquiry

fields.headline: Officers still held in Welsh murder inquiry
fields.trailText: Detectives were last night given more time to question three people arrested in connection with the murder of three generations of a family in a south Wales village last year.
fields.body:
Detectives were last night given more time to question three people arrested in connection with the murder of three generations of a family in a south Wales village last year.

The three, two police officers and a former policewoman, were picked up in raids on three addresses earlier this week, and have been questioned about the killings of Mandy Power, her mother and her two young daughters.

A 38-year-old man and a 33-year-old woman have been held on suspicion of murder. Another man, also aged 38, was arrested on suspicion of attempting to pervert the course of justice.

Mandy Power, 34, her mother, Doris Dawson, 80, and her daughters Katie, 10, and Emily, eight, were beaten to death with a four-foot metal rod at their home in Clydach, near Swansea, in June last year.

Their house was set on fire after the killings in an apparent attempt to destroy any evidence. Firemen discovered the bodies when they were called to put out the blaze. Mrs Dawson, who had leukaemia, had been so badly beaten she could be identified only by her wedding ring.

South Wales police, who have faced strong criticism from locals about the pace of the murder investigation, raided three addresses in the Pontypridd and Pontardawe areas on Tuesday morning.

Arrests were made at the homes of Mrs Power's lesbian lover, Alison Lewis, a former woman police constable, and of Mrs Lewis's estranged husband, Steve Lewis, a police sergeant. Police have until 11pm today to continue their questioning of the three.

Another arrest was made at the home of Mr Lewis's twin brother, Stuart, who was recently appointed an inspector in the South Wales force. Police yesterday continued to refuse to name those arrested.

The Clydach killings became Wales's biggest murder inquiry, involving three appeals for help on the BBC's Crimewatch programme.

fields.headline: Deserted islanders
fields.standfirst: In 11 days' time, the exiled population of a tiny, little-known British colony will be taking the government to the high court. Natasha Mann on the Chagossians' battle for the right to go home
fields.trailText: In 11 days' time, the exiled population of a tiny, little-known British colony will be taking the government to the high court. Natasha Mann on the Chagossians' battle for the right to go home
fields.body:
Louis Olivier Bancoult was four when he left his homeland, a coconut palm-covered island in the middle of the sparkling Indian Ocean. He was banished with the rest of the population of the Chagos archipelago, one of Britain's last colonial outposts. Dumped 1,200 miles away in Mauritius, Louis and his compatriots were left in abject poverty, without shelter, food or jobs. And they have been there now for more than 30 years, largely forgotten, an alienated community in exile.

Today, however, the story of the Chagos islands, a ghost of our colonial past, has finally returned to haunt the British government.

In the ramshackle district of Cassis, 10 minutes away from the polished modern buildings of the Mauritian capital, Port Louis, a historic legal challenge is being mounted. Here, the jobless shelter from the heat under a tree or sprawl on the pavement drinking beer. Louis Bancoult's own home is down a rough dirt path past corrugated shacks that overspill with children. It is an unlikely spot for any kind of legal action, but out in the backyard, seated amid roaming chickens, Creole-speaking Chagossians (known as the Ilois) are in discussion. Last year Bancoult, the community leader, was given leave to contest the ban that prevents his people from setting foot in the place they refer to as "the motherland". A judicial review is scheduled for July 17 at London's high court, and the Ilois are gearing themselves up for the next stage in their battle to go home.

Many of the Ilois are elderly now, but they recall the circumstances of their expulsion. With Mauritius, the Chagos islands formed part of a British colony, but in the 60s, when Mauritius was negotiating independence, Britain struck a deal. Mauritius became independent in 1968 with £3m in compensation. Meanwhile Britain retained sovereignty of the archipelago.

The reason for the deal later became transparently clear. On a map of the Indian Ocean, the Chagos islands look like a cluster of dots, but their location, between the eastern coast of Africa, the Middle East and South West Asia, gave them enormous strategic significance. For western defence strategists, jittery about the Soviet empire, they were a gift. Britain leased the US the biggest island, Diego Garcia, allegedly in return for a discount on Polaris submarines.

Today Diego Garcia houses a vital US military base. Complete with a 12,000ft runway and a natural harbour, it was used to launch B-52 bombers during the Gulf war and supported UN intervention in Somalia in 1992.

The British government has always preferred to describe the Illois population, which in the 60s was spread across the British Indian Ocean Territory (which included Chagos), as "migrant workers". But the Ilois, many of whose families had been there since the early 19th century, having originally come from Mauritius, Madagascar, Mozambique and India to work on copra plantations, certainly liked to think of themselves as a proper, settled community: Diego Garcia boasted a school, a prison, a church and a cemetery. They regarded themselves as British subjects and Bancoult still holds a British passport, which gives his place of birth as the Chagos archipelago. But between 1967 and 1973, the Chagossians claim, they were tricked, bullied and cajoled into leaving the islands. In 1968 Bancoult's family sought medical treatment in Mauritius after a cart drove over his sister's foot. She died two months later and the family prepared to return. "It was a big surprise when my parents registered their names - they were told by the officer that we could not because the land had been given to the US to make a military base," says Bancoult.

"I remember it as if it was today. My mother was crying because she was very sad about our beautiful country and our wonderful life. Her brother and her father were left in the Chagos and all our belongings. We had to stay in Mauritius, and face all the difficulties we still are facing."

The people left behind on the islands had little idea of what was going on but supplies of essential provisions - rice, flour, sugar and oil - stopped. Then in 1971 a meeting was held on Diego Garcia. Lisette Talate, 59, was there. "We were told by the residential manager of the Chagos that the Ilois must move to Mauritius to make way for the military base. The island had been sold in order to give independence to Mauritius. When we received the message we said that we did not want to leave, but we had no choice. Many people wanted to stay but all the provisions had been stopped and there were no doctors and nurses."

At first, the islanders were told that they could stay on the island of Peros Banhos, 100 miles away, but in 1973 a ship arrived to take them to Mauritius, with promises of a new life. "In Chagos they had been told they would have a house, a portion of land, animals and a sum of money," says Bancoult. "But when they arrived nothing had been done." After refusing to disembark for several days, the Ilois were finally offered accommodation in the dockers flats. "They were in very bad condition with no doors or windows, but they had no choice but to go and live there. Another place they had been offered had been used to keep animals. This is the treatment we have had in Mauritius."

Adapting to life on Mauritius was difficult - they might as well have been abandoned on the streets of New York. The islanders were not used to living in a money economy having made a living from the sea and the coconut trees. They had no jobs, their skills were redundant, and they were forced to live in cramped, unsanitary conditions, with up to 20 people sleeping in one room.

Compensation of £650,000 was paid by the Mauritian government, but not until 1978, when the promised sum had been eroded by inflation.

"Life was very difficult," says Rita Elysee, 74, Bancoult's mother. She found work as a domestic servant to feed her nine children. "Sometimes I had to use old bread cooked with sugar to feed the family."

As well as poverty, there was racism. "The Mauritian people did not agree that we came to Mauritius and we have had bad treatment. When facing all these difficulties I became mad. I was thinking my life in Chagos was better than in Mauritius. Mauritius had become a hell for me."

Life is still rough for the 8,000 Ilois living in Mauritius. The displaced community faces problems with alcohol, drugs, prostitution and suicide. Two of Bancoult's brothers died in their 30s, one an alcoholic, the other a drug addict. Illiteracy is common, as is unemployment. What little work there is tends to be loading lorries or domestic service.

Extra compensation was paid to the Ilois in 1982, after the women went on hunger strike, but the agreement included a "no return" clause, which Bancoult says the illiterate Ilois did not understand.

Rita David lives in a corrugated iron hut with a roof perforated with holes. In summer, when temperatures can reach 45C, it is an oven. In the rainy season, it offers little protection. Seventeen people sleep in the three-bedroomed house. With work irregular, David "does" for a local family to provide some sort of income. But it's a poor living.

In the kitchen, Bancoult surveys the grimy, uneven floor and the two aged gas rings, which are all there is to cook on, and says: "This is why I must have the courage to fight for my people."

He knows he has a difficult fight ahead but it will be fuelled by his outrage. "It was a great injustice that the UK government has done to its own people. We consider it is because we are black people, because we came from slaves. Otherwise, I think, we would have had a better treatment."

If the Ilois win the right to return home, it will take financial aid to make living in the Chagos archipelago viable. But for those who want to go, it will mean a new life in the land of their forebears - the place those old enough to remember still call home.

Our colonial present

Territories still ruled by Britain:

Anguilla : Most northerly of the Leeward Islands in the Caribbean. Mostly privately owned.

Bermuda : Britain's oldest colony. Has to import up to 80% of its food.

British Antarctic Territory: Big, cold ice shelves, uninhabited.

British Indian Ocean Territory: Chagos archipelago and 54,400 sq km of ocean, of which 60 sq km is dry land. Access restricted.

British Virgin Islands: More than 40 islands and 153 sq km in all, "discovered" by Columbus in 1493. Hilly, beachy and sub-tropical, 60% privately owned.

Cayman Islands: Named after a type of crocodile. Three islands - Grand Cayman, Cayman Brac, Little Cayman.

Falkland Islands: Archipelago of 200 bleak, windy islands.

Gibraltar: Peninsula of 5.8sq km secured in Treaty of Utrecht, 1713.

Montserrat : Volcanic island has been erupting since July 1995.

Pitcairn Islands: East of French Polynesia, these islands are the British empire's last stronghold in the Pacific. Small, volcanic, 3.8 sq km.

St Helena and dependencies: In the South Atlantic, with no airport; the only physical link with the outside world is the Royal Mail ship. The territory includes Ascension and Tristan De Cunha. 5,000 inhabitants.

South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands: Lying 1,290 km east of the Falkands, mostly covered in snow, ice and mountains.

Turks and Caicos Islands: South east of the Bahamas, six inhabited.
