"Life was very difficult," says Rita Elysee, 74, Bancoult's mother. She found work as a domestic servant to feed her nine children. "Sometimes I had to use old bread cooked with sugar to feed the family." As well as poverty, there was racism. "The Mauritian people did not agree that we came to Mauritius and we have had bad treatment. When facing all these difficulties I became mad. I was thinking my life in Chagos was better than in Mauritius. Mauritius had become a hell for me." Life is still rough for the 8,000 Ilois living in Mauritius. The displaced community faces problems with alcohol, drugs, prostitution and suicide. Two of Bancoult's brothers died in their 30s, one an alcoholic, the other a drug addict. Illiteracy is common, as is unemployment. What little work there is tends to be loading lorries or domestic service. Extra compensation was paid to the Ilois in 1982, after the women went on hunger strike, but the agreement included a "no return" clause, which Bancoult says the illiterate Ilois did not understand. Rita David lives in a corrugated iron hut with a roof perforated with holes. In summer, when temperatures can reach 45C, it is an oven. In the rainy season, it offers little protection. Seventeen people sleep in the three-bedroomed house. With work irregular, David "does" for a local family to provide some sort of income. But it's a poor living. In the kitchen, Bancoult surveys the grimy, uneven floor and the two aged gas rings, which are all there is to cook on, and says: "This is why I must have the courage to fight for my people." He knows he has a difficult fight ahead but it will be fuelled by his outrage. "It was a great injustice that the UK government has done to its own people. We consider it is because we are black people, because we came from slaves. Otherwise, I think, we would have had a better treatment." If the Ilois win the right to return home, it will take financial aid to make living in the Chagos archipelago viable. But for those who want to go, it will mean a new life in the land of their forebears - the place those old enough to remember still call home. Our colonial present Territories still ruled by Britain: Anguilla : Most northerly of the Leeward Islands in the Caribbean. Mostly privately owned. Bermuda : Britain's oldest colony. Has to import up to 80% of its food. British Antarctic Territory: Big, cold ice shelves, uninhabited. British Indian Ocean Territory: Chagos archipelago and 54,400 sq km of ocean, of which 60 sq km is dry land. Access restricted. British Virgin Islands: More than 40 islands and 153 sq km in all, "discovered" by Columbus in 1493. Hilly, beachy and sub-tropical, 60% privately owned. Cayman Islands: Named after a type of crocodile. Three islands - Grand Cayman, Cayman Brac, Little Cayman. Falkland Islands: Archipelago of 200 bleak, windy islands. Gibraltar: Peninsula of 5.8sq km secured in Treaty of Utrecht, 1713. Montserrat : Volcanic island has been erupting since July 1995. Pitcairn Islands: East of French Polynesia, these islands are the British empire's last stronghold in the Pacific. Small, volcanic, 3.8 sq km. St Helena and dependencies: In the South Atlantic, with no airport; the only physical link with the outside world is the Royal Mail ship. The territory includes Ascension and Tristan De Cunha. 5,000 inhabitants. South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands: Lying 1,290 km east of the Falkands, mostly covered in snow, ice and mountains. Turks and Caicos Islands: South east of the Bahamas, six inhabited.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Solar Blast | Twelve Monkeys | The Last Boy Scout | The Big Lebowski
fields.body:
Solar Blast

9pm, National Geographic

While training our telescope to the outer reaches of the universe, it's easy to forget that we are in the vicinity of an enormous star, which affects our weather more than any other outside influence, and periodically bombards the earth with "a billion tonnes of matter travelling at a million miles an hour". This thorough documentary highlights how little we know about the sun and how vulnerable we are to "solar rage" - a 1989 blast produced a blackout in half of Canada, the next one could be far worse.

Twelve Monkeys

(Terry Gilliam, 1995)

10pm, FilmFour

Brilliant but flawed science fantasy inspired by Chris Marker's 60s time travelling conundrum, La Jetée. Bruce Willis is a man sent back through time to trace the origin of a virus which has wiped out most of mankind. Brad Pitt is the loopy leader of the Army of the 12 Monkeys, suspected source of the tragic disease; Madeleine Stowe is the doc helping Willis in his quest. Full of the visual chaos theory that was Gilliam's Brazil.

The Last Boy Scout

(Tony Scott, 1991)

10pm, Sky MovieMax

Bruce Willis as a latter-day Philip Marlowe trying to do the right thing in a bad world. Quipping and fighting with Die Hard bravado, he is teamed up with ex-footballer Damon Wayans against Major League corruption. Scott is effective in the intense bursts of violence, but Willis's laconic humour wears a little thin.

The Big Lebowski

(Joel Coen, 1998)

11pm, Sky Premier

A wonderful, wacky Coen brothers comedy that filters a noir plot through the confused consciousness of hippy throwback the Dude (Jeff Bridges), aka Lebowski. Helping him navigate the dangerous world of his rich, objectionable namesake, when he'd rather be smoking weed and going bowling, is the double act of John Goodman's cracked Viet vet Walter and Steve Buscemi's dopey Donny: but stealing the show is John Tutturro's cameo as Jesus, the lilac-clad bowler.

webTitle: Straw plays down fears on hooligan law

fields.headline: Straw plays down fears on hooligan law
fields.standfirst:
Football Unlimited

Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday moved to play down suggestions that there was "a Scottish loophole" in his emergency anti-hooligan legislation which would allow trouble makers to get to England away games by travelling via Scottish ports.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday moved to play down suggestions that there was "a Scottish loophole" in his emergency anti-hooligan legislation which would allow trouble makers to get to England away games by travelling via Scottish ports.

Mr Straw also tried to reassure some of the 900 fans who the Belgian police admit were innocents caught up in events when they arrested them that they would not automatically face orders banning them from football matches for the next 10 years under his new legislation.

The details of the bill, to be rushed through Parliament by the end of the month, are to be published tomorrow.

But yesterday the Conservative party was already making clear that it wants to see the bill restricting the right to jury trial abandoned by ministers as the price of its cooperation to get the anti-hooligan measure on the statute book by the time of the next England game on September 2.

Scottish opposition parties yesterday accused Mr Straw of making a glaring omission when it was realised that his proposal to prevent suspected hooligans travelling abroad will have no validity in Scottish law and in theory the whole package could be undermined by English hooligans travelling to away games from Scottish ports.

But the Scottish executive said yesterday this was highly unlikely as the majority of cases could be handled by cooperation between Scottish and English police forces. Banned football hooligans would have their passports confiscated at such times and so could not travel.

Shared cross-border intelligence would allow police forces north of the border to detain suspected trouble makers while English forces apply for a warrant. "The vast majority of cases will be covered by the Westminster legislation," said a spokesman for the Scottish executive.

There are no plans by Holyrood ministers at present to draw up legislation to formally close the loophole. Those banned hooligans who did manage to leave the country despite being banned from travel would face criminal proceedings when they got home.

Mr Straw also tried to calm fears that anybody arrested by the police during an international football tournament would automatically find themselves the subject of a banning order. A home office spokeswoman said that the Belgian police had acknowl edged that many of the 900 plus English people who had been arrested and deported during Euro 2000 had been caught up in events. Only about 25 have been convicted of any offence so far. "Arrest by the Belgian police would not in itself be sufficient to justify a banning order," she said, adding that other evidence would be necessary.

She said that the Football Supporters' Association were collecting dossiers on those who believed they had been wrongfully arrested that would be passed on to the home office. Kevin Miles of the FSA said initially about 60 people had come forward in response to an appeal they launched last week.

The Home Secretary admitted the timing of the crackdown had been "strongly influenced" by England's 2006 World Cup bid - a decision on which is made today in Switzerland.

He said: "The timing of the announcement that I made to Parliament was very strongly influenced by the fact that FIFA are meeting today and tomorrow to discuss the site of the World Cup competition in 2006.

"It would have been daft to have published them at the end of the week rather than the beginning," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

fields.headline: Hair of desperation
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: Hair. Ally McBeal (C4) is really just about hair. There's Ally's hair: once mousy and lank, but last night - being the first episode of a new series - bursting with follicular life: perky and wavy and prancing like a pony in a scented meadow.
fields.body:
Hair. Ally McBeal (C4) is really just about hair. There's Ally's hair: once mousy and lank, but last night - being the first episode of a new series - bursting with follicular life: perky and wavy and prancing like a pony in a scented meadow. Even John noticed a change: "Why are you so wet?" he said, spitting the words out. There was an unrequited passion in his voice. My household immediately placed bets on John and Ally snogging by the end of the series. "It's the new look", Ally replied, quick as a knife, omitting to mention she'd just had sex with a complete stranger in the carwash.

Nell's new hair, meanwhile, was unfurled in the over-congested toilets, looking even more preposterously Rapunzel-like than she did last series. It's a wonder Nell can walk down a corridor without tripping over her freak-show mane.

Is Ally McBeal a satire? Is all this cascading hair just a clever feminist joke about the bestial desires of men? No. It's just hair. And lots of it, to boot.

Even John, the strange little man who talks to unicorns, seems to be growing his executive bouffant. His hair balloons as his libido declines. Ostensibly, because he's stopped having imaginary conversations with Barry White. "I've lost him", John confided to Elaine, the office gossip. John, it transpires, is the tastiest guy in the office, with or without the spritual assistance of Barry White. "You're a hot little biscuit", Elaine whispered, giving hope to small, unattractive men across the globe.

Flatmates (C4), like Ally McBeal, examined the modern family, ie the family that isn't a family at all, but a group of people who have the misfortune to bump into each other each day at the photocopier or the student kitchen.

Channel Four have based the show on a long-running Sky magazine feature, crossing it with their successful TV format, Streetmate. The show is understandably less racy than the Sky feature, which focuses on inter-household sex, usually in the shower. Instead, C4's show follows the process of choosing a new flatmate.

The existing household grills each applicant, takes a Polaroid to remind itself what they look like, and then makes them all stand in the street while it decides who it hates the least.

It's a most attractive TV idea (a carbon copy of the flatmate interview scene in Shallow Grave), high on cruelty. In episode one, a candidate is eliminated for being stupid... but only after she's made it to the final two. "Who would you vote for?" the flatmates ask her. "Pro..ba..bly Conservative, because my parents do."

No matter how many times one feels one's seen such a show, and such people, one can never have enough dirty washing. The show's only real drawback is the lack of a decent finale: making a garden bench from instructions does not make for the most riveting of showdowns.

The winner, of course, was Shaun, the gag-a-minute gay guy. Two weeks after moving in, however, Shaun was starting to get on their nerves. The flatmates felt a bit guilty about not liking him, but Shaun had the ultimate let-out clause. He could always call them homophobic.

The Bentalls, an old-fashioned family, came under the microscope for The Secret Life Of The Family (BBC1). Cameras on toothbrushes, inside trainers, and literally getting up everyone's noses.

Janine, the mum, was an actress. I recognised her as "the ugly woman" in assorted BBC sitcoms. Except, as husband Paul pointed out, she wasn't ugly at all. She was uncommonly beautiful. A behavioural psychologist was on hand to play the modern Desmond Morris role. Continual testing of the family led to Janine being informed she was going through the menopause. "As a result of our tests," the voice-over explained helpfully, "Janine began hormone replacement therapy".

The Bentalls, it transpired, were not ordinary at all. They lived in an Elle Deco house with beautiful children and a big David Hockney swimming pool. I wasn't sure if this was a science programme or an aspirational lifestyle show. Maybe it was both - an HG Wellsian model of future living, complete with decking, spiky plants and a surveillence camera in every room.

The most chilling fact of the programme was that a kitchen dishcloth carries more germs than a toilet seat. The little girl had nits, which scuttled greasily through her hair. Just imagine the pandemonium if she walked onto the set of Ally McBeal.

webTitle: The price is right: What will be the subject of Chris Evans's next show?

fields.headline: The price is right: What will be the subject of Chris Evans's next show?
fields.trailText: New gameshow 1/5
fields.body:
New gameshow 1/5

Quiz show 4/1

Big Brother 5/1

Children's show 6/1

Candid camera 10/1

"From his humble beginnings on London's GLR to the Big Breakfast, Evans has entertained millions. But with his flagship TV series TFI finishing, he needs to find something high profile to do next", says Ed Nicholson, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler.

"He doesn't have to do anything - lets face it," says Ed. "But he will do something else. Having seen him on SMTV last week it could be a children's show, but would TV executives want Chris Evans preaching to our children?"

Evans might like to see himself as a sexy specksy, or a Virgin with Attitude, but on a children's TV show that's an impossible image. "The show would simply have to be time delayed. And anyway, Blue Peter have just found a replacement for Katy Hill," adds Ed.

The favourite is a new game-show concept. "Chris is just brilliant at knowing what people want to watch and his greatest commercial success was Don't Forget Your Toothbrush. For those reasons he has the form and the breeding to create a new humdinger of a series."

Some might say Evans has already been publicly humiliated enough, but perhaps he might want to helm a show about Joe Public's mishaps? "Despite the fact that Jeremy Beadle has disappeared from our screens, I just can't see Chris wandering down this un-adventurous path."

The big concept for the future is looking to be Big Brother shows, with Channel 4 about to broadcast its 24-hour CCTV show. "Big Brother will be huge here as it has been on the Continent - but discussions are well advanced for this particular show - and Chris does not seem to be in the running. Perhaps in the future."

The odds on a new general knowledge quiz show have been slashed in recent weeks. "I have been informed by my best contact that Millionaire-type programmes will be winging their way onto our screens shortly from BBC and ITV - but will Chris be part of it?"

Interview by Jennifer Rodger

fields.headline: £1bn for science 'a brief cure only'
fields.standfirst: Chancellor's cash injection must be sustained, say insiders
fields.trailText: The £1bn shot in the arm for British science confirmed by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, yesterday was welcomed by scientists as just that: a shot in the arm.
fields.body:
The £1bn shot in the arm for British science confirmed by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, yesterday was welcomed by scientists as just that: a shot in the arm.

But they were not convinced it would keep the best brains in Britain's laboratories. The money will be used to increase incomes for young researchers, upgrade equipment and restore crumbling buildings. But it would need more to put British science back in the major league, scientists said.

The trouble, said Chris Llewellyn Smith, provost of University College, London, and until recently head of Europe's biggest laboratory, at Cern, in Geneva, was that a shot in the arm merely helped a patient to recover. "What we need is an increase in recurrent funding which will allow us not to get into a backlog in the future, and allow us to pay and employ the best people.

"I have had senior staff leaving for the US, and we have also been recruiting from the US. At the top level we have managed to stem the brain drain and even buy back, but at the bottom end it is increasingly hard to attract really good people."

Science is international: good young scientists are encouraged to work abroad, to be stimulated by new ideas, and to set up research partnerships with teams in other countries. English is the language of science, and Britain has a 350-year tradition as a scientific powerhouse. Senior scientists see it as both inevitable and desirable that the nation's brightest new hopes should go to Germany, or Japan, or the US - for a while.

But British university science is still reeling from more than a decade of underfunding, during which laboratory equipment grew out of date, buildings began to deteriorate and science students began to vote with their feet.

The Royal Society - the "club" of the most powerful brains in British and Commonwealth science - recently pointed out that the proportion of its membership working in the US had doubled in the past 30 years, to more than 12%. All the biggest investments in science are now on the other side of the Atlantic, and the US national institutes of health (NIH) is putting more and more into developments in biomedicine.

The problem is ever more urgent because of the unravelling last month of the entire DNA code - an achievement that opens new and once unimaginable opportunities for researchers, and for industry.

John Gurdon, head of the Wellcome Cancer Research Campaign Institute in Cambridge, said: "Every time I go to the US there seems to be another $50m building going up, and I say 'What are you going to do with it?' And they say: biomedical sciences. I say, 'How are you going to run it?' And they say: NIH money.

"And I say: 'Where are you going to get all these scientists?' They say Europe. There is no hesitation. They say: 'We can't get any here, we just go to Europe and pick them up there.' No problem, they say, because of the salary scales."

He thinks things could get worse. The real problem, as he sees it, is that many young people see a science research career as barely worth having: they can make more money in the City, or they can go to the US.

Colin Blakemore, the Oxford neuroscientist, was delighted with what he saw as a signal of enthusiasm for science from the government. But it would take more to put Britain back into the forefront.

"It will look very good on paper, on an annual basis ... But one has to realise it is making up for probably a decade of chronic underfunding."

He, too, was worried about the flow of talent aboard. Lady Thatcher, when challenged about the brain drain, always argued that as many scientists came to Britain from the US and Canada as emigrated.

"The problem is, most of the people who leave, leave for good," Prof Blakemore said. "Most of the people who come, come for a year or two. I have absolutely no doubt that the areas I know about are suffering from a loss of people at the top end, and even more important, from a failure to recruit very high quality graduates at the other end. It will take a long time to rebuild confidence to attract young people."

Lure of US hard to resist
Sir Harold Kroto went abroad as a young scientist, but came back, and shared a Nobel prize in 1996 for the discovery of carbon molecules.

First he went to the National Research Council in Canada, and then to the Bell telephone laboratories in the US.

"I was offered a position at the University of Sussex and found that it was worthwhile, because I wanted to come back. But that climate has gone," said Prof Kroto yesterday. "It is important to enable students to go, but to also give them the freedom to come back to a position which is as promising as the ones they might be offered in the US."

Keith Devlin is a Yorkshireman who is dean of science at St Mary's College in California, and a mathematician at Stanford University. He was gloomy about prospects for change. British universities had only a shadow of their former glory, he believed. "Most expat Brits would come back in a flash if the career opportunities were there, myself included.

"To match US conditions, it would require salaries of £85,000 and up, a good research/travel budget, good pension, and support toward purchase of a house. In other words, a typical executive package in industry."

Tim Radford

But they were not convinced it would keep the best brains in Britain's laboratories. The money will be used to increase incomes for young researchers, upgrade equipment and restore crumbling buildings. But it would need more to put British science back in the major league, scientists said. The trouble, said Chris Llewellyn Smith, provost of University College, London, and until recently head of Europe's biggest laboratory, at Cern, in Geneva, was that a shot in the arm merely helped a patient to recover. "What we need is an increase in recurrent funding which will allow us not to get into a backlog in the future, and allow us to pay and employ the best people. "I have had senior staff leaving for the US, and we have also been recruiting from the US. At the top level we have managed to stem the brain drain and even buy back, but at the bottom end it is increasingly hard to attract really good people." Science is international: good young scientists are encouraged to work abroad, to be stimulated by new ideas, and to set up research partnerships with teams in other countries. English is the language of science, and Britain has a 350-year tradition as a scientific powerhouse. Senior scientists see it as both inevitable and desirable that the nation's brightest new hopes should go to Germany, or Japan, or the US - for a while. But British university science is still reeling from more than a decade of underfunding, during which laboratory equipment grew out of date, buildings began to deteriorate and science students began to vote with their feet. The Royal Society - the "club" of the most powerful brains in British and Commonwealth science - recently pointed out that the proportion of its membership working in the US had doubled in the past 30 years, to more than 12%. All the biggest investments in science are now on the other side of the Atlantic, and the US national institutes of health (NIH) is putting more and more into developments in biomedicine. The problem is ever more urgent because of the unravelling last month of the entire DNA code - an achievement that opens new and once unimaginable opportunities for researchers, and for industry. John Gurdon, head of the Wellcome Cancer Research Campaign Institute in Cambridge, said: "Every time I go to the US there seems to be another $50m building going up, and I say 'What are you going to do with it?' And they say: biomedical sciences. I say, 'How are you going to run it?' And they say: NIH money. "And I say: 'Where are you going to get all these scientists?' They say Europe. There is no hesitation. They say: 'We can't get any here, we just go to Europe and pick them up there.' No problem, they say, because of the salary scales." He thinks things could get worse. The real problem, as he sees it, is that many young people see a science research career as barely worth having: they can make more money in the City, or they can go to the US. Colin Blakemore, the Oxford neuroscientist, was delighted with what he saw as a signal of enthusiasm for science from the government. But it would take more to put Britain back into the forefront. "It will look very good on paper, on an annual basis ... But one has to realise it is making up for probably a decade of chronic underfunding." He, too, was worried about the flow of talent aboard. Lady Thatcher, when challenged about the brain drain, always argued that as many scientists came to Britain from the US and Canada as emigrated. "The problem is, most of the people who leave, leave for good," Prof Blakemore said. "Most of the people who come, come for a year or two. I have absolutely no doubt that the areas I know about are suffering from a loss of people at the top end, and even more important, from a failure to recruit very high quality graduates at the other end. It will take a long time to rebuild confidence to attract young people." Lure of US hard to resist Sir Harold Kroto went abroad as a young scientist, but came back, and shared a Nobel prize in 1996 for the discovery of carbon molecules. First he went to the National Research Council in Canada, and then to the Bell telephone laboratories in the US. "I was offered a position at the University of Sussex and found that it was worthwhile, because I wanted to come back. But that climate has gone," said Prof Kroto yesterday. "It is important to enable students to go, but to also give them the freedom to come back to a position which is as promising as the ones they might be offered in the US." Keith Devlin is a Yorkshireman who is dean of science at St Mary's College in California, and a mathematician at Stanford University. He was gloomy about prospects for change. British universities had only a shadow of their former glory, he believed. "Most expat Brits would come back in a flash if the career opportunities were there, myself included. "To match US conditions, it would require salaries of £85,000 and up, a good research/travel budget, good pension, and support toward purchase of a house. In other words, a typical executive package in industry." Tim Radford

webTitle: Drug gangs turn to migrant trade

fields.headline: Drug gangs turn to migrant trade
fields.trailText: Organised crime gangs are turning away from drug trafficking to smuggling migrants because it is relatively risk-free and hugely lucrative, a police conference was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Organised crime gangs are turning away from drug trafficking to smuggling migrants because it is relatively risk-free and hugely lucrative, a police conference was told yesterday.

John Abbott, director of the National Criminal Intelligence Service, said the number of illegal entrants brought into Britain had risen from 61 in 1991 to 16,000 last year. Many had paid criminals thousands of pounds.

Mr Abbott told the Association of Chief Police Officers that new penalties - including fining lorry drivers £2,000 for each migrant found in their vehicle - would not stem the flow in the short term, and called for the trade "to be tackled on several fronts" to produce an effective international solution.

The speech, to Acpo's annual conference in Torquay, came a month after the deaths of 58 Chinese nationals, whose bodies were found in a lorry container during a routine inspection by customs officers in Dover. The 54 men and four women were illegal entrants from the Fujian province of China.

Mr Abbott said NCIS had identified dozens of gangs that concentrated solely on "people trafficking".

He cited a United Nations report which estimated that some one million migrants were transported in illegal operations worth up to $20bn last year. "Our analysis suggests increased involvement in this type of activity because it is low risk."

The British gangs involved, Mr Abbott said, had links with criminals abroad, which made cross-border cooperation between investigators imperative.

The conference heard that some migrants were duped into thinking they were paying for legitimate passage.

Many end up as hostages or being forced into prostitution to pay the smuggling fees.

Roy Penrose, director general of the National Crime Squad, said five or six investigations into "this miserable trade" were in progress. "Drugs cannot hide, people can," he said.

fields.headline: Inventors hail Euro-patent
fields.trailText: British hi-tech companies keen to do business in Europe but unable to afford the cost of patenting their inventions will soon be able to apply for a cheap "super patent" valid in all 15 EU countries.
fields.body:
British hi-tech companies keen to do business in Europe but unable to afford the cost of patenting their inventions will soon be able to apply for a cheap "super patent" valid in all 15 EU countries.

In a decision which will cut the cost of protecting intellectual property, plans to create a so-called "community patent" won the backing of the European commission yesterday - after 30 years of discussion.

The new patent - which should be in operation by the end of next year - will eliminate the need to apply for patents in individual member states. At present European patents can be obtained from the European patent office in Munich. But they have no Europe-wide force until translated into every community language and are at the mercy of national courts in the event of a dispute.

That has led to small firms facing big bills for a patent to be translated into all 11 official community languages.

In future, however, when a patent has been approved by the European patent office in any one language it will immediately take effect in all 15 member states.

A special tribunal to deal with all European patent disputes will also be set up in an effort to give companies greater legal certainty.

These developments are particularly important because the prohibitive costs of patenting across Europe are often cited as one of the reasons why Europe is trailing the US and Japan in the development of hi-tech business.

The average cost of obtaining a European patent - which can often take four years - is about £35,000, compared with £7,000 for a US patent and £11,000 for a Japanese one.

Britain's patent office, aware that its own role may be under threat, gave a guarded welcome to the EC's plans but said that it would need time to study the proposals. "The devil is in the detail and it's too early to comment," an official said.

The proposals must be approved by EU trade ministers before the community patent can become a reality.

webTitle: US regulators close to clearing £118bn drugs deal

fields.headline: US regulators close to clearing £118bn drugs deal
fields.standfirst: Chairman will take £500,000 pay cut when Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham tie the knot
fields.trailText: Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham are close to an agreement with the US competition authorities, and expect to complete their £118bn merger on August 21.
fields.body:
Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham are close to an agreement with the US competition authorities, and expect to complete their £118bn merger on August 21.

The two groups yesterday sent out documents giving further details of the merger to shareholders, a move which suggested that they were confident of escaping any serious sanctions from the federal trade commission.

The documents revealed that Glaxo's boss Sir Richard Sykes will be paid £300,000 a year as non-executive chairman of the combined company. This is a substantial pay cut - his current salary is more than £1m. However, Sir Richard has accepted a "day job" next year as rector of Imperial College, London, which will pay him about £200,000.

Sir Richard and SKB's Jean-Pierre Garnier hailed the deal as a potential winner for both investors and patients. They said it would increase the efficiency of drug development by "playing a leading role in harnessing the rapid advanced taking place in science and technology to produce new and improved medicines".

The two admitted they expected to have to sell herpes drug Famvir and nausea product Kytril in the US, adding that it was possible that a few "minor" additional drugs would need to be sold.

There had been speculation that Glaxo could be ordered to divest a potential treatment for diabetes, which will compete with SmithKline's recently launched Avandia, but this now looks unlikely.

Coincidentally, Glaxo yesterday revealed that the latest phase three trials of its product have been extended for two years until 2003.

The documents also revealed that the two groups are setting aside £325m for an incentive programme to encourage employees to make a long-term commitment to the new company.

The money will fund a bonus for staff who roll over their share options into the new company, rather than cashing them in immediately. The bonus is only payable if employees stay with the group for a minimum of two years.

Glaxo's shares fell 28p to £19.58. SmithKline's dropped 13.5p to 884.5p.

Glaxo SmithKline will be the world's biggest drugs company, with a market share of 7.5%. Shareholders' meetings to approve the deal are to be held on July 31, and a court hearing to sanction the merger is scheduled for August 17.

webTitle: At Dixons, it's something old, something new

fields.headline: At Dixons, it's something old, something new
fields.standfirst: Markets dither over retailer
fields.trailText: The stock market appears to have a problem making up its mind about Dixons. To say the shares have been on a roller-coaster ride over the past 12 months or so is to understate the case.
fields.body:
The stock market appears to have a problem making up its mind about Dixons. To say the shares have been on a roller-coaster ride over the past 12 months or so is to understate the case. At the turn of the year the shares lost, and then regained, more than £1 within the space of little more than a month. At the beginning of March they stood at 397p, six weeks later they had hit 244p.

But why such volatility? One explanation is that Dixons is simultaneously a "new" and "old" economy company and the market has mixed emotions about both bits.

It is heavily exposed to "new" economy sentiment through internet service provider, Freeserve - where Dixons owns 80% of the shares - which has endured the violent mood swings towards that sector. To that generality can be added a specific. Dixons is looking to reduce its shareholding in Freeserve but, post the collapse of talks with T-Online, the market is not sure just how that is to be achieved.

As for the "old" economy, Dixons is one of the most familiar names on Britain's high streets - even if a fair proportion of what it sells might be part of the "new" economy. Life in the retail sector is anything but an easy ride, as the latest survey evidence from the Confederation of British Industry makes clear. Shoppers generally are in careful mood and in Dixons' case, competition from the likes of Comet and Carphone Warehouse is fierce and margins are under pressure.

For all that, investors should not feel too uncomfortable. Dixons has not allowed itself to be carried away with "new" economy hype. It does have a growing online presence - albeit an as-yet modest one in the overall scheme of things and is continuing to invest. But it reckons, sensibly, that its physical presence will be a big help in building a strong brand on the internet. In the meantime, as the biggest player in electrical retailing, it is as well placed as any to tough its way out of the problems of margin erosion and price pressure.

European expansion is well up the corporate agenda, which should provide scope for further expansion in the longer term.

Nor, as the "what are they going to do about Freeserve" debate rages on, should it be forgotten that Dixons makes healthy profits. These days, that is not something to be sniffed at.

High stakes

Any hopes the boards of Dresdner and Commerzbank might have cherished of being allowed to carry on talks about a possible merger in an atmosphere of dispassionate calm have long since been dashed. These days they must think a goldfish bowl would provide more privacy than their present environment.

The frustration is beginning to show. Yesterday, in a letter of reassurance to staff, Commerzbank said the pros and cons of a deal were in danger of being obscured by a fog of speculation.

The stakes are considerable for the banks, for Frankfurt's status as a financial centre and for those with an interest in the way in which Europe's banking industry will consolidate.

Dresdner's credibility has already been damaged by the failure of the planned merger with Deutsche. If it comes out of the talks with Commerzbank empty-handed its position will be further weakened. It will be "in play" with a vengeance and top staff unsettled by months of instability will scarcely be able to move for headhunters.

Commerzbank is scarcely better placed. Despite the bank's efforts to draw a distinction between talks and negotiations, the board has effectively said the bank's much prized independence is in fact negotiable. There must be those within the board who are wondering whether this was a wise move and who think the bank would have been better to pursue a looser, more limited alliance with one or more of its friends elsewhere in Europe. As the talks with Dresdner become ever more detailed and, by implication, more difficult, those who are privately considering such arguments may start to muse aloud - if they are not already doing so.

Funny old game

Structural dynamism, strong job creation and growth. What more could any finance minister want? Well, the occasional football triumph would not come amiss. Take France, where consumer confidence hit a record level following the 1998 World Cup victory. Now economists expect it to scale new peaks as the Euro 2000 euphoria kicks in. Just as well, then, that Kevin Keegan's boys took early leave of the Low Countries.

Otherwise the Bank of England's monetary policy committee might have jacked up interest rates - just to be on the safe side.

Funny old game, economics.

webTitle: BBC talent search waste of time, says Wogan

fields.headline: BBC talent search waste of time, says Wogan
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Terry Wogan, the veteran Radio 2 presenter, has criticised the BBC's nationwide talent search as a waste of time and money.
fields.body:
Terry Wogan, the veteran Radio 2 presenter, has criticised the BBC's nationwide talent search as a waste of time and money.

The £5m initiative, launched earlier this year, was "window dressing", he claimed. The BBC did not have to trawl the country for talent, because so many people approached the BBC for work.

Instead of finding television stars, the corporation should be nurturing behind-the-scenes talent, Mr Wogan told an audience at the Radio Academy's annual festival in Glasgow on Tuesday night. "You shouldn't be just looking for presenters, you should be looking for creative people, writers, and ideas people," he said.

The BBC replied yesterday, saying the presenter was mistaken. It pointed out that the initiative, led by Matthew Bannister, the director of marketing, and Alan Yentob, the director of television, was designed to harness a wide range of talent.

More than 9,000 people had been auditioned for eight TV presenters' contracts; 5,200 comedy scripts and 1,300 music compositions had been submitted; 750 people had taken part in an "ideas lab"; and 16,000 people had auditioned for Radio 1 traineeships.

"It would be wrong to say that we are just looking for TV presenters. We are looking for all sorts of people: writers, people with ideas, composers. Unfortunately, Terry appears to have been ill-informed about BBC Talent," a spokeswoman said.

In the past, the corporation has been criticised for failing to nurture talent.

High profile defections, such as those of Des Lynam and Frank Skinner to ITV, increased the frustration at the corporation.

Earlier this year, Mr Wogan publicly criticised the BBC for having mishandling his television career - although he is enjoying renewed success as the presenter of Radio 2's breakfast show.

Jim Moir, the controller of Radio 2, praised the presenter at the conference yesterday for his show's "mix of humour, listener interaction and music of the last five decades". He attacked the BBC's commercial radio rivals, who have argued for the privatisation of radios 1 and 2, saying the BBC should not spend the licence fee on services where competitors were doing similar things.

The universal licence fee placed upon the BBC an obligation to provide popular services for all the community, Mr Moir said, rather than be restricted to the "earnest, high-minded and worthy" parts of the market not served by the commercial sector.

Earlier at the conference, the Radio Authority outlined its submission to the government's communications legislation review, calling for a single radio regulatory system to cover the BBC and the commercial sector.

"It would be wrong to say that we are just looking for TV presenters. We are looking for all sorts of people: writers, people with ideas, composers. Unfortunately, Terry appears to have been ill-informed about BBC Talent," a spokeswoman said. In the past, the corporation has been criticised for failing to nurture talent. High profile defections, such as those of Des Lynam and Frank Skinner to ITV, increased the frustration at the corporation. Earlier this year, Mr Wogan publicly criticised the BBC for having mishandling his television career - although he is enjoying renewed success as the presenter of Radio 2's breakfast show. Jim Moir, the controller of Radio 2, praised the presenter at the conference yesterday for his show's "mix of humour, listener interaction and music of the last five decades". He attacked the BBC's commercial radio rivals, who have argued for the privatisation of radios 1 and 2, saying the BBC should not spend the licence fee on services where competitors were doing similar things. The universal licence fee placed upon the BBC an obligation to provide popular services for all the community, Mr Moir said, rather than be restricted to the "earnest, high-minded and worthy" parts of the market not served by the commercial sector. Earlier at the conference, the Radio Authority outlined its submission to the government's communications legislation review, calling for a single radio regulatory system to cover the BBC and the commercial sector.

webTitle: Some of our art is missing, minister admits

fields.headline: Some of our art is missing, minister admits
fields.trailText: They are some of the nation's most cherished possessions and they have disappeared - presumed stolen or missing - forever.
fields.body:
They are some of the nation's most cherished possessions and they have disappeared - presumed stolen or missing - forever.

The government yesterday took the humiliating step of releasing the full list of every work or art and artefact which has been removed from Britain's national collection in the last decade.

Alan Howarth, the arts minister, said that nine museums which house the priceless collection have admitted losing nearly 150 items that range from expensive paintings to trivial items. Some have been stolen, some are missing while others are simply "unaccounted for".

Top of the list of offenders is the National Maritime Museum in Greenwich which admits that it has lost 15 paintings. The museum failed for months to notice that the paintings, which are 17th, 18th and 19th century seascapes worth £90,000, had disappeared from its store room. The alarm was raised last year by a dealer in Amsterdam whobecame suspicious when he bought an early 17th century Dutch oil painting which he traced back to Greenwich after discovering that it had been sold under a false name.

His action prompted the museum's first audit in 14 years which uncovered errors in compiling the inventory.

Archaeologists will be pained by the loss of 15 Roman coins, a gold pectoral disc and a Japanese porcelain figure from the British Museum. Curators at the Victoria and Albert Museum are said to be dismayed by the missing items from its premises in South Kensington.

The scale of the losses shocked the Labour MP Gordon Prentice who asked the department of culture, media and sport to release full details of the missing artefacts. He said that he would be calling on the culture secretary Chris Smith to tighten procedures.

"These are huge breaches of security from our national col lection," Mr Prentice said. "It's a disgrace that these hugely significant items literally walk through the doors of these museums."

A spokeswoman for the V&A said that the museum was concerned about the losses. "This does not just happen - we are extremely worried about the loss of any items from the national collection," the spokeswoman said.

The culture department pointed out the missing items were from a collection numbering more than 4m.

webTitle: Last points of order as time called on late night sittings

fields.headline: Last points of order as time called on late night sittings
fields.standfirst:
Labour MPs back 'family friendly' modernisation move but Tories fear undermining of opposition in big Commons culture change

Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Late night sittings of the House of Commons, which fequently force MPs to remain at Westminster until the early hours, are to be consigned to the past as part of the most radical shake-up of parliament in more than 20 years to be unveiled today.
fields.body:
Late night sittings of the House of Commons, which fequently force MPs to remain at Westminster until the early hours, are to be consigned to the past as part of the most radical shake-up of parliament in more than 20 years to be unveiled today.

In a move which will delight modernisers, but dismay traditionalists who like to drink through the night in Westminster's numerous bars, the business of the Commons is to be brought to an end by 10pm throughout the week.

Labour backbenchers, who have been pressing for more "family friendly" hours, will warmly welcome the reform which is to be announced today by Margaret Beckett, the leader of the Commons.

But Conservative MPs will criticise the end of late night sittings, saying that it will weaken the ability of the Opposition to hold the government to account.

Mrs Beckett, who chairs the Commons modernisation committee which yesterday approved the reforms, will insist that the government is planning to give opposition parties a far greater role in the running of the house.

In a gesture to the Tories and the Liberal Democrats, Mrs Beckett will announce the unprecedented setting up of a cross-party committee to agree on how the government arranges its business in the Commons. The committee, which was the brainchild of the Liberal Democrat chief whip Paul Tyler, will meet after the annual Queen's speech in November to try to reach agreement on the order of parliamentary bills in the following session.

The government will also agree to give opposition MPs a say in how bills are debated. The government will allocate an overall time for a bill, but it will be up to MPs to decide how much time to devote to specific areas. But the greatest attention today will focus on the demise of late night sittings, which will usher in the greatest cultural change in Westminster in more than a century.

Under the government's plans, strict timetabling of government business will mean that debates on bills will end at 10pm from Mondays to Wednesdays, allowing MPs to escape from Westminster after voting at around 10.30pm. MPs are already free to leave early once a week after the Commons starts to sit on Thursday morning under an earlier government initiative. One government source said that reform of the Commons hours was long overdue. "Most people have come to the conclusion that you cannot allow legislation to be taken through the house at 3am," the source said. "This is the biggest shake-up at Westminster since the introduction of select committees in 1979."

The source said that ministers regarded the setting up of the cross-party "Queen's speech committee" as an example of the government's attempts to co-operate with other parties, most notably the Lib Dems. "The government is particularly keen to be inclusive because that will eventually lead to better legislation," the source said.

However, today's report will be denounced by the Tories who will dismiss it as a cynical attempt by the government to tighten its grip over the commons. Forcing the Commons to sit through the night is an old tactic deployed by opposition parties down the ages - including Labour in the 1980s - to upset the government's carefully choreographed timetabling of Commons business.

Some Tory MPs on the committee rejected the report. However, their attempt to publish an official "minority report" today failed, forcing them to publish their own report.

The announcement today will be the most radical Commons reform introduced by the government, which has been criticised by some of Labour's new backbenchers for refusing to embrace change. The government has also introduced new debates in Westminster Hall, which have to be attended by the relevant minister, to give backbenchers greater scope to debate issues that are dear to their hearts.

Show me the way to go home: MPs who talked until dawn

Old timers from both sides of the house will mourn the passing of late night sittings which allow for raucous evenings in the Commons' many bars.

 One of the most recent all night sittings forced the cancellation of the weekly session of prime minister's questions on Tony Blair's 1,000th day in office.

 Rightwing Tory MPs joined forces with Unionist hardliners last January to filibuster the disqualifications bill which would allow Irish MPs to stand for the Westminster parliament. Eric Forth, the Tory maverick, kept MPs awake all night after teaming up with the Unionist hardliner Willie Thompson to filibuster the bill clause by clause.

 One recently elected Labour MP, who expressed outrage at the behaviour of the Tories and Unionists, was met with a withering response from the veteran Dennis Skinner. "We did that throughout the 80s to keep the Tories on their toes," Mr Skinner said.

 In one of the most famous all night sittings under the Tories - during the 1981 bill to privatise British Telecom - Tony Benn popped out of the chamber to announce that he would challenge Denis Healey for the deputy leadership of the Labour party. The leftwinger did not want to wait until the next day for fear that he would be dissuaded.

webTitle: Fayed renews legal fight for British passport

fields.headline: Fayed renews legal fight for British passport
fields.trailText: Harrods owner Mohamed Al Fayed demonstrated yesterday that he has no intention of giving up his fight for a British passport when he opened a new round in his six-year battle in the courts to get citizenship.
fields.body:
Harrods owner Mohamed Al Fayed demonstrated yesterday that he has no intention of giving up his fight for a British passport when he opened a new round in his six-year battle in the courts to get citizenship.

His counsel, Michael Beloff QC, told the court of appeal that it should allow a judicial review of the home secretary's decision on May 6 last year to refuse the Egyptian-born businessman to go ahead because Jack Straw's decision had been biased and should be quashed.

The home secretary refused to give Mr Fayed a British passport on the grounds that his payment of cash and benefits to MPs to ask questions and his role in the break-in to a bank safe deposit box belonging to his business rival, "Tiny" Rowland, meant he could not pass the necessary "good character" test to qualify for citizenship.

But Mr Beloff repeated claims yesterday that an unsourced Sunday Express article on September 6 1998, which claimed Mr Straw had "told friends" that he could not see how Mr Fayed could have citizenship if he did pay MPs, meant that he had not approached the decision with "an open mind".

He should have delegated the decision to another home office minister. Mr Straw has said he has no recollection of making such a remark.

Mr Beloff argued that his role in the safe deposit box incident and the "cash for questions" affair should not have outweighed other factors such as Mr Fayed's employment of 3,000 people in Britain, that he paid his taxes in full, and faced "compassionate circumstances" at the time - the decision came not long after his son, Dodi, died in the car crash with Diana, Princess of Wales.

He said the safe deposit box incident was "one regrettable lapse" and Mr Fayed had not broken into the box himself or asked others to do so but had failed to stop the "actions of others". As to the payment of cash and benefits to MPs, he said there was a "risk of applying the standards of the 1990s to the events of the 1980s".

They were more a reflection on the bad character of the MPs who had accepted them rather than on Mr Fayed, who did not believe them to be unlawful.

But Jonathan Crow, for the home secretary, said the appeal court application was nothing more than an attempt to appeal against the merits of a decision Mr Fayed did not like.

The fact that he was a well-known individual and there had been considerable media interest did not affect Mr Straw's decision.

The decision by the high court judge in October 1999, who ruled that Mr Straw had taken the right decision for the right reasons, should not be disturbed, Mr Crow said.

Judgment was reserved.

webTitle: Prison officers beat up inmate, court told

fields.headline: Prison officers beat up inmate, court told
fields.trailText: A prisoner lay bleeding and gasping for air as he was held down and punched repeatedly by prison officers at Wormwood Scrubs after an apparently trivial dispute over a rug, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A prisoner lay bleeding and gasping for air as he was held down and punched repeatedly by prison officers at Wormwood Scrubs after an apparently trivial dispute over a rug, a court heard yesterday.

Timothy Donovan, 33, who is serving a life sentence at the west London prison, was punched in the face, grabbed by the neck and forced to the floor by one prison officer before others entered his cell and joined in beating him, Blackfriars crown court heard.

The four prison officers, who cannot be named for legal reasons, all deny assaulting Donovan causing actual bodily harm on July 1 1998.

Donovan, who was left with bruising to the ribs and a bloody nose, described how he tried to reach for his asthma inhaler because he was struggling to breathe, but was forced back on to the floor and held down.

The prisoner had been housed in E wing since shortly after he was convicted of murder at Liverpool crown court in November 1996.

Donovan yesterday told the court that prior to the alleged assault, he had been involved a dispute with defendant D over a rug removed from his cell during a search. He had been told by defendant D he could not keep the rug, a gift from his mother, because it was too big and contravened prison rules.

Donovan had argued with defendant D before throwing the rug over a balcony in anger and returning to his cell, the court heard.

Defendant D later returned the rug to his cell.

Donovan said: "He was more aggressive. He just said 'About the carpet', then dropped it and punched me on the nose with considerable force.

"My nose was bleeding. He grabbed my head and pushed me down towards the floor."

Donovan said he was forced to the floor and then became aware of other officers coming in to his cell.

"I felt other punches to my ribs. I could feel them on my right hand side. They were hurting me."

Earlier, the court heard that witnesses had seen an officer punch Donovan and another kick him.

The prisoner told the officers he could not breathe and reached for his inhaler, but his arm was pushed down.

He told the court he heard the voice of defendant A, a senior prison officer, say: "Listen scumbag, I am the new officer on E wing and things are going to change."

He was also told he would be disciplined for assaulting one of the staff, would get years added to his tariff, and would never get out of prison.

Donovan was later treated by the prison doctor following the alleged assault, the jury heard.

Earlier, Mark Heyward, prosecuting, told the court Donovan had not been aware of anyone else being around when defendant D entered his cell, but it appeared that the other prison officers were on the landing.

Mr Heyward said: "The purpose of the exercise that followed was to teach Donovan a lesson."

He told the court: "There together they joined in a physical assault on an inmate which involved punches and perhaps kicks. They are each responsible for the assault and together responsible for the assault."

Donovan was later charged with assaulting defendant D and found guilty by the prison governor, who sentenced him to 14 days solitary confinement and reduced his privileges to a minimum.

The trial, which is expected to last three weeks, continues today.

fields.headline: It's grand up north
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: I went palace-hunting this week, which is basically much like house-hunting, except that the quarry is bigger. Not for myself, you understand, but for the Queen, whom Mo Mowlam says ought to vacate Buckingham Palace in favour of something more modern.
fields.body:
I went palace-hunting this week, which is basically much like house-hunting, except that the quarry is bigger. Not for myself, you understand, but for the Queen, whom Mo Mowlam says ought to vacate Buckingham Palace in favour of something more modern. Some people, including her "ardent monarchist" boss, seem to think Mo was cruel, or worse still, republican, in wanting the Queen relocated. Yet Mo is a kindly soul, not the sort to favour eviction. Could it be that her real aim was not to offend the Queen, but to liberate her?

She is, after all, in her mid-70s, and nearly 50 years into her reign. A large and famously boring building in London SW1 may not seem the most appropriate address at this stage in one's life. Look at it this way: where would she like to live? Happily, we know the answer. Long ago, in an uncharacteristically unguarded moment, she confided that the place where she'd most like to live is the Forest of Bowland in Lancashire.

Accordingly, I went to the forest, some 400 square miles of moorland, fell, majestic river and bubbling stream east of Lancaster and north of the Preston-Blackburn-Burnley industrial belt. As monarch she is also Duke of Lancaster, so this is part of her Duchy to which she pays regular visits. One can certainly see the attraction. There is mile upon mile of enchantment. Try the drive east from Slaidburn to Lancaster along the Trough of Bowland - the valley which cleaves through the forest from east to west. The Yorkshire Dales, the Lake District (minus the lakes), the highlands of Scotland, wild Wales - there are echoes of all of them here, and it's wonderfully unravaged by time. I met only one tourist coach on Tuesday, though weekends are no doubt busier.

There are not, it must be said, many properties which would serve unchanged as palaces. Stately homes are few. The Parker family have been at Browsholme Hall in the south-east for 500 years and may not yet be ready to quit. The Duke of Westminster has a place at Abbeystead on the wandering road to Lancaster but he too is no doubt keen to hang on to it. The Queen, they say, is a kindly soul and so not the sort to favour evictions.

There are huge, remote, empty spaces here into which you could smuggle a marvellous 21st-century palace. Yet one would not wish to encourage promiscuous building in such a beautiful place. Better a brownfield site where an existing building could be adapted or an earlier one replaced. And happily, just such a spot exists to the east of the forest, in a sector which used to be Yorkshire but was cruelly wrenched into Lancashire in the 70s. In the delicious village of Bolton-by-Bowland, just south of the church, is a gate with a long and dignified avenue stretching into the distance. Follow the track and you come to a huddle of buildings which clearly used to belong to something statelier. This is the site of Bolton Hall, now demolished, but once the home of the Pudsay family. A monument in the church celebrates Sir Ralph Pudsay, his three wives and 25 children sleeping beside him: "the faithful adherent" says a plaque "of King Henry VI whom he sheltered at Bolton Hall after the battle of Hexham."

Here is the ideal site for a fine post-Mowlam palace. There is ample room to exercise corgis. For Prince Philip, there are regular trotting races just up the road at Hellifield. For Prince Charles, should he visit, there are villages like Chipping and Ribcheter to put him in mind of the Cotswolds. Communications are imperfect. But visiting heads of state could travel by rail to Hellifield on the breathtaking line between Leeds and Carlisle, and then on by state coach through delightful lanes (which might need a bit of widening) down to Bolton. For more mundane occasions, a station could be added to the rarely used line between Hellifield and Clitheroe, linking with the Virgin train service at Preston.

There would still be times when the Queen had to travel to London, for instance to open parliament. But if parliament were moved to Hawes in Richmondshire, as Matthew Engel recommended on Tuesday, the Queen would be able to swap the trip down the boring old Mall for a glorious ride through Yorkshire: either by sensible roads through Skipton, Harrogate and Ripon, or by the beautiful lanes which ramble up through Kettlewell and on up to Middleham - great racehorse country, by the way, which she would be bound to enjoy. Were I monarch, I would use all the powers the state had left me to bring about such an amendment of life; especially now that the ardent monarchist, as we discovered this week, had frozen my state-funded income for the whole of the new decade.

The Yorkshire Dales, the Lake District (minus the lakes), the highlands of Scotland, wild Wales - there are echoes of all of them here, and it's wonderfully unravaged by time. I met only one tourist coach on Tuesday, though weekends are no doubt busier. There are not, it must be said, many properties which would serve unchanged as palaces. Stately homes are few. The Parker family have been at Browsholme Hall in the south-east for 500 years and may not yet be ready to quit. The Duke of Westminster has a place at Abbeystead on the wandering road to Lancaster but he too is no doubt keen to hang on to it. The Queen, they say, is a kindly soul and so not the sort to favour evictions. There are huge, remote, empty spaces here into which you could smuggle a marvellous 21st-century palace. Yet one would not wish to encourage promiscuous building in such a beautiful place. Better a brownfield site where an existing building could be adapted or an earlier one replaced. And happily, just such a spot exists to the east of the forest, in a sector which used to be Yorkshire but was cruelly wrenched into Lancashire in the 70s. In the delicious village of Bolton-by-Bowland, just south of the church, is a gate with a long and dignified avenue stretching into the distance. Follow the track and you come to a huddle of buildings which clearly used to belong to something statelier. This is the site of Bolton Hall, now demolished, but once the home of the Pudsay family. A monument in the church celebrates Sir Ralph Pudsay, his three wives and 25 children sleeping beside him: "the faithful adherent" says a plaque "of King Henry VI whom he sheltered at Bolton Hall after the battle of Hexham." Here is the ideal site for a fine post-Mowlam palace. There is ample room to exercise corgis. For Prince Philip, there are regular trotting races just up the road at Hellifield. For Prince Charles, should he visit, there are villages like Chipping and Ribcheter to put him in mind of the Cotswolds. Communications are imperfect. But visiting heads of state could travel by rail to Hellifield on the breathtaking line between Leeds and Carlisle, and then on by state coach through delightful lanes (which might need a bit of widening) down to Bolton. For more mundane occasions, a station could be added to the rarely used line between Hellifield and Clitheroe, linking with the Virgin train service at Preston. There would still be times when the Queen had to travel to London, for instance to open parliament. But if parliament were moved to Hawes in Richmondshire, as Matthew Engel recommended on Tuesday, the Queen would be able to swap the trip down the boring old Mall for a glorious ride through Yorkshire: either by sensible roads through Skipton, Harrogate and Ripon, or by the beautiful lanes which ramble up through Kettlewell and on up to Middleham - great racehorse country, by the way, which she would be bound to enjoy. Were I monarch, I would use all the powers the state had left me to bring about such an amendment of life; especially now that the ardent monarchist, as we discovered this week, had frozen my state-funded income for the whole of the new decade. david.mckie@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Barrier-breaking ballet
fields.standfirst: Homage to Freddie Mercury
fields.trailText: Any remaining barriers between pop and high art will collapse in a cloud of gold lamé, in a ballet by the Béjart Ballet celebrating the life of singer Freddie Mercury, set to music by Queen and Mozart, in costumes designed by the late Gianni Versace.
fields.body:
Any remaining barriers between pop and high art will collapse in a cloud of gold lamé, in a ballet by the Béjart Ballet celebrating the life of singer Freddie Mercury, set to music by Queen and Mozart, in costumes designed by the late Gianni Versace.

The British premiere of the ballet in September at Sadler's Wells in Islington, north London, coincides with yet another revival of Queen, the disbanded but stubbornly undead supergroup, whose glory days came to an end in 1991 with the death of Mercury, but who are about to release a new single version of We Will Rock You with boy band 5ive.

Legendary choreographer Maurice Béjart, who has led his own companies since 1959, created Ballet for Life in memory of Freddie Mercury, and a principal dancer from his own company, Jorge Donn. Both men died of Aids, both aged 45.

Within months of its premiere in 1997 the ballet became even more emotionally charged, when designer Gianni Versace was gunned down, aged 50, outside his Miami home.

The ballet was described yesterday by Roger Taylor, Queen's drummer, as "a wonderful thing, visually stunning, very moving for anyone who knew Freddie Mercury". He added: "We don't need to be reminded, we never forget him - he was part of our lives, part of the wallpaper. "

Taylor was speaking from the BBC's Top of the Pops studio, where the remaining members of Queen were rehearsing with 5ive . Their joint recording of We Will Rock You will be released next week, and is tipped to go straight into the charts. The bands are also performing live at the Party in the Park in London on Sunday.

"They're great," Taylor said of his co-stars. "The last thing we ever dreamed of was recording with a boy band, but they've got a lot more edge. I think they just think we're amazingly old."

He and the rest of Queen were scratching their ancient heads to work out when they last appeared on Top of the Pops. "None of us can remember. I think it was back in the days of wax cylinders and we were all wearing doublet and hose."

Queen reformed for their first live performance of the 1990s for the Paris world premiere of Ballet for Life, when they performed on stage at the first night with Elton John, leading to a worldwide wave of speculation that the band was about to start recording and touring again.

"We're still alive, me and Brian May speak all the time, we never say never," Taylor said.

fields.headline: Underground shortlists partners
fields.trailText: The partial privatisation of the London Underground took a step forward yesterday, when the city's transport authority shortlisted four bidders vying to run six lines of the cash-starved Tube.
fields.body:
The partial privatisation of the London Underground took a step forward yesterday, when the city's transport authority shortlisted four bidders vying to run six lines of the cash-starved Tube.

Linc, a consortium led by Canada's Bombardier, and the Metronet group, led by DaimlerChrysler's rail unit Adtranz, will compete to take over the Bakerloo, Central and Victoria lines, London Transport said.

TubeRail, led by US project management company Halliburton Brown & Root, and TubeLines, led by US-based, privately held construction company Bechtel, will vie for the Jubilee, Northern and Piccadilly lines.

London Transport said selection of the finalists meant that plans to deliver the government's controversial tube policy - a public-private partnership deal which will use multi-million pound private sector contracts to build its infrastructure - were proceeding on schedule.

webTitle: Rival bookmakers bet on IG price

fields.headline: Rival bookmakers bet on IG price
fields.trailText: Bookmaker Stuart Wheeler, the founder of IG Group, is a betting man but even he must be concerned at the odd situation that the company has found itself as his rivals run a grey market on the likely success of his company's flotation.
fields.body:
Bookmaker Stuart Wheeler, the founder of IG Group, is a betting man but even he must be concerned at the odd situation that the company has found itself as his rivals run a grey market on the likely success of his company's flotation.

City Index and Cantor Fitzgerald, also financial spread betting groups, are offering a grey market on IG's shares of 262p-272p and 272p-277p each.

IG, the parent company of IG Index, has priced its shares at 240p each, valuing the company at £125.5m.

The original backers of the company who invested in the operation started in 1974 with £300 have seen their stake multiply to about £12.5m.

IG Index spokesman Paul Austin said that while legally the group was restricted from offering a grey market in its own shares, there was a more important reason for choosing not to do so.

"It would be too embarrass ing if we got it wrong," he said. "We expected to be under the microscope as the offer seems to have drawn a lot of interest."

Financial Spreads is one bookmaker which is not offering a grey market on IG Group which intends to list on July 19.

"Obviously they are another interesting company that is about to float and obviously one that's close to our heart," said Simon Mansell, managing director at City Index. "It's a little bit more fun when it's one of the competitors."

David Buik, marketing director at Cantor Fitzgerald, said it was in the betting industry's interests that IG Group float went well.

Mr Wheeler is expected to own about 33% of the listed group after cashing in about 10% of his holding for £5m.

IG Group is raising just £1.15m net of expenses through a placing of 833,333 shares.

The funds will be used for working capital and acquisitions.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Six men aged between 16 and 21 were arrested on suspicion of attempted murder after the stabbing of three Kosovan asylum seekers yesterday morning in Chatham in Kent. The three are in hospital, one seriously wounded.
fields.body:
Three Kosovans stabbed

Six men aged between 16 and 21 were arrested on suspicion of attempted murder after the stabbing of three Kosovan asylum seekers yesterday morning in Chatham in Kent. The three are in hospital, one seriously wounded.

It happened in a street where Kosovan families live. Although there had been an incident involving local youths, the street's Neighbourhood Watch coordinator, Jackie Rogers, 35, said: "We heard it was a rival group of Albanians who carried out the attack."

Bid for Thatcher handbag

A bid of £101,000 has been received for a black Ferragamo handbag donated by Lady Thatcher to an internet auction in aid of breast cancer care.

A tiger print handbag from Cherie Blair has attracted a bid of £205.

Smart move for Bafta awards

Next year's British Academy of Film and Television Arts awards ceremony will be held on February 25, a month before the Hollywood Oscars instead of, as in past years, a week after.

Bafta said it hoped the change would increase the ceremony's stature and influence.

British tourists killed in crash

Three tourists have been killed in Queensland, Australia. They are Robert Sherwood, 75, his wife Naomi, 74, from Abingdon, Oxfordshire, and Patricia Beyger, 80, from Brampton, Cumbria. Their hire car collided with another car, and a woman and five children were taken to hospital but are expected to live.

Love Parade given go-ahead

BBC Radio One's Love Parade, billed as the world's biggest dance party, will go ahead in Roundhay Park in Leeds on Saturday, it was agreed yesterday.

West Yorkshire police are concerned about safety, and have cancelled all leave.

'Lord Woodbine' dies in fire

Harold Phillips, 72, known as Lord Woodbine for his choice of cigarettes, and his wife died yesterday in a fire at their home in Liverpool.

"Woodie" joined John, Paul, George, Pete Best and Stuart Sutcliffe on the Beatles' Hamburg tour in 1960.

Speed record broken twice

The British land speed record was broken twice yesterday by two jet-propelled cars at Elvington airfield near York.

Mark Newby achieved 272mph, and two hours later Colin Fallows reached 300.3mph.

webTitle: Managers 'overlooked risk' in airport tunnel collapse

fields.headline: Managers 'overlooked risk' in airport tunnel collapse
fields.trailText: Construction managers were yesterday blamed for exposing workers and public to the risk of serious injury when a series of tunnel collapses occurred at Heathrow in one of the worst civil engineering disasters in Britain.
fields.body:
Construction managers were yesterday blamed for exposing workers and public to the risk of serious injury when a series of tunnel collapses occurred at Heathrow in one of the worst civil engineering disasters in Britain.

It took place during building of the £500m Heathrow Express line between Paddington and the airport, and came within 20 metres of the Piccadilly underground line.

A report by the health and safety executive concluded that warning signs that all was not well had not been recognised. It said the problem would not have occurred if safety had been put before results.

The collapses, in October 1994, continued over three days. Only an emergency concrete plug prevented the collapses from reaching the Piccadilly line.

Construction workers escaped uninjured with minutes to spare, but the collapse of three tunnels led to widespread disruption at the airport. The incident severely delayed the project, and also the Jubilee extension project, on which the same tunnelling methods were used.

Kevin Myers, the executive's chief inspector of construction, said: "The collapses could have been prevented but for a cultural mindset which focused attention on the apparent economies and the need for production rather than the particular risks."

The investigation found that the direct cause of the collapses was a chain of events that started with substandard construction, inadequate repairs, and the construction of another tunnel in failing ground.

Mr Myers said there were salutary lessons that had to be learned by the construction industry. The potential for disasters had to be recognised, and new or unfamiliar technologies needed to be fully understood and assessed before being adopted.

He said large projects carried out close to the public required particular attention, and production pressures had to be balanced by precautionary safety systems. Mr Myers blamed management for not seeking the views of staff on health and safety matters.

The rail project was a joint venture between what was then British Rail and BAA, the airports operator. The principal contractor, Balfour Beatty Civil Engineering, was last year fined £1.2m after pleading guilty to offences under the Health and Safety Act. Austrian advisers were fined £500,000, and the executive found that the incident exhibited all the hallmarks of "an organisational incident".

fields.headline: Brown 'delayed renewal plan'
fields.trailText: John Prescott's attempts to play up measures designed to improve rundown cities after strong criticism from his own advisers were undermined today when Labour MPs accused the Treasury of threatening key regeneration plans.
fields.body:
John Prescott's attempts to play up measures designed to improve rundown cities after strong criticism from his own advisers were undermined today when Labour MPs accused the Treasury of threatening key regeneration plans.

In its report, the Commons environment committee rekindled last week's row between the architect Lord Rogers, chairman of the deputy prime minister's urban task force, and ministers.

The Labour peer accused the government of stifling his recommendations a year ago for breathing new life into cities with US-style tax breaks for developers in priority areas.

Hours after Mr Prescott claimed in a speech to US-businessmen that the government had begun to "learn the value" of the American approach, the committee accused the chancellor, Gordon Brown, of kicking the Rogers proposals "into the long grass".

"It is disgraceful that over a year after the report was published the Treasury has come to no conclusion about the proposed fiscal measures put forward by the task force," it said. The committee sided with Lord Rogers by calling for much more cash to improve cities, and special measures to penalise developers who hold onto land wanted for regeneration schemes.

"We are appalled by the slow progress made by the Treasury in evaluating such important matters," it said.

Long-delayed urban and rural white papers should stress that patterns of development which characterised the last century cannot continue. The government should introduce a string of new measures, from grants to tax write-offs, to encourage large-scale investment.
