webTitle: British Biotech considers new name to hide its shame

fields.headline: British Biotech considers new name to hide its shame
fields.trailText: British Biotech is seriously considering changing its name, in an attempt to leave behind its history of scandal, disappointment and failure.
fields.body:
British Biotech is seriously considering changing its name, in an attempt to leave behind its history of scandal, disappointment and failure.

The idea emerged as the drug development company cut its annual pre-tax loss by 36% to £25.4m after making a big cut in its workforce and ending several clinical trials for the cancer drug marimastat.

Chief executive Elliot Goldstein said he was "intrigued" by the possibility of a new name. "The essential thing is to ensure we change the company. As part of that, a change of name would probably be a good idea."

Dr Goldstein is frustrated by the company's continuing struggle to escape the shadow of marimastat, which was once considered a cure for cancer but which has failed in four sets of clinical trials.

A new name is likely if marimastat fails in a trial for single cell lung cancer later this year. If that study is unsuccessful, the product will be dropped.

One suggestion, from the business development director, Tim Edwards, was to rename the company Tarragon - used as a codeword for a business deal earlier this year. Mr Edwards believes that naming the company after a herb would conjure up an image of freshness and natural therapy - but the idea has been rejected by Dr Goldstein.

British Biotech's workforce fell from 311 to 237 last year, and a further cut to just 140 is being implemented. The group has leased out several outlying buildings, concentrating its activities on just one site. Cash burn fell from £34.8m to £22.2m.

Dr Goldstein expressed frustration at the constant stream of disappointing recent news on marimastat: "This story's torturing us. It just makes you crazy, this uncertainty and unpredictability. It's like self-inflicted torture."

He identified a treatment for lung cancer, huN901-DM1, as one of the most promising future prospects in the group's product portfolio. In trials on mice, the drug has caused tumours to disappear.

The group is also working on a follow-up to marimastat, BB-3644, and several antibiotics, which could reach the market within a few years.

British Biotech's reputation was damaged two years ago when a dissident scientist, Andrew Millar, correctly predicted the demise of several key products. The shares rose 1.5p to 22p yesterday.

webTitle: Lib Dems vow to increase pensions by £5 a week

fields.headline: Lib Dems vow to increase pensions by £5 a week
fields.trailText: Labour will face further embarrassment over its meagre 75p rise in the basic pension when the Liberal Democrats today announce that they will increase it by £5 a week.
fields.body:
Labour will face further embarrassment over its meagre 75p rise in the basic pension when the Liberal Democrats today announce that they will increase it by £5 a week.

The plans come days before delegates to the Labour national policy forum press for the government to restore the link between the basic pension and earnings.

In a further blow, the social security minister, Jeff Rooker, was yesterday forced, under cross examination by MPs, to admit that he could not live on the minimum income guarantee of £78.45 a week.

The basic pension rose to £67.50 in April and it has been predicted it will rise by £2 to £3 a week next year.

The Liberal Democrats will announce a £3bn package for all 11m pensioners, including £2bn to increase the basic pension and a further £1.1bn by giving an additional £5 a week to over 75s and a further £10 a week for over 80s.

Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, will attack Labour's record in an attempt to make pensions a key dividing line in the election.

He will claim Labour has broken its promise to give older people a share in rising national prosperity and that it is a national disgrace that nearly one in three of our pensioners are still lving below the poverty line.

He will also challenge the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to make the increase a central plank of the spending review this month.

Ministers have claimed they are spending more than if they had increased pensions in line with earnings, but the complex ways in which pensioners have been helped has meant a lower political impact.

The Liberal Democrats will also propose abolishing the upper limit on the minimum income guarantees on savings set at £8,000 and due to rise to £12,000. A total of 25,000 pensioners would be helped at a cost of only £50m. They also propose abolition of the retirement age, and suggest in the long term they want to re move the means test from the minimum income guarantee. At present more than 50% of women are unable to claim the basic pension due to the earnings of their household.

The Conservatives have proposed an extra £5 a week increase in the basic pension, but almost all of this would be financed by abolishing the existing winter fuel allowance, the Christmas bonus and free TV licences.

Steve Webb, the Liberal Democrat welfare spokesman, said: "Pensions as a proportion of national income has fallen under Labour. No-one would have believed this would have happened before the election, but it has."

Mr Rooker told the social security select committee yesterday: "If you asked me could I live on £78.45 a week, the answer is no I couldn't. I would have problems living on £90. I don't think £78 is enough. The government has got to do more for poorer pensioners.

"We want to do more. It is the speed with which we are able to carry that out which is the barrier."

The plans come days before delegates to the Labour national policy forum press for the government to restore the link between the basic pension and earnings. In a further blow, the social security minister, Jeff Rooker, was yesterday forced, under cross examination by MPs, to admit that he could not live on the minimum income guarantee of £78.45 a week. fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: BA suffers traffic fall
fields.body:
BA suffers traffic fall

Two days of computer problems at British airports and a strike by French air traffic controllers caused a 1.4% drop in British Airways' June air traffic. But the airline said it had high hopes for the important summer season, as a slowdown in market capacity growth was helping to boost yields.

Like several other airlines, British Airways cancelled 90% of its flights to and from France on June 26. Flights were also affected by a computer breakdown which caused problems at Heathrow on June 17 and 18.

Canal-Plus to keep autonomy

Pay television group Canal-Plus will continue to exist as a separate company run by its present chairman, Pierre Lescure, within Vivendi Universal, Vivendi's chairman Jean-Marie Messier said. He set out in a letter to Mr Lescure dated 19 June, published yesterday by Vivendi, how the pay-TV group will function following a three-way merger between Vivendi, Seagram and Canal.

The group will cover all the activities now held by Canal-Plus - including buying, producing and selling rights to films, television programmes and sporting events - but will also include Seagram's Universal Studios.

Bank of Ireland pays up

A long-running investigation into the non-payment of tax in Ireland came to a head last night when Bank of Ireland, one of the top two Irish banking groups, admitted it had paid more than IR£30m (£24m) to the revenue commissioners. Other big payments are now anticipated from other banking groups.

The payment follows a parliamentary investigation into allegations of non-payment of deposit income retention tax by bank account holders. An audit revealed that IR£12.75m was owed in back tax over a 13-year period. The balance was made up of interest and penalties.

US traders win approval

American members of Tradepoint, the British electronic stock exchange, have been given regulatory approval to trade directly in European equities. The Securities and Exchange Commission has issued instructions which will allow US firms to deal on Tradepoint's pan-European blue chip market when it is launched next week.

Tradepoint provides trading in 2,000 listed British companies but will add around 230 continental European equities.

Car firm to lose 400 jobs

Up to 400 jobs are to be lost through the closure of a factory which makes rubber sealing systems for cars. Automotive Sealing Systems' plants at Dunstable in Bedfordshire will undergo a "phased closure" by the end of next year.

The company blamed overcapacity in the market and a drive for lower prices. The company will ask for volunteers, but some compulsory losses are expected.

webTitle: Open verdict on fire death Tory MP and wife

fields.headline: Open verdict on fire death Tory MP and wife
fields.trailText: A discarded match thrown into a waste paper basket was the most likely cause of a fire that destroyed the country mansion of Conservative MP Michael Colvin and his wife Nichola, killing them both, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A discarded match thrown into a waste paper basket was the most likely cause of a fire that destroyed the country mansion of Conservative MP Michael Colvin and his wife Nichola, killing them both, an inquest heard yesterday.

Mr Colvin, 67, the MP for Romsey, Hampshire, and his wife, 62, died when the blaze swept through Tangley House, near Andover, Hampshire, early on February 24.

The mid-Hampshire coroner, Grahame Short, recorded an open verdict after concluding that the devastation caused by the fire meant it was impossible to establish the cause of death.

The hearing in Winchester was told that fumes and flames would have spread upstairs through an open door to the bedrooms in which the couple were sleeping.

Nichola Woolnough, the Colvins' housekeeper since 1990, told the inquest how she and her husband Peter, who lived in a nearby cottage, were woken by the smell of smoke at about 3am.

With the couple's butler, Alvaro Perreira, who also lived on the Tangley estate, they tried to rescue the couple before calling the fire brigade.

"We saw a glow in the sky. We thought at first it was the summerhouse but as we got round there we realised there was a glow coming from the main house," Mrs Woolnough said.

She said her husband and Mr Perreira had tried to enter the house but were beaten back by thick black smoke.

Firefighters, who arrived shortly after 4am, tried to enter through the bedroom windows but were beaten back by the intense heat.

The couple were identified by Mr Colvin's artificial hip joint and his wife's jewellery.

webTitle: Angry minister in SAS outburst over Briton held in Saudi prison

fields.headline: Angry minister in SAS outburst over Briton held in Saudi prison
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office minister, John Battle, entered into an extraordinary war of words with a Labour MP yesterday when he followed her out of a Commons chamber and demanded: "What do you want us to do, invade Saudi Arabia?"
fields.body:
The Foreign Office minister, John Battle, entered into an extraordinary war of words with a Labour MP yesterday when he followed her out of a Commons chamber and demanded: "What do you want us to do, invade Saudi Arabia?"

He launched the attack on Lynne Jones, MP for Birminghal Selly Oak, following a debate in Westminster Hall in which she raised the plight of a British citizen jailed in Saudi Arabia for more than a year without being charged.

Mr Battle - who once aspired to be a priest and even retreated to a Trappist monastery - was so riled by the MP's questions that he followed her out to carry on the row before storming off. "What do you want us to do, invade Saudi Arabia?" he demanded, as the wife of the jailed man and other stunned onlookers watched.

Dismissing Dr Jones's claims that the government was putting Britain's lucrative arms exports to Saudi Arabia before human rights, Mr Battle demanded: "What do you want me to do, send in the SAS to spring him out of jail?"

The spat centred on Dr Jones's constituent, Mohammed Chaudhry, a father of two who was a manager at a military hospital in Riyadh, and who has been in prison since June 1999 without charge after £3m of stock went missing. Mr Battle, visibly irritated by the MP's questions, said that the government had raised his case with the Saudi authorities on 46 separate occasions, including at the highest level with the Saudi royal family, but said it could not override the Saudi justice system.Last night Mr Battle issued a statement saying: "The point I made in a private conversation was the same point I made in the Commons, that we're doing all we can to pursue this case, which we take very seriously."

After witnessing the spat, Mr Chaudhry's wife, Shaen, urged the Saudis to free her husband. "If they have got evidence, bring it forward," she said.

Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, said: "He shouldn't have shouted at a fellow MP and he certainly shouldn't have said what he did in front of the wife of the jailed man."

webTitle: These days toys are no longer us

fields.headline: These days toys are no longer us
fields.standfirst: As children become streetwise earlier the market for juvenile playthings is changing rapidly
fields.trailText: Big Ears turned to his friend one day: "Noddy, why don't we make any profits any more?" With a sad tinkle of the bell on his hat, Noddy replied: "I don't understand children these days. All they're interested in is Reebok trainers and Pokémon cards."
fields.body:
Big Ears turned to his friend one day: "Noddy, why don't we make any profits any more?" With a sad tinkle of the bell on his hat, Noddy replied: "I don't understand children these days. All they're interested in is Reebok trainers and Pokémon cards."

These are difficult times in Toytown. Tastes are changing, and Britain's traditional toy shops and manufacturers are struggling to keep up.

Celebrated names are making news for all the wrong reasons. Hamleys, the country's most famous toy retailer, has just turned down a takeover bid from a group of financiers for a measly £35m - remarkably low, considering the company's brand name and the central London store's Regent Street location. Meanwhile, Hornby, the 99-year-old model railways specialist, has put itself up for sale.

Jimmy Hunter, chairman of the British Toy and Hobby Association, says: "Things are quite bleak for the industry just now. We're not enjoying the easiest of times, particularly at the retailing end."

The Pokémon craze - Japanese icons depicting a series of monsters - has helped a little: "Toy shops have been helped a bit by the success of Pokémon cards but that doesn't paper over all the cracks - they're only little cards, after all."

The travails of Hamleys and Hornby are merely part of the story. The BTHA has just 200 manufacturing members left, having seen 30 or 40 disappear or get swallowed by multinationals over the past five years. Meanwhile, another trade body, the British Association of Toy Retailers, reckons that the number of independent toy shops in the high street has halved in the last decade.

Spend increasing

So why all the gloom and doom? Is it true that children are boycotting dolls, board games and skipping ropes in favour of Gameboys and other electronic gadgets?

Jon Salisbury, publisher of the magazine UK Toy News, says the picture is a little more complicated: "The total spend on children is actually increasing quite considerably. The trouble is that a lot of the money spent on children is going into other industries' pockets - think of the amount spent on football, for example."

Many in the toy industry bemoan the fact that "kids are growing older, younger". Children as young as 10 are targets for the music industry, sportswear manufacturers and even mobile phone retailers.

A spokesman for Mattel, the US toymaker, says: "Girl bands and boy bands are catering for a younger and younger audience. Children are changing - they want the latest Spice Girls CD."

Mr Salisbury says: "The traditional toy industry has got to fight for its share. There's a need to redefine what categorises toys."

Many independent toy shops initially resisted stocking video games, leaving them to chain stores and specialists such as Electronics Boutique. But the growth of the market has forced them to change; sales of video games now top £1bn a year and they are particularly important in attracting male customers.

Children increasingly know their own minds from an early age - with access to the media almost from birth, they want television tie-ins such as Teletubbies, Power Rangers and WWF wrestlers.

This is one of the reasons behind the takeover of a long list of British toymakers over the last decade by American multinationals. Mattel has led the charge, snapping up Fisher Price, Matchbox, Spears and Bluebird Toys - best known for its Polly Pocket dolls. Hasbro has followed, buying Waddington and Subbuteo.

Signs of life

The news is not all bad. Overall sales of toys in Britain are pretty static, worth a total of £1.65bn last year, against £1.67bn in 1998 and £1.66bn in 1997. These figures, from the British Association of Toy Retailers, exclude video games.

In the US, toy sales grew by 12% last year - but revenue often comes from sudden crazes for mass-produced items such as Furbies, Pokémon or the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles.

There are signs of life at the smallest end of the market- individual craft workers. Robert Nathan of the British Toymakers' Guild says: "It's not too bad at our level. The old days of selling into a strong retail market are gone and the pond has got a bit smaller. But there are a lot of mail order and direct sales."

The guild has identified 2000 "micro companies" making toys, with a factory-gate turnover of about £35m. Many sales are to older collectors. Others are to nostalgic aunts and uncles who buy toy trains or spinning tops for their reluctant younger relatives.

But the middle ground in toymaking is slipping away. The BTHA is fighting back with its first consumer exhibition this year - the Total Fun show being held in London at Earls Court in October. Jimmy Hunter of the BTHA says that this will showcase traditional children's products. "Kids have got all this virtual reality stuff now," he says. "Rather than virtual reality, reality is going to be the thing for us."

British toy sales

1998/1999

Infant/pre-school: £269m/£254m

Dolls: £187m/£179m

Plush toys: £130m/£183m

Action men: £135m/£132m

Vehicles: £123m/£128m

Ride-ons: £101m/£78m

Games and puzzles: £194m/£192m

Activity toys: £278m/£260m

All other toys: £252m /£246m

Source: NPD Eurotoys

fields.headline: Carphone Warehouse
fields.trailText: Carphone Warehouse, Europe's largest independent mobile phone retailer, is expected to come to market with an initial valuation of at least £1.8bn after a strong retail investor response to its public offer.
fields.body:
Carphone Warehouse, Europe's largest independent mobile phone retailer, is expected to come to market with an initial valuation of at least £1.8bn after a strong retail investor response to its public offer.

The share offer opened last Thursday and according to sources close to the company a strong response has been received from retail investors who have applied for shares on the condition they cannot sell for three months after trading begins on July 14.

Retail investors who agree not to sell their shares for three months will receive priority allocations in the Carphone Warehouse flotation.

The retail offer closes next Tuesday. The company set its indicative range for its float at 170p to 220p a share.

IG Index and City Index both had a grey market spread price for the telecoms company of 218p-223p. Carphone Warehouse managers are visiting institutional investors across Europe and the US this week.

Founder Charles Dunstone, who is expected to cash in some £56m from selling shares in the offer and who will own 38% of the company, said of the float: "We are feeling good. There's a very good conversion rate from meeting institutions."

Around one-third of the proceeds from the flotation will be used to reduce debt and a further third will be used to fund the continued expansion of Carphone Warehouse across Europe.

The company has 450 stores in Britain and a further 430 or so trading under the Phone House name throughout countries including France, Germany and the Netherlands.

The remainder will be used to develop its other services in cluding Value Telecom, which repackages One2One airtime under the Carphone-owned brand, and Mviva, the group's wireless internet portal.

Mr Dunstone said the greater complexity added by wireless internet coupled with the anticipated huge demand for replacement handsets made Carphone Warehouse's independent advice a strong selling point.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Dealers were left with a sense of déjà vu yesterday, after the main FTSE 100 index retreated for a second consecutive session thanks to continued weakness in the oil and banking sectors.
fields.body:
Dealers were left with a sense of déjà vu yesterday, after the main FTSE 100 index retreated for a second consecutive session thanks to continued weakness in the oil and banking sectors.

However, thanks to a late telecoms inspired rally the blue chip index finished off its intraday low at 6,382.5, a decline of 34.5 points.

BP Amoco had another torrid session hit by concerns over Saudi Arabia's plan to pump more oil into the market and a downgrade from heavyweight broker Merrill Lynch, which cut its near-term recommendation to "neutral" from "accumulate", citing the recent strong per formance of the stock. BP shares fell 29.5p to 600.5p.

There was more woe for the banking sector, as Dresdner Kleinwort Benson rubbed salt into gaping wounds.

Following negative comments on Tuesday from Deutsche Bank, Dresdner cut the entire sector to "underweight" from "neutral" and downgraded Alliance & Leicester , which fell 30p to 527p, and Lloyds TSB , which lost 14.5p to 590p.

Royal Bank of Scotland , down 54p at £10.26, and Halifax , off 23.5p at 564.5p, were also under fire.

But the biggest casualty was Egg , the internet bank owned by the Pru, which dipped below last month's offer price. The shares, which came to market at 160p, closed down 14p at 149.5p.

Bid speculation enlivened Cable & Wireless. It shares climbed 85p to £12.46 after a report that claimed Deutsche Telekom was poised to strike.

Vodafone AirTouch spiked up 7.5p to 297p on hopes that the third-generation mobile phone licences that are coming up for grabs in Germany and Holland may fetch sums nearer to their reserve prices than the staggering sums seen in Britain. News that Vodafone had signed a record 6.6m new customers in the second quarter helped underpin sentiment.

After good gains earlier in the week, Dixons came off the boil, falling 6p to 247p as full-year figures raised more questions about the group's future growth prospects.

Arriva , up 32p at 210p, topped the FTSE 250 performance table on reports of a £620m bid from a venture capital group.

But advertising group Cordiant surrendered 27.5p to 344.5p after buying US communications company Lighthouse Global Network for $421m (£279m) and Baltimore retreated 42p to 488p spooked by a profit warning from US peer Entrust. Shortly after the market closed Baltimore issued a statement that said its sales performance was in line with management expectations.

BP shares fell 29.5p to 600.5p. There was more woe for the banking sector, as Dresdner Kleinwort Benson rubbed salt into gaping wounds. Following negative comments on Tuesday from Deutsche Bank, Dresdner cut the entire sector to "underweight" from "neutral" and downgraded Alliance & Leicester , which fell 30p to 527p, and Lloyds TSB , which lost 14.5p to 590p. Royal Bank of Scotland , down 54p at £10.26, and Halifax , off 23.5p at 564.5p, were also under fire. But the biggest casualty was Egg , the internet bank owned by the Pru, which dipped below last month's offer price. The shares, which came to market at 160p, closed down 14p at 149.5p. Bid speculation enlivened Cable & Wireless. It shares climbed 85p to £12.46 after a report that claimed Deutsche Telekom was poised to strike. Vodafone AirTouch spiked up 7.5p to 297p on hopes that the third-generation mobile phone licences that are coming up for grabs in Germany and Holland may fetch sums nearer to their reserve prices than the staggering sums seen in Britain. News that Vodafone had signed a record 6.6m new customers in the second quarter helped underpin sentiment. After good gains earlier in the week, Dixons came off the boil, falling 6p to 247p as full-year figures raised more questions about the group's future growth prospects. Arriva , up 32p at 210p, topped the FTSE 250 performance table on reports of a £620m bid from a venture capital group. But advertising group Cordiant surrendered 27.5p to 344.5p after buying US communications company Lighthouse Global Network for $421m (£279m) and Baltimore retreated 42p to 488p spooked by a profit warning from US peer Entrust. Shortly after the market closed Baltimore issued a statement that said its sales performance was in line with management expectations.

webTitle: Spirits world is shaken by Allied

fields.headline: Spirits world is shaken by Allied
fields.trailText: Size matters in the global spirits industry and the chance to acquire the spirits operations of Canadian group Seagram is Allied Domecq's chance to turn itself into a world leader.
fields.body:
Size matters in the global spirits industry and the chance to acquire the spirits operations of Canadian group Seagram is Allied Domecq's chance to turn itself into a world leader.

The likely disposal of the business, a consequence of Vivendi's $34bn (£22.5bn) acquisition of Seagram, could not have come a better time for Allied's new management team headed by Philip Bowman, analysts say. Under his leadership Allied has managed to establish credibility with the investment community for the first time in years.

Its underperforming retail division has gone, sold to Punch Taverns in a deal worth £2.75bn, and recent interim figures beat City expectations. But now comes the real test for Mr Bowman - he has made it clear that Allied must feature in the next round of consolidation and he now must deliver on his promise.

The omens, however, are good. In an industry where all the major players have expressed an interest in the operations, Allied appears to be in the driving seat.

In a report yesterday, analysts at Deutsche Bank highlighted the lack of alternative buyers. They claim the current circumstances of the other potential buyer's places Allied in the pole position.

Bacardi, the most likely competitor, lost its management team in the wake of its abandoned flotation, while Brown-Forman, the face behind the Jack Daniels brand, simply does not have the financial firepower.

This leaves Diageo and Pernod Ricard. Diageo would not get regulatory approval to buy the entire business and Pernod Ricard with a market capitalisation of just £2bn is not in a position to acquire a business valued at £6bn, they claim.

By contrast Allied Domecq has a new management team, and the disposal of the retail division has left it with a healthy financial position.

Nevertheless, until Allied manages to pull off the deal and turns itself into a rival to Diageo, its shares are likely to mark time.

Allied shares, which closed 3.5p higher at 368.5p yesterday, have risen nearly 75p since the start of the year.

But the good news is that should Allied acquire Seagram's spirits business it shares could easily break through the 400p barrier.

fields.headline: Matthew Norman
fields.trailText: • Few movie directors have as good a reputation as the mildly right-on Ridley Scott for portraying strong females, so he is wise to guard his liberal fan base. Following the report in yesterday's paper about union militancy in Los Angeles, we are intrigued to hear of the efforts by the British director to break industrial action by actors. The director of Thelma and Louise and Alien has delighted the US Screen Actors Guild (SAG) with some newspaper adverts SAG describes as "racist and sexist". The ads, placed by Ridley and his brother Tony's production company RSA USA, are intended to promote South Africa as a strike-free alternative location and frighten striking actors back to work. They feature a close-up of an elderly black woman's chest, accompanied by the caption: "In South Africa this is what SAG means. They've never heard of the guild". Delightful stuff.

 Few movie directors have as good a reputation as the mildly right-on Ridley Scott for portraying strong females, so he is wise to guard his liberal fan base. Following the report in yesterday's paper about union militancy in Los Angeles, we are intrigued to hear of the efforts by the British director to break industrial action by actors. The director of Thelma and Louise and Alien has delighted the US Screen Actors Guild (SAG) with some newspaper adverts SAG describes as "racist and sexist". The ads, placed by Ridley and his brother Tony's production company RSA USA, are intended to promote South Africa as a strike-free alternative location and frighten striking actors back to work. They feature a close-up of an elderly black woman's chest, accompanied by the caption: "In South Africa this is what SAG means. They've never heard of the guild". Delightful stuff.

 A so-called rival on the Express names and shames some political journalists as "pet lobby correspondents of the Downing Street spin machine". Is that the same Express whose editor, Rizla Rosie Boycott, was vetoed from hiring Brownite man of the people, Paul Routledge, as political editor and was ordered to give the job to ultra Blairite Anthony Bevins instead? The same Express where that least charlatan of pollsters, Philip Gould, has his office?

 A letter arrives from Mrs MD Ainsworth of Herts. "I don't always understand your Diary column," she writes, "but I read it." Very kind. "Twice recently you have referred to someone as alopecian," she goes on. "This is a medical condition for which the unfortunate patient has no personal responsibility at all... please do not use illnesses as fodder for your venom," she concludes, mentioning her own full head of hair at 77 (hats off!). The slaphead referred to is David Yelland, the editor of the Sun and (according to another so-called rival) soon to be star of the new board game Editor! We have considered David fair game because he once made a frontpage issue of Robin Cook's perceived ugliness, Mrs Ainsworth, but in the light of your letter will be considering your objection carefully in the days ahead.

 Time for some warmed-up leftovers from yesterday's item about my chatterbox old friend Roger Liddle, Mr Tony's policy adviser on Europe who spent Friday night sharing secrets from No 10 at a BBC dinner party. Apart from confirming how much Mr T and Gordon loathe each other, Roger discussed various plans for the future of Europe. The Germans, he said, want a federal superstate, while the French are even more militant and favour a directoire. But what, someone asked, is the British plan? Ah, he replied, that's a very interesting question. Yes, said the questioner, but what is the plan? There isn't one, said the Europe policy adviser. Not yet.

 Poor Mr T. Beset by woes, he cannot even lose himself in drink. At the recent party at Lincoln's Inn celebrating the launch of Matrix, Cherie's new left-of-centre chambers, he was given a champagne cocktail. After just one sip Mr T wrinkled his nose and handed it back, complaining "I think there's something wrong with this one." Well, yes. A sugar cube in brandy, in fact, like you get in a champagne cocktail.

 Anyone tempted by this to produce a compilation entitled The Hilarious Faux Pas of Mr Tony Blair is reminded of the one noted by a reporter covering a speech in Oxford before the election. Mr T was surrounded in the street by young foreigners asking for his autograph and to have their pictures taken with him. "They're Brazilians," he said affably. "I'm very big in Brazil." "When you become prime minister you can go there," said the reporter, "but you'll have to brush up your Portuguese." "Portuguese?" said Mr Tony. "Why Portuguese?" Bless him, he can be very sweet.

fields.headline: King of the hill
fields.standfirst: It's a long overdue promotion for television's toughest cop. But finally The Bill's legendary DCI Burnside has his own series. How will he fare without his colleagues at Sun Hill?  Ed Waller  investigates
fields.trailText: It's a long overdue promotion for television's toughest cop. But finally The Bill's legendary DCI Burnside has his own series. How will he fare without his colleagues at Sun Hill? Ed Waller investigates
fields.body:
Along with warm beer and fish 'n' chips, ITV's cop drama The Bill occupies a place in the nation's psyche. The flashing-blue-lights show began 17 long years ago and has since survived when lesser precinct dramas have fallen by the wayside. It has withstood its producers, Thames TV, losing their ITV franchise in 1991; condemnation by police and TV watchdog alike; and a heap of criticism for rather too accurately reproducing the tedium of everyday procedural policing.

Its format has switched from a weekly hour-long series to a thrice weekly half-hour show. A couple of years ago it reverted back to its hour-long slot and was deliberately "soapified" in an attempt to keep up with the far-fetched plots of other ongoing dramas. The characters' domestic lives, once forbidden, crept in to spice up the show's notoriously mundane storylines and ratings duly rose.

But The Bill is still a pale shadow of its former self, with audiences down from 13m in the heady days of 1992 to about 7m today. Last month there were even brief rumours that Thames's parent company Pearson was to cart the show off to that dinosaurs' graveyard of television, Channel 5. So it's perhaps an odd time for ITV to launch a spin-off series, Burnside, based on a character who stopped appearing on a regular basis seven years ago.

Always something of a refugee from the 70s, DCI Frank Burnside (played by Christopher Ellison) often found himself up against The Bill's pre-watershed constraints. He'd burst into some petty criminal's council house, growl "You're nicked, you slag" and vanish, forever kept on a tight leash by the writers. Hence Ellison's departure from The Bill in the first place, lured away by the promise of his own show, Ellington, an ill-fated Minder-style drama about a boxing promoter. It eventually appeared on ITV in 1996 and was never heard of again. Though Ellison has since shown his face in a couple of shows, like Birds Of A Feather, his recent reappearance in The Bill was only as the warm-up for his own long-promised series.

Now, with six post-watershed hours of his own to play with at last, Burnside begins as he means to go on. Five minutes into the first episode and we've been treated to a couple of "shits" and a "wanker" - words you'd never hear from his colleagues at Sun Hill. And the bodycount has gone through the roof. No longer fighting The Bill's unglamorous war against shoplifting single parents and domestic violence, Burnside now faces Uzi-wielding Yardies, international gun-runners and warped serial killers. "Dark and adult", is how the show's producer Jamie Nuttgens describes it all. "The Bill has faced some criticism in the past but with Burnside we've pulled out all the stops."

The series' writers capitalise further on our hero's often Neanderthal approach (eg bog-washing suspects till they confess) by placing him in the softly softly catchee monkey National Crime Squad. And yet more dramatic friction comes from writing Burnside's two new underlings as epitomes of political correctness - a no-bullshit feminist (played by Zoe Eeles) and a black gay character (Justin Pierre).

Having the latter openly gay is not only something of a first for British mainstream telly, reckons Nuttgens, but also gives the character an interesting contradiction - gay but straight-laced. "The UK is really bad for good black roles on TV," he says, "and I wasn't going to make a major series set in London in the year 2000 without a black lead." Despite this, viewers will certainly notice some of the show's Sweeney-esque touches. (Ellison himself won his first acting job on that 70s series, and continued his TV tough-guy apprenticeship in shows like The Professionals, Minder and Widows.) Thames's new series also allows sitcom favourite Paul Nicholas to break out from his usual role and try something more serious as a ruthless, media-friendly gangster. Even more surprising is the appearance of a peroxide blonde Shane Ritchie, who pops up throughout the series as Burnside's lowlife grass.

But while these two co-stars of this elegantly-shot series seem able to shuffle off their typecasts with relative ease, Burnside's star, judging by his return to a role he vacated in 1993, is obviously finding it a little harder.

Burnside, tonight, 9pm, ITV

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: It must be said that postwar Democratic presidents have had far more memorable First Ladies (8.0pm, Radio 4) than their rivals. Anthony Howard's second programme covers the range from the charismatic glamour of Jacqueline Kennedy to the sad courage of Pat Nixon.
fields.body:
It must be said that postwar Democratic presidents have had far more memorable First Ladies (8.0pm, Radio 4) than their rivals. Anthony Howard's second programme covers the range from the charismatic glamour of Jacqueline Kennedy to the sad courage of Pat Nixon. Even in the aftermath of her husband's assassination, Jackie maintained her extraordinary cool. Pat, on the other hand, seemed overwhelmed by her sojourn in the White House, even before her husband's shaming resignation.

In the lead-up to the singer's 70th birthday, Stuart Maconie launches a four-part series about Ray Charles - Man And Music (9.0pm, Radio 2). In spite of going blind at six and the shock of his mother's premature death a few years later, Charles carved out a musical career from the age of 15. He attracted attention all along America's west coast and got into the charts with his first record. It was never an easy life, but that set the pattern.

fields.headline: Notes and queries
fields.standfirst: England's smallest man * Where's the proof for homeopathy? * Why it's not 'the Uruguay'
fields.trailText: I recently heard of Jeffrey Hudson, a 17th century "dwarf", who ran with the pirates, constantly duelled his detractors and was frequently presented to high society encased in a pie or a cake. Does anyone know more about him?
fields.body:
I recently heard of Jeffrey Hudson, a 17th century "dwarf", who ran with the pirates, constantly duelled his detractors and was frequently presented to high society encased in a pie or a cake. Does anyone know more about him?

* It is, perhaps, only right that Sir Jeffrey Hudson (1619-1682), England's smallest man, was born in England's smallest county, Rutland. The son of an Oakham butcher, Sir Jeffrey was normally proportioned but only 18 inches tall until well into middle age, when he "grew" to a height of 3ft 6ins.

He came to the attention of Henrietta Maria, the wife of Charles I, when he was hidden inside a venison pie at a banquet in her honour held at the Duke of Buckingham's home near Oakham, where he was a page. He remained a loyal servant to the Queen and saw service during the civil war but, as a Catholic, was caught up in the panic surrounding the Popish Plot. After a spell in prison, he was released and lived off a pension supplied by the new Duke of Buckingham, the son of his first sponsor.

There is a short (sic) biography of Sir Jeffrey in Aubrey's Brief Lives, and he was also written into one of Sir Walter Scott's lesser-known Waverley Novels, Peveril of the Peak, where his appearance and life are described in detail.

The most famous painting of Sir Jeffrey is Van Dyke's Queen Henrietta Maria with Sir Jeffrey Hudson and an Ape, in the National Gallery, Washington DC. There are other portraits in a private collection near Oakham and at Petworth House in Sussex; his clothing can be seen at Sherborne Castle, Dorset; but the strangest artefact is a life-sized statue in the public bar of the Boat Inn in Portumna, County Galway.

The house where Sir Jeffrey was born (The Dwarf's Cottage) has recently been given a blue plaque and, although it is privately owned and not open to the public, its traditional English garden will be opened this coming Sunday, July 9, as part of the festival Oakham in Bloom.

Michael Walton, Pordenone, Italy.

* In her contribution "Some Famous Dwarfs" to A Pageant of History (Collins, 1958), Frances Collingwood gives the following information:

"When the Queen [Henrietta Maria] fled to Paris, [Hudson] went with her and there fought two famous duels. The first was against a turkey cock and the second against a Mr Crofts. The man did not take his little opponent seriously and turned up armed only with a squirt. Sir Jeffrey, mounted on horseback to bring him up to Crofts' level, shot his opponent dead. Leaving Paris in a hurry, he tried to return to England, but pirates caught him in the Channel and he was sold into slavery."

Mrs A A Hesson, Burnley, Lancs.

Why are some countries, such as The Gambia, prefixed with "The", even when they are not plural (like The Netherlands).

* It isn't a question of singular and plural. Some countries do not have true names but only descriptions ("the United Kingdom", "the Czech Republic", "the Netherlands", etc). As for "the Gambia" and "the Congo", they simply use the names of their main rivers (as if England were called "the Trent") - but then Uruguay is similarly named, and we don't call that "the Uruguay". A few take "the" purely by accident of language ("the Ukraine") and this applies to regions as well as countries: consider "the Algarve" and "the Punjab", but not "the Tuscany" or "the Kosovo". All in all, it's more or less random, like most things in language (and I live in the only town on earth whose English name takes "the").

Jim Burfield, The Hague, Netherlands.

Is there any proof that homeopathic medicine works?

* No, but the less proof there is, the more effectively it works.

Les Killip, Newton-le-Willows, Merseyside.

* No properly conducted study has yet produced convincing evidence that it has any more value than a placebo. The Homeopathic Medicine Research Group, convened by the European Commission, examined 184 published and unpublished reports of controlled trials of homeopathic treatments.

Its report (1996) concluded that only 17 of these trials were conducted well enough to be considered. While some may have demonstrated an effect greater than a placebo, overall the number of participants in the 17 trials was too small to permit any conclusions about the effectiveness of any given treatment for a specific condition.

This is not surprising. The basic principles of homeopathy, laid down by Samuel Hahnemann in the late 1700s (diseases are a manifestation of a "psora" or suppressed itch, the smaller the dose the greater the effect) have no demonstrable relationship with each other or with what we know about human biology. The only people for whom it could be said to "work" are hard-pressed GPs, who can pass their more persistent and intractable patients on to an "alternative" practioner, safe in the knowledge that no great harm is likely to be done.

The best detailed critique of homeopathy is probably still Homeopathy and its Kindred Delusions, first delivered as two lectures by Oliver Wendell Holmes in 1842.

Michael Hutton, Camberwell, London SE5.

* There are several levels of evidence for the effectiveness of homeopathy, which has the best research profile of the alternative medical systems. Thoughtlessly disregarded by the scientific community is so-called "anecdotal evidence", the best of which includes reports of clinical experience by homeopathic doctors who have used conventional methods with less success. Taken together, this material suggests to a fair-minded observer that something interesting is taking place.

Secondly, there is some good-quality historical evidence, particularly the experience of the American and European homeopathic hospitals in the 19th century, where mortality from infectious diseases like cholera was markedly lower than in conventional hospitals. In the modern period, the Society of Homeopaths has published reports on the work of members in primary care groups in the UK.

Most importantly, a significant body of scientific literature, mainly reports of clinical trials, has accumulated over the past 20 years or so. Four meta-analyses have been published, and the broad agreement is that homeopathic medicines work well. Where there is still a lack of clarity is the question of how they work. Not that a lack of understanding of mechanism ever stopped drugs and therapies being introduced into orthodox medicine.

Dr Denis MacEoin, chairman, The Natural Medicines Society, Newcastle upon Tyne.

In the novel The Devil Rides Out, Dennis Wheatley refers to the "Sussamma Ritual" - the only one of his mythological references I have been unable to track down. Was it made up by the author?

* William Hope Hodgson wrote a series of connected short stories, Carnacki the Ghost-Finder (1913) in which the eponymous hero investigated apparently supernatural events, some of which proved to have a natural explanation while others were genuine.

The stories contained several motifs - protective pentacles, ancient manuscripts and rituals - found in later novels, including The Devil Rides Out (1935). In several of the stories, reference is made to the Saaamaaa Ritual, which has protective properties like the not dissimilar Sussamma Ritual. fields.bodyText: I recently heard of Jeffrey Hudson, a 17th century "dwarf", who ran with the pirates, constantly duelled his detractors and was frequently presented to high society encased in a pie or a cake. Does anyone know more about him? * It is, perhaps, only right that Sir Jeffrey Hudson (1619-1682), England's smallest man, was born in England's smallest county, Rutland. The son of an Oakham butcher, Sir Jeffrey was normally proportioned but only 18 inches tall until well into middle age, when he "grew" to a height of 3ft 6ins. He came to the attention of Henrietta Maria, the wife of Charles I, when he was hidden inside a venison pie at a banquet in her honour held at the Duke of Buckingham's home near Oakham, where he was a page. He remained a loyal servant to the Queen and saw service during the civil war but, as a Catholic, was caught up in the panic surrounding the Popish Plot. After a spell in prison, he was released and lived off a pension supplied by the new Duke of Buckingham, the son of his first sponsor. There is a short (sic) biography of Sir Jeffrey in Aubrey's Brief Lives, and he was also written into one of Sir Walter Scott's lesser-known Waverley Novels, Peveril of the Peak, where his appearance and life are described in detail. The most famous painting of Sir Jeffrey is Van Dyke's Queen Henrietta Maria with Sir Jeffrey Hudson and an Ape, in the National Gallery, Washington DC. There are other portraits in a private collection near Oakham and at Petworth House in Sussex; his clothing can be seen at Sherborne Castle, Dorset; but the strangest artefact is a life-sized statue in the public bar of the Boat Inn in Portumna, County Galway. The house where Sir Jeffrey was born (The Dwarf's Cottage) has recently been given a blue plaque and, although it is privately owned and not open to the public, its traditional English garden will be opened this coming Sunday, July 9, as part of the festival Oakham in Bloom. Michael Walton, Pordenone, Italy. * In her contribution "Some Famous Dwarfs" to A Pageant of History (Collins, 1958), Frances Collingwood gives the following information: "When the Queen [Henrietta Maria] fled to Paris, [Hudson] went with her and there fought two famous duels. The first was against a turkey cock and the second against a Mr Crofts. The man did not take his little opponent seriously and turned up armed only with a squirt. Sir Jeffrey, mounted on horseback to bring him up to Crofts' level, shot his opponent dead. Leaving Paris in a hurry, he tried to return to England, but pirates caught him in the Channel and he was sold into slavery." Mrs A A Hesson, Burnley, Lancs. Why are some countries, such as The Gambia, prefixed with "The", even when they are not plural (like The Netherlands). * It isn't a question of singular and plural. Some countries do not have true names but only descriptions ("the United Kingdom", "the Czech Republic", "the Netherlands", etc). As for "the Gambia" and "the Congo", they simply use the names of their main rivers (as if England were called "the Trent") - but then Uruguay is similarly named, and we don't call that "the Uruguay". A few take "the" purely by accident of language ("the Ukraine") and this applies to regions as well as countries: consider "the Algarve" and "the Punjab", but not "the Tuscany" or "the Kosovo". All in all, it's more or less random, like most things in language (and I live in the only town on earth whose English name takes "the"). Jim Burfield, The Hague, Netherlands. Les Killip, Newton-le-Willows, Merseyside. * No properly conducted study has yet produced convincing evidence that it has any more value than a placebo. webTitle: Work in progress: David Clayton, editor, The Culture, the Iain Banks fanzine

fields.headline: Work in progress: David Clayton, editor, The Culture, the Iain Banks fanzine
fields.trailText: Editing a fanzine can be a thankless task, but you have to remind yourself one thing: nobody is asking you to do it.
fields.body:
Editing a fanzine can be a thankless task, but you have to remind yourself one thing: nobody is asking you to do it. There's no money in it and filling a 32-page booklet can be a tough job... especially if your co-editor drags his heels as deadlines approach. The object of our labour is The Culture - a quarterly publication dedicated to the works of Iain Banks. Issue 12 - our latest - features an interview with screenplay writer Bryan Ellsey who recently adapted his second Iain Banks novel, Complicity, to add to The Crow Road, which you might remember from a few years back.

It was Complicity that should have given both me and my fellow editor, Neil Scott, our big-screen debut, but things didn't turn out quite like that. We were invited last year to the film's Glasgow set. The cast and crew made a fuss of us and we had lunch with the star, Jonny Lee Miller. In the afternoon, the assistant director asked us if we'd like to be in the film. I'd love to, I said. Neil declined. The cameras rolled and I pottered around in the background as the actors played out the scene. I was in three different shots that would take up about ten seconds of screen time. Later on, Neil was asked again and he reluctantly agreed.

Months later a preview tape of the film arrived. I waited for my big moment but I'd been edited out. And worse was to come: Neil's scene was untouched and, painfully, quite prominent. There he was, standing in the toilet in the newspaper office, as a coked-up Jonny Lee Miller came out of a cubicle.

The cutting room floor can be a tough place...

Complicity is available now to rent. Iain Banks's new novel, Look To Windward, is published next month.

webTitle: London fails to head off MEPs' inquiry into economic spying

fields.headline: London fails to head off MEPs' inquiry into economic spying
fields.standfirst: The European Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Britain became liable to renewed accusations of divided loyalties yesterday when the European parliament set up a committee to investigate allegations of its involvement in a US-led economic espionage network.
fields.body:
Britain became liable to renewed accusations of divided loyalties yesterday when the European parliament set up a committee to investigate allegations of its involvement in a US-led economic espionage network.

Ignoring intense lobbying by the British government, Euro-MPs promised to look into the so-called Echelon system of satellites and listening posts, reported to be used to intercept millions of telephone, fax and e-mail messages.

Britain and the United States have repeatedly denied using Echelon to gain commercial advantages over their European allies. The French counter-intelligence service, the DST, is already conducting an investigation.

The parliamentary committee's mandate is to establish whether Echelon really exists, whether European industry has been damaged by the clandestine interception of communications, and whether the privacy of individuals can be protected from spying.

The committee, chaired by a Portuguese MEP, aims to report its findings in about eight months.

British officials were studying its precise terms of reference last night. As it has no power to summon witnesses or subpoena documents, any cooperation would be purely voluntary.

"It is in danger of being no more than a talking shop," said Heidi Hautala, co-leader of the Green faction in parliament, whose call for a wider mandate was defeated by 340 votes to 210.

Whitehall worked hard to stifle the debate, insisting that any discussion would have to be a general one about the interception of communications, so that other countries' intelligence capacity - notably that of France - would also come under scrutiny.

Britain also pointed to the benefits of intelligence shared with allies in the struggle against drug trafficking, terrorism, "rogue" states and money-laundering.

But the issue is an uncomfortable one for the Blair government, because it highlights and exaggerates its choice of loyalties - to its US or its European partners - at a time when strenuous efforts are being made to advance Europe's defence capacity without weakening Nato.

"We have always made it clear that the civil rights of EU citizens are not jeopardised by legally endorsed interception as practised in the UK," a British diplomat said.

MEPs demanded an investigation after a former director of the CIA, James Woolsey, admitted that eavesdropping equipment had been used to intercept the communications of European companies.

He said it was a question not of industrial espionage but of checking for sanctions-busting and bribery.

Echelon, based at Fort Meade in Maryland and GCHQ in Cheltenham, has out-stations in Canada, New Zealand and Australia, giving rise to the suggestion that it is an anti-European "Anglo-Saxon" conspiracy.

The concern of libertarians, although focused on privacy and accountability, is mixed with a strong dose of anti-American feeling, some of which is shared by governments, especially France's.

But most national capitals are extremely wary about opening up what could prove to be a can of worms.

The French investigation into Echelon is unlikely to be followed through, simply because its own spying could then be easily exposed.

"Anything which focuses attention on Echelon specifically, and the interception of communications in general, is a good thing," said Tony Bunyan of the civil liberties group Statewatch.

"There's no doubt that the UK potentially has an advantage, both in economic and diplomatic matters, over its 14 EU partners."

The shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, accused MEPs of "trying to drive a wedge between Britain and the United States".

"This commission is nothing more than a political witch-hunt," he said. "Anti-American members of the European parliament are being used to put our special intelligence relationship with the United States on trial.

"Robin Cook should make very clear where he stands . . . and condemn this commission and the EU governments who are manipulating this issue.

"For the French to accuse others of running an intelligence service without democratic control is laughable. Who sunk the Rainbow Warrior?"

Useful links:

Anti-Echelon links page
US National Security Agency
GCHQ

fields.headline: The naked truth
fields.standfirst:
Derek Malcolm's 100 greatest movies. This week, number 75: John Cassavetes' The Killing of a Chinese Bookie

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Derek Malcolm's 100 greatest movies. This week, number 75: John Cassavetes' The Killing of a Chinese Bookie
fields.body:
John Cassavetes, the actor, writer and director, was one of the most influential American film-makers of the post-war era - a big claim, since he only had one hit movie and made many which were only shown in art houses. But, at one time, there was scarcely a film-maker who was not inspired by his improvisatory work and his capacity to achieve exceptional performances from actors. He has been called the first American independent.

His hit film was A Woman Under the Influence, in which Gena Rowlands, his wife, was celebrated for her portrait of a family woman pitched into manic psychosis by the pressures upon her. Otherwise, the films of Cassavetes were always more praised than seen and some of the fulsome tributes to him when he died in 1989 were nauseously hypocritical.

Cassavetes acted so that he could make his own films in the way he wanted. Shadows, his first, made well away from Hollywood in 1959, was a huge critical success that prompted Hollywood to sign him up for Too Late Blues and A Child Is Waiting. But both films were compromised and flopped, and he decided to go his own way with funds gathered from taking parts in films such as The Dirty Dozen and Rosemary's Baby.

The result was a collection of films, usually inhabited by Rowlands, Ben Gazzara, Peter Falk and Seymour Cassel. The films were called indulgent and disorganised by those who hated them, but they were adored by his supporters for their passionately truthful depiction of American life.

One of them was The Killing of a Chinese Bookie, a film that displays most of the faults of his kind of on-the-hoof film-making - and all the virtues. Cassavetes always used to say that the emotion in his films was improvised but the lines written. There is no doubt, though, that when he let his actors loose on the set, there were considerable surprises in store.

Ben Gazzara is the star of Killing, the story of the owner of The Crazy Horse West, a failing LA strip joint he is determined to keep open because it's the only thing he's built up from scratch in his somewhat tawdry life. In order to remain solvent, he has to kill a Chinese bookie for the mob. The sequence in which he breaks into the old man's luxurious apartment and does the job is as terrifying as anything in The Godfather.

The film is a thriller, but equally it is a treatise on the sleazier side of showbiz, and on the persistence of hope in almost ludicrously unhopeful circumstances. It's about a man hanging on for dear life to dear life. As such, you could call it pretentious, bombastic, indulgent and full of actorly tropes, concocted by Cassavetes and Gazzara as they progress through a waywardly philosophical tale. Why, then, can one simply not forget it?

It's principally because of its accurate summation of one man's American dream in all its absurdity - the girls in the strip-joint are nurtured almost as part of him, and the club itself, which looks like a particularly seedy purgatory to us, is clearly heaven to him. You can see why he will do anything to save it and feel the sincerity of even the most portentous of his monologues.

Above all, Cassavetes orchestrates the whole thing almost as if it is a dream from which we are about to wake up. But even his most eccentric worlds have a point in them which seems to parallel our own lives. Most Cassavetes films were like that. They didn't make you fantasise, like the best of Hollywood. They faced the messiness of life and then turned to you and said: "But it's the truth, isn't it?"

fields.headline: Whatever turns you on...
fields.standfirst: There's no single ideal form now - just fixations and fetishes. Jonathan Jones continues his search for beauty
fields.trailText: There's no single ideal form now - just fixations and fetishes. Jonathan Jones continues his search for beauty
fields.body:
One of Sigmund Freud's observations about the patients who passed through his Viennese consulting room was that they did not share the same idea of the beautiful. Instead of pursuing what 19th-century culture defined as a legitimate object of desire, they formed weird and wonderful attachments to things no one else would find interesting. One man came to him saying he "exulted" in seeing a certain sort of shine on the nose. This was the kind of encounter that led Freud to develop his theory of fetishism.

You can see how this conflicted with the idea of the beautiful human form that Freud and his contemporaries inherited from the Renaissance. If Michelangelo, instead of sculpting David in his entirety, had confined himself to his nose, western art would look very different.

The story of modern times is the story of beauty's fragmentation. The idea of a universal beauty, an ideal, a norm, has disintegrated. Art has become as idiosyncratic as Freud's patients. Instead of painting a vision of supreme human beauty like Botticelli's Venus, modern artists fixate on fragments, details, bits of the body. Salvador Dali, for example, prided himself on painting women's bottoms better than anyone else; his fellow surrealist Hans Bellmer made life-size female dolls that he delighted in dismantling and putting back together.

Today very few people would say we like to look because we are students of the beautiful. We know our pleasures to be base. We have heard of Freud. Fetishism is main stream culture. And this has consequences for the way we look at art. As the French surrealist Georges Bataille put it: "I defy any art lover to love a painting as much as a fetishist loves a shoe." What does it all mean? Has the religion of an ideal beauty given way to a democracy of perverse pleasures - and if so, is that a good or a bad thing?

According to the feminist cultural theorist Laura Mulvey, the key aspect to Freud's theory of fetishism is that it "involves the overvaluation of something that would not be valued by the rest of the culture. An individual invests their erotic energy into it and makes it into a sexual fetish that can be a replacement for, or an enablement of, an actual sexual relation."

Beauty is to do with wholeness. Fetishism is a pleasure in fragments, explains Mulvey. She is talking specifically about the way we watch films. Mulvey's manifesto reads like the great modern attacks on art, from the Dada manifestos that appeared in Zurich during the first world war denouncing culture as a bourgeois lie to the post-war Paris Situationists who demonstrated against Charlie Chaplin. This phenomenon is explored obsessively, she wrote, in the films Josef von Sternberg made with Marlene Dietrich, in which the close-up overwhelms the film. Sternberg produces the ultimate fetish."The beauty of the woman as object and the screen space coalesce." Today, we are all amateur von Sternbergs, able to fix on the images we like, download them, play with them.

The birth of this culture is anticipated in Alfred Hitchcock's Vertigo (1958). "It's pretty clear now with all the research that's been done on Hitchcock that he was very conscious of what he was doing," says Mulvey. In Vertigo the detective played by James Stewart believes he is simply susceptible to beauty when he falls in love with the woman he is following; but then she appears to die before his eyes and he tries to make over a woman he meets at a hotel to look like her, to replicate her icy blonde beauty. We recognise - as he seems unable to - the madness of it all as he fetishistically re-creates her hair, her dress, her shoes. "It can't matter to you," he tells the young woman he is forcing into this straitjacket of Hitchcockian beauty.

The fetish is about loss, says Mulvey. Stewart in Vertigo is obsessed with reconstituting a lost moment of perfect happiness. For Freud, she explains, the birth of the fetish is always about a sense of something missing; and Marx, too, used it in this way. Marx described the aestheticisation of the commodity in a capitalist culture as "fetishistic". You could see today's plural, consumerist visual pleasures in just this way. For Marx, she says, "what is lost is the worker's labour, which is concealed under the gloss and glamour of the commodity itself".

Mulvey's analysis of fetishism may refer to film narrative and the way we can now disassemble it as we watch, but it can also be applied to contemporary culture generally, the way it is given over to endlessly multiplying and dividing visual pleasures. We value the clip over the film, the aesthetic fragment over the whole. You can see this in contemporary art where the object of desire is systematically broken up and mutated. Take Sarah Lucas's sculptures in which breasts covered in phallic tubular cigarettes float free of the body. Take the American artist Matthew Barney, whose films and installations dissolve the body in glossy make-up, masks and prosthetic limbs. This sensibility began with Andy Warhol's fragmentation of Marilyn Monroe's image in the Marilyn Diptych - which he painted after her death and based on a fan's fetishised photo collection.

The rise of the fetish is the final chapter in the death of beauty as Ruskin imagined it, as a moral language implanted in nature by God. But the point about the fetish, as Mulvey points out, is that it contains a hidden history. For Freud this history is personal, for Marx it is social. It is a history that haunts modern pleasure, and means that every time we console ourselves we are also acknowledging what has been lost.

And the thing we might be missing is the idea of a social whole. For all the oppression and authoritarianism that cling to the old idea of formal beauty, it is also true that it was an image of wholeness. This aesthetic wholeness was connected, in 18th-century thought, with the image of a healthy society. Today we are no more able to talk about political utopias than aesthetic ideals. Is it possible they are related?

Next week: John Berger explores light in painting.

fields.headline: Quotes of the day
fields.trailText:
"The headmaster of top public school Gresham's has warned girl pupils, in all seriousness, that blindly pursuing careers could leave them lonely and unfulfilled. The gist of John Arkell's lecture was that females might end up in top jobs but alas, too late find themselves in their mid-thirties with neither husband nor children. I don't think this was a sketch for Monty Python but it came very close. If fewer Neanderthals like Mr Arkell inhabited this earth, employers might finally accept that it's possible for women to have both a family and a career. Just like he did, in fact"
Sue Carroll, Mirror
fields.body:

The gist of John Arkell's lecture was that females might end up in top jobs but alas, too late find themselves in their mid-thirties with neither husband nor children. I don't think this was a sketch for Monty Python but it came very close. If fewer Neanderthals like Mr Arkell inhabited this earth, employers might finally accept that it's possible for women to have both a family and a career. Just like he did, in fact"
Sue Carroll, Mirror

"I have made it one of my aims to make sure my boys know that No means No. Men don't understand that No can never mean Maybe"
Ealing vicarage rape victim Jill Saward on her three sons, Daily Mail

"The only thing I can say is that being a sex-symbol is the fastest way to becoming a mother"
Uma Thurman, Hello!

"Though not quite as true as it should be, I like to think of myself as the girl who has everything. This fantasy is in constant need of topping up with new personnel, holiday destinations, shoes and upgrades that I can compare and discuss over long lunches with like-minded devotees ... When designer Kelly Hoppen artfully placed two real buddhist monks in the centre of her garden for meditation ... she provided the answer to what the girl who has everything should be keeping in her potting shed. I can't think why no one thought of it sooner"
Emma Soames, Daily Telegraph

"What does the term 'girlie' denote? Something frivolous, frothy, probably pink, just wanting to have fun. Something uncomplicated and disposable. Sticking the prefix 'girlie' on something essentially trivialises it. 'Girl power' is a tragic effort to turn this lack of seriousness and substance into a position of power. As if one can claim power in this world on a platform of heels"
Helen Laville, New Statesman

"I think I must be a new man. I buy flowers, I wear fabulous clothes, I'm caring, nurturing and I love babies. I can cook, albeit at gunpoint, wash up, iron shirts and I always put the loo seat back down. I'm an avid football fan, have speeding convictions, adore manual labour, cry at sad films. The only problem with this litany of must-have masculine traits is that, despite sharing the same name as Mr Macho himself - John Wayne - this particular Marion is a woman"
Marion McGilvary, Times

fields.headline: Of mouths and men
fields.standfirst: Is a kiss ever just a kiss? On National Kissing Day,  Joan Smith reads a few lips
fields.trailText: Is a kiss ever just a kiss? On National Kissing Day,  Joan Smith reads a few lips
fields.body:
Lovers exchange them. Photographers stage them. Italians eat them. Rodin sculpted a naked couple sharing one. In advance of National Kissing Day, there was even a conference in London last weekend about the role of the kiss in history, with discussions of its place in art and culture from Graeco-Roman antiquity to Paris in the 1950s. A slight subject, at first sight, for a serious academic conference? Not according to the organisers, who describe the kiss as "a capacious carrier of much social, political and cultural freight".

A kiss, in other words, is more than just a kiss. It consists, in Freud's passion-killing formulation, of the "sexual use of the mucous membranes of the lips and mouth". But if sex is the first connection that comes to mind when considering the kiss, it is far from being the only one. The programme for the conference, organised by Royal Holloway's Bedford Centre for the History of Women, points out that it ranges from "the stylized performative gesture to the ordinary ingredient of daily conversation" - from stage kisses to perfunctory ones, from politicians kissing babies to a peck on the cheek between friends.

But wait a minute. How many of us have actually witnessed a parliamentary candidate kissing a passing infant? Did Nelson really say "Kiss me, Hardy" as he lay dying? Other theories about kissing claim it is such an intimate act that prostitutes never allow clients to kiss them, but no one ever quotes an indentifiable source for this piece of wisdom. Kissing is so embedded in everyday life, whether in the form of a passionate embrace or an affectionate salutation, that myths have grown up around it and exist, for the most part, unchallenged.

Last weekend's conference set out to examine some of these meanings. There were discussions of the dying kiss in the trenches of the first world war, the kiss of peace in early modern religion, the kiss of life in 18th-century resuscitation. That such attention is being paid to an apparently spontaneous gesture is a step in deconstructing it, for one of the most striking things about the kiss is how often it is anything but impulsive.

The most famous images, such as Robert D'Oisneau's photograph of lovers kissing outside the Hotel de Ville in Paris, often turn out to have been staged. In spite of the woman's apparent oblivion to anything but her boyfriend's passion, they were in fact actors who spent hours under D'Oisneau's direction.

Another celebrated kiss, when the Prince of Wales embraced his bride on a balcony at Buckingham Palace, travelled around the world on TV screens and was reproduced in millions of newspapers and magazines. Yet this picture, which all but cynics and republicans read at the time as a pure expression of romantic love, has now come to represent a very different kind of kiss, that of betrayal.

It is quite likely that both readings are wrong, in the sense that Diana was trying to inhabit a fairy tale and her spouse simply going along with what was required of him; royalty is a species of performance, staged for the masses, and Charles's kiss may have been no more insincere than the Queen's small talk at official ceremonies and garden parties. But the notion of the Judas kiss, the embrace offered with an evil motive, remains powerful. A Kiss Before Dying, Kiss Me Deadly, Kiss of the Vampire, Kiss of Death, Kiss Tomorrow Goodbye and Kiss Me, Kill Me are just a few of the movie titles that explicitly link intimacy, deception and danger.

This is because the kiss is an intimate gesture involving two people whose actions may mimic each other while their intent is very different. It is an unspoken transaction, fraught with opportunities for bad faith and misunderstanding: it may mean anything from "Hello" to "I love you", from "I quite fancy you" to "I would like to have passionate sex with you this instant". Although the distinction between a peck on the cheek and a kiss with erotic intention may seem obvious, the taboo on certain kinds of kissing suggests the opposite, at least in the eyes of some observers.

"The kiss of friendship between men is strictly avoided as inclining towards the sin regarded in England as more abominable than any other," a German travel guide advised in 1819. A recent NOP poll suggests that homophobia is as rampant as ever in Britain: 62% of the men questioned said they would be terrified of being labelled gay if they gave another man a kiss or accepted one from him, while 53% of Yorkshiremen said they would hit a man who tried to kiss them. When Prince Charles greeted his brother Andrew with a kiss at Ascot two years ago, it was unusual enough to cause speculation, though not about his sexuality. Commentators wondered whether it marked a relaxation in royal mores, a perfect example of the weight of meaning attached to this simple act.

Another is the fear, sometimes expressed by pubescent girls who have not received sex education, that kissing can lead to pregnancy. If discussions of kissing almost always lead back to sexuality, it is no accident, for the mouth is a potent vehicle of desire, even if what it is seeking is not always obvious. Naturally it represents appetite, in the sense of being the organ that ingests food, but it is more complicated than that. In the language of romance, kisses are often hungry or greedy, as though one person (usually the man) is intent on devouring the other.

Kissing as a form of insatiable hunger is the theme of Roman writer Catullus's famous poem, in which he demands hundreds, then thousands, of kisses from his lover. The image becomes positively cannibalistic in Under The Jaguar Sun, where Italo Calvino's lovers kiss with the intensity of "serpents concentrated in the ecstasy of swallowing each other in turn". These are potent images, confusing and conflating two pleasures, sex and eating, in a way that supports Freud's characterisation of kissing as an unconscious repetition of infantile delight in feeding.

"No one who has seen a baby sinking back satiated from the breast and falling asleep with flushed cheeks and a blissful smile can escape the reflection that this picture persists as a prototype of the expression of sexual satisfaction in later life," he wrote in Three Essays on Sexuality. In infancy, the flow is one-way, which is a significant difference between a child ingesting milk and two adults kissing; it may explain not only the intensity of the adult experience, but the unconscious fears that seem to accompany it.

It is clearly right to view the mouth-on-mouth kiss not just as a preliminary to genital sex but as an erotic end in itself. If it wasn't, people would not have expended so much energy on banning it in public places, setting limits to how it could be shown in movies, painting it on Greek vases and writing poems about it. No wonder a friend of mine insists that those delicious Italian confections named after kisses ( baci ) are really chocolate orgasms.
