fields.headline: Zorn to be wild
fields.standfirst: John Fordham  sees a star of jazz improv at the Barbican
fields.trailText: When John Zorn, the volcanically productive new-music alchemist, picked up his alto sax at the Barbican this week, the audience braced itself for a ride to the brink of migraine.
fields.body:
When John Zorn, the volcanically productive new-music alchemist, picked up his alto sax at the Barbican this week, the audience braced itself for a ride to the brink of migraine. The American saxophonist and composer had appeared on this stage twice in the previous nine months. But while those occasions featured first chamber music, then a blend of jazz and traditional Jewish music, this time Zorn brought a heavyweight improvising band featuring former Henry Cow guitarist Fred Frith, drummer David Lombardo and bassist Bill Laswell.

Lombardo's sinister tappings heightened expectations at the opening, and sure enough Zorn opened with probably the loudest and longest overblown alto-sax note heard on that stage. The pieces were urgent and succinct, frequently winding up on abrupt crash-stops or circuitous but logical decelerations.

With barely perceptible nods and gestures, Zorn determined who played with whom, and when. While some improv purists might describe this as cheating, the framework kept the audience insured against everything that Zorn and Frith could hurl at it. Nor was it all white-heat improvising. A scrambling, lopsidedly swinging Frith intro brought Zorn to a spine-tingling sax lament, which ended in a trancelike fluttering of the instrument's pads alone. A whirling, repeated Ornette Coleman-like figure brought an exquisite solo of glinting sounds from Frith.

A barrage of squalling between Frith and Zorn gave way to an episode of movie soundtrack atmospherics between Laswell and Lombardo. Zorn made a motorbike sound way below the alto's range and Frith detuned to follow him, but then the saxophonist turned to breezy, dancing figures. It was fluid, restless, wild, and rich in contrast. The audience reaction was ecstatic, despite the mugging of its eardrums by Zorn's ferocious music.

It is 20 years since Zorn first came to London, and the changing reaction gives an intriguing insight into the way the audience for contemporary music is changing, and how the administration of a high-art temple like the Barbican is adapting. Not much more than five years ago, most of the music there was played by the London Symphony Orchestra. Now, in the space of little more than a week, Zorn, the quartet led by saxophonist Michael Brecker and guitarist Pat Metheny, and the great Brazilian composer Hermeto Pascoal are all due to make an appearance. Miles Davis once described the latter as "the most complete musician I ever met in my life".

The current jazz programme is the responsibility of the Barbican's Charlotte Wadham, working with John Cummings of promoter Serious Productions. Wadham rejects the suggestion that jazz is now big at the Barbican because it is easier to sell to curious younger audiences than much contemporary music. "Five years or so ago," she says, "very little contemporary music of any kind was represented here. Then we decided to put our toe in the water. Out of those beginnings Barbican Jazz became a core commitment, but so did our Folk and Roots festival, and a growing involvement with world music.

"I wouldn't deny there is a core jazz audience - you even get to recognise them. But something else has happened, as artists have jumped on this bandwagon to cross and mix the music genres. Now you can't be so sure who you'll get.

"When we re-formed Herbie Hancock's Headhunters, which had hit records 30 years ago, we were surprised by the fact the audience was young. There doesn't have to be one audience for this, another for that. My friends don't hear music that way any more - and neither do I."

Hermeto Pascoal plays the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 8891), tonight. The Michael Brecker/Pat Metheny Special Quartet with Larry Goldings and Bill Stewart follow on July 10.

fields.headline: Of birds and buds
fields.trailText: I hadn't seen them there, down by the stony shore, for years. They ambled over the rocks and then, as if responding to a signal, they all sat down in a circle. Our wild mountain goats seemed to be content with warm weather and a gentle sea breeze.
fields.body:
The Burren, Ireland

I hadn't seen them there, down by the stony shore, for years. They ambled over the rocks and then, as if responding to a signal, they all sat down in a circle. Our wild mountain goats seemed to be content with warm weather and a gentle sea breeze.

Then I visited a site of greater butterworth, some still in flower. As Charles Nelson tells us in his Wild Plants of the Burren and Aran Islands, these Burren colonies are the most northern in Europe, far from the flower's native regions of southern France and northern Spain. The delicately veined, blue-purple flower seems all the more fragile in its rocky setting.

I meandered on, sometimes by stonewalls, sometimes by hedges of fuchsia or wild roses. Then I saw a field of spotted orchids - Wordsworth could apply his verse about daffodils to the myriads of flowers here. And what a year it has been for wild roses - I've never seen Burnet roses in such splendid profusion as they were last month. All but a few have released their petals.

I returned home to find a great tit lying on the tiles in our conservatory, its beak open, a geranium petal caught in one of its claws. I picked the bird up and took it outside to a waist-high Burren rock where we have a water container for the birds. I kept the creature in my palm, my fingers encircling it, for warmth. I gently talked to it, dipping its beak in the water several times.

After about half-an-hour I placed the little bird on the warm limestone of the rock. I rested one hand on the stone and continued talking. Within a few minutes the little creature gave three hops towards my hand, laid its beak on it for a second, looked skyward and then took off, flying away over the roof-top. I watched as the geranium petal fluttered earthward.

Sometimes the creatures of the wild are very dependent on us -it is a frightening thought.

fields.headline: Slavery link shames newspaper
fields.standfirst: America's oldest publication makes front-page apology for profiting from trade in lives
fields.trailText: As corrections and clarifications go it was late and long, but America's oldest newspaper in continuous publication has apologised for its complicity in the slave trade nearly 180 years ago.
fields.body:
As corrections and clarifications go it was late and long, but America's oldest newspaper in continuous publication has apologised for its complicity in the slave trade nearly 180 years ago.

In an 1,800-word article on its front page, the Hartford Courant in Connecticut said it felt obliged to acknowledge that it had profited from advertisements for the sale of slaves and the recapture of runaways until at least 1823.

"We are not proud of that part of our history and apologise for any involvement by our predecessors at the Courant in the terrible practice of buying and selling human beings that took place in previous centuries," said Ken DeLisa, a spokesman for the paper, which sells more than 200,000 copies a day.

The adverts - which cost 25 cents for 10 lines in three issues in the mid-18th century - included detailed descriptions of scars, brandings and amputations.

One read: "To be sold, a likely, healthy, good-natured Negro boy about 15 years old. Inquire of T Green."

This was Thomas Green, who founded the paper in 1764 and who acted, among other things, as a slave broker.

The Courant's role in the trade was raised by Billie Anthony, a teacher whose students found 90 of the adverts while researching African-American history in colonial Connecticut.

She raised the issue after the paper ran a series of pieces earlier this year about an insurance company which apologised for having sold policies to slave owners.

"The stories about Connecticut's slave profiteers had a glaring omission: the Courant itself," said the paper.

"It was accepted practice. Slavery was so woven into the nation's economy and social fabric that such ads were probably less controversial than gun or tobacco marketing would be today."

But Ms Anthony said: "I will never, ever forget the looks of dismay on their [the students'] faces as they were scrolling through all the microfilm and finding these ads and for-sale notices. The complicity of the Courant in the slave trade is evident."

One black student, Andriena Baldwin, said she remembered coming across one listing a young boy, pigs and butter. "We just stood still for, like, five minutes.

"We were just shocked that they would put a person in the same category as food."

Early editors openly embraced racism. Thomas Day, who bought the newspaper in 1855, wrote in one editorial: "We believe the Caucasian variety of the human species superior to the Negro variety; and we would breed the best stock."

Slavery came to Connecticut in 1640 and by 1774 the state had more blacks than any other New England colony: about 6,500, or 3% of the population. As a rule they were treated better than those in the southern states.

But in a 1798 autobiography, Venture Smith, a former slave, wrote of a beating from his master: "I received a most violent stroke on the crown of my head with a club 2ft long and as large around as a chair post . . . the scar of it remains to this day."

Slavery - what the American south called its "peculiar institution" - was banned in Connecticut in 1848, three years before the outbreak of the civil war. Abraham Lincoln declared slaves to be free in the Emancipation Proclamation in 1863.

Richard Newman, a research officer at the WEB DuBois Institute for Afro-American Research at Harvard University, said: "These ads have become extremely useful to scholars because they are one of the few places that describe slaves physically, their appearance, what type of clothes they wore, whether they were literate, what type of talents they had."

fields.headline: Fighting talk
fields.standfirst: Bonnie Greer  on the truth behind the reported rivalry between Anna Kournikova and Liz Hurley
fields.trailText: Bonnie Greer  on the truth behind the reported rivalry between Anna Kournikova and Liz Hurley
fields.body:
On one of the darkest days of my secondary school life, I was sitting quietly at my desk when a note was dropped into my lap. It was a command to meet the biggest, baddest girl in my year, after class, down at the vacant lot. This was not, of course, an invitation to join her in a discussion around the finer points of the Jane Austen text we were studying. Rather, her note ordered me to be present at my own annihilation. In other words, she was going to fight me.

That day, I had made the fatal mistake of daring to carry the latest fashion in school bags before it had been collectively sanctioned and now I had to pay for my transgression in blood. There was no way out, at least as far as my pride was concerned, so I busied myself for the rest of the afternoon looking for allies.

Quaking with fear, I approached a guy I considered a kind of boyfriend. After I had pleaded with him to intervene, to save me from certain death, he looked at me as if I had just arrived from Mars. "No way," he said. "I like to see girls fighting."

This need to see women clawing one another to bits from time to time underlies the coverage given to this week's alleged "cat fight" between Liz Hurley and Anna Kournikova. The pair, who attended a charity tennis match at Buckingham Palace last weekend, have been set up as bitter rivals after it was reported that Kournikova described Hurley as "ugly" in the latest issue of Russian Vogue. Never mind that Hurley has since described Kournikova as "smashing ... a pretty girl", nor that Kournikova has denied the comment. And notice that in the latest news reports, Hurley has progressed from "Liz Hurley" to "Liz Hurley, aged 34". Kournikova is 19. These women must be simmering with barely concealed envy and rivalry, simply because we want them to be.

Let's face it. If a fight breaks out between two men at the pub, we get out of the way fast. If a fight breaks out between two women, we stick around because women fighting, why, that's entertainment - with more flesh exposed and the obligatory bits of blood and hair swishing about. From professional mudwrestling to a set-to in the club car park, women having a go at one another is considered titillating.

Women are always perceived by men to be at odds with their sisters. Confronted with the threat of female solidarity, it's more comforting for them to assume that, deep down, we actually hate each other's guts. This negativity is taken as a natural aspect of womanhood. The female is, above all, the Other. She is sinister and out of control. Consider Ken Follett's remarks about Tony Blair's lack of "manliness". In his world, men are upfront. Therefore to be underhand is to be not a real man but a woman, devious and jealous.

In much of the so-called "city girl fiction", there is always one woman who is The Bitch, The Enemy, the one all the other girls are happy to see get her comeuppance. She is the dark night of the soul made flesh, the part of all of us that continuously checks one another out for flaws, for imperfections. Yet aren't those comparisons as much about finding reassurance and commonality as expressing aggression? The concept of the bitch is an age-old and potent piece of mythology that taints all woman-on-woman interaction. Thus any conflict involving women is thought to be nastier and cruder. And also more fun, especially if it's a matter of "older v younger".

There is nothing more trivialising than bolstering the notion that women consider their appeal to exist only on the surface and, by extension, in their ability to use that surface to snare men. But despite this false framing of women's relationships, there exist on a deeper level complex questions of envy, suspicion and solidarity that are difficult to confront.

How many times have you heard a man say: "You know, I really don't like men. I don't trust them." I've watched my own mother's circle of women friends dwindle over the years and the decline hasn't all been caused by attrition. When I asked her whether she liked women, she said: "No, not really." And that was that, as if I would not only completely understand her but would nod my head in agreement.

But such complexities escape the notice of those who want to believe that because Liz Hurley and Anna Kournikova are two beautiful women, then surely they must be at each other's throats for that reason alone. In the end, it is down to power and the lack of it. As long as youth and beauty are considered women's only currencies, we will always be thought to be on the edge, ready to leap out, claws unsheathed, at the nearest rival.

webTitle: Porno label gives film the kiss of life

fields.headline: Porno label gives film the kiss of life
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: The film director Jean-Luc Godard has joined a growing group of cineastes and performers protesting against the decision by the French state council to classify the film Baise-moi - Fuck me - as pornographic.
fields.body:
The film director Jean-Luc Godard has joined a growing group of cineastes and performers protesting against the decision by the French state council to classify the film Baise-moi - Fuck me - as pornographic.

The protesters, led by the film's directors, Virginie Despentes and Coralie Trinh Thi, gathered outside the Left Bank cinema MK2 Odeon, which has refused to stop screening the film, although it can be legally shown only in specialised cinemas.

The protesters, including the directors Tonie Marshall, Romain Goupil and Claire Denis, were reacting to a decision by the state council to overturn a censorship board ruling that it could be seen by over-16s.

The original decision made it compulsory to display a warning that the film was "an uninterrupted sequence of particularly crude sex and images of particular violence that could profoundly disturb audiences" - a warning which did not mention that the production had been panned by the critics.

It was described as a "bad film" by Le Parisien, as "bad advertising for sex" by Le Point, of "no interest" by Les Echos, and "using ass to sell blood and horror" by the left wing Nouvel Observateur.

But cineastes claimed that the council's decision amounted to a revival of post-war censorship. The X film circuit, which was still profitable 10 years ago, has all but disappeared with the easy availability of home videos. Since then, general release films have become more explicit.

But the question of Baise-moi's content, which was inspired by Ms Despentes's own novel, has been overtaken by anger that the council decision was based on a complaint by an extreme rightwing association, Promouvoir.

The French society of authors, SACD, and the directors' society, SRF, both backed a petition for its general release organised by the director Catherine Breillat, whose own explicit film, Romance, caused a stir last year because of pornographic sequences, but was cleared for general release.

The affair has seriously upset the Socialist-led government and particularly the culture minister, Catherine Tasca, who cleared Baise-moi for the over 16s on the advice of the censorship board, which includes a cross-section of opinion, including church advisers.

She has been accused of allowing the extreme right to control the content of films.

Until it was banned, the film had little success, but the cashier at the MK2 Odeon said there had been a sharp increase in mainly middle-aged filmgoers curious to see what the fuss was about.

"They are extremely embarrassed to ask for tickets for a film with as crude a title as Baise-moi," she said. "They usually mumble, but one couple asked me for tickets to fais-moi l'amour [make love to me]."

webTitle: Company to compensate farmers for GM muddle

fields.headline: Company to compensate farmers for GM muddle
fields.trailText: Farmers who unwittingly planted GM contaminated crops are to get a total of about £1.5m in compensation, the seed company involved said yesterday.
fields.body:
Farmers who unwittingly planted GM contaminated crops are to get a total of about £1.5m in compensation, the seed company involved said yesterday.

They will get at least £337 a hectare, meaning those who planted an average-sized crop of 50 hectares of the oil seed rape, and then destroyed it, will be paid nearly £17,000 by Advanta Seeds UK.

Farmers north of a line between Newcastle and Carlisle will get at least £370 a hectare because of higher yields, and there may be extra compensation where farms were converting to organic status or were on tenancies forbidding GM crops.

About 400 farmers in Britain will benefit from the pay-outs. The money, designed to cover both losses and inconvenience suffered by farmers, is on top of about £1.5m in EU subsidies for which rules were changed to take account of the mistake.

Farmers' unions welcomed the outcome of month-long negotiations. The company has not accepted liability.

fields.headline: Just an everyday disaster
fields.standfirst:
We see the great tragedies but far worse things go on quietly, all the time, writes Tim Radford
The weather: special report
fields.trailText: We see the great tragedies but far worse things go on quietly, all the time, writes Tim Radford
fields.body:
In 1999 there were more disasters than ever before and they killed more people than any year in the decade except one. According to the latest Red Cross report, there were 623 forest fires, floods, landslides, avalanches, earthquakes, tsunamis, epidemics, droughts and volcanic eruptions in Africa, the Americas, Asia, Europe and Oceania. They did economic damage estimated at $72bn, they disrupted the lives of 212 million and they killed more than 80,000.

This death toll was the worst since 1991, when a single cyclone swept over Bangladesh and killed 139,000, and a series of cholera epidemics took 19,000 lives in Africa. Last year, floods in Venezuela claimed 30,000 lives when a hillside collapsed and took the shanty towns with it. It was a particularly destructive year in a destructive decade, ironically declared by the UN to be the International Decade for Natural Disaster Reduction: ironic because there were more disasters, more deaths and greater economic damage at the end of the decade than the beginning.

But the sum of these things, each appalling on its own, was nothing compared to the real catastrophe, says Peter Walker, director of disaster policy at the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies in Geneva. The real disaster was not that 80,000 died from natural calamity. It was that in the same year 30 million died from entirely preventable diseases.

"I have just had a colleague come back from the Sumatra earthquake. It was a huge earthquake in geological terms, and hit a very undeveloped area of Indonesia. But when he gets there, the actual damage from the earthquake isn't that great; the houses are wooden structures so they don't collapse much. But what he found was an endemic problem of rampant malaria, rampant communicable diseases and levels of mortality and morbidity that are totally unacceptable. That is the disaster, not the earthquake."

North Korea is billed as a food emergency, says Walker. But the chronic stunting of children was caused not by hunger this year, but by repeated, year-by-year health problems. North Korea used to be fine: cradle-to-grave security, a doctor for every 134 families and a state which had eradicated tuberculosis. Now there are 40,000 new cases of TB a year, people are giving themselves diarrhoea by eating corn husks and grass to stave off famine and to keep the hospitals warm, the medical staff have had to scrape soot from the chimneys and burn it again.

People who are sick cannot work. People who cannot work cannot feed themselves or their families. People who are not well-fed cannot get better. Poverty and ill health stalk each other, and sick nations end up with sick governments which have been spending up to 50 times as much on military hardware as they do on disease control. Since 1945 a total of 23 million people have been killed in war. But 150 million have been killed by just three infectious diseases: Aids, malaria and tuberculosis.

Since the nuclear reactor at Chernobyl blew up 14 years ago, thyroid cancer figures are rising and deformities have risen 83% in the most contaminated areas of Belarus. Two million people in the region - including 500,000 children - lack adequate health care.

"Those are the real disasters and tackling them isn't done by firefighting. In many ways we at the Red Cross have got to change our arsenal. It is no longer good enough to have the commando troops, we have got to have the infantry on the ground - our volunteers - and they have got to start working in a way that is much more programmed," says Walker.

The African Red Cross and Red Crescent societies sat down with government health ministries, Unicef, the World Health Organisation. They came up with a set of 20 things that could be done in the community, and which could be bankrolled for 10 years rather than one or two. They were simple things that Red Cross volunteers could tackle: clean water, nutrition advice, hygiene education, and vaccination against the great child-killing diseases.

But south of the Sahara, there could be 23 million cases of HIV infection; more than two out of three cases of Aids or HIV infection in the world are concentrated in one continent alone. Life expectancy in Africa had been rising until the nineties. Now it is falling, and in five years it will be back to where it was in 1945. As the average lifespan in Europe heads towards 80 years of comfort, the average lifespan in Africa heads back towards 40 years - because of Aids.

"When you spend your life dealing with disasters, you get used to big numbers. But when you start getting to the size of numbers we are talking about..." says Walker. He starts again. "A child aged 15 in Africa has a 50-50 chance of being infected by Aids. In Zambia, there are 1200 deaths a week from Aids. If that was from political riots, it would be headlines. If that was from famine, the C-130s would be flying. But they are not. In Zambia, again, the rate at which teachers are trained doesn't match the rate at which teachers are dying. Just think of the ramifications. The health system goes, the economies begin to shrink by 14 or 15%, because of Aids."

Who got hit hardest in the Venezuelan floods last December? The poor in the shanty towns on the steep slopes. They live there because the land is not wanted by the rich. It is not wanted because it is unstable, but what choice have the poor got? Recently the World Bank quizzed 60,000 poor people and asked them what poverty meant for them. The biggest factor was poor health.

"It is not about income. If I had my health, I could work, I could support my family," says Walker. People could recover from disaster if they had some control over their own health - if they had health educa tion, reliable advice, clean water and nutrition. That is what public health is about.

"If you know what makes you healthy, if you know you have a disease then you have a chance; you can start to do something about it. If you don't know, you can't. In Africa, it is estimated that something like 90% of the people who have Aids don't know they have got it. All the drug therapy in the world is worth spit if you don't know you have got the disease: you won't get treated. So if we don't turn the way we regard health, and look at public health issues, this problem is going to get bigger."

• World Disasters Report 2000, Red Cross (£15.95)

fields.headline: Ruth Harrison
fields.standfirst: Campaigner revealed the grim realities of factory farming - and inspired Britain's first farm animal welfare legislation
fields.trailText: Campaigner revealed the grim realities of factory farming - and inspired Britain's first farm animal welfare legislation
fields.body:
Ruth Harrison, who has died aged 80, was the first person to open the doors of the factory farm to the public. Her Animal Machines, published in 1964, revealed the indignities and suffering inflicted on farm animals by industrialised agriculture.

Her descriptions of the new agricultural systems, including battery cages for hens, individual crates for veal calves and tether stalls for sows, in which animals were reduced to the status of production units, inspired Britain's first farm animal welfare legislation, the 1968 Agriculture (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act and also the European Convention for the Protection of Animals Kept for Farming Purposes, which was set up by the Council of Europe in 1976.

From the publication of Animal Machines, which was translated into seven languages, until her death, Ruth worked within the political processes to obtain a fair deal for farm animals to ensure that, as she wrote in a contribution to Animals, Men And Morals, an "animal has pleasure in life while it lives and is then humanely slaughtered."

In her lifetime she saw many improvements. Veal crates (1990) and sow/tether stalls (1999) become illegal in Britain. Last year saw the announcement that battery cages will be phased out by 2012, and application of the protocol to the Treaty of Rome, which defines farm animals as "sentient beings" and obliges the European Union to take this status into account when formulating legislation.

Born in London, Ruth read English at London University. She was a member of the Society of Friends (Quakers), working with the Friends' Ambulance Unit during the war and with displaced persons in post-war Germany. Back in Britain she attended the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art and obtained a university diploma, and directed An Inspector Calls with Peter Barkworth and Robert Shaw, being commended for her direction by JB Priestley.

She later worked for a firm of architects. In 1954 she married architect Dex Harrison.

In Britain Ruth served on the Farm Animal Welfare Advisory Committee, (later the Farm Animal Welfare Council), and on those expert independent committees appointed by the Ministry of Agriculture. In Strasbourg, she participated in the Council of Europe's standing committee of the convention on the protection of animals kept for farming purposes, as representative of the World Society for the Protection of Animals and, latterly, the Eurogroup for Animal Welfare. She was deeply committed to the work of the Council of Europe and for the past few years, during her final illness, timed her hospital treatments to ensure that she would be fit enough to travel.

Ruth was enormously respected, but would not suffer fools gladly. She had an innate moral sense, and an in-depth knowledge of farming practices and of the latest scientific papers. When researching killing methods for mink on fur farms, she was asked what she thought of the use of carbon monoxide.

Ruth said this was highly irritant - she had tried it herself in a small experiment and presented the findings to the Council of Europe to assist its discussions on humane killing method for factory farm mink. In fact, she opposed the adoption of standards for fur farms. She believed it was immoral to farm and kill animals for their fur.

She served either as a director or council member of the Conservation Society, Soil Association, Animal Defence Society, Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and Society for the Protection of Animals. Her work for animals won her many awards including the OBE. She lectured extensively in Europe.

Because of her illness Ruth never completed a project to write a sequel to Animal Machines, but the legacy of that book, and her example, will continue to inspire campaigns throughout the world. Ruth will be missed by her family, her friends and by the many animal welfarists, farmers, scientists and campaigners with whom she worked.

Her husband predeceased her. She leaves two children, Jonathan and Jane.

Ruth Harrison, animal rights campaigner, born June 6 1920; died June 13 2000

webTitle: Co-op to end junk food ads on children's TV

fields.headline: Co-op to end junk food ads on children's TV
fields.trailText: The Co-op yesterday announced it would no longer advertise "unhealthy" foods during children's television programmes, thereby assisting government agencies trying to change the way the food industry promotes fizzy drinks, sweets, biscuits and snacks.
fields.body:
The Co-op yesterday announced it would no longer advertise "unhealthy" foods during children's television programmes, thereby assisting government agencies trying to change the way the food industry promotes fizzy drinks, sweets, biscuits and snacks.

The store chain said it would not advertise its products that were high in fat, sugar and salt during children's TV, saying it felt such methods "blackmailed' parents by appealing directly to young people. It would also stop using character and cartoon merchandising.

In addition, the Co-op promised to use a large chunk of its £16m a year TV advertising budget to promote healthy diets among children - such as the need to eat plenty of fruit and vegetables. It will consult the new food standards agency on how best to do so.

The advertising and food industries reacted with suspicion, casting doubts on whether the Co-op move would reduce "pester power", but Suzi Leather, deputy chair of the food agency, said: "This is an interesting idea. Clearly the company is interested in taking an ethical stance on food promotion and labelling. That is to be welcomed."

This latest attempt to meet consumers' concerns' as well as appealing to their pockets follows store wars over offering the best deals on GM-free and antibiotic-free foods, organic and local produce, and products from livestock reared by welfare-friendly methods.

But the Co-op undoubtedly has one eye on government intentions to pressurise manufacturers and retailers to tone down what it perceives as a hard-sell approach to children's advertising. Last month ministers published evidence that the poorest children were suffering most from their generation's failure to eat enough fruit and veg, and were storing up the potential for health problems later.

The food agency's board will discuss the problems later this month before approaching industry executives in attempt to persuade them to voluntarily draw up rules stronger than required by law.

The Co-op, which has 1,100 stores, said the Independent Television Commission should impose restrictions that would effectively stop much food advertising aimed at children. In the past, children's programming would have included Co-op commercials for ready meals, soft drinks, cream cakes and biscuits.

A survey for the Co-op by Sustain, an alliance of food and farming groups, earlier this year found 99% of food and drink advertised to children during Saturday morning television contained high fat, sugar or salt. The figure was 96% for the Big Breakfast, and 95% for children's ITV on weekday afternoons. The figure for adult late-evening TV was 88%.

Cakes, biscuits and confectionery constituted 24% of food advertised on Saturday morning, 46% on children"s ITV, and 53% on the Big Breakfast -compared with a combined figure of 13% for all late evening TV.

The Co-op said: "Our customers, parents in particular, are crying out for action to be taken against the mass advertising of these products to children." Tesco, the biggest supermarket, said it had long set an example in this field by not aiming TV adverts at children or using cartoon characters. It had been the first to ban sweets from check-out counters to stop "pester power".

The Advertising Association said the Co-op move was "corporate strategy masquerading as an ethical policy", and the Food and Drink Federation said there were already codes of practice that banned methods which condoned excessive consumption. "Studies have shown that parents in Sweden,where advertising for children is banned, complain more about children pestering them than they do in Spain where advertising is completely deregulated."

Ads ignore health

Fatty and sugary foods are being promoted at levels out of all proportion to their importance as part of a balanced diet, the Co-op said yesterday.

It commissioned a survey which suggested 70% of advertising during programmes aimed at children involved such products, when they should account for only about 7% of their diets. Yet fresh fruit and veg, which should be taken to the tune of around five portions a day and account for a third of their nutritional intake, were not advertised at all. Bread, other cereals and potatoes should account for another third, but only 16% of advertising was aimed that way.

The advertising industry insists such links are simplistic and that a commercial is not going to make a child immediately eat chocolate instead of an an apple. Companies are more interested, too, in keeping or increasing market share rather than widening the size of a particular food sector and helping competitors. JM

webTitle: Hollywood dogs lap up film-star life

fields.headline: Hollywood dogs lap up film-star life
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: From Lassie and Rin Tin Tin to Skip, 101 Dalmatians, and now the two Great Danes who have big parts in the new Mel Gibson film, The Patriot, dogs have always played a key role in movies, and it is only right that they should enjoy the creature comforts that go with film stardom.
fields.body:
From Lassie and Rin Tin Tin to Skip, 101 Dalmatians, and now the two Great Danes who have big parts in the new Mel Gibson film, The Patriot, dogs have always played a key role in movies, and it is only right that they should enjoy the creature comforts that go with film stardom.

So a Los Angeles hotel, Le Montrose Suite in West Hollywood, is offering dogs a chance to enjoy the luxury previously only available to bipeds.

Dogs spending the night with their owners will be able to relax with a "personal pooch massage" at $60 (£40) an hour or "aromatherapy grooming" for $35.

They can also take advantage of the "quadruped community centre" where single dogs will be able to interact.

Organic dog food will be served to help that difficult unwinding process at the end of the day.

And each animal with an owner willing to spend $189 for the night will be entitled to a "keepsake signature bowl and bone".

If the dogs want to explore the area near Sunset Boulevard, seasonal collars - leather in winter, fabric in summer - are available and they will be able to visit the nearby Chateau Marmutt's day-care centre, where "lonely pets can fend off separation anxiety for a few hours".

A hotel spokeswoman explained: "It's furnished with brightly coloured plastic accoutrements: a fire hydrant, a pool, a picnic table - the room is essentially a quadruped community centre."

The inherent threats to stars relaxing had been taken account of, she added.

"Candidates have to be neutered and all of them are carefully screened to weed out bullies."

Dogs who have had star parts in films have stayed at the hotel during their shooting schedules. Frankie, who was in both Armageddon and Mr Magoo, spent the long months of filming relaxing in the hotel.

Dogs in downtown LA must look on enviously; strays there have been rounded up to be "euthanised" in advance of the Democratic party's convention in the city next month, since it was thought that wild packs of feral creatures might alarm out-of-towners.

Le Montrose hotel already prides itself on being "Los Angeles's only luxurious and discreet hotel hideaway for post-cosmetic surgery care".

That service includes private underground entry and transport to and from the doctor's. Presumably, dogs seeking to perk up floppy ears or sagging tums will be offered the same facility.

As it happens, the creatures that are currently wowing Hollywood are the animated hens from the successful film Chicken Run.

As yet there is not a hotel offering them a special deal, but surely some enterprising hotelier might want to guarantee relaxation to any movie hen tired of the film business and of always being considered an easy lay.
fields.bodyText: From Lassie and Rin Tin Tin to Skip, 101 Dalmatians, and now the two Great Danes who have big parts in the new Mel Gibson film, The Patriot, dogs have always played a key role in movies, and it is only right that they should enjoy the creature comforts that go with film stardom. So a Los Angeles hotel, Le Montrose Suite in West Hollywood, is offering dogs a chance to enjoy the luxury previously only available to bipeds. Dogs spending the night with their owners will be able to relax with a "personal pooch massage" at $60 (£40) an hour or "aromatherapy grooming" for $35. They can also take advantage of the "quadruped community centre" where single dogs will be able to interact. Organic dog food will be served to help that difficult unwinding process at the end of the day. And each animal with an owner willing to spend $189 for the night will be entitled to a "keepsake signature bowl and bone". If the dogs want to explore the area near Sunset Boulevard, seasonal collars - leather in winter, fabric in summer - are available and they will be able to visit the nearby Chateau Marmutt's day-care centre, where "lonely pets can fend off separation anxiety for a few hours". A hotel spokeswoman explained: "It's furnished with brightly coloured plastic accoutrements: a fire hydrant, a pool, a picnic table - the room is essentially a quadruped community centre." The inherent threats to stars relaxing had been taken account of, she added. "Candidates have to be neutered and all of them are carefully screened to weed out bullies." Dogs who have had star parts in films have stayed at the hotel during their shooting schedules. Frankie, who was in both Armageddon and Mr Magoo, spent the long months of filming relaxing in the hotel. Dogs in downtown LA must look on enviously; strays there have been rounded up to be "euthanised" in advance of the Democratic party's convention in the city next month, since it was thought that wild packs of feral creatures might alarm out-of-towners. Le Montrose hotel already prides itself on being "Los Angeles's only luxurious and discreet hotel hideaway for post-cosmetic surgery care". That service includes private underground entry and transport to and from the doctor's. Presumably, dogs seeking to perk up floppy ears or sagging tums will be offered the same facility. fields.headline: Vera Atkins
fields.standfirst: A power behind the SOE's operations in wartime France, she combined loyalty, brains and a seraphic smile
fields.trailText: Vera Atkins, who has died aged 92, was a powerful figure in the Special Operations Excutive (SOE), set up in 1940 to "set Europe ablaze" in Winston Churchill's words by sabotage and subversion.
fields.body:
Vera Atkins, who has died aged 92, was a powerful figure in the Special Operations Excutive (SOE), set up in 1940 to “set Europe ablaze” in Winston Churchill’s words by sabotage and subversion. Atkins worked in Section F, its extremely important French section which sent 470 agents into France, of whom 39 were women. The head of Section F’s London HQ was Major Maurice Buckmaster, but for many people Vera Atkins was the brains behind him.

Born Vera Maria Rosenberg in Bucharest, she moved to England with her parents in 1933, and later adopted her English mother’s maiden name. She read modern languages at the Sorbonne and attended a finishing school in Lausanne. Joining SOE in February 1941, she was Buckmaster’s assistant and soon became, as he said, indispensable to him. The eight-strong London HQ - which also included Lewis Gielgud, brother of the actor - was not in any conventional way hierarchical and there was no part of its work in which Atkins was not involved: interviewing recruits, organising and participating in their training, planning their reception in France. Often she would also help interpret seemingly indecipherable or badly scrambled messages, which had defeated all the efforts of official decoders.

The SOE agents came from all walks of life - they included a music hall drag artist, a racehorse trainer, a banker, a chef - but they all had to speak perfect French. Atkins built up detailed knowledge of conditions in occupied France - curfews, rationing, transport problems, police regulations - so that the agents were briefed on every detail of daily life. She helped provide each agent with a convincing cover story and furnished them with mementos, letters and photos to keep in their wallets, adding verisimilitude to their new identities. She sent one to the dentist in order to have his teeth refilled in the French manner.

Atkins’s remarkable efficiency and intelligence was accompanied by deep humanity and sense of responsibility to those whom she was sending to possible death. She was often businesslike and even severe - “immaculate, every hair in place” with a “detached and seraphic smile” as one agent put it. Sometimes she was mocking: one agent who admitted that he had fallen in love produced the riposte: “Oh the bloody English... We never have this sort of bother with the French...They copulate and that is that.”

But there was no doubting her loyalty to, and fondness for, her agents. She saw them all off in person, and as she recalled years later: “the burden of stress was probably on the person who was seeing them off. The realisation that they were going out on a very dangerous mission, and this was probably the last glimpse they would have of the lovely countryside through which you were travelling with them, while you remained quite safely at the end. There was a considerable strain on one at this time. I think I must have been extraordinarily tough - I was extremely exhausted by it.”

She also kept in contact with the agents’ next of kin, and organised coded messages on the BBC so that they were kept informed about people they had left behind. This solicitude continued even after the war when Atkins, as a member of the British War Crimes Commission gathering evidence for the prosecution of war criminals, set about tracing the fate of the 118 agents who had never returned.

After a year visiting concentration camps and interrogating the German guards, she established how and when the missing agents had perished. (The only unresolved case concerned one agent who had been sent to Marseilles with three million francs in his pocket and was unable to resist the temptation of betting this sum at Monte Carlo: it was never established whether he had won and was secretly living on the proceeds or whether he had lost and committed suicide.)

Atkins displayed formidable skills as an interrogator. Hugo Bleicher, the Abwehr officer who had reaped havoc among the French Resistance, judged her interrogation the most skilful to which he had been subjected by his captors. In March 1946 she also interrogated Rudolf Hoess, the German commandant of Auschwitz, who had been living disguised as a farmer. When asked whether it was true that he had caused the deaths of 1.5m Jews, he indignantly protested that this was wrong: the real figure was 2,345,000.

The French government appointed Atkins a commandant of the Legion of Honour in 1987 (this tardy recognition was because General de Gaulle had never approved of SOE having its own separate French section independent of his London based operations). Eventually she settled in Winchelsea, Sussex, and, although she never wrote her memoirs, her infallible memory was of priceless benefit to historians. It would be a pity if this remarkable figure was remembered only because of the myth that she had inspired.

Vera May Atkins (Vera Maria Rosenberg), intelligence agent, born June 16 1908; died June 24 2000

webTitle: West to fund a new tomb for Chernobyl

fields.headline: West to fund a new tomb for Chernobyl
fields.standfirst: Donors to provide most of the millions needed to repair the shell around the exploded reactor
fields.trailText: Western-led donors agreed yesterday to pledge most of the $768m (£507m) needed to make permanently secure the ageing and leaking concrete sarcophagus built around the melted core of the stricken Chernobyl reactor.
fields.body:
Western-led donors agreed yesterday to pledge most of the $768m (£507m) needed to make permanently secure the ageing and leaking concrete sarcophagus built around the melted core of the stricken Chernobyl reactor.

Delegates from 37 donor states, led by the G7 leading industrialised nations and the European Union boosted the contributions already pledged for work on the Ukranian plant's fourth reactor, which exploded in 1986 in the world's most serious nuclear disaster.

After the disaster, the then Soviet authorities entombed the reactor. But the so-called sarcophagus placed over it began to deteriorate, and at a conference in New York three years ago a group of countries pledged almost $400m for extensive repair and construction work. Most of the money came from the G7 and the EU.

Representatives of the donor states ended a second meeting in Berlin yesterday with the German environment minister, Jürgen Trittin, announcing that the total on offer had risen to $715m.

The prime minister of Ukraine, Viktor Yushchenko, told a press conference afterwards that "expectations have been surpassed". Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, said he expected that the shortfall could be raised at a third donor conference.

The former Swedish foreign minister Hans Blix, who was appointed to run the fund, added that the precise amount needed would depend on exchange rate fluctuations and the cost of the work remaining.

Nothing like it has been attempted before, so companies on the site were operating at the frontiers of nuclear engineering knowledge, Mr Blix said.

"They will have to learn as they go along, and that makes for a lot of additional difficulties," he told the Guardian.

Work began last year on the concrete tomb to isolate fully the molten, intensely radioactive material still in its core.

A vent stack which was in danger of collapsing on to the sarcophagus has been made safe, and beams in the roof were strengthened, but the biggest share of the work - providing support for some of the walls - has yet to begin.

Despite the completion date of 2005 for the reconstructed Chernobyl "shelter", Mr Blix said work might not be finished until 2007.

He expected the new structure to hold good for "a number of decades". After that, an attempt could be made to extract and store the radioactive material inside it.

The entombment project is only part of the overall cost of closing down Chernobyl. It has been estimated that constructing waste storage facilities and building power stations to replace lost output from the site could run to $2bn.

Ukraine, which is in the throes of an energy crisis, depends on Chernobyl's last remaining reactor for 6-8% of its energy needs.

Last month the country's president, Leonid Kuchma, announced that it would be closed on December 15, though he later made clear that this was because it was close to exceeding all safety limits.

To the dismay of environmental campaigners, two new nuclear reactors are being built in Ukraine to replace the Chernobyl plant. Critics have argued that rehabilitating conventional power stations would be safer and no more expensive.

The issue is expected to dominate talks in Leipzig next week between the German and Ukrainian governments.

Mr Trittin, a member of the Green party, which last month pushed Germany into phasing out its own nuclear energy programme, said that he would continue to press for coal- or gas-fired power plants.

fields.headline: Bombs rattle Jakarta's nerve
fields.standfirst:
Paralysed government sees rupiah plunge to 16-month low

Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: Two attempts have been made to bomb the staff of the Indonesian attorney general as they investigate allegations that the former dictator General Suharto, his family and his cronies were involved in 30 years of corruption.
fields.body:
Two attempts have been made to bomb the staff of the Indonesian attorney general as they investigate allegations that the former dictator General Suharto, his family and his cronies were involved in 30 years of corruption.

A bomb estimated to comprise about 2.25kg (5lbs) of explosives destroyed several rooms at the attorney general's office on Tuesday night. Another, twice as big, was found in the building yesterday before it went off.

Jakarta's financial markets, already jolted by regional unrest, a barely functioning government and a very public spat between the President Abdurrahman Wahid and the legislature, tumbled yesterday.

The currency, the rupiah, fell 5% to a 16-month low against the US dollar.

No one was injured in the first blast, which happen an hour after prosecutors finished questioning Gen Suharto's youngest son, Hutomo (Tommy) Mandala Putra.

The national police chief, General Rusdihardjo, said the terror tactics were "clearly political and not criminal in nature", but he added that there was not yet sufficient evidence to link the blast directly to the former president, who is the subject of several corruption investigations.

Brigadier-General Erwin Map, the head of the Indonesian police forensics department, said after inspecting the device yesterday that the bombs were made by professionals.

He dismissed suggestions that this was the start of a bombing campaign against the whole government.

The attorney general, Marzuki Darusman, said he would not be affected by the threat.

"We cannot be deterred in our investigation of Suharto." But he added that security measures, both at his office and around him, would be increased immediately.

Mr Darusman has promised to start court proceedings against Gen Suharto by the middle of next month.

The current investigations are focused on the accumulation of wealth by six charitable foundations Gen Suharto used to control, and the distribution of their assets.

Mr Wahid said last month that he reckoned that Gen Suharto had stolen about £30bn while in office.

He has repeatedly said that he will pardon Gen Suharto if he returns the stolen money.

Three weeks ago Gen Suharto lost a libel suit against the American news magazine Time, which alleged that he amassed a fortune of about £27bn while in office. He has lodged an appeal.

His lawyers say the 79-year-old general is too ill to stand trial, although an independent team of doctors has declared him fit for investigation.

Among those also being investigated are his six children; Mohammad "Bob" Hasan, one of his closest cronies; and the governor of the central bank, Sjahril Sabirin. The last two are in detention at the attorney general's office.

Many analysts believe the bombs are part of a more widespread attempt to undermine Mr Wahid and destabilise the country before a crucial parliamentary session next month, when the president will have to account for his first 10 months in office.

The main element of the destabilisation campaign is a resurgence of Islamic militancy, particularly in the Moluccas, where more than 3,000 people have been killed in 18 months of sectarian fighting.

Radical Islamic groups from Java and Sumatra, with outside help, have begun a massive offensive in recent weeks in the area, known historically as as the Spice Islands.

Mr Wahid has not helped his own cause, however. His constant vacillation over key issues has led to an almost complete policy paralysis, both in central government and at the provincial level.

A western banker in Jakarta said yesterday: "There is no good news out there at the moment, and lots of negative sentiment.

"In the short term things are probably going to get worse."

fields.headline: Franta Belsky
fields.standfirst: Czechoslovak-born sculptor who insisted his art was not for the elite but for the general public
fields.trailText: Czechoslovak-born sculptor who insisted his art was not for the elite but for the general public
fields.body:
In 1940, five weeks after the Dunkirk evacuation, the remnant of the Czechoslovak army which had been formed in France arrived in England and was inspected by Winston Churchill. The prime minister stopped in front of one of the young soldiers, Franta Belsky, who had been operating with a horse-drawn artillery battery that had survived from the first world war.

Belsky, who has died aged 79, recalled that Churchill looked him in the eye for what seemed an age, chin thrust out, hat in hand, leaning on his stick. "You wait," Belsky said to himself, "one day I shall model a statue of you, just like this".

The day came in 1968, when Belsky completed his statue of Churchill for Fulton, Missouri, where the statesman had made his "iron curtain" speech in 1946. In 1988 the then Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, stood near the statue and, commenting that "the sculptor of this statue expressed the spirit of wartime England," announced the end of the cold war.

Born in Brno, Czechoslovakia, Belsky was a major force in British sculpture. He sculpted portrait busts of four generations of royalty, the Queen Mother (for the Queen Elizabeth Hospital, Birmingham), the Queen, the Duke of Edinburgh, Prince Andrew (as a baby and as a young man) and the three-and-a-half-year-old Prince William. He has five works - including three of the royal family - in the National Portrait Gallery, and 15 public sculptures in central London.

He was the first foreign-born sculptor to be commissioned for a work in Trafalgar Square, where Prince Philip unveiled a bust of Admiral Cunningham in 1970. His statue of Lord Mountbatten stands on Horse Guards Parade and his bust of Lord Cottesloe is in the National Theatre.

But his work is not invariably about, and for, the great and occasionally good of the nation. His sculpture of a mother carrying her child in the Town Square, Stevenage, is a burst of joyous action. Like the 30ft Shell Fountain on the South Bank, it is listed as a Grade II sculpture to be preserved even if, as in the case of the fountain, the building it was commissioned for is no longer in use.

These pieces and many others, including his Triga (three rearing horses in Knightsbridge), the Totem in the Arndale Centre, Manchester, and a delightful owl and pussycat on the wall of an infant school in Baldock, Herts, all demonstrate Belsky's conviction that sculpture was not for the elite but for the delight of the general public.

"You have to humanise the environment," he said. "A housing estate does not only need newspaper kiosks and bus-stop shelters but something that gives it spirit."

He did that at Stevenage, where his mother and child spread their arms against nearby trees and mirror their soaring spirit. With the Shell Fountain, "I thought of whirlpools and stagnant pools, of rivulets and brooks; of streams and eddies. I began by looking at shells and listening to Bach's Toccata and Fugue in D Minor... I realised that what I wanted to do was to evolve a sculptural counterpart for the form of Bach's music."

He was never associated with any particular gallery or dealer, believing that younger artists in particular were often exploited. He himself kept free of any connection that might intrude on, or distort, the relationship between the sculptor and the space.

For many years he exhibited at the Royal Academy. Then, at his peak, the selection committee started rejecting his work. The crucial point was reached when the Queen offered to lend him her own cast of the infant William to submit to the Academy. The Academy turned it down, along with two other portrait busts. "Sour grapes," Belsky said. "They were trying to slow me down."

Belsky spent his boyhood in Prague where, at the age of 16, he won first prize in a student sculpture exhibition. He went to art school despite the opposition of his father, an eminent economist. This was replaced by graver concerns when the family sought refuge in England the following year, 1939.

When war broke out, Belsky volunteered for the Czech army. When his unit returned from France to Cholmondeley Park, Cheshire, he carved a memorial stone that marked the Czechoslovak fighting presence on British soil. Subsequently, it was the apparent reason for a mention in despatches, "ridiculous in this context," he would say, reluctantly admitting that there was "a bit more to it." He became impatient when pressed.

Another mention, in France in 1944, was linked with his getting the Czech bravery award for repairing a manual telephone line while under constant fire "in conjunction with some other unpleasantness that I survived," he would say, refusing to be drawn. "All faded now," he snapped, "I just had incredible luck."

After the war, he returned to Czechoslovakia with his wife, Margaret Constance Owen, whom he had met at the Royal College of Art during an extraordinary two terms he was allowed to spend there as a student between the fall of France and the Normandy invasion. A gifted cartoonist, Margaret died in 1989.

In post-war Czechoslovakia Belsky discovered that 22 relations on his Jewish father's side had been killed by the Nazis. His 82-year-old grandmother's body was found dead on the railway embankment not far from her home. He and Margaret left Czechoslovakia in 1948, when the Russians effectively took over the country, but not before he had created the Paratroop Memorial in Prague (1947) and a medal to mark the achievements of the Czech athlete, Emil Zatopek.

On his return there 42 years later he created the Prague memorial to Czechoslovaks who had served with the Royal Air Force, and the statue of Churchill outside the British Embassy. In 1999 the Czech president, Vaclav Havel, gave Belsky, who holds the rank of colonel (Rtd) in the Czech army, the Presidential Medal of Merit.

Second only to sculpture was Belsky's love of skiing, in which he was - until a debilitating cancer forced him off the slopes - both daring and expert. So constant was his devotion to Zermatt that the town gave him a badge which allowed him priority access to the ski-lifts. Spotting it, an Englishman demanded to know who he was and what the badge was for. Belsky found his questioning intrusive, but his interrogator was insistent. "Is it for climbing?" the Englishman eventually demanded. "No," Belsky told the late Alan Clark, MP, " even for social climbing."

He was a long-serving member of the Royal Society of British Sculptors' council, and a governor of St Martins School of Art from 1967 to 1988, when he resigned in protest against the consolidation of London's art colleges. He was a founder member - and twice president - of the Society of Portrait Sculptors.

His studio is at the bottom of the garden of his thatched double cottage in Sutton Courtenay, Oxfordshire, where he joyfully cultivated 30 different species of roses. The house is full of his work, drawings by his first wife, Margaret, and his old friend Ronald Searle. His second wife, the Czech-born sculptor Irena Sedlecka, recently completed a portrait bust of him that captures his patrician looks and his strength. They married in 1996.

fields.bodyText: In 1940, five weeks after the Dunkirk evacuation, the remnant of the Czechoslovak army which had been formed in France arrived in England and was inspected by Winston Churchill. The prime minister stopped in front of one of the young soldiers, Franta Belsky, who had been operating with a horse-drawn artillery battery that had survived from the first world war. Belsky, who has died aged 79, recalled that Churchill looked him in the eye for what seemed an age, chin thrust out, hat in hand, leaning on his stick. "You wait," Belsky said to himself, "one day I shall model a statue of you, just like this". The day came in 1968, when Belsky completed his statue of Churchill for Fulton, Missouri, where the statesman had made his "iron curtain" speech in 1946. In 1988 the then Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, stood near the statue and, commenting that "the sculptor of this statue expressed the spirit of wartime England," announced the end of the cold war. Born in Brno, Czechoslovakia, Belsky was a major force in British sculpture. He sculpted portrait busts of four generations of royalty, the Queen Mother (for the Queen Elizabeth Hospital, Birmingham), the Queen, the Duke of Edinburgh, Prince Andrew (as a baby and as a young man) and the three-and-a-half-year-old Prince William. He has five works - including three of the royal family - in the National Portrait Gallery, and 15 public sculptures in central London. He was the first foreign-born sculptor to be commissioned for a work in Trafalgar Square, where Prince Philip unveiled a bust of Admiral Cunningham in 1970. His statue of Lord Mountbatten stands on Horse Guards Parade and his bust of Lord Cottesloe is in the National Theatre. But his work is not invariably about, and for, the great and occasionally good of the nation. His sculpture of a mother carrying her child in the Town Square, Stevenage, is a burst of joyous action. Like the 30ft Shell Fountain on the South Bank, it is listed as a Grade II sculpture to be preserved even if, as in the case of the fountain, the building it was commissioned for is no longer in use. These pieces and many others, including his Triga (three rearing horses in Knightsbridge), the Totem in the Arndale Centre, Manchester, and a delightful owl and pussycat on the wall of an infant school in Baldock, Herts, all demonstrate Belsky's conviction that sculpture was not for the elite but for the delight of the general public. "You have to humanise the environment," he said. "A housing estate does not only need newspaper kiosks and bus-stop shelters but something that gives it spirit." He did that at Stevenage, where his mother and child spread their arms against nearby trees and mirror their soaring spirit. With the Shell Fountain, "I thought of whirlpools and stagnant pools, of rivulets and brooks; of streams and eddies. I began by looking at shells and listening to Bach's Toccata and Fugue in D Minor... I realised that what I wanted to do was to evolve a sculptural counterpart for the form of Bach's music." He was never associated with any particular gallery or dealer, believing that younger artists in particular were often exploited. He himself kept free of any connection that might intrude on, or distort, the relationship between the sculptor and the space. For many years he exhibited at the Royal Academy. Then, at his peak, the selection committee started rejecting his work. The crucial point was reached when the Queen offered to lend him her own cast of the infant William to submit to the Academy. The Academy turned it down, along with two other portrait busts. "Sour grapes," Belsky said. "They were trying to slow me down." Belsky spent his boyhood in Prague where, at the age of 16, he won first prize in a student sculpture exhibition. He went to art school despite the opposition of his father, an eminent economist. This was replaced by graver concerns when the family sought refuge in England the following year, 1939. When war broke out, Belsky volunteered for the Czech army. When his unit returned from France to Cholmondeley Park, Cheshire, he carved a memorial stone that marked the Czechoslovak fighting presence on British soil. Subsequently, it was the apparent reason for a mention in despatches, "ridiculous in this context," he would say, reluctantly admitting that there was "a bit more to it." He became impatient when pressed. Another mention, in France in 1944, was linked with his getting the Czech bravery award for repairing a manual telephone line while under constant fire "in conjunction with some other unpleasantness that I survived," he would say, refusing to be drawn. "All faded now," he snapped, "I just had incredible luck." After the war, he returned to Czechoslovakia with his wife, Margaret Constance Owen, whom he had met at the Royal College of Art during an extraordinary two terms he was allowed to spend there as a student between the fall of France and the Normandy invasion. A gifted cartoonist, Margaret died in 1989. In post-war Czechoslovakia Belsky discovered that 22 relations on his Jewish father's side had been killed by the Nazis. His 82-year-old grandmother's body was found dead on the railway embankment not far from her home. He and Margaret left Czechoslovakia in 1948, when the Russians effectively took over the country, but not before he had created the Paratroop Memorial in Prague (1947) and a medal to mark the achievements of the Czech athlete, Emil Zatopek. On his return there 42 years later he created the Prague memorial to Czechoslovaks who had served with the Royal Air Force, and the statue of Churchill outside the British Embassy. In 1999 the Czech president, Vaclav Havel, gave Belsky, who holds the rank of colonel (Rtd) in the Czech army, the Presidential Medal of Merit. Second only to sculpture was Belsky's love of skiing, in which he was - until a debilitating cancer forced him off the slopes - both daring and expert. So constant was his devotion to Zermatt that the town gave him a badge which allowed him priority access to the ski-lifts. Spotting it, an Englishman demanded to know who he was and what the badge was for. Belsky found his questioning intrusive, but his interrogator was insistent. "Is it for climbing?" the Englishman eventually demanded. "No," Belsky told the late Alan Clark, MP, " even for social climbing." He was a long-serving member of the Royal Society of British Sculptors' council, and a governor of St Martins School of Art from 1967 to 1988, when he resigned in protest against the consolidation of London's art colleges. He was a founder member - and twice president - of the Society of Portrait Sculptors. His studio is at the bottom of the garden of his thatched double cottage in Sutton Courtenay, Oxfordshire, where he joyfully cultivated 30 different species of roses. The house is full of his work, drawings by his first wife, Margaret, and his old friend Ronald Searle. fields.headline: Watch those balls bounce straight out of the box
fields.trailText: Stephen Bierley (Williams duo waltz into history, July 5), begins: "Independence Day proved one of high celebration for the stars and bars." Given that this term is the nickname for the flag of the confederate states of America, commonly used as an emblem by white supremacist groups, I'd imagine that a Wimbledon semi-final contested by two brilliant Afro-American athletes would be anything but a celebration.
fields.body:
Stephen Bierley (Williams duo waltz into history, July 5), begins: "Independence Day proved one of high celebration for the stars and bars." Given that this term is the nickname for the flag of the confederate states of America, commonly used as an emblem by white supremacist groups, I'd imagine that a Wimbledon semi-final contested by two brilliant Afro-American athletes would be anything but a celebration. The stars and stripes (the US flag) is the flag which celebrates the wins of three American women, in so far as a flag can celebrate.
Virginia Anderson
Leicester
assembly1@waitrose.com

 Terrestrial parents of terrestrial children: do let them hog the box for another week. Why? This week is the last of our five-week tennis season, the end of the time in which children could have built up an interest in and love of the game and found some heroes to follow.

From next Monday our watching season is over for a year. We will only see the occasional final of a grand slam; the US Open no longer (but daily for the two weeks, on Sky TV). We saw the two singles finals of the Australian Open last January on BBC television, although Andre Agassi's great performance was not even mentioned on the ITV News.

During the past five weeks, from the French Open, through the Queen's Club and Eastbourne tournaments, then Wimbledon, children have had a chance to become inspired; their heroes can be American, Swedish or Australian - they don't have to be British. One reason we do not produce British tennis champions is the lack of tennis on TV to sustain children's interest. It would be good if there could be a regular programme showing highlights of exciting matches, plus news and gossip.

During a recent Wimbledon second week, two boys kicking a football around in my street were having a heated argument over whether Agassi or Sampras would win.
Margaret Pryor
London

 BBC Worldwide has just announced record profits this financial year, with exploitation of children's brands and properties realising over £70m. This makes the company the UK's biggest seller of children's media-based products, which it should be, operating as it does from the world's most powerful, subsidised broadcasting springboard. However, it is unfair and discriminatory that children are expected to pay for BBC audio-tapes while they continue to be denied free-to-air radio. Is the corporation scared that families may record stories and songs off radio rather than buy tapes?

A substantial proportion of the £82m profit returned this year for reinvestment in programming should be transparently ring-fenced for the redevelopment of high quality, wide ranging radio for young listeners.
Susan Stranks
National Campaign for Children's Radio

fields.headline: This bank is united
fields.trailText: Charlotte Denny (Don't bank on it, July 4) depicts the World Bank research department as dominated by a so-called ultra-orthodox school of economists. By this she appears to mean belief in a statement which goes something like "only growth matters for poverty reduction and only orthodox economic policies deliver growth".
fields.body:
Charlotte Denny (Don't bank on it, July 4) depicts the World Bank research department as dominated by a so-called ultra-orthodox school of economists. By this she appears to mean belief in a statement which goes something like "only growth matters for poverty reduction and only orthodox economic policies deliver growth". This "school" is set against those who are pro-poor such as Oxfam and Joe Stiglitz, my predecessor as the chief economist of the World Bank.

This polarisation is an absurd caricature. There are many views in the research department, as there should be, but one thesis that would be shared by virtually everyone is that an effective attack on poverty requires both policies to promote growth and direct measures to promote participation and protection of poor people.

David Bryer, director of Oxfam, says in his letter to the Financial Times on June 27, "economic growth is self-evidently essential for poverty reduction . . . but the rate at which growth is converted into poverty reduction depends on the extent to which the poor share in the benefits, which is a function of income distribution". I am in strong agreement with Bryer on this issue as Denny could have discovered from my interview with Larry Elliott in the Guardian, July 1.

The attack on poverty is a deeply serious issue to which Oxfam and the World Bank are devoted and on which they have much common ground. Attempts such as Denny's to polarise the debate into growth versus income distribution try to create a sham conflict and devalue the discussion.
Prof Nicholas Stern
Chief economist, World Bank Group

fields.headline: United by euro doubts
fields.trailText: The government's continued refusal even to acknowledge its major implications for political union has reached the point where its whole credibility is at risk. Not one of its European contemporaries fails to recognise the consequences of the single currency for political union - and to applaud it for just that reason.
fields.body:
Hugo Young and I disagree on most things to do with the UK and Europe, including our assessment of the benign or malign effects on the UK economy of Britain joining the euro. But I find myself in agreement on one vital matter (Never mind the economics, the euro is a political issue, July 4): the single currency.

The government's continued refusal even to acknowledge its major implications for political union has reached the point where its whole credibility is at risk. Not one of its European contemporaries fails to recognise the consequences of the single currency for political union - and to applaud it for just that reason.

If our more ardent Europhiles are still capable of rational consideration of these matters, do they really think that Chancellor Kohl signed up to economic and monetary union, and the single currency, in order to give greater strength and stability to the deutschmark?

The pretence that political and constitutional issues are not at the centre of the whole enterprise deserves language a good deal stronger than Hugo Young's "government evasions".

This fundamental dishonesty not only distorts the debate inside the UK, but is inflicting increasing damage to our reputation abroad, not least in the European Union.
Lord Shore of Stepney

fields.headline: With friends like these. . .
fields.trailText: Dylan Thomas once said to a friend: "Stick to the Labour party, whatever the weaknesses; the alternative is the Conservatives, infinitely worse." Jonathan Freedland (Careless talk costs votes, July 5) has finally woken up to that fact.
fields.body:
Dylan Thomas once said to a friend: "Stick to the Labour party, whatever the weaknesses; the alternative is the Conservatives, infinitely worse." Jonathan Freedland (Careless talk costs votes, July 5) has finally woken up to that fact.

I have been a member of the Labour party on and off for 40 years, including being a constituency chairman in 1964 and a parliamentary candidate in 1966. In the 80s, given the chaos of the Livingstone and Militant Tendency dominated party, I joined the SDP then through to the Liberal Democrats.

Despite the flimsiness of Lib Dem politics, it was a pleasure to be somewhere free of the vicious back-biting that bedevils Labour. But why is it that the press does not acknowledge its part in this? As ever, there is a scurrilous tirade from most papers, but what is devastating is that supposedly friendly papers like the Observer and Guardian regularly publish the Folletts, the Hattersleys and the Foots.

We have without question the best government since Attlee's and they had the advantage of coming straight from the wartime coalition. Yet they have to put up with constant ignorant criticism from their supposed friends.
Ian Hamilton
Richmond, Surrey

 Jonathan Freedland's warning is timely. A smiling William Hague could haunt us for another 13 years. The last election was simply an example of people finally getting fed up with the Tories and giving Labour a break. The only way for Labour to win the next election - with a reasonable margin - is for both the old and the new wings to forget their differences and start putting in the necessary work in the vulnerable constituencies. The last election was won by history, the next one will really depend upon effort.
Dr Arthur Gould
Loughborough University
A.R.Gould@lboro.ac.ukew

 If Ken Follett is right (and he has so far provided not a shred of evidence for his allegations), why doesn't he name his sources? For that matter, why doesn't the Guardian name names, rather than basing so much of its political reporting on non-attributed "sources"? Or are you afraid that would reveal the real spinners to be newspapers themselves?
Ben Bradshaw MP

 The real problem facing the disaffected members of the Labour party is not so much Tony Blair's alleged imperious manner or the "spinners of Downing Street", but William Hague. Activists in the Labour party have always found it beneficial to have a personalised enemy - something they enjoyed under Thatcher. It's impossible to demonise Hague, however. While they may gain cathartic satisfaction from their outbursts, they might remind themselves that, despite the reassurance of the polls, mud still sticks.
R G Jenkins
Hove
Reg.Jenkins@btinternet.com

 I am dismayed to find myself agreeing with Ann Widdecombe (Police push Blair into yob fines climbdown, July 4) when she says of Blair's scheme: "Anyone with an ounce of common sense would have seen that this scheme was unworkable."

That the prime minister should have made such an error of judgment causes me concern. This incident may seem trivial, but it is not the first instance of his lack of wisdom, and I wonder what he might do when he has to make a really important and well-informed decision. He seems to have developed a trait which prevents him listening to advice and changing course even when he is clearly locked into a nose-dive.
Colin Hartley
Deal, Kent
