fields.headline: Mothers' boys
fields.trailText: Criminologists still fail to address the fact that violence against the person is overwhelmingly committed by males - by no means all from poverty-stricken homes (Lost boys of Thatcherism, July 5).
fields.body:
Criminologists still fail to address the fact that violence against the person is overwhelmingly committed by males - by no means all from poverty-stricken homes (Lost boys of Thatcherism, July 5). If the rise in such crimes was attributable to poverty and violence-inducing parental patterns as Oliver James suggests, how come young women are immune?
Professor Sue Lees
University of North London

 Beatrix Campbell jumps to two predictably wrong conclusions in her tract on young male delinquency (Missing the target, July 3). According to her, mothers targeted by parenting orders tend to have been victims of childhood abuse and domestic violence, so shouldn't be "scolded" for bringing up criminals. Living with violent or abusive partners is a choice; until we all stop pretending otherwise, nothing will change.

Second, Jack Straw's reference to "young children running riot at night" is not "irrelevant". In London children are still shoved on to the streets every evening by parents (mothers) who don't want them around. The kids consider crime and antagonistic relationships with authority in all its forms to be an essential element of their group "character". And, no, they are not poor or deprived in any material way: just people for whom lawlessness is the traditional way of life.
Stephanie Calman
London

 Your correspondent evidently heard a sanitised version (The price of caging football's louts, July 5). The beer-drinking English gentlemen I remonstrated with on the Brussels Eurostar concourse were chanting: "I'd rather shag a Paki than a Turk."
Chloe Starr
Darlington

We said that Nord Anglia Education plc was led by Kevin McNeary. His name is Kevin McNeany (apologies for that). The turnover which increased by 11% was the interim or half-year turnover. It went up to £31.2m (not £1.2m). In the same panel we described the Centre for British Teachers (CfBT) as one of the biggest Ofsted inspection contractors. It used to be but no longer does that work for Ofsted. In the article itself we said that Cambridge Education Associates were coordinating the training for heads and management consultants implementing the government's performance-related pay package. That was wrong. CfBT is coordi nating the training and then, from September this year, CEA will work with schools to implement the process.

fields.headline: Science off the boil
fields.standfirst: Mr Brown's boost is only a start
fields.trailText: A few decades ago, our scientists were the equal of any in the world. Now they are the poor relations - producing, for the most part, good work on paltry salaries in dilapidated laboratories; our investment in research trails woefully behind Finland and Iceland. Our Nobel prize count has dropped dramatically.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's largesse towards British science - £325m for investment in laboratories and equipment in 2002-3 with a further £450m the following year - is a welcome boost, but this has to be seen as a kickstart rather than a one-off goody-bag which will put right 18 years of Tory short-termism. A few decades ago, our scientists were the equal of any in the world. Now they are the poor relations - producing, for the most part, good work on paltry salaries in dilapidated laboratories; our investment in research trails woefully behind Finland and Iceland. Our Nobel prize count has dropped dramatically. Between 1940 and 1980 British laboratories averaged 10 Nobel prizes each decade; since 1980, there have been only six. Already, Britain is in danger of losing out to the US on most of the new bio-medical revolution emerging on the back of the genome project. Helping Britain catch up, and keep up, will require many more forays into Mr Brown's coffers.

But the dangers to the vitality of British science are now not simply financial. Scientists are concerned at the growing public hostility to their work, from Prince Charles down; blame for issues as diverse as BSE and GM are (often erroneously) laid at the door of science. The popular suspicion affects the way research is regulated - for example, we reported earlier this week on restrictions on animal experiments holding back scientists. These attitudes are also deterring bright youngsters from studying science; 40 years ago, 50% took three sciences at A-level; now it is less than 20. At university level the picture is even grimmer, with many physics departments forced to close in the last 15 years for want of applicants. The paradox is that this decline has paralleled a huge rise in the sales of popular science books which have made scientists into best-seller celebrities. The challenge now is how to convert that interest into a new generation of Nobel prize winning scientists.

fields.headline: Betrayed by the weather
fields.standfirst: The night the Titanic sank was so calm it hid the tragedy ahead, writes  Paul Simons
fields.trailText: The night the Titanic sank was so calm it hid the tragedy ahead, writes Paul Simons
fields.body:
She was one of the largest ships in the world and the pride of the White Star Line. RMS Titanic steamed into a large iceberg off the Grand Banks of Canada just before midnight on April 14, 1912 and sank.

The bones of the disaster have been picked over in minute detail, but one mystery remains. Why didn't the lookouts on the Titanic spot the iceberg in time when the conditions at sea were perfect and avoiding action could so easily have been taken?

Research by Edward Lawrence, a scientist at the Meteorological Office for more than 30 years, shows that the role of the weather has been sorely overlooked in the Titanic's fate. In the journal Weather, he has re-examined the testimony of eyewitnesses and pieced together circumstances which together created a lethal setting for the disaster.

The most obvious thing all the survivors from the Titanic remarked on was the eerie calm. "Perfect serenity for miles... the water looked like molten silver," one passenger reported. These are the sort of conditions maritime experts expect in the North Atlantic only once in a lifetime.

"Everyone thought the weather was so lovely it couldn't have had anything to do with the sinking," explains Lawrence, "But the weather was a crucial factor." In fact it was too calm as the Titanic's second officer, Lightoller, pointed out to the subsequent British accident inquiry.

Without any swell there was no phosphorescence from plankton in the sea which would have glowed around the iceberg like a warning beacon. And although the sky was sparkling with stars there was no moon, so a lookout would have seen an iceberg only at less than a quarter of a mile away, and with the Titanic steaming at 22 knots (25 mph), that would allow only 30-40 seconds' warning.

To make matters worse, the iceberg itself was said to be dark, possibly because it was carrying a load of moraine from its original birthplace off one of Greenland's glaciers. But there was one good signal of icy waters ahead and it came earlier in the night when the temperature aboard the ship suddenly plunged from 6 C to -0.6 C in just two hours. This sudden chill was probably caused by iceberg meltwater spreading out over the sea surface, with cold air sliding off the exposed parts.

But this warning was ignored because usually when a ship approaches an iceberg the temperature first rises before it falls, and the calm conditions may have prevented the normal sequence of events. In fact, the Titanic had sailed into a field of massive icebergs, some of them over 200ft high, and by the time the liner Carpathia had come to her rescue at 4am the sea was swarming with them.

A stiff northerly wind had also blown away the mill pond conditions and the Carpathia was itself in extraordinary danger of colliding with some of the two dozen or so icebergs now floating around. The whole rescue operation was horrendous, as stewardess Violet Jessop later wrote in her memoirs: "The sea became more violent, tossing our overloaded boat helplessly about." There was also a vicious windchill. "The wind rose to an icy keenness cutting through our numbed bodies," she recorded, "an icy blast across my face felt like a knife in its penetrating cold."

With the temperature of the sea now at -2 C, plus the windchill, no soul left in the water stood a chance of surviving. So with no moon, no wind, no swell and a dark iceberg, the Titanic had sailed into a very peculiar set of cir cumstances. But it also faced yet another piece of bad luck. April is one of the worst months for icebergs in the North Atlantic, and that year icebergs had pushed unusually far south. On average only 70 icebergs in April get past Newfoundland at latitude 48 N, where they sweep into the open North Atlantic and the busiest shipping lanes in the world. But the Titanic was much further south at 41 N, so for more than 20 bergs en masse to reach this point was extraordinary.

Lawrence suggests that the number of icebergs in the North Atlantic matches the 11-year cycle of sunspots. These gigantic magnetic storms raging across the surface of the sun spew highly charged electrical particles into space which can batter the earth's own magnetic field. This also causes the magnificent auroras at the poles, as the surge of electrical energy rips along the earth's magnetic field and sets gases glowing in the upper atmosphere like a fluorescent light.

Sunspots have been linked with dozens of other phenomena, from cyclones, thunderstorms, and droughts to mild winters although quite how they could influence the weather is hotly debated. Lawrence believes that a year or two before the sunspots reach the lowest numbers in their cycle, northerly winds and cold waters sweep icebergs much further south into the Atlantic. As the Titanic sailed just a year before the sunspot minimum of 1913, she caught the worst possible time to sail into icy waters.

What is certain is that the iceberg tore into the hull 20 feet below the waterline, 39,000 tons of water surged in, the pressure was so intense the vessel eventually broke in half, and sank. And the orchestra did indeed play on. The saddest part of this whole story is that just 50 miles south the Carpathia had been basking in a warm breeze coming off the Gulf Stream, where icebergs meet their final meltdown.

webTitle: Fijian rebels given two days to leave

fields.headline: Fijian rebels given two days to leave
fields.standfirst: The Fiji coup: special report
fields.trailText: The Fijian military authorities told the rebels who have been holding the deposed prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and 26 other hostages in the parliament for the past six weeks that they have two days to leave the building.
fields.body:
The Fijian military authorities told the rebels who have been holding the deposed prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and 26 other hostages in the parliament for the past six weeks that they have two days to leave the building.

They said they were creating a no-go zone around the sprawling parliament complex, but the "military option" had been ruled out.

"The decree will come into effect from midnight tonight . . . everyone in the parliamentary complex will be given 48 hours to move out," their spokesman, Lieutenant-Colonel Filipo Tarakinikini, said.

Similar amnesty offers have been made before, but the military ruler, Commodore Frank Bainimarama, said that George Speight and the rebels he leads would be charged with taking hostages if they did not take up the latest offer.

The rebels' spokesman, Joe Nata, said any of them was free to go.

"We will announce tomorrow that anyone that wants to leave, especially women and children, will be free to leave," he said.

"But we don't expect anyone to take up the offer, because we are all committed to the rights of indigenous Fijians."

Mr Speight and his gunmen stormed parliament on May 19 in the name of indigenous rights, seizing Mr Chaudhry, Fiji's first ethnic Indian prime minister, and his multi-racial cabinet.

He demanded an end to Indian political power.

Indians were first brought to Fiji about 100 years ago to work on sugar plantations. They now make up 44% of the population and dominate the economy.

Comm Bainimarama said that negotiating with the rebels was still an option, and he hoped both sides would focus on freeing the hostages. "The military will not consider the military option," he said.

The imposition of an exclusion zone around the parliament comes after a gun battle between troops and rebels on Tuesday in which three civilians and two armed rebels were wounded.

Military officials said later that inexperienced troops had overreacted to a crowd of rebel supporters when they emerged from the parliamentary compound.

webTitle: Letters tell of suspect's suicide aim

fields.headline: Letters tell of suspect's suicide aim
fields.trailText: Sid Ahmed Rezala, who died in a Portuguese prison while awaiting extradition to France on charges of killing a British student, wrote to his parents and girlfriend indicating that he wanted to commit suicide.
fields.body:
Sid Ahmed Rezala, who died in a Portuguese prison while awaiting extradition to France on charges of killing a British student, wrote to his parents and girlfriend indicating that he wanted to commit suicide.

Rezala, 21, died of suffocation in a Lisbon jail last week after setting fire to his mattress, but there were doubts as to whether it was an accident or suicide.

His last letters make no mention of the murdered student, Isabel Peake, 20, or two other alleged victims, but make it clear that he would not return to France for trial.

In a letter to his girlfriend in Amiens he said he no longer wanted to cause suffering and preferred "to leave and settle my accounts with God".

Three of Rezala's childishly written, error-strewn letters were published in the French weekly VSD yesterday. All carried the same theme of self-destruction because he felt he had "lost everything in my life and the only way out is to return to my creator".

Rezala, who allegedly murdered Peake, a Birmingham University exchange student, by throwing her out of a night train window in October, fled France in December. French police claimed he had also killed Corinne Caillaux, 36, in the Paris-Ventimiglia sleeper, and strangled a former girlfriend, Emilie Bazin, 20, in Amiens.

Police revealed that he had a record of violent sex offences against men and women. VSD published a long interview with a prisoner, identified as Manuel, who said Rezala had "pretended to be mad" to avoid extradition and was ready to commit murder in prison so he could be judged in Portugal rather than France. But he had not meant to kill himself.

fields.headline: Bahrain jails Briton for stabbing
fields.trailText: A Bahraini court has sentenced Richard Mechan, of Gloucester, to 15 years in prison for the manslaughter of an American man this year, the English-language Gulf Daily News reported yesterday.
fields.body:
A Bahraini court has sentenced Richard Mechan, of Gloucester, to 15 years in prison for the manslaughter of an American man this year, the English-language Gulf Daily News reported yesterday.

The newspaper quoted Mechan's lawyer as saying his client planned to appeal against the sentence in September. Mechan denied manslaughter, saying he acted in self-defence.

The paper said Marshall Earl Emmons, 31, a fibre-optics engineer from Tucson, Arizona, was knifed at a housing compound in Bahrain during a visit to the island state in January.

Mr Emmons, who had been working in the Saudi Arabian eastern province city of al-Khobar, was on his way to Amsterdam at the time, his family were quoted as saying.

Mechan also worked in al-Khobar and was on holiday in Bahrain at the time of the stabbing. Reuters

webTitle: Ski centre fined after novice dies

fields.headline: Ski centre fined after novice dies
fields.trailText: A dry ski centre was yesterday fined £13,500 after a schoolboy skiing for the first time died when he hit a barrier.
fields.body:
A dry ski centre was yesterday fined £13,500 after a schoolboy skiing for the first time died when he hit a barrier.

Antonio Dispenza, 13, was not asked if he had skied before and went to the main slope instead of the nursery slope at Wycombe Ski Summit at High Wycombe in Buckinghamshire.

He died from head injuries after "hurtling" into the barrier, Aylesbury crown court was told.

Mark Bishop, prosecuting, said a catalogue of errors by Wycombe Summit Ltd led to the "foreseeable" accident on December 5 1998. In similar accidents, James McGee, 10, broke his leg eight months earlier, and Ben Thomas, 11, broke his the month before Antonio's death.

Antonio, of Maidenhead, Berkshire, crashed at 30mph head first into a foam-padded barrier at the bottom of a 100-metre slope.

Staff let the "complete novice" on to the slopes all afternoon with more experienced friends despite regulations requiring skiers to be competent in parallel turns.

Mr Bishop, prosecuting for the health and safety executive, added: "[Antonio] was seen standing at the top of the slope and asked the boys questions about how to stop."

The firm admitted one charge of failing to review risks after an accident and two counts of failing to ensure the safety of two skiers, Antonio and Ben Thomas.

Roger Eastman, defending, said the death had shocked the company. But he said it had been a "freak accident", and that only 0.2% of 125,000 customers a year were involved in accidents.

Judge John Slack ordered the firm to pay costs of £10,000 on top of a fine of £13,500.

Press Association

webTitle: Malaysian forces lay siege to jungle hideout

fields.headline: Malaysian forces lay siege to jungle hideout
fields.trailText: Thousands of police and soldiers are laying siege to a hamlet in the hills of northern Malaysia where a group of men armed with stolen military weapons are holding three hostages.
fields.body:
Thousands of police and soldiers are laying siege to a hamlet in the hills of northern Malaysia where a group of men armed with stolen military weapons are holding three hostages.

Two soldiers were injured and one of the gunmen was believed killed yesterday in sporadic exchanges of fire as the group tried to break through a security cordon around their jungle hideout. They are believed to have used a grenade launcher in a failed attempt to clear a path.

The local military commander, Lieutenant-General Zaini Said, said that around 30 gunmen had split up into small groups of two or three and were engaging the security forces in several places.

The chief of police, Norian Mai, said the gunmen belonged to a little-known Islamic spiritual cult with "certain political motives" - but he declined to name the group. He said there were several ex-army men in their ranks.

That military background enabled them to carry out what Malaysian newspapers are calling a "Hollywood-style heist" at two arms depots about 150 miles north of Kuala Lumpur.

Posing as senior army officers carrying out surprise inspections, the 15 raiders - dressed in camouflage fatigues and speaking "army lingo" - tricked their way past sentries. They then seized more than 80 M-16 rifles, more than 10 machine guns, five grenade launchers and 6,000 rounds of ammunition.

Initially it was assumed that the gang stole the weapons, worth more than £140,000, to sell on the black market to pirates or guerrilla groups in south-east Asia, such as the Acehnese separatists in neighbouring Sumatra.

But they did not head for the Thai border, 13 miles away, as expected. Instead, they took the arsenal south to Jenalik, near the town of Sauk.

Local farmers reported seeing "armed men in army greens wearing red and white turbans and skull caps" enter the jungle near their tropical fruit orchards.

The Malaysian Sun newspaper spoke to villagers who saw the men lugging a generator and cooking utensils up to their hideout. They were traced to Jenalik through their vehicles, which were found abandoned nearby.

By the time the security forces surrounded their hideout on Tuesday, the gang had taken three hostages - two special branch police officers who were reportedly sent to infiltrate the group and an ethnic Chinese fruit picker. The captives are reported to be in good health.

The defence minister, Najib Tun Razak said yesterday that there had been "no formal contact" with the hostage takers and they had not yet made any demands. He claimed that the government could not reveal who they were for security reasons.

"We appeal to their good sense, if they have any, to surrender and give up what they are doing," he added.

webTitle: Pigeons get their day in court

fields.headline: Pigeons get their day in court
fields.trailText: A flock of pigeons which has taken up residence beneath a railway bridge stood accused at the high court yesterday of posing a public nuisance and a threat to human health.
fields.body:
A flock of pigeons which has taken up residence beneath a railway bridge stood accused at the high court yesterday of posing a public nuisance and a threat to human health.

The birds, which roost under the bridge in Balham High Road in south London, have for years been blamed for fouling the footpaths and spattering pedestrians. Now Mr Justice Gibbs is being asked to decide who is responsible for clearing up the mess and getting rid of the pigeons.

The London borough of Wandsworth is suing Railtrack for the £11,000 annual cost of cleaning the footpaths under the bridge seven days a week. It is also seeking a declaration that getting rid of the birds is Railtrack's responsibility, and an injunction forcing it to evict the pigeons and put up netting, at a cost of £9,000, to stop their return.

Railtrack insists the council is responsible.

Anthony Porten QC, for Wandsworth, said Railtrack owned the bridge and the council was responsible for maintaining the footpaths and ensuring safety.

He said pigeons had been roosting there "for at least the past 15 years" and their droppings made the paths so slippery they were a danger. Pedestrians had complained of being hit by bird droppings and there were concerns that salmonella posed a threat.

Mr Porten said: "Railtrack have not spent one penny of their money, nor are they prepared to take any steps to remove the nuisance."

The hearing, which was adjourned until today, is expected to end tomorrow.

fields.headline: Afghanistan intellectuals under threat
fields.trailText: Hundreds of Afghan academics and former politicians who have taken refuge in Pakistan are in danger from Islamic extremists, the chairman of the Pakistani Human Rights Commission said yesterday.
fields.body:
Hundreds of Afghan academics and former politicians who have taken refuge in Pakistan are in danger from Islamic extremists, the chairman of the Pakistani Human Rights Commission said yesterday.

Last month an Afghan writer was seriously injured by gunmen in Peshawar. Two weeks later Pakistan expelled a liberal professor: the first time it has deported an Afghan academic. Now the extremists are thought to be preparing to attack other liberals opposed to the hardline Taliban regime in Kabul.

"This is a message to other Afghan liberals to keep their mouths closed," the commission chairman, Afrasiab Khattak, said.

"They are in serious danger. Muslim fundamentalists will hunt them and kill them."

Scores of Afghans living in Peshawar, just two hours' drive from the Khyber Pass, have been killed in attacks by rival mojahedin groups since the Soviets finally retreated from Afghanistan in 1989.

Now, for the first time, refugees are being picked on for their opposition to the Taliban, who seized Kabul four years ago and imposed their brutally strict interpretation of Islamic shariah law.

Mohammad Enam Wak was injured in an assassination attempt after publishing a book arguing that few in Afghanistan supported the Taliban. Gunmen burst into his Peshawar home and shot him in the chest and twice in the arm.

Then Abdul Rehman Elham, a former professor at Kabul University and a critic of Islamabad's support for the Taliban, was ordered to leave Pakistan and return to an uncertain future in Afghanistan. He was reported to have been expelled for "anti-Pakistan activities".

"This is the first time the Pakistan government has deported an academic. It is a major policy shift," Mr Khattak said. "People like Professor Elham would face death at the hands of the Taliban."

Leaders of the Afghan community in Peshawar believe that friends have taken Mr Elham into hiding in the lawless tribal areas along the border rather than hand him over to the Taliban.

Amnesty International, which protested to Pakistan about the deportation, said scores of prominent Afghans had been jailed and tortured by the Taliban in the past two years for supporting the idea of a multi-ethnic government.

More than 2m Afghans are refugees in Pakistan, with little legal protection from the state. Many live in Peshawar, where their neighbours are mojahedin commanders, Taliban fighters and pro-Taliban Islamic extremists.

Abdul Rashid Waziri believes his name is high on the hit list drawn up by the radicals. For five years he was a minister in the pro-Soviet government of Mohammad Najibullah before it was brought down by Pakistan-backed mojahedin groups in 1992.

Since then he has lived in Peshawar, too frightened to return home. "The leader of the Taliban says everybody is allowed to go back to Afghanistan, except the communists," he said.

Several times he has gone into hiding after being warned his life was in danger, and he now changes his address every few months.

Hundreds of other Afghans in Pakistan share Mr Waziri's hatred of the Taliban. Most support the idea of a multi-ethnic government led by the former king, Zahir Shah.

"There is a great security problem. My name is always on the top of the hit list. But we cannot cooperate with the undemocratic government in Afghanistan," he said.

"And now Pakistan is changing because the Islamic groups are very powerful and want to impose an Islamic order. They will kill me, I know that."

webTitle: Tory anger over Welsh pub name

fields.headline: Tory anger over Welsh pub name
fields.trailText: Directors of an independent brewing company have defended a decision to name their flagship pub after a Welsh separatist leader who was jailed for public order offences on the eve of Prince Charles's investiture as Prince of Wales more than 30 years ago.
fields.body:
Directors of an independent brewing company have defended a decision to name their flagship pub after a Welsh separatist leader who was jailed for public order offences on the eve of Prince Charles's investiture as Prince of Wales more than 30 years ago.

When Cardiff's former Apollo Hotel reopens tomorrow after a refit, it will do so as the Cayo Arms, in memory of the late Julian Cayo Evans, the self-styled commandant of the Free Wales Army.

Brewers Tomos Watkin, the pub's owners, say the decision to name the pub after the public school-educated separatist reflects the company's policy of commemorating famous and "colourful" personalities from Wales's past. But the move has been condemned by Conservative assembly members.

Jonathan Morgan, AM for South Wales Central, said Wales should not be honouring people who broke the law in the name of patriotism.

"The disruptive antics of Welsh nationalists should be consigned to the dustbin," he said yesterday.

Evans, the Millfield-educated son of a former high sheriff of Cardiganshire, served with the British army in Malaya during the 1950s but played a leading part in establishing the FWA after his return to Wales.

He was sentenced to 15 months' imprisonment for public order offences after a special branch crackdown on the organisation before the 1969 Caernarvon investiture. He died five years ago, at 57, and was given a paramilitary funeral by FWA colleagues.

Tomos Watkin's managing director, Simon Buckley, who knew Evans well, said: "He was a Robin Hood character of the late 1960s."

fields.headline: Can Xerox copy old success?
fields.standfirst: Karlin Lillington visits the firm that developed modern computing but didn't market it
fields.trailText: Karlin Lillington visits the firm that developed modern computing but didn't market it
fields.body:
'A hanging garden of Babylon overlooking Silicon Valley," is Rich Gold's whimsical description of the most famous research laboratory in the history of computing. Set into the hills above Stanford University, the blocky buildings of Xerox's Palo Alto Research Center, or Parc, have tiered gardens, roomy windowed offices, and views of San Francisco Bay and the roofs of the corporate powerhouses that worship the silicon chip.

Oddly, the place where virtually all of modern computing was invented is not a computer company at all but a self-proclaimed "document company". Windows, screen icons, the mouse, the laser printer, WYSIWYG (what you see is what you get) printing and Ethernet (a method of connecting computers into a high-speed local network), even funny screensavers - all were developed more than two decades ago in Xerox's Parc. Xerox brought almost none of these ideas to market.

Such twists and turns of fate leave Xerox working hard to re-establish its digital credentials, especially since it hopes to forge a reputation as an internet technologies and business solutions company.

Turning the company in new directions has been a partial contributor to severe quarterly losses recently, but Parc seems oblivious to something as ephemeral as quarterly results.

"Parc is a cauldron of ideas, of thought, of new technology," says the pony-tailed Gold, whose company biography describes him as an "applied cartoonist" and "former consultant in virtual reality". Parc "is like a great university, with all the kids taken out". New ideas include curious prototype modular robots that can move by themselves, link and modify their function as part of a larger unit. They now make simple snake and spider forms but researchers want to create them on a microscopic level, where millions would gather to create working objects.

"You could buy a box of modules and tell them to make a printer," suggests Gold, although he adds dryly that this particular research area "won't be a product soon".

The lab has a full-blown Mems (micro electro mechanical systems) division. Mems are minute machines built on a silicon chip; researchers have created, for example, tiny mechanised tweezers capable of grabbing a single bacterium.

Xerox is interested in optical Mems, which could enhance printers and copiers. Now such devices run on a single or dual laser focused through a mirror - a printing mechanism that is book-sized - but Mems could make them pea-sized.

One project involves placing hundreds of silicon mirrors on a single microchip, then tilting them to direct an array of several hundred lasers. Another aims to position thousands of lasers on a single chip. These technologies would enable what researcher Eric Peeters calls "bat out of hell printing".

Another division is exploring the use of multiple microchip sensors that could eventually make inanimate matter intelligent. Researcher Feng Zhao says that peppercorn-sized sensors could one day be sprayed across a road surface, enabling the road to tell a car the traffic conditions for a region and select the best route. He imagines a world of smart environments where sensors would provide factual information to be analysed by computers, enabling humans "to bridge two worlds - the physical world and the digital and virtual world".

Individual sensors could eventually be part of a vast feedback network on the net, as well, he says, since individual sensors could be given their own internet address.

Underlying all Xerox research is ethnography, the study of human behaviour. Xerox employs some 15 ethnographers. One of them, Jack Whalen, says ethnogra phy is "at the very heart of this center" because of a study at Parc decades ago. Researchers videotaped volunteers who were told to make certain kinds of copies on a copier they had never used before. The engineers and researchers were stunned to see that real people didn't interact with the machine in the ways they expected and were confused by features that were supposed to be self-explanatory. The video led to a radical rethink at Parc and now ethnographers routinely work on all research projects.

"Truly useful technology supports and enhances natural human capacities and practices," says Whalen. "We're trying to look five, 10, 20 years down the road and ethnography helps with that human-scape envisioneering." This may sound rather bizarre, but out of the strange and idiosyncratic often come flashes of brilliance athat mark a pure research laboratory. "Parc is about inventing the future," says Whalen.

fields.headline: Anorexia 'not just a western ill'
fields.trailText: Anorexia is not just a problem of the west, where girls are under pressure from the glamour industry to be thin, new research shows.
fields.body:
Anorexia is not just a problem of the west, where girls are under pressure from the glamour industry to be thin, new research shows.

The eating disorder anorexia nervosa has been discovered in young rural African woman, undermining the theory that it is caused by the media's fascination with thin females, Alan Carson told the annual meeting of the Royal College of Psychiatrists.

But Dr Carson, a consultant psychiatrist at the Royal Edinburgh hospital, said: "This is a preliminary finding and it does not overturn all the traditional thinking on anorexia. What it does show is that factors other than the role of the media should be examined as the condition is a multi-factoral disorder."

The study screened all 668 female pupils in two secondary schools in rural Upper East Ghana for height and weight.

Thirty of the students had a body mass index below the average for their group, of which four linked their restricted intake to religious fasting while two related their condition to feelings of self-control.

The conference also heard pregnant women who suffer from the eating disorder bulimia are at risk of having a miscarriage, giving birth prematurely and developing post-natal depression.

John Morgan, senior registrar in psychiatry at St George's Hospital and Medical School, University of London, studied 122 women with "active" bulimia, focusing on complications in pregnancy and childbirth.

The group was compared with 82 women who had a history of the disorder but who had the condition under control, and, at the time, had no evidence of either bulimia or anorexia.

Dr Morgan told the delegates that of the 122 women, one quarter miscarried, 23% had premature births, and 36% suffered from post-natal depression. In the group of 82 women, 10% had miscarriages, 8% experienced premature births, and 21% suffered from post-natal depression.

webTitle: House buyers left in the dark

fields.headline: House buyers left in the dark
fields.trailText: People moving house often take lightbulbs and even electrical fittings in pound-pinching efforts to save money, according to research published today. Four out of 10 home buyers find previous owners have removed light bulbs, according to a survey by HouseWeb.com
fields.body:
People moving house often take lightbulbs and even electrical fittings in pound-pinching efforts to save money, according to research published today. Four out of 10 home buyers find previous owners have removed light bulbs, according to a survey by HouseWeb.com, the online estate agents.

In addition, 23% of new owners are amazed to discover that light fittings and fixtures have also been removed, potentially exposing them and their families to electric shocks.

The worst offenders are people living in south-east England, where one in seven respondents moved into homes without light. Other tight-fisted tactics include taking door knobs.

A buyer in Scotland who was persuaded to buy a property because of its mature, well-stocked garden found instead a bare wasteland because the seller had dug it up.

To combat these house-buying pitfalls, HouseWeb.com has introduced the House Spec, a comprehensive checklist for buyers and vendors to complete and agree before reaching the expensive solicitor negotiation level. It can be downloaded from the site, free of charge for homeowners selling direct via the internet, and for those selling through an estate agent.

Mark Desvaux, of HouseWeb.com, said: "Our survey illustrates the absurdity of moving house the British way. Although the average property price has soared to £84,000, signalling good news for sellers, we still go to ridiculous lengths to save a few pounds and risk incurring ill will."

fields.trailText: ICC2000 | Diablo II | Wacky Races | Walt Disney Magical Racing Tour
fields.byline: Jack Schofield,  Andy Bodle  and Greg Howson
fields.body:
Pushing back the boundaries
ICC2000
PC £29.99 Empire ****
What do Championship Manager players do during the summer? They keep playing Championship Manager, of course. But the ones who want a break could do worse than try the latest edition of International Cricket Captain, endorsed by Nasser Hussain.

ICC2000 puts the emphasis on captaincy rather than management, though it does include picking the team, negotiating contracts and training youngsters. However, the main aim is to let you play through one-day, county and international matches ball by ball. This isn't an action game, but you can tell players how aggressively (or how defensively) to play. You can set a line and length for bowlers to follow, and either set standard fields or design your own.

Like the real thing, this takes a long time. Fortunately you can skip the graphics, or just watch highlights (such as when a wicket falls), and get through more games in what might be called scorecard mode. One mouse-click can either represent a single ball or an over. If you're really in a hurry, you can click "Skip game" and let the computer calculate the result.

Player statistics are based on Wisden's Cricket Almanac, and teams are commendably up to date. However, there are some "historical scenarios" that let you replay classic test series or last year's World Cup. ICC2000 also provides a two-player game, and will support online play when the server comes online.

The game is mouse-driven and the polished interface makes it very easy to play. It also seems very fair. Active management generally seems to produce good results, or at least palliates the inevitable disasters. Even repeatedly skipping games does not seem to be a barrier to success.

All in all, ICC2000 is an outstanding game for cricket fans, especially those who follow the English county game.

Unfortunately this is a limited market, even by international cricket standards. What the game lacks is the introductory tutorial and background information that might help bring it the wider audience it deserves. (JS)

Fiendishly clever but not enough
Diablo II
PC £29.99 Blizzard ****
There are some people out there who have the temerity to assert that Diablo - that's the original Diablo, released in 1996 - is still the best role-playing game on the market. Despite Might & Magic, Fallout and Ultima.

Most of these people, of course, also believe that the sun revolves around the earth. But the real question is: if the first game won so fanatical a following, can its sequel become the champion of RPGs? Well, no, but not for want of trying.

The setup and interface are still recognisably Diabolical, except for the fact that it has incorporated all the advances in the RPG world and a few more to boot. There are five character classes instead of three, 3D support, shadows, weather and water effects, cheatproof multiplayer support, and some innovative new skills and enemies (anyone ever use a corpse explosion on a scarab demon before?).

Not only do you get different maps and non-player-character responses with each class, but because of the nature of the interface, you'll find yourself developing totally different keyboard techniques for barbarian, amazon, paladin, necromancer and sorceress.

Left-click for melee attack and right for ranged might suit one character, but assigning left-click to spells and switching between them might be a better option for another.

Then there are the little touches, the sort that make you curse other programmers for being so lazy. Rats that flock to feed off the corpses of your vanquished opponents, only to scatter when you turn back. Chickens that squawk and flutter out of your way when you walk into them. Zombies that moan differently according to the extent of their injuries.

Moments such as these make the opening chapters of Diablo II a delight.

Only when you're some way into the game do the design flaws start to get to you. Stingy inventory space means you're heading back home every 10 minutes to sell off your excess baggage. Customised options revert to default every time you start a game. Creatures that hit obstacles spin crazily instead of standing still. The control system becomes more and more cumbersome, the more skills you learn. And the way that characters often face in a different direction from the way they're walking, creating a sort of diagonal- moonwalking effect, is just sloppy.

One flaw smarts from the start: the lack of save slots. Sure, you can save and exit, but thanks to the perennial autosaves, you can't save and reload. This is no biggie from the death point of view: you die, you're resurrected in town, you go back and pick up your stuff. But the save facility is not just there for death. It's there for moments when you accidentally spend all your hard-earned cash on a useless weapon, or spend an experience point on the wrong skill, which can ruin a game right up to the end.

The saving disgrace aside, Diablo II's drawbacks are mostly minor. But they're enough to ensure that Baldur's Gate hangs on to its RPG crown. (AB)

Dastardly does down Disney

Wacky Races
Dreamcast **** Infogrames £39.99

Walt Disney Magical Racing Tour

Sony Playstation ** Eidos £29.99
Often imitated but never bettered is one way to describe Nintendo's classic racing game, Mario Kart.

However, the fat plumber's reign may be coming to an end with the release of Wacky Races. Continuing the recent 70's revival -Dukes of Hazzard, and the Muppets have appeared in games -Wacky Races breaks the standard inverse relationship between quality and license by actually being cracking fun.

Graphically the game is a beauty, with the Hanna Barbera look captured expertly by the Dreamcast. Very much like Diddy Kong Racing, Wacky Races sets you a variety of karting challenges. Win race, gain stars, gain access to new track is the general rule, though if you get stuck on one course, you can quickly try a challenge on another.

The game will really appeal to those who remember Penelope Pitstop, the Anthill Gang and the rest but, frustratingly, the real heroes, Dastardly and Muttley, are available to play only when a large proportion of the game has been completed.

Surely as cruel a denial as any half-baked plan they may have hatched on TV. Thank fully there are no such problems in this months other kart release, Walt Disney Magical Racing Tour. Despite the licence the characters are strictly C list, with the likes of Chip 'n' Dale offering little incentive to persevere on some surprisingly tough circuits. A Goofy or a Mickey would have helped, and while the Disneyland visuals will appeal to the juvenile target audience, Wacky Races is by far the better game.

It seems Mario may finally have met his match. (GH)

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.trailText: Virtual DNA | Not just any old bag
fields.body:
Virtual DNA
Now we have the complete human genome, why not try virtual DNA sequencing? The Virtual Bacterial ID Lab, www.biointeractive.org, has a fantastic interactive Shockwave program that lets you go through the whole process. You begin by grabbing your own bacterial colony out of a petri dish and it keeps on getting better. While you work in the virtual lab to the left, the right side of the browser gives a detailed commentary on what you're doing and why. Budding scientists and anyone with a general interest in the area will enjoy this. While there, pay a visit to the Virtual Cardiology Lab as well, or have a look at other science resources for children, teachers and adults.

A handbag?
Handbag.com's celebrity handbag auction began Monday, but bidding continues until the 13th, so you have plenty of time to go after Maggie's, Cherie's or Mo's little numbers. All proceeds will go to the charity Breast Cancer Care. Have a peep at the bags and find out how to make a bid at www.handbag.com/auctions/handbags/

Tasty site
Sainsbury's has a bright new website, www.tasteforlife.co.uk, a compendium of information on food and drink. Along with a special section on organic foods (Sains bury's was the first supermarket to offer organic gin, the site says helpfully), there are 4,000 recipes, tips on buying and serving wine, and an "it's gone wrong" Q&A section. Especially useful is the recipe search engine, which locates recipe suggestions by main ingredients, time to prepare, calories, course, or dietary requirements. The selection I looked at all sounded pretty mouthwatering.

Tune in
Wondering whether you can legally use that line from Romeo and Juliet on your new trance single? Find the answer at www.hobomusic.com, a just-launched music site that has a number of features that musicians should find very useful. There's a free online legal clinic run by music lawyers Clintons, a booking service that lets you reserve studio time over the Net, and a directory of contacts and companies.

Drop the debt
Comic Relief, www.comicrelief.org.uk , is using an email campaign this year to urge world leaders to keep debt cancellation on the agenda at the next G7 summit, taking place July 21-23 in Okinawa, Japan. Plenty of celebrities have swung in behind the initiative, including Ewan McGregor, Steve Coogan, Angus Deayton, Douglas Adams and Tony Robinson. The idea is that you get an email forwarded from the celebs and then either add your name and send it on to your friends, or you can create your own email. You can also think about becoming part of an anti-debt "virtual human chain" on July 21; details at www.dropthedebt.org

Pension plans
If the word pension has always brought on the frights, try www.pensionsorter.com, which proves that low-tech delivery of information is sometimes all that a site needs to be effective. Every aspect of pension-purchasing is gone through in detail, and all the terminology is explained in easy-to-understand language.

Black hole
Former Disney studio head Joe Roth and the man behind The Blair Witch Project internet hype has launched a sci-fi site, www.DistantCorners.com It has an initial disclaimer warning that the site really needs a high bandwidth DSL or cable connection for optimal viewing - that's a setup that's rare still in the States, let alone over here. Then, there's a silly, pretentious Shockwave sequence while the site loads. If you're still with them by this point, most of the site seems to run perfectly well on a 56k modem connection.

New and noted
International legal site A HREF="http://www.law.com/uk" TARGET="_NEW">Law.com<.a> now has a UK version, ... Macmillan Cancer Relief has a new site for its September World's Biggest Coffee Morning fundraiser, see www.everyoneswelcome.com... A1 Learn , has launched a range of interactive online training courses in computing_ try a web-delivered short movie at www.405theMovie.com, then read about how it was made... health and beauty site www.changeslive.com features information, makeovers and a section for men.

Wap watch
UK Directory has a web - not wap - site wap.ukdirectory.co.uk explaining how to build your own wap pages which are downloaded to your phone for £10 a month (after a free trial). Http://loot.com has potential but we drew blanks on finding a home while holiday queries found "File too large".

Wap.breathe.com was OK for cricket, news and weather and also found the nearest Pizza Express. Wap.wapgata.com checks out domain names. (Victor Keegan)

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Clinton calls Israel summit
fields.body:
Clinton calls Israel summit

The US president, Bill Clinton, has called a Middle East peace summit for next Tuesday at Camp David in an effort to seal a peace deal between Israelis and Palestinians.

He will meet the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian Authority president, Yasser Arafat, with the aim of bridging the "significant differences" that have led to deadlock.

Reuters, Washington

Vienna seeks Nazi labour fund

Austria's 1,000 biggest companies have been asked to make voluntary contributions of 0.2% of their 1999 turnover to a compensation fund for former slave and forced labourers.

The government's envoy, Maria Schaumayer, said yesterday that the companies had been selected for their size, not whether they had profited from forced labour during the second world war.

Reuters, Vienna

Strike prompts mass burial

The mass burial has taken place in Lagos, Nigeria, of about 1,200 bodies left in mortuaries because of a public sector strike, officials said yesterday.

Lagos state employees have begun their third week of strikes to demand the implementation of a minimum wage of 7,500 naira (£47) a month announced by President Olusegun Obasanjo in May.

Reuters, Lagos

Endangered tigers die in zoo

Nine endangered royal Bengal tigers have died in a zoo in the eastern Indian state of Orissa after being infected with a parasite.

Seventeen tigers at Nandan Kanan zoo near Bhubaneshwar were treated for the infection.

India's tiger population has fallen to about 3,500 from 4,300 11 years ago.

Reuters, Bhubaneshwar

Canberra OKs extradition deal

Australia has approved the signing of an extradition treaty with Latvia which could pave the way for the war crimes suspect Konrad Kalejs to be sent back to his native country.

Mr Kalejs, 86, who holds Australian citizenship and has lived in Melbourne since fleeing Britain six months ago, is suspected of aiding the killing of Jews in Latvia during the second world war. He denies the accusation.

Reuters, Canberra

Stranded whales killed

Ten pilot whales stuck in shallow water off Nantucket, Massachusetts, were put down after volunteers and experts failed to steer them back out to sea.

The whales were washed up on shore on Tuesday and stranded at low tide. When the tide returned, volunteers tried to turn them out to sea, but the dominant male kept leading them back to shallow water.

AP, Nantucket

fields.headline: Second sight
fields.standfirst: Why tap out messages on a phone? They were meant for talking to
fields.trailText: Why tap out messages on a phone? They were meant for talking to
fields.body:
Bill Gates, talking in Asia recently, made a point about the future of user interfaces and the limitations of keyboards and screens. One obvious interface is speech. The idea of talking to a computer rather than typing, pointing, pressing or touching it in any way is not only embedded in our shared cultural vision of the future (remember HAL?) but makes sense because it is so natural to us as a way of communicating.

Following this line of thinking would lead one to suspect that voice-enabled e-commerce (ie, v-commerce) will become a common way to do business on line: the question is when? It may not be so far away. The medium being the message, and all that, the greater part of this article was in fact dictated to my Macintosh laptop through IBM's splendid ViaVoice package.

I estimate that the machine got the words right about 95% of the time: not perfect, by any means, but still a very convenient way to get some work done while both hands are otherwise occupied (looking through relevant doc uments, making a few notes and so on). So voice recognition is starting to work, but how will it combine with the net? There is already a standard for accessing web sites through the telephone (it's known as VoiceXML, or VXML) and there are already companies offering, or planning to offer, services in this area.

The VoiceXML Forum, which was founded by AT&T, IBM, Lucent Technologies and Motorola recently completed Version 1.0 of the VoiceXML specification, which aims to make content more accessible via voice commands and "traditional" phone interfaces. Services like this mean that people will be able to follow up a web site and navigate their way through to find the information that they want using voice commands, and then have the information spoken back to them. How ever, navigating through vast amounts of information to find specific items probably works better through a web browser and large screen.

Where the use of voice interfaces comes into its own is in this field of remote transactions. Phoning a bank to find an account balance or to initiate a bill payment is the perfect example.

At the heart of v-commerce are two rapidly evolving technologies: natural language speech recognition and speaker authentication. These will, in the medium term, make it possible for users to complete transactions all the way through from initial inquiries to giving payment details. A voice recognition system would not have to be that comprehensive to satisfy these requirements.

All it has to do is recognize that you are asking it to pay a bill and then present you with a list of pre-configured ways to pay (eg, "press 3 for Visa") to make it useful. Recognition technology is coming along nicely and some mobile operators already have voice-recognition systems for customers to dial phone numbers or access voicemail messages (eg Orange's Wildfire) just by talking.

Another potentially important factor is that speech recognition may be combined with voice identification to add flexibility and security to interfaces. If someone was able to phone their bank and say "give me my balance", it would be rather useful if the voice interface were to both recognise the customer's request and simultaneously authenticate the customer to the bank back-end systems.

This obviates the need for passwords and PIN numbers, or other additional authentication codes. Certainly it would be more convenient than navigating tiny mobile phone screens and punching data in using a tiny mobile phone keyboard. The voice authentication systems already in the market are capable of authenticating the user even if they have a cold or their voice is altered slightly.

In the case of voice authentication through mobile handsets, the combination of possessing the handset and having your voice recognised should be more than sufficient for every day security purposes. If that happens, the new voice services could have a powerful effect on electronic commerce.

Right now, 80% of people who begin a transaction on the web cancel it before it's completed. This may be because they can't be bothered to type in all of their details, because they can't understand the instructions or because it's just too much hassle: imagine just calling Amazon, saying what you want and then hanging up.

V-commerce isn't a niche. Once voice recognition and synthesis systems come in to use, their impact will be immediate and huge. Think of it this way: did Mr Spock ever use a Wap interface on his communicator? Of course not: he spoke to it.

That's what we're used to doing to phones, which is why voice-enabled services will actually be critical to the success of "wireless web" rather than just being a cute add-on. Putting all of this together, then, indicates a medium term future for the digital mobile phone as a general purpose transaction device with the primary interface remaining voice. If, as some people suspect, wireless transactions could be responsible for almost half of all e-commerce in three to five years, then we'll all be talking telephone numbers.

How ever, navigating through vast amounts of information to find specific items probably works better through a web browser and large screen. Where the use of voice interfaces comes into its own is in this field of remote transactions. Phoning a bank to find an account balance or to initiate a bill payment is the perfect example. At the heart of v-commerce are two rapidly evolving technologies: natural language speech recognition and speaker authentication. These will, in the medium term, make it possible for users to complete transactions all the way through from initial inquiries to giving payment details. A voice recognition system would not have to be that comprehensive to satisfy these requirements. All it has to do is recognize that you are asking it to pay a bill and then present you with a list of pre-configured ways to pay (eg, "press 3 for Visa") to make it useful. Recognition technology is coming along nicely and some mobile operators already have voice-recognition systems for customers to dial phone numbers or access voicemail messages (eg Orange's Wildfire) just by talking. Another potentially important factor is that speech recognition may be combined with voice identification to add flexibility and security to interfaces. If someone was able to phone their bank and say "give me my balance", it would be rather useful if the voice interface were to both recognise the customer's request and simultaneously authenticate the customer to the bank back-end systems. This obviates the need for passwords and PIN numbers, or other additional authentication codes. Certainly it would be more convenient than navigating tiny mobile phone screens and punching data in using a tiny mobile phone keyboard. The voice authentication systems already in the market are capable of authenticating the user even if they have a cold or their voice is altered slightly. In the case of voice authentication through mobile handsets, the combination of possessing the handset and having your voice recognised should be more than sufficient for every day security purposes. If that happens, the new voice services could have a powerful effect on electronic commerce. Right now, 80% of people who begin a transaction on the web cancel it before it's completed. This may be because they can't be bothered to type in all of their details, because they can't understand the instructions or because it's just too much hassle: imagine just calling Amazon, saying what you want and then hanging up. V-commerce isn't a niche. Once voice recognition and synthesis systems come in to use, their impact will be immediate and huge. Think of it this way: did Mr Spock ever use a Wap interface on his communicator? Of course not: he spoke to it. That's what we're used to doing to phones, which is why voice-enabled services will actually be critical to the success of "wireless web" rather than just being a cute add-on. Putting all of this together, then, indicates a medium term future for the digital mobile phone as a general purpose transaction device with the primary interface remaining voice. If, as some people suspect, wireless transactions could be responsible for almost half of all e-commerce in three to five years, then we'll all be talking telephone numbers.

fields.headline: What's new
fields.trailText: Bush telegraph | Mint Telecom
fields.body:
Bush telegraph
Bush says its 21in and 28in internet TV sets have now reached the high street with prices starting at under £200. The system includes a remote control that opens up to provide a small keyboard for typing email.

A standard cordless keyboard and a colour printer are also available. Virgin Net is developing a home page and content for Bush Internet, the internet service provider.

Although some commentators have hyped the potential of TV-based internet services, most services based on television set-top boxes have flopped and Microsoft's WebTV, on sale in the US since 1996, has not been a noticeable success.

Mobile Mint
Mint Telecom promised to make it easier and cheaper to take a mobile phone abroad when it launched a pre-pay global roaming service this week. It also launched the first scratch 'n' sniff GSM system.

You buy a Mint BasicCard SIM (from www.mint-tele.com or 0800 00 33 55) and put it in your existing phone when you go abroad. After that, all calls and SMS messages to your usual number are re-routed via Mint servers to your new Mint number. This avoids roaming charges and variable call charges, because Mint charges the same price for calls from any country to any country.

Mint charges 85p per minute to make calls and £0.425p per minute to receive them. This compares with £3.43 per minute to call London from Moscow on BT Cellnet, and the 94p per minute to receive calls in Brussels. On average, Mint expects to be about a third cheaper than rivals.

But it will face competition from Deutsche Telekom's One 2 One, which plans to launch a pre-pay roaming package on July 17.

One 2 One's service will be more expensive, from 99p to £1.99 per minute to make calls and £1.50 to receive them. And it may not offer such wide coverage:it has signed up more than 160 roaming partners in 80 countries, whereas Mint covers 240 networks in 114 countries.

Guard mouse
Bannerbridge claims that the easiest way to protect your PC from passers-by is to plug in a U-Match BioLink mouse. This contains a fingerprint scanner to check each user's identity before they are allowed access to the machine. The mouse is available with serial, PS/2 and USB interfaces and works with Microsoft Windows 95B/98 and NT. See www.bannerbridge.co.uk. (JS)

IBM bombs
IBM's latest computer is anything but user-friendly. Reliability isn't great: it's expected to run for only 100 hours before breaking down. The delivery bill could well be huge - it requires several large convoys of articulated lorries to move it, and it takes two months to assemble. And don't even ask about Energy Star compliance: the thing needs enough power to fuel a small, air-conditioned town.

But the new $110m IBM ASCII White, pictured above, does go jolly fast. It is so speedy it can do in 30 days what a 1995-model Cray supercomputer would have taken 60,000 years to complete.

For those who can imagine it, the IBM machine is running at a mind-boggling 12.3 trillion operations a second.

And - the good news - if the pace of improved computer performance continues, some estimates suggest we'll have this kind of power on our desktops in less than 10 years.

For now, however, this vast machine - actually made up of 8,192 individual processors and 512 connected computers - will be busying itself with things a little less mundane than networked games of Doom. The computer, running an IBM version of Unix, will simulate nuclear weapons tests to an unprecedented level of detail. The simulations could help ease the US Congress' opposition to the comprehensive test ban treaty, which bans all real-world nuclear testing.

Even this machine isn't good enough to fully replace nuclear tests. Scientists estimate it would take a computer running eight times faster, at a trillion operations a second, to do that.

But that kind of power is on its way - for those who can afford it. David Cooper of the US president's council on computing, says: "We're still on timescale to do that by 2004." (NM)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please.
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Waiting game
Unlike new boots and panties, simple websites and old computers do not have to be thrown away once the shine has worn off. Just because you have a fast modem, it does not automatically mean that you will be able to download stuff from the web any faster.

A useful analogy is to think of the chain that brings information to you, and compare it to ordering a meal in a restaurant.

First step is to try to attract the waiter's attention (access the website). Second step is to wait for him to acknowledge you (the website responds).

Third, he takes your order (you specify a certain page you want). Fourth, the chef creates the dish (the page is assembled from HTML text, graphics, background "wallpaper", Javascript etc).

Fifth, the food is served (the components of the web page are sent over the internet). Sixth, the food is laid out on the table (the web page is assembled by your browser on your screen). Now substitute a waiter on roller skates for a fast modem.

What's the difference? Well, stages one, two and three are still the same - out of the waiter's hands (so to speak). Stages four and five are faster, and stage six is still the same (as it is the speed of the browser rendering that is key here).

A final thought: does a hungry man care if the plate of food is tastefully garnished so that it pleases the eye? No - at this stage his stomach is in control.
Micky Allen
fisi@salamander.co.uk

On the cards
Regarding Iain Noble's letter about fraudulent credit card use, I had a merchant account with an internet credit card processing company and was shocked to discover that it could charge back fraudulent card use to me personally a full six months after it authorised the transaction.

The company seemed to have made no effort to verify the cardholder's address (the card was registered in Australia, the customer gave a US address).

At least consumers are protected by law and operating procedures if they fall victim to card fraud - merchants have no protection whatsoever. Which may well explain why, when I bought a monitor over the net last week, the company insisted I fax them proof of my name and address before dispatching the goods.
Simon Briggs
simon@forward-internet.co.uk

Stat attack
Stat of the week on Microsoft's web browser domination, below the "Suspect Statistics" referred to by Neil McIntosh (Online, June 29), may be more suspect than you think if the data has been collected from websites.

I regularly use minority browsers - Fresco on my Acorn and Opera on my PC. Many websites identify your browser and refuse to work unless it is Netscape or Internet Explorer.

To overcome this, the latest version of Opera and most of the later Acorn browsers allow the user to set up "browser faking": my version of Opera can identify itself as Netscape or IE by setting the user preferences. Thus the major players may appear to be more popular than they actually are.
John Purser
john@jpurser.demon.co.uk

Pirates ahoy
I found Roy Emerson's remarks about "piracy" incredible (Feedback, June 29). At no time does the consumer own media - in reality we only own the right to enjoy it. Does Mr Emerson back up his hard drive or record from the TV? Then he, by his own standards, is a software pirate.

The whole argument about home recording harming the industry is a fallacy. Having spent some years in music retail, I concur that professional piracy is detrimental, but friends swapping LPs and CDs exposes people to new bands or styles of music.

Consumers owning multiple copies of a recording, for whatever reason, is just a fantasy of sales and marketing executives. How much do you think that it costs to remaster a "classic" analogue recording onto CD? How many musicians are involved? We would all be shocked at how little and how few. The real threat to the music industry is the domination of the supermarkets in the sales figures, skewing charts and ensuring that we get lots of safe and bland artists and compilations.

Keep taping CDs, keep swapping CDs and keep buying CDs. Most of all support your local independent retailer.
Paul Baldwin
citizen.zero@excite.com

I disagree with Mr Emerson on the issue of replacing vinyl with MP3. I do not endorse wholesale piracy, but "upgrading" format from vinyl/CD to MP3 should not be a problem.

The situation is most definitely not exactly parallel to Mr Emerson's vacuum cleaner analogy. The cost of a vacuum cleaner is mainly made of manufacturing costs, distribution costs and the margin of the retailer. The cost of a CD is made of more factors: recording costs, manufacturing costs, distribution costs, shops' margin and, of course, artists' royalty - effectively your payment to the artist for the right to listen to their work.

With MP3 however, only the artists' royalty remains in any serious quantity, as there is no manufacturing, no shop margin and distribution can be from a single file, recorded from an existing CD, at the recipient's cost.

When I buy a CD I pay for all of the above, fair enough. But by doing so I have bought the right to listen to the music, so why should I pay again to listen to the same music in a different format?
Antony Hawkins
a.d.hawkins@sheffield.ac.uk

As a musician I find Roy Emerson's attitude towards downloading music rather disconcerting. I am fully in support of music for everyone, irrespective of whether we are paid for it.

For far too many years musicians have been the pawns of the record industry fat cats. I will welcome the downfall of the current regime where record bosses with no musical creativity take a big cut from those that actually create the records.

MP3s can still be security keyed and so in effect the songs will always remain the property of the creator. The internet has opened up a vast market for individuals like myself and I am very grateful.
Andy Lucas
AndyRLucas@aol.com

fields.headline: The best jargon scene:  U-571
fields.trailText: The US submarine crew attempting to steal the Enigma code machine from a German U-boat find themselves under attack from a German destroyer.
fields.body:
The US submarine crew attempting to steal the Enigma code machine from a German U-boat find themselves under attack from a German destroyer.

Wentz (Jack Noseworthy), listening for torpedoes on a pair of headphones, grimaces as two screech by.

"Torpedo missed!" he cries. "Two more torpedoes in the water. Bearing to the U-boat, zero point zero!"

His commanding officer, Lt Andrew Tyler (Matthew McConaughey), addresses the torpedo bay through the tannoy.

"Rabbit! Get ready to fire a spread!"

Rabbit (Will Estes) attempts to launch a pair of torpedoes, but is interrupted by an ominous high-pitched clanking echoing through the sub. Everyone on board instinctively covers their ears.

Tyler looks bemused.

"What is going on?"

Rabbit peers at the torpedo hatch.

"They must be stuck."

He rushes from lever to lever, attempting to open the hatch.

"Rabbit!" Tyler screams. "Get those fish out of the boat before they blow!"

"Fire again!" exclaims Rabbit. He does so: this time the torpedoes are successfully released.

"One and two away! Lining up tubes three and four!"

"Three and four - fire!", yells Tyler.

Another pair of torpedoes leave the sub.

"All fish hot, straight and normal", Wentz announces. The crew breathe a sigh of relief - until, that is, a German torpedo batters into the side of the sub...

See also: House Of Games, Galaxy Quest, Good Morning Vietnam, Fast Times At Ridgemont High

Don't see also: Star Trek - The Motion Picture

Pointless trivia: Matthew McConaughey's older brother, Rooster, appeared with him in Richard Linklater's The Newton Boys (1998).

webTitle: School head quits to drive a lorry

fields.headline: School head quits to drive a lorry
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A headteacher said yesterday that pressure and bureaucracy were increasing in the profession and he was leaving his job to become a lorry driver.
fields.body:
A headteacher said yesterday that pressure and bureaucracy were increasing in the profession and he was leaving his job to become a lorry driver.

Tim Gunn, 51, headteacher at Wolsingham primary school in county Durham, said: "There is a lot of pressure and that was one of the factors in my decision to leave. Every headteacher will tell you there's too many administrative procedures. The whole climate has changed. The government has set targets for the local education authorities, who then set targets for schools and there is a tremendous amount of pressure."

Mr Gunn, who has taught for 30 years, is going full-time as an HGV lorry driver with the company he has worked part-time for during school summer holidays.

The north-east regional officer of the National Association of Head Teachers, John Heslop, said headteachers were under too much pressure: "Other headteachers are doing this day by day, I'm convinced of it.

"It is appalling the amount of pressure that is on headteachers. There are so many headteachers I meet on a day-to-day basis who feel so overpowered by the volume of work and the diversity of tasks.

"If you made a list of all the things a headteacher was required by law to do there would not be enough time in the day to do them.

David Tiley, of Stiller Distribution Management Ltd, based in Stockton, Teesside, said: "There are new vehicles coming in and Mr Gunn applied for a full-time position, for which he was successful, and will be starting in August."

Durham county council yesterday confirmed that Mr Gunn would be leaving on July 21.

The shadow education secretary, Theresa May, said Mr Gunn's case was a "classic example" of how red tape was stopping teachers from doing their job: "Conservatives will slash bureaucracy to keep teachers like him from leaving the profession - we will use lorries to remove paperwork, not to remove teachers."

webTitle: England: A diary of a failed World Cup bid

fields.headline: England: A diary of a failed World Cup bid
fields.standfirst:
How England's world came to an end
Inquest into England World Cup flop
Football Unlimited
fields.trailText:
1993
Over a private drink between FA chairman Bert Millichip and his German counterpart, a "gentleman's" agreement is discussed: Germany say they will back England to host Euro 96 in return for English support in the 2006 World Cup campaign. "Kein Problem!" says Bert. Both leave happy.
fields.body:
1993
Over a private drink between FA chairman Bert Millichip and his German counterpart, a "gentleman's" agreement is discussed: Germany say they will back England to host Euro 96 in return for English support in the 2006 World Cup campaign. "Kein Problem!" says Bert. Both leave happy.

1996
Fuelled by the success of Euro 96, England decide to enter the bidding for the World Cup. Not surprisingly the decision outrages Germany, who accuse the FA of reneging on a deal. The FA disagree - no agreement was made, they insist. Uefa president Lennart Johansson doesn't believe them and sides with Germany, leaving the English bid lacking crucial European support from the outset.

1998
Knowing Johansson is firmly behind the German bid, England cunningly switches its allegiance in the race for the Fifa presidency to Sepp Blatter. But there's a problem: Blatter has already pledged to take the World Cup to Africa if he's elected. But the FA aren't too bothered - they're confident that Blatter will back England's bid when crime-ridden South Africa are forced to pull out after they fail to meet the technical criteria.

Later on in the year, FA chief executive Graham Kelly and chairman Keith Wiseman try to remove Scotland's David Will from the Fifa executive to increase support for England's bid. "Wouldn't Wiseman make a better replacement," Kelly whispers onto the ear of the Welsh FA, while dangling a financial carrot in front of them. Unfortunately the plot unravels and Kelly and Wiseman are removed from their posts.

Then the FA come up with another brilliant scheme. Thailand just happen to need a coach, so they offer to install Peter Withe. Of course it has nothing to do with the fact that Thailand are one of the countries with a vote on the 24-man Fifa executive. No sirree. But then the Thais discover Withe's managerial record at Wimbledon, and another vote looks lost.

1999
The hand-shaking and back-scratching begins in earnest. The England World Cup 2006 organising committee hope that meeting Hugh Grant or dining with Prince Charles will guarantee a few votes. It doesn't. So England cleverly arrange a prestigious pre-Euro 2000 friendly in Malta, ironically one of the countries with a member on the Fifa executive panel.

At last England have a possible vote on board. But they suffer a setback when Tony Blair turns on the charm during a meeting with Fifa president Sepp Blatter only to find he immediately reiterates his support for South Africa.

2000

May
England leave the Concacaf congress in Nassau believing they have secured the three votes for the region and are becoming increasingly confident of success. Tony Banks in particular lets it be known that England can win by amassing the required second and third preference votes. At this stage the bookies believe him: South Africa are 10/11, England are 11/10 and Germany are 4-1.

17th June
England hooligans riot before the Euro 2000 clash between England and Germany, and Uefa threaten England with expulsion. Although seen by supporters of England's bid as an over-reaction and, indeed, a Uefa plot, their stance hardens opinion against the English bid.

A copy of Rothenburg's technical report is leaked, which claims England stadiums are ranked only third of the five contenders - apparently South Africa and Germany are both better. Campaign director Alec McGivan is not happy and accuses Sepp Blatter of political interference: "I think he will regret the fact that he took such a partial position at the outset of the campaign."

A deal is struck between the South African FA and Brazil, which sees the South Americans withdrawing their bid and supporting the Africans. Even England now accept they're up against it, but still talk of a "miracle" happening.

England muster two votes in the second round and are eliminated. McGivan blames hooligans. Chances of getting the World Cup again seem lost for a generation.
